Dear Sirs,

Re Purchase Order No. 10447

The Credit Manager for Prairie Division of your company, has pressed for payment of sales tax amounting to $85.11 on the above order. This order was placed with you following receipt of competitive prices. It will be noted on your copy of our request for quotation that the words "Prices to include Dominion Sales Tax" are indicated and underlined on our form. In fairness to your competitors, we expect you to stand-by your quotation. To allow you sales tax extra would make your quotation ($813.81) in excess of that of other firms quoting.

Under the circumstances I regret that we are unable to recommend payment of sales tax totalling $85.11.

Thirdly, due to the desire of the Oblate Fathers to reduce the cost of this new wing to the smallest amount possible, the necessary planning was omitted with the consequence that costs gradually accumulated far beyond the amount originally provided and originally planned.

The above remarks were once more made to me this week by Reverend Father Lavigne, Provincial of the Oblate Fathers and I was asked to write to you again and leave with you as well the list of accounts that was handed to me by Father Lavigne.

In conclusion may I be allowed to remark that the new wing was an essential necessity to safeguard the lives of the Indian children attending that school and that its cost was far below what the Department would have spent had it itself undertaken its construction.

The above are the principal reasons why Father Lavigne insists once more on the payment of these accounts and I do hope that the Department will wish to reconsider its former decision.

OTTAWA, 19th November 1946

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

I take the liberty to place before you once more, for your serious attention, the accounts incurred for the completion of the new wing of the Kenora Indian Residential School. These accounts were paid by the school with money advanced by the Reverend Oblate Fathers and not by the Department so that the school might be able, in time, to reimburse them, but as it was impossible to do so, Reverend Father Lavigne has asked me to place the matter before you once more for further attention by the Department.

It is not my intention in this letter to go over the history of the increase in size of this school, as I do not see that any good purpose would be served by it.

May I say in the first place that we were asked by the Department to use the new wing for dormitory purposes only. You might in this regard consult your letter of September 11th, 1941, file 129-1-5.

Secondly, the Kenora School is the property of the Indian Affairs Branch and not of the Oblate Fathers. It is used for the education of Indian children who are the wards of the Government and whose education is a duty which the Oblate Fathers are performing in the name of the Indian Affairs Branch and not as a personal obligation.
St. Mary's Indian Residential School

Dear Sir:

re: Auto Accident - Maurice Taillieu
and St. Mary's Indian School.

Replying to your letter of January 9th, 1947, with reference
to the above mentioned, I would advise that this accident oc-
curred on a road between the Kenora Golf & Country Club and
Cameron Camps and St. Mary's Indian School.

It appears that about 10:15 A.M., January 8th, 1947, Henry
Turcotte, driving an 800 weight army, right hand drive truck
for the St. Mary's Indian School, was returning to the School
when descending a grade and rounding a curve met truck driven
by Maurice Taillieu. Turcotte applied his brakes which cause
his truck to skid on icy road surface and swerve into Taillieu's
truck, damaging left door, running board, gas spout and left
rear fender to the approx... extent of $100.00.

Yours truly,

Chief Constable,
J. PILE.

Jl 13/47
Feb. 11th, 1947.

The Minister of Mines & Natural Resources,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

On the morning of January 8, 1947 at about 10:30 a.m., an automobile owned by St. Mary's Indian School and operated by Henry Turcotte collided with an International Truck operated by Mr. Taillieu, doing considerable damage to the latter.

On investigation of the accident, it was determined that the collision was caused by a failure to observe the proper rules for proceeding in the opposite direction on the road. Mr. Turcotte appeared to have assumed he had control of his vehicle and struck the left hand side of the truck causing damage to the extent of approximately $500.00.

I obtained a report from Chief Constable J. Ride, Toronto, and I am attaching hereto a copy for your information. From the report that was furnished by the Chief of Police it could be seen that the entire blame for responsibility for the accident rests with Mr. Turcotte.

I have had some little correspondence with Rev. P. Lacelle of St. Mary's Indian School pertaining to the accident and it was not until his letter of February 10th arrived, indicating that the school was a Dominion Government Institution, that I realized that it would be necessary for us to get in touch with you regarding this matter.
Min. of Mines

2-11-47

an opportunity to complete your investigation, we would be very pleased to hear from you regarding the matter.

As previously indicated, it appears that the entire onus of responsibility rests with the driver of the truck belonging to the School and we therefore make our demand for damages in the amount of $105.30. We will be very pleased to arrange with Mr. Taillieu to furnish you with a Release contingent on payment of this amount.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

J.M. [Signature]
B.S.C., C.B.E.

Re: Fire Protection at the Residential Schools Kenora Indian Agency.

Attached hereto, please find a report covering the above noted subject.

The report embodies several recommendations for the replacement and remodelling of the fire equipment at the Kenora R.C.I.R. School and Cecilia Jeffrey I.R. School.

In connection with the recommendation that all exit doors leading to the fire escapes in these two schools be fitted with Push Type Doors with Hazard Hardware, this is of sufficient importance, that I would respectfully suggest, that you request Mr. Williams calling in to thoroughly check over both schools, so that expert advice may be given, as to the necessity and also as to the method to be adopted, in installing this type of exit door.

The replacement of these several doors, will cost including material, labour and installation, in the neighborhood of $75.00 or $80.00, which could be installed by any local contractor.

The installation of a more efficient alarm system at the schools, could also be checked over by an engineer, as I believe this of some importance.

The several changes to the fire hose couplings and connections, the installing of another Valve and hose connection on the stand pipe in the main hallway and the reed filling of Fire Extinguishers is now being done, as this is of immediate importance. A local pipe fitter is at present on the job, and I trust this action will meet with your approval.

Also attached hereto, are requisitions covering much needed new hose and equipment, especially at the Kenora R.C. School.

Your comments and advice would be much appreciated.

Norman Soliver,
Indian Agent.
REPORT

on Fire Protection at the Residential Schools in the Kenora Indian Agency.

Several visits have been made to the Residential Schools, in the Kenora Agency, fire drills held and inspections made of all fire equipment, exits, and escapes.

On these visits I was accompanied by Chief Reg. Davies of the Kenora Fire Department, who kindly gave of his time, in the interest of safety and the furtherance of efficient fire protection in and around the community.

After checking over the equipment, exits and fire escapes, certain recommendations were made, for the repair and remodelling of the present equipment. These recommendations are submitted for your information and action and are as follows:

Kenora R.C.I.R. School.

That all exits to the fire escapes be altered and remodelled. Present exits are through hinged windows which either open in or out. These are fastened with hooks and eyes or by hasps. This does not allow of a safe or quick exit. There are THREE such exit doors and it is recommended that these be replaced with new doors of the push type, fitted with hazard hardware.

At several escapes, it is necessary to climb through the window or exit to get to the landing on the escape. It is recommended that steps be installed at the foot of these windows.

The exit from the 2nd floor, to North escape, is through a hallway leading to a room which is occupied by one of the staff, then through a window, to the escape. This is not a good set-up and does not allow for a quick exit from the school. It is recommended that this room be vacated and free access given to the fire escape.

The present balanced fire escape at the north end of school should be made permanent, with a step or platform built at the bottom of escape.

A fire door should be installed in the doorway, leading from the school laundry to hallway on main floor.

Fire Alarms and warning or directional lights should be placed at most efficient position in building. At present a small triangle gong is used for an alarm. It is recommended that an electrician install either one large electric alarm or Boomer, or several smaller alarms, one in each hallway, also small alarms in the dormitories and laundry.

Guide or warning lights should be placed near entrance to each fire escape.

Fire hose & Fittings etc. The old 1½" linen fire hose should be replaced. Male hose couplings to be welded to nipples from the valves on stand pipes. The present flat hose racks to be attached to the stand pipes with clamps, instead of being on wall brackets. It is also recommended that two lengths of 1½" hose be placed in the racks, as only one length is in position at present. This will allow of a 100 foot run in the building.

A new hose connection should be installed on stand pipe in main hallway. This will require a new valve and nipple.

Fire extinguishers to be refilled and checked at regular intervals by the school engineer and placed in permanent positions in building.
Cecilia Jeffrey I.R. School.

It is recommended that all exits to fire escapes be remodelled. The exits at present are through hinged windows, opening outside and fitted with hooks and eyes or hasps. This arrangement does not allow for a quick exit and therefore should be replaced with new exit doors, push type, fitted with hazard hardware.

There are no direct exits from the dormitories in this school, and it is recommended that at some future time, provision will be made for the installation of a spiral or slide type of escape, to provide for the safe and orderly exit of the pupils and staff at the school.

The electric alarm system is fair, but could be made more efficient by having larger electric alarms placed on each floor, also placing smaller alarms in the residence, all the dormitories, furnace room, and hallway to laundry.

Guide or warning lights should be placed near entrance to all fire escapes.

An extra 50 foot length of 1½" standard linen fire hose should be placed in all hose racks.

Fire extinguishers to be refilled and checked at regular intervals by the school engineer and placed in permanent positions in building.

Kenora Indian Agency

Ottawa, July 2nd, 1947.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ontario.

We are in receipt of a letter requesting the Department to supply the following in order to modernize the barn at the Kenora Residential School:

(a) Manure Carrier
(b) Individual drinking trough
(c) Repairs to sewage system.

Please consult the principal and obtain more definite information regarding what he considers necessary in the above regard. At the same time we would like to have an estimate of the cost.

You should point out to the principal that an amount of $1,500 was provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at this school during the current fiscal year; we have already issued a purchase order for $256.60 for new mattresses and another purchase order for $268.08 for fire hose.

In addition, we have under consideration your letter of June 13th recommending an expenditure of $675 for repairs to the floor, walls and foundation of the laundry. The items mentioned amount to slightly over $1,200.

In official letter of June 12th, you were authorized to purchase ten milking cows.
for this school. As yet we do not know what these will cost.

You will note from the above that the amount specifically provided in the current year's appropriation would be considerably exceeded when payment has been made for the items mentioned. It is, therefore, very doubtful that we can find funds this year for the equipment required to modernize the barn. However, as stated above, we would like to have definite information and an estimate of the cost. When this is received the matter will have further consideration.

Bernard J. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

OTTAWA, February 6, 1948.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.

Re: Electric Frigidaire for Kenora R.C. School.

My dear Mr. Phelan,

Reverend Fr. Perreault, principal of the above school would very much appreciate an electric frigidaire for his school. There is at the present time a one-compartment frigidaire which could be used for meat and butter but which cannot be used for kitchen left-overs, fruit, desserts and other cooking necessities.

Your agent might be written to about this frigidaire and along with the principal, he might be able to advise as to its size. Personally I believe that the largest unit in home frigidaires might solve the problem and I think the sooner it is supplied to the school the better it will be.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Dear Sir,

RE: Water Pressure Tanks.

In reply to the letter you have referred to regarding our requisition on one water pressure tank, as soon as possible, we are pleased to give these explanations.

We have been purchasing the present tanks periodically for the last three years and we find that they lose the air which has to be pumped daily, which is not normal. It is only by keeping the pressure very low that we have kept them from breaking apart.

The repeated advice of two local plumbers has decided us to put one tank on our 1947-48 estimates, and to ask for it now.

No authorized Inspector or engineer being available from the Department we have thought the tank should be available if and when the present ones give away.

One only tank is considered so the pumps can supply as much water as the outlet will handle the tank being used more for pressure than for supply.

Trusting that this will enable you to inform the department more adequately as to what our requisition is all about, I remain,

Yours very sincerely,

C. Patterson.

EQUIPMENT AND METHOD FOR HAND DISHWASHING

Nutrition Division,
Department of National Health and Welfare, Ottawa.

EQUIPMENT:

Proper dishwashing equipment and methods of operation are essential to any food service operation.

The efficiency and sanitation of the dishwashing is gauged by the number of bacterial organisms per utensil surface at the end of a given process and is expressed in terms of "swab count." The average count for ten utensils usually falls within the figure of 15-25. Ideally, the swab count be kept well below 100 and this can be done by proper utilization of the sinks, soap, hot water and disinfectant compound; while properly operated dishwashing machines may keep the count as low as 17.

Dishes may be washed by hand or by machine. Hand dishwashing may be done in dish pans or sinks. In either case, there must be a soapy water solution and at least one hot, clean, clear rinse water (170°F). A disinfectant compound is optional if the rinse water is sufficiently hot so as to kill any remaining bacteria on the dishes after they have been washed. Dish pans will serve the purpose for small numbers of people, two or three-compartment sinks recommended for numbers exceeding 50. They may be used for numbers up to 300 if the operation is efficient. However, for numbers of 150 and over, a dishwashing machine is certainly desirable as a cleaner, more sanitary product is assured because of higher controlled water temperature. The time allotment is also a factor to be considered when doing dishes for 150 or more people.

SPACE:

The dishwashing room or area should be clean, bright (light coloured walls add much to the appearance of this area) and well ventilated. Proper lighting is essential to better working conditions and eliminates the association of 'drudgery' in dishwashing. All cracks and square corners as far as possible should be eliminated in the walls, floor and equipment. Walls should be of a hard-finish material which is easily cleaned. The floor covering should be of a non-skid, non-porous, easily cleaned material properly laid.

Sufficient space is essential to eliminate overcrowding of equipment and workers. Adequate table space should be allowed for scraping and stacking of dirty dishes and draining and stacking of clean dishes.

DISH PAN WASHING: (for numbers not over 50)

1. Dish scraper - one or more.
2. Dish pans for washing, rinsing and sterilization. (The rinsing and sterilization pans should be deep enough to allow for complete immersion of dishes).
3. Clean dish rack.

SINK WASHING:

A three-compartment sink with adequate drain boards, is strongly advocated for washing of dishes up to 150. For durability and to facilitate cleaning, stainless steel or Monel Metal sinks and drain boards are recommended. Stainless steel sinks if well cared for, will wear for 35 years whereas galvanized metal sinks and drain boards have a guaranteed lifetime of 8 years.
EQUIPMENT AND METHOD FOR HAND DISHWASHING

Nutrition Division,
Department of National Health and Welfare, Ottawa.

EQUIPMENT:

Proper dishwashing equipment and methods of operation are essential to any food service operation.

The efficiency and sanitation of the dishwashing is gauged by the number of bacterial organisms per utensil surface at the end of a given process and is expressed in terms of "swab" counts. The average count for ten utensils is usually taken as the dish count. It is necessary that the swab count be kept well below 100 and this can be done by proper preparation of the sinks, soap, hot water and disinfectant compound; while properly operated dishwashing machines may keep the count as low as 17.

Dishes may be washed by hand or by machine. Hand dishwashing may be done in dish pans or sinks. In either case, there must be a soapy water solution and at least one hot clean, clear rinse water (170°F). A disinfectant compound is optional if the rinse water is sufficiently hot so as to kill any remaining bacteria on the dishes after they have been washed. Dish pans will serve the purpose for a limited number of people, but two or three-compartment sinks are more efficient for large numbers. They may be used for numbers up to 300 if the operation is efficient. However, for numbers of 150 and over, a dishwashing machine is certainly desirable as a cleaner, more sanitary product is assured because of higher controlled water temperature. The time allotment is also a factor to be considered when doing dishes for 150 or more people.

SPACE:

The dishwashing room or area should be clean, bright (light coloured walls add much to the appearance of this area) and well ventilated. Proper lighting is essential to proper working conditions and eliminates the association of 'drudgery' in dishwashing. All cracks and square corners as far as possible should be eliminated in the walls, floor and equipment. Walls should be of a hard-finish material which is easily cleaned. The floor covering should be of a non-skid, non-porous, easily cleaned material properly laid.

Sufficient space is essential to eliminate overcrowding of equipment and workers. Adequate table space should be allowed for scraping and stacking of dirty dishes and draining and stacking of clean dishes.

DISH PAN WASHING: (for numbers not over 50)

1. Dish scraper - one or more.
2. Dish pans for washing, rinsing and sterilization. (The rinsing and sterilization pans should be deep enough to allow for complete immersion of dishes).
3. Clean dish rack.

SINK WASHING:

A three-compartment sink with adequate drain boards, is strongly advocated for washing of dishes up to 150. For durability and to facilitate cleaning, stainless steel or Monel Metal sinks and drain boards are recommended. Stainless steel sinks if well cared for, will wear for 35 years whereas galvanized metal sinks and drain boards have a guaranteed lifetime of 5 years.
Sinks and drainboards should be installed at least 3" from the wall so that the space behind the sink may be easily cleaned. The height of the working area should be from 32" to 34". The sinks must be at least 24" x 24" x 12" deep. Double sinks will more readily accommodate the various pots and pans. Such sinks are about twice as wide for a short person's reach. Taps should be high enough above the sink so as not to interfere with the placing of utensils in the sink (10" above the working surface). A two-compartment sink is less expensive to install and requires less space than a three-compartment sink. If a two-compartment sink is used, a gas or electric heater may be necessary under this second compartment to maintain the temperature of 170°F. in the rinse water. This is an extra expense. If the temperature is not controlled there is a danger of the workers burning themselves. With the rinse water at 170°F., it should not be necessary to towel the dishes (Drawing No. 1).

A three-compartment sink allows for one compartment for washing, one clear rinse and one rinse with disinfectant compound. When this method is used, the utilization of 170°F. water is not essential. However, with rinse water at less than 170°F., dishes may have to be towelled. (Drawing No. 2).

DRAIN BOARDS:

Adequate soiled and clean dish drain boards are necessary at the ends of the sinks. Drain boards of 3' and preferable 3' x 24" or 3' (depending on the size of the sink) are essential for both soiled and clean dish shelves for units of 100 person dish capacity. Tables of same dimensions can be used instead of the drain boards but are not recommended. The clean drain board should be installed with a pitch of 1/8" per foot sloping to the rinse sink. The scrap drain board might have a drain installed 20" from wash sink or be installed similarly to the rinse sink.

Between the washing and rinsing sinks, there should be a drain board table top of 20" x 24" with a pitch of 1/8" to the dishwashing sink to accommodate wire baskets in which the dishes are placed after washing for rinsing and chlorinating.

WIRE BASKETS:

Four wire baskets of suitable size, 12" x 20", 13" x 16" or 19" are recommended for submerging the dishes in the rinse and sterilizing sinks. These baskets should have proper handles to facilitate lifting in and out of the sinks. The baskets for cups, mugs and bowls may be used for cutlery but the best container for cutlery is a wire basket 4" x 5" in diameter and 5" deep with handles.

OTHER EQUIPMENT AND MATERIAL REQUIRED FOR DISHWASHING UNIT:

(a) Trays - sufficient for workers removing food and dishes from tables.

(b) Table-washing cloths - 6 or more.

(c) Dish scrapers - 3 or more.

(d) Recommended soap or disinfectant for water available for dishwashing.

(e) Wire whip - one to dissolve soap or detergent in wash water and disinfectant in sterilization water.

(f) Measures or ladles - 2 - for measuring soap or detergent.

(g) Dish cloths or mops - 4 or more.
(h) Tea towels - if absolutely necessary to towel dishes sufficient towels should be provided for proper drying of the dishes and to allow for using clean towels for each meal.

(i) Scrub brushes - 2 or more.

(j) Containers, closed - one for storage of soap or detergent, one for storage of disinfectant.

(k) Garbage cans with lid - one for wet garbage, one for dry garbage.

(l) Floor mop - one.

(m) Cupboard - one for proper storage of dishwashing materials.

METHOD:

An effective system of dishwashing is an important aspect of any food service. The proper sanitation of all utensils and equipment used for food during storage, preparation, cookery and service is important. The standard of dishwashing should be on an equal level with other operations.

Satisfactory dish sanitation is as complete mechanical removal of bacteria and soil as possible. The essentials of dishwashing, regardless of method, are as follows:

1. Clearing Tables, Scraping and Stacking of Dishes:

An organized system of clearing, scraping and stacking dirty dishes on the dirty dish drainboard or table is an important step before washing. Breakage can be curtailed to a great extent by careful scraping and stacking of dishes.

(1) Remove any left-over food from tables and store.

(2) Remove all tableware to dishwashing unit for scraping and stacking on the dirty dish drainboard or unit in the following order:

(a) Cutlery
(b) Cups or mugs
(c) Plates, bowls, etc.

(3) Clean tables in dining-room.

(4) Sweep dining-room floor.

2. Washing:

A good soap or detergent is 'cheaper' than a poor and ineffective soap or detergent. Soap is not an item on which it pays to economize. Too much will mar the dishes but sufficient must be used. The concentration of soap varies with local water hardness and the type used. The individual manufacturers will advise on the appropriate concentration.

Wash dishes in the following order:

1. Cutlery
2. Cups or mugs
3. Plates, bowls, etc.

The wash water should be changed at least once during washing dishes for 100°. The most logical time is after the washing of the cutlery and mugs and any other time the water is lukewarm, dirty or greasy.
Dishes should be washed as soon as possible after use. Dishes should be washed until clean with a cloth or mop and a good soap or detergent thoroughly dissolved in sufficiently hot water (110°F. to 120°F.) to facilitate the removal of fats. Lukewarm water is unsatisfactory for a good job of dishwashing.

3. Rinsing:

For safe tableware, dishes must be rinsed in real hot water. Wherever it is impossible to provide for an adequate supply of hot water, a burner arrangement under a special constructed sink to keep the rinse water hot is advocated.

(a) Rinsing when two-sink unit used:

(1) Water in rinse sink must be kept at 170°F. Changes water whenever soapy, dirty or below given temperature.

(2) Submerge dishes, arranged in wire rack, in rinse water for at least one minute.

(3) Remove rack of dishes to clean dish drainboards.

(4) Allow dishes to drain and dry.

(5) Stack and store clean dry dishes.

(b) Rinsing when three-sink unit used:

Rinsing will accomplish a great percentage of the cleaning, but some type of 'sterilization' is good protection. A chlorine compound is most generally employed. An effective rinsing after washing and before immersion in compound solution is essential as is a clean sink, since the presence of either organic matter or detergent rapidly depletes chlorine strength.

(1) Water in rinse and sterilization sinks must be hot but not necessarily 170°F., but dishes rinsed in water below this temperature may have to be towelled.

(2) Dissolve disinfectant in sterilization water by use of a wire whip.

(3) Submerge dishes, arranged in wire rack, in rinse water for at least one minute.

(4) Submerge dishes, arranged in wire rack, in sterilization water for at least one minute.

(5) Remove rack of dishes to clean dish drainboard.

(6) Allow dishes to drain and dry.

(7) Stack and store clean dry dishes.

4. Cleaning of Dishwashing Equipment and Materials:

(a) Drain all sinks.

(b) Clear the dirty dish drainboard of all food particles.

(c) Scrub unit, including dishracks, with hot soapy water. Rinse.

(d) If tea towels are used and it is necessary to use them again at next mealtime, wash in hot soapy water.
(e) Wash table washing cloths and dish cloths or mops after each meal, in hot soapy water.

(f) Rinse tea towels in clear hot water.

(g) Rinse table washing cloths and dish cloths or mops in clear hot water.

(h) Hang tea towels, dish cloths or mops and table washing cloths to dry.

(i) Rinse sinks after washing tea towels, etc.

(j) Polish all surfaces with a clean dry cloth.

(k) Mop up any water which may have been spilt on floor.

Re: Repairs to Roof - St. Mary's Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ontario.

We are enclosing, in duplicate, plan of roof of St. Mary's Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ontario, Scale 8 ft. to one inch, and also a memorandum to the writer, both prepared by Mr. W.H. Wallace of this office. The plan and memorandum were prepared in May last following an investigation made of the roof by Mr. Wallace and an assistant. The plan and memorandum were not forwarded to you at that time, inasmuch as no conclusions had been reached as to what work should be done in connection with the roof.

The upper floor of this school originally was used as dormitories but with the completion of the addition to the school, about ten years ago, it has been used for class-rooms. The low ceiling, inadequate walls, and narrow windows do not permit of satisfactory conditions in these class-rooms and this situation, aggravated by damage to plaster through leakage, necessitates consideration being given to the rebuilding of the upper storey of the old structure. The writer has examined the structure at least twice with contractor's representatives and agree with them that there is impossible to definitely localize the origin of the leakage. The metal roofing appears to be in good condition but it is quite possible that the roof rafters, sheeting, ceiling joists and the 2" x 2" ribbing have deteriorated, permitting the metal roofing to become detached in places, to sag in certain areas and permit loosening of the eaves-trim. As a result of our visit Mr. Wallace in paragraph four of his memorandum, the most likely source of the leakage is at the juncture of the metal roofing with the shingled mansard roofing. This was originally faulty construction as the metal roofing did not sufficiently overlap the edge of the roof to prevent driving rain from penetrating above the shingles and under the metal roofing. Due consideration has been given to the idea of raising an extension to the outer edge of the metal roofing but this work, together with the reshingling of the mansard roof, the replacement of the metal flashing around the former windows and considerable auxiliary work, would be so expensive as to necessitate consideration being given to the replacement of the upper storey of the structure, particularly in view of the present unsatisfactory class-room accommodation.

Upon receipt of the plan and memorandum as prepared by Mr. Wallace and also upon receipt of this letter, we would appreciate an expression of opinion from your office as to what further line or action should be followed. We believe that it is desirable that members of the Indian Affairs Branch were to make an investigation of the condition of the class-rooms in this building in order that they may state definitely whether or not they are considered satisfactory.

D.B. Gow,
District Engineer.

Memorandum

Mr. D.B. Gow
Res St. Mary's (R.C.) Indian Residential School near Kenora, Ontario.

I visited the above school on the 3rd and 4th of May to inspect the condition of the roof and obtain necessary information for preparation of a plan.

The main roof, exclusive of the felt and gravel roof over the new addition at the south end, is of a mansard type with dormer windows. The slope of the top part of the roof from centre to front and rear of building is possibly 1 in 40, and may be considered relatively flat over the length or 122 feet and varying widths of 22 to 28 feet.

The top part is metal covered (galv. Iron No. 26 gauge), with 2" x 2" ribs at approx. 27° c.g. across the width of the roof; and the sloping sides of the roof are shingled. Although there is evidence of leakage at many points on the ceiling and on the upper part of the sloping walls in the class room below, and especially at that part of the ceiling and wall under the site of the water tank that was once on the roof, it could not be definitely ascertained whether leakage would occur if the roof over our time water tank was in position on the roof at the front side where tank was removed and the roof structure repaired and patched at the site. At the time of the inspection, this patched area, which is slightly depressed from the general slope, had water over it; and it is possible there was some leakage at this point. However, the general condition of the metal appeared to be sound. In effect, the metal does not lie flat and tight to the wooden sheeting below and the small slope from the centre to front and rear is not uniform as many slight depressions were noticed. The soldering at joints appeared to be good. The shingles on sloping part of roof are old; some slightly warped and a few missing and many are loose.

Most leakage probably occurs at the edge of the metal roof and its junction with the shingled part, by water draining off the metal top and getting in behind the shingles.

An attempt to ascertain the condition of the roof rafters, sheeting and ceiling joists was limited to a very small area, through a trap door in the ceiling of the class room. At this point, which is near centre of roof, with maximum height of 16' between ceiling and roof, the rafters, sheeting and joists appeared to be in good condition. There was no possible way to see the condition of the wood support for the roof rafters at a width sufficiently at the points where leakage may occur. However, from information given by the Fathers at the School, the condition of the ends of rafters would appear to be poor as difficulty has been experienced when trying to find secure nail hold in fastening eaves troughing. The wooden sheeting may be in similar poor condition in places.

Memorandum

Re: Roof Repairs, St. Mary's (R.C.) Residential School, Kenora, Ont.

We have noted your marginal request of December 8th on a memorandum from the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch, dated December 8th, 1949 respecting repairs to the roof of the above school.

We have made an analysis of the data available and would comment as follows:- Of the three proposals summarized by Indian Affairs in their memorandum, viz:

(1) The building of a new classroom block, with repairs only to the roof of the dormitory building;

(2) The rebuilding of the upper storey to provide better classroom accommodation and the replacement of the roof;

(3) The replacement of the roof only,

we prefer Item (1), that of building a new classroom block with repairs only to the roof of the dormitory building with any necessary plastering and painting to the interior caused by leakage, for the following reasons.

The information that Indian Affairs propose to erect a new 4-classroom school alters the entire complexion of this project; as to reconstruct the top storey as suitable classroom accommodation would entail new walls, roof, windows, wall board, everything, the acquisition of electric lighting, fire escapes, and numerous other features which we feel could not be done under some $25,000.00. The building was built in 1897, is of brick veneer with the floor of the top storey 27 feet above the ground and is, in general, altogether unsuitable for classrooms. Finally, we do not consider the structure worth the considerable expenditure which would be involved in reconstructing this storey.

Before making this recommendation final, we are writing Mr. Gow, who has twice examined the building, for his comments, with the suggestion that he consult several reasonable contractors with a view to obtaining tenders for repairs to the roof only. It is not feasible for us to evaluate the cost of these repairs but we feel that they should not be excessive.

It may be that some time will elapse before this information can be made available. You will be advised however, as soon as Mr. Gow's comment on our recommendation is received.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,

In reply to your letter No. F.129,992/1 of May 25th, 1916, with a communication from the Rev Father Magman, in reference to the surrender of a portion of the reserve by the Hat Portage band, for use of the Kenora boarding school.

I beg to inform you that I brought this matter before the band during the payments, and had the whole matter gone into and thoroughly explained to the Indians, but could not get any definite reply from them, they promised me to have a meeting and decide the question later on, and let me know.

A few days ago the Chief George Skeet or Enos wessex came into the Office, and handed me the enclosed paper, and said that was their decision, always provided they were to be paid the majority of the proceeds of the sale of the land.

This land has been surrendered for the purpose of its being added to the 50 acres at present connected with the Kenora Indian Boarding School. The Rev. Father Magan, writing for the Provincial Superior, has offered $8.00 per acre for the land for the school, which price is acceptable to the Indians.

As the Indians stated when giving the surrender that it was on condition that they receive half of the proceeds when the sale has been effected, their request will be complied with, there being provision for such action in section 99 of the Indian Act.

The Indian Agent reports that there are 16 Indians in this band entitled to vote; that 9 were present and all present voted in favour of the surrender. He adds, "The Chief states that he is sure that nearly all if not all the absentees would vote for the surrender if they were present."

Memorandum for Agent's Guidance.

1. The names of all heads of families (including absentees) entitled to participate in a distribution should be entered on the pay-list each year.

2. The Band Number of a family should on no account be changed.

Should a family become extinct, its number should be dropped and not used again.

3. When a member of a family is to be paid separately, as all adults should be, his or her name must be added at the end of the pay-list, under a new number; and the reason for paying separately should be given in the column for remarks.

4. All increases and decreases that affect the number in a family must be entered in the increase or decrease columns; those entered in the column headed "Other Causes," must be carefully explained in the column for "Remarks."

5. No money should be paid to Merchants or other persons who are not Indians, except by special permission of the Department.

6. No money should be paid to any Indian other than the one entitled, unless upon presentation of a written order, which should be attached to the pay-list.

7. Wherever possible the share of an absentee is to be remitted to him, by express order or post office order, at his expense, and the stub or number of the order is to be attached to or stated in the list. When money is sent by registered letter, a receipt for the letter from the postmaster should be attached to the list.

8. All money columns and the columns showing the number of Indians should be correctly added and balanced. The difference between the number on the list paid at this and the previous payment must equal the difference between the total increases or decreases noted in the increase and decrease columns.

9. The Statutory Declarations should be taken before a Justice of the Peace, or a Commissioner for taking affidavits, according to regulations.

10. The pay-list should be returned to the Department promptly after the distribution with a covering letter and statement. Only under very exceptional circumstances should it be retained longer than one month.

11. No additions are to be made to the pay-list unless title to be paid is made clear. The best attainable evidence of birth is to be got. In organized districts the paymaster should demand production of a copy of certificate of birth.

In the case of women from other districts entering the Band by marriage the paymaster must assure himself that they are not paid elsewhere by communicating with the Agent of the district from which they come. No one but newly born children and women entering the Band by marriage should be added to the list without the sanction of the Department.

Sir,

Rev Kerbrat, Principal of the Kenora Industrial School has been in to see me today and informs me that there are quantities of fallen trees and unsafe ones on the School property, which it is absolutely necessary to cut down for safety sake and to save the timber.

He wanted to know if it would be in order for him to cut these trees and sell them to the Hewatin Lumber Company, so as to get something for them. The amount received to be used by the School. As this amount would be very small I would recommend his request be granted.

The Principal allows the older pupils to cut cordwood for the School and pays them $1.00 a cord for the cutting, the boys use this money for various purposes such as purchasing hockey shoes, skates &c, and is a very good training as many of them will have to work in the woods to make a living when they leave school. The wood cut is of course used by the School.

I have told the Principal, he can cut down any dangerous trees and await authority to dispose of same.

My Dear Doctor Scott:

Rev. Fr J.E. Baillargeon O.M.I., Principal of Kenora Indian Residential School, is calling my attention to a rather sad situation existing in his neighbourhood and at the same time giving a suggestion that may bring relief. He desires me to write you in the matter.

The Indians of the Lake of the Woods through the failure of the blueberry crop have been unable to earn money and consequently are in need of even the necessities of life. The Reverend Principal would like to give them a little work that would help them specially in view of the coming Winter. He has for the use of his school only a few acres of cleared land which have given him this year just two tons of hay for about 15 head of cattle. There is certainly a necessity of clearing more land. It is quite a proposition as the rocky condition of the soil is a great handicap. The Reverend Principal requests the authority to proceed with said clearing and enough money for the same purpose, said money to be paid to the Indians in food or otherwise.

A little work on a road which leads to a small hayfield, three quarters of a mile from the school is also urgent. Same authority as above would be appreciated.

I therefore ask in the name of Rev. Fr Baillargeon for a sum of $700 to $800 for above improvements with the authority to have work done without delay.

Yours very truly,

REPORT OF INSPECTOR J. SEMMENS ON THE CECILIA JEFFREY BOARDING SCHOOL, DATED August 22nd, 1916.

In my last report reference was made to the condition of the mud banks of the point upon which the school buildings are situated. It was this time observed in addition to the erosion of the shore line and the fall of many valuable shade trees, the surging waves have ploughed a deep channel through the neck of the peninsula so that the school site has become an island and the construction of a bridge has become necessary to connect with the mainland. The cattle wade this stream night and morning and every passage deepens the channel. This might not be worthy of special mention were it not for the fact that the water intake and the sewer escapes are brought into proximity by the new channel connecting the stretches of water north and south. High winds will be sure to make reverse currents and the intermingling of water may be unfortunate. It may be that the level of the lake will so far subside that the filling of the new channel will be possible. If so it will be most fortunate but I fear trouble if this cannot be done.

Sir:

We have just finished taking in our potatoes and, as in the previous years, we have about one fourth of what is necessary for the year. All the rest will have to be bought. It is about the same thing with hay; every year we have to purchase two or three carloads.

To keep our school going we have to make very heavy expenses, and when we have to buy these commodities we can hardly live on the grant we receive from the Government; this you can easily understand.

Why have we such a poor crop? Because we have not not enough land cleared. There are about fifty acres that could could be cleared at about one hundred dollars an acre; but, up to the present time we have received very little help from the Department. It is true, in the past, we received a grant of a few hundred dollars, but, it was not even sufficient to prepare the land for clearing. It is a low lying piece which must be drained, and the grant received was about equal to one half of the money necessary to have the drainage done.

I have asked the Department four thousand dollars to clear some land next year. I should have asked for six or seven thousand at least. I did not dare do so; it is so often said to me; "The Department has no money!" Nevertheless I am convinced that six or seven thousand dollars would be hardly enough to prepare enough land to derive a substantial revenue from our work, and give some work to our Indian boys and train them to cultivate the soil in a profitable way. This proposition should, it seems, receive attention from the Department.

Now, I have a suggestion to make about some work I wish to have done this fall, as soon as possible. I wish to have four or five acres of land drained, and ditches dug in order to prepare the soil for next spring to grow potatoes and other vegetables. It is a very good time to do this work now; the ground is in the best condition possible on account of the extra dry weather we experienced last summer.

Most of our Indians have nothing to do now, have hardly anything to live on, and are asking for work in order to be able to buy the necessities of life. To prepare this piece of land now would fulfill a double purpose, namely give Indians work and food, and give us a chance of raising at least a good crop of potatoes next year. Consequently, I come to ask you to obtain for us the sum of $1800.00 at once to start the work immediately before it is too cold.
As it is impossible to let the Indians work alone, I have the intention to engage as foremen Mr. Joseph Gauthier and his son. They have supervised already very successfully some work done by the Indians in draining and clearing land. They are expert workers themselves, and while supervising do more work than their men.

Awaiting a favorable reply, I remain Sir,

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir;-

No doubt you have read with satisfaction that our new Government will spend twenty million dollars to relieve unemployment.

May we not take advantage of this situation to help our poor Indians in helping ourselves at the same time.

You have experienced several times that there is practically no road leading from the Golf Club to our School, a state of things that should not exist; we should have a decent road to go from here to town, there is no doubt about this.

May I ask you to kindly obtain that a road be built from the Golf Club to our school. It would cost approximately one thousand three hundred dollars, I suppose.

The work could be done mostly by Indians who are already in need of food and money. You are interested in these Indians; I had the occasion to notice it several times, and I am sure you will do your utmost to alleviate their misery and at the same time give us a hand in the best way possible.

I thank you for your kind cooperation.

Believe me,

Yours faithfully,

May 5th, 1941.

Mr Frank Edwards, Capt.
Indian-Agent,

Dear Sir;

Yesterday morning I was told that one horse was very sick; I was surprised because both horses were at work the day before. I send the farmer right away to get someone to doctor the sick horse, and they did all what could be done, but could not save him. The infection was so far gone from retention of stale. Dear Mr. MacKay,

I have been informed that several of your Indian Schools in my constituency and particularly those located in Kenora conduct farming operations and have livestock to supply food products for the Indian children.

Until recently if any farmer had trouble with his herds of cattle, horses and pigs no veterinary services were available from sources nearer than Winnipeg Port Arthur or Fort William and usually as this was exceedingly expensive, a substantial loss had to be suffered alternatively. On a co-operative basis the Kenora Agricultural Society made arrangements for the establishment of veterinary service in the Kenora area with precedence of service going to members of the Association.

The Province of Ontario is paying one half of the annual cost up to $2400 per year. That means that the Kenora Agricultural Society must raise $1200 per year.

I am told that since the establishment of this service Indian Schools have been getting regular aid but in return have given only varying support more or less at the discretion of the principals. Though it is understood that the Indian Department would supply veterinary services to the schools from Dr. Watts at Fort William, I am informed that emergency needs often arise and the only immediate help is to be found from the Kenora Agricultural Society's veterinarian.

It has been suggested that it would be better if the Department of Indian Affairs were to arrange to make an annual contribution to the Kenora Agricultural Society in return for veterinarian service at their several schools. I would appreciate it very much if you could have an enquiry made as to

Re: Kenora Agricultural Society,

The above society provides veterinary services for members who own cattle. The Cecilia Jeffrey Residential School, Kenora Residential School, and the McIntosh Residential School have membership in the above society.

The following is the determining factors in regard to the membership fees which make the schools eligible for veterinary services:

Minimum charge - $3.00
3 to 10 head of cattle @ $1.00 per head,
all over 10 head are charged at the rate of 50¢ per head with a maximum charge of $25.00. There is also a mileage charge of 10¢ per mile payable by the school management to the veterinary for the use of his car on each call.

The membership fee for the Cecilia Jeffrey School therefore is $14.00 per year. This school has 14 cattle and 4 horses making a total of 18 head.

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Michael Charley Macheegabow, Pupil No. 199, of the Kerrora R.C. Indian Residential School at Kerrora, Ont., who died at St. Joseph's Hospital (place) on 1st June 1937.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

CHURCH. Mr. Bilkie took all the services and administered Holy Communion March 6th and April 3rd. On Easter Sunday the School-room was appropriately decorated with flowers and plants and the Church brass by the pupils. On April 10th it was warm enough for us to commence services at the Church and it has been arranged that services be held at 10 a.m. for the season.

RECREATION. The boys show great enthusiasm in the Cadet Corps drills and are busy preparing for the Annual Inspection on May 10th. To relieve the monotony of drilling under the same Instructor Mr. Rogers arranged for the Sergeant-major of the local Regiment to train the boys in certain work and they have responded very well. Much time is spent at the river fishing and ball games occupy most of the short recesses. Good Friday was a holiday after service and all Easter Monday. Easter Day all pupils had eggs for breakfast and candy eggs for supper.

HEALTH. We have had a troublesome epidemic of "pink eye" with the boys, one case of uremic poisoning, one of erysipelas, and another of Scarlet Fever which was sent to the Isolation Hospital. One girl who had tubercular trouble in hand was sent to Doctors and X-rayed. Amputation was advised below the wrist but the father took the girl away for home treatment. Several pupils have been attending dentist and others the oculist. The changeable weather has given rise to several cases of sore throat and rheumatism.

Incidentals. The Apple-storehouse was broken into one night and the chicken house locks were damaged. Strange men have been reported about the buildings on several occasions. On April 22nd a very heavy rain flooded the man-holes and one caved-in. The river and creek flooded the flats. The transformer was affected by the lightning and had to be replaced as did a pole carrying high-tension wires to it.
IMPROVEMENTS. The gas was found to be inferior and causing damage to plumbing fixtures so it was cut-off entirely with the exception of the kitchen which must have an auxiliary cooking stove in case of emergency. Electric irons in laundry necessitated additional wiring. The Medicine chest was removed from Main Building to Girls Study Room and another was built in the Boys Wing. Drinking Fountains were placed in Boys and Girls Corridor. The Lower Corridor was grained and the School-rooms were painted. The Entrance steps were rotting at the Base so the lower one was removed and replaced by a brick step and the others were under-stayed. Brick steps were built on the front of the Gardeners Cottage to replace the wooden ones which were unsafe. The Chicken runs were re-fenced.

The Furnace chimney was re-built. The mortar had dried out and was crumbling away leaving the bricks loose and dangerous to those passing underneath. This was dangerous work and we protected ourselves by taking out an accident insurance for the period the work was in progress. A chimney which had been partly built when the building was erected was completed - coming through the roof directly behind the Cupola.

A brick fire-place was built in the visiting room which was papered and decorated as an officers sitting-room. The former sitting-room is now used as a visiting-room. The gas-pipes throughout the entire building were removed, excepting the kitchen. The gas grate on the Principal's flat was converted into a coal grate.

Extra wiring was required upon the removal of the gas stoves and a few wall connections for reading lamps were installed. The condemn control board was replaced by a new panel also the Entrance Service was altered to come up to Inspector's requirements at a cost of $600.

The Drawing Room and two Bed-rooms on the Principal's flat were papered, painted and the floors done over.

FARM AND GARDEN. In spite of a very early Spring the varied weather made farming difficult. We have Spring ploughed 65 acres on Chabo commenced March 21st. We commenced working the low lands on April 4th and sowed oats. April 13th we commenced fencing the Plats and picking up stone after the floods. Planted the first potatoes April 22nd. We have ploughed the orchards and planted out new
Bi-Monthly Report. Mohawk Institute, Brantford Ont. March and April 1921

and fruit bushes, transplanted the strawberries, sprayed the trees (this operation was hindered by the sprayer working badly). The greenhouse and hot-beds are filled to capacity much of the work being done by the girls. April 26th, we sowed barley and commenced working the root land. Farm teams hauled coal from the Grand Trunk Station, removed ashes, manured land and much wood was cut. The ice-house was re-shingled and sundry other roofs were repaired. The frost April 16th, did a good deal of damage. Killed three pigs for school consumption. Engaged Cattle-man and assistant-gardener for the season April 1st.

NOTE: Mrs Boyce went to Ottawa for a week early in March. Miss Ward acted as Nurse and looked after the cleaning during her absence. Mr. Mutter Manual Training Instructor was delighted with the progress the boys made. Some of the models are excellent. Major Smith inspected both months. The Hydro Electric Commission made specifications for new line serving Institute. The Coal Contract was let to Gibson Company who commenced hauling March 21st, and filled all the bins. March 26th received cheque for $1,000, to be refunded in two years. The Buffalo visited the School and Reserve and photographed some of the pupils. We set our incubator in the Hospital with good results. April 13th, moved part of Mrs Boyce's furniture to the principal's flat. Mrs Ashton died April 14th, suddenly and the funeral took place on Sunday afternoon April the 17th. The Boys acted as Guard of Honour several of the older Girls sang in the Service very sweetly. Mr Lee for a long time Missionary at Cayuga and Mr Jeaking took the service. The Church was beautiful with Easter lilies and forms. Mr. Ashton was moved to the Institute April 18th, and the rest of the furniture sent down April 25th.

Report on Manual Training at Mohawk Institute

A start was made in Manual Training in this school on Saturday, February 19th, 1921. I was engaged as teacher of the subject by the Principal Mr. Boyce, to take classes every Saturday morning until the beginning of May. Work started with a class of sixteen boys but as the tools supplied were not sufficient, the class was divided and came on alternate days. The work taken up was: The theory of timber and tools with notes and sketches of same.

Elementary exercises in woodwork. Planing, sawing, the making of halving and mortise and tenon joints, followed by more advanced work, entailing the use of these joints, such as the Oxford picture and four legged low seats. These latter were glued and clamped. Additional lessons were given in upholstering (webbing, stuffing, covering, etc.)
Additional work was taken up in the way of small local repairs.

I attended 12 Saturdays for three hours per day, making a total of 36 hours so that 16 pupils received 18 hours instruction. The discipline and attention of the boys was excellent; they took naturally to the work and made a success of it in every instance and compare favourably with any pupils in this work that I have ever handled, showing fine self-reliance and perseverance.

I would suggest that this is an excellent opportunity for a technical department being introduced at the Institute which would work in well with the training in farm work that the boys receive, besides opening other avenues of vocational choice for them. To continue there are only tools for a limited number. The workshop at the Institute could easily be arranged to accommodate a full class.

CHURCH. We had Holy Communion Service at home on May 1st, on account of the heavy rain but all other services have been held at the Mohawk Church. Mr. Morrison officiated on June 29th and Mr. Birkie all other services. We have Holy Communion on first Sunday in each month.

DRESS. On June the 19th, the girls wore their new dresses of aeroplane linen trimmed with blue and their new black hats. They looked very nice. The boys wore their summer Cadet uniforms on June 25th.

IMPROVEMENTS. The grounds and buildings look a great deal fresher and brighter of late. The girls painted the windows, doors and verandahs of the center building; the boys doing these parts difficult of access. The front hall and the stairs have all been renovated. The beds, sheets and counterpanes from Ottawa make our girls dormitories look better and the cupboards, clothing racks, etc., all fill a long-felt want. Considerable work has been put on to the front entrance, the road has been repaired and the grass and borders trimmed. The flower beds have also been set out. The orchards have been well worked and the fruit trees and bushes have been planted. In fact, the orchards and farm and garden look cleaner and better than they have done for years.

HEALTH. Scarlet Fever broke out on May 10th, and as we had five cases we opened our own Hospital and obtained the services of Miss Ward, trained nurse. The nurse came out of quarantine on May 19th, but she stayed in the building until May 27th looking after the sick in hospital. We closed the hospital on June 27th and fumigated the same day and also the following day.

Charlie Stans, suffering from T.B.C. abscesses was allowed sick leave on May 20th.

George Johnson dislocated his elbow on May 16th.

NOTES. The soups and pilchards sent by the Department are very much appreciated.

Manual Training Course finished May 5th.

Cadet Inspection by Lt. Col. Barker May 10th.

Russell Longboat, one of three senior boys who are buglers in the...
regiment, took first prize in a Battalion Shooting Match on May 9th.

On May 11th, Mr. Rogers went to Toronto re D.S.C.R. supplies.

Inspector Wylie, Canadian Fire Underwriters Association passed our wiring in general but pointed out that unless certain alterations were made in connection with lighting the basement and dining halls, he would have to render an report condemning the same.

The census sheets were sent in.

Mr. Cook of Department and Major Smith inspected June 9th.

Mr. Rogers went to Mount Pleasant to inspect and select desks for Junior school on June 10th.

On June 15th, we commenced to unload the car of Stores from Ottawa at 8.30 a.m. and the last load was taken off by 11.15 p.m. By 6p.m. the goods were checked and stored in addition to the mattresses being carbolised and scrubbed.

Mary came here on June 16th, from the O.S.E.

On June the 20th, the school was favoured by a visit from Mrs Scott accompanied by Mr. Harold and Major Smith.

Mrs Burnett was on holiday from June 23rd to 26th.

Laureen Hill on June 25th, was allowed out with friends and was apprehended for theft at the local store of Messrs Woolworths.

On June 29th, Mrs Boyce Miss Hardie and Mr. Rogers motored to Mount Elgin.

June the 30th, the pupils went to see Circus procession in the morning after which they were invited to a free performance in the afternoon.

During the passed two months all blankets have been washed. The boys have been issued with two new shirts and the girls have had a set of blue aprons. All pupils have had new shoes and stockings.

FARM and GARDEN. Early potatoes were planted May 3rd, and the late on May 31 and June 2nd.

We commenced sales on local Market on May 7th.

We have had a period of very heavy rains and thunderstorms followed by a spell of extremely hot weather. The potatoes have required frequent spraying. We have been selling new potatoes since 25th June and we are able to offer a very good specimen on the market besides using them freely in the Institute. The fruit trees and bushes...
Purchased by the Department are all doing well, there being only a very small percentage that are not thrifty.

The pupils have been enjoying strawberries, cherries, red and white currants for their suppers in addition to lettuce etc.

Much repair work has been put on to the fences and we managed to procure a quantity of fence posts at a very reasonable figure.

The shingles on Horse Barn have been repaired.

Our first sowing of Mangolds proved a failure and we consequently had to re-work and re-sow that crop on May 26th.

The sowing of the Silo corn was completed on May 26th.

The approach to the Canal bridge was washed away by heavy rains but half a day's work using old material on hand remedied this.

We commenced to cut hay on the 20th June.

All teaming in connection with stores from Ottawa and the deskes from Mount Pleasant has been done by the Farm Department.

August 4th., 1921.

Sir,

I beg to report that on Tuesday last I made an inspection of the Mohawk Institute. It being holiday season there were no classes in instruction. The plumbers were there putting in the new toilets and the farm section of the Institute was busily engaged in taking in the crops.

Mrs. Boyce has received a very large consignment of hospital supplies from Toronto which cost her nothing but freight, as a result she expects very little clothing will have to be bought for the children for the next two years. Besides clothing a large amount of useful material for the kitchen and other portions of the building were obtained.

Work in the greenhouse extension will be started this week. In the farm they have sold over $50.00 worth of early potatoes while large returns have been received for green beans produce.

A cow was killed by lightning, in a recent storm but insurance has been recovered for it.

Mrs. Boyce has secured the services of Mr. Buchanan a farrier who is possessed of certificates for Social Service Work Ltd. and is willing to go up to advise the girls in light farm work during the holidays, at least for those who attend the Institute. His salary will be $25.00 a month.

Mrs. Boyce says that there is nobody to look after the girls in the winter, no satisfactory work would be accomplished and she feels that she must be employed for at least half the day during the holidays.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mrs Boyce,

I am having a lovely time out here. But I didn't feel well the first two weeks I was here.

Well—how are all of the girls? I hope they are all leaving themselves, are they? I wrote to Mrs Bennett but she hasn't answered me yet—so you must tell her to answer will you?

Eloise told me to send you her love, she said. I stole all the news worth telling so she can't write.

I really don't think that's the case, is it? The case of laziness don't you? Is Mr Rogers still living? I often think about you all. You couldn't imagine how lonesome I got for you.

Mrs Cocksheutt is very nice to me.

Well, I must close now till everybody you see to write back so good—Bye from one by your bed.
I don't think I'll close yet because it will look so silly with only a few words on.

Edie is just sitting here laughing for all she's worth. She isn't worth very much what do you think.

Have you any new girls down there.

I suppose the girls are very glad they passed the Entrance Exams.

I know Edie was, she sang all day and night.

We have an awful time up here with the mice and rats.

I am so skinny I can hardly see myself. Well, I really must close now.

From Ozell.

P.S. Answer soon please.

Monthly Report July and August 1921

The farm teams drew the gravel for the greenhouse foundations.

The sewers were inspected and repaired. Cowls were built on new chimneys and the furnaces were overhauled and new grates put in.

Three new toilets were installed and one that had been a continual source of trouble and was found to be damaged was replaced by a new fixture.

The sewing room was whitewashed and the girls then painted the woodwork and lower walls. The floor was also thoroughly painted and varnished and the old benches replaced by modern desks and tables. The tables were sent us by the D.S.C.R.

The Junior teachers' room was re-decorated and the music-room while the various officers were away their room floors were done over.

The pianos and organ were repaired and tuned.

The girls worked on the flower beds, lawns and churchyard.

The farm cottage near the church was wired and water was laid into the gardener's cottage. The front steps were re-inforced with cement and repaired.

The greenhouses purchased were pulled down and moved here. We commenced the new foundations on August 12th.

Extensive repairs were made to furniture in the Dining Hall and the Girls' playroom.

Entire new cutlery and chinamugs for girls, enamel for boys, plates and serving dishes were purchased for the Dining Hall.

The Junior School was fitted with modern desks in graduated sizes.

The teachers had six weeks vacation and the matron a month.

The house was filled by a girl

farmerette, Miss Buchanan was engaged to look after the girls during the mornings and to take charge of them during their walks afternoons.

The Housekeeper, Miss Davidson contracted blood-poisoning after being ill a week left for her holiday and Miss P. took place in the kitchen.
Holidays commenced July 17th, those having homes were given three weeks. School re-opened August 27th. We had an average of 42 girls and 25 boys here during the holidays. They had a half-day holiday each day with the exception of a few older boys who were employed on the farm all day and were paid accordingly.

Amusements were arranged for them, and Old Home Week in Brantford provided much interesting recreation. The old benches in the Junior School were removed early in the holiday and the pupils had several enjoyable evenings dancing, playing parlour games, or boxing.

August 29th, new classifications were made and the clothing issues issued were checked up making it possible to have school in regular running order on August 30th.

Carrie Crowe and Elsa Clause commenced their course at the Business College.

Flo Elliott took honours at the Conservatory of Music examinations and Creatha Thomas passed.

Carrie Crowe passed the Collegiate Entrance with honours whilst Elsa Clause and Kathleen Macrae passed and Jesse MacKenzie failed in arithmetic.

The boys' clothing from Regina arrived August 18th.

The stores from Toronto and the stationery from Ottawa arrived July 6th.

Lily Fox, a student at the Collegiate, went out with a man employed on the farm and as we had had trouble with her before we secured her a place as cook. The man was discharged.

A blanket insurance was placed on crops harvested on August 10th.

We were able to buy heavy underwear for girls to very great advantage at the Paris Mills.

Emmie Gibson ran away from the people who have been in the habit of taking him home for holidays and was arrested for vagrancy at Oakville. Mr. Rogers, however, was able to get charge withdrawn and the boy returned.

Instead of the "Budge System" we have formerly used we have now commenced a fresh scheme. Each pupil is allowed 16 cents monthly and this amount is paid into a fund controlled by a committee of pupils and one officer, who may spend it in any way they choose for the benefit of the others in general; (for instance corn roasts, feasts, sporting...

However, deductions are to be made from this amount in the manner of fines for clothing and articles found out of place, careless smashing of windows, destruction of property, loss of cutlery and any other carelessness which is constantly increasing the running expenses. It is hoped that this method will help to make all careful and that the older pupils will realise that they are in some way responsible for the proper conduct of the younger.
