BI/MONTHLY REPORT.

BRANT INSTITUTE BRANTFORD, ONTARIO.

September and October 1921.

CHURCH. All the services were held at the Church except that on September 25th when wet weather kept the children at home. Holy Communion was administered September 4th and on October 9th. Mr Pearson officiated on the latter date. We held Harvest Festival services on October 16th for which occasion the girls had artistically decorated the Church. On October 30th the pupils attended a special Children's Service at St. Jude's Church.

HEALTH. We had an outbreak of Chicken-pox amongst the boys and a general epidemic of influenza which kept several of the staff and many of the pupils in bed. John Antone met with an accident while threshing and broke his arm as a result of falling from the mow. Leonard Benhamke fell on the stairs and injured his hip. Both boys received immediate medical attention and are well again. George Staats underwent an operation in the local hospital for double hernia. The minor complaints include several cases of sore eyes, the usual outbreak of itch following holidays and one case of acute eczema.

STAFF. Miss Walker engaged for one month as Housekeeper, on trial, was succeeded by Mrs Heale.

Miss Kayen left October 1st having been ill off and on all September.

Miss Cummings, teacher, from Reserve School No. 5 was engaged at once but could not assume her duties until October 25th. In the meantime Jessie MacNaughton took the Junior School very creditably.

Mrs Burnett, sewing teacher, had her vacation.

Miss Lee, farmerette, had to leave suddenly, October 6th on account of illness at home.

NOTES. Major Smith inspected September 1st.

Mr Standing, Public Schools inspector, was here October 17th.

Mrs Baythornhaeit of Moose Factory School spent several hours here on three different occasions.

The Staff of the French Train and the Board of Trade paid us a visit when they were in Brantford.

LABOUR DAY. September 6th. The Boys were interested spectators.
at the Battalion Rifle Matches held on the Ranges of this property. One of our senior boys taking part made a very fair score. The girls went swimming and visited the stores.

SPORTS DAY. October 12th. In spite of very cold weather our sports were a great success. This year the local merchants were asked to provide the prizes and a very useful collection of articles was made. Our baker provided the refreshments. The pupils were very enthusiastic in their races and events. We were however disappointed that Mr. Abrahams was not present and he promised to judge our horses and Cattle. The boys' horses were splendid and our visitors expressed their admiration both of the cleanliness of the teams and harness and of the skilled manner in which the teams were driven. The cattle were also in good condition and very clean. Refreshments were provided in the School-room where we also staged a boxing contest. Mrs. C. J. Smith presented the prizes at the close of the afternoon.

PLOUGHING MATCH. October 26th. It was considered advisable that our boys should attend the local ploughing match in company of the farm staff who were instructed to use the opportunity from an educational point of view. A marked difference in the quality of the work done by our teamsters since that date shows the benefit derived already.

Chawaken Fair. October 14th. The boys attended this Fair and attracted a lot of attention by their very smart turn-out.

REGIMENTAL CHURCH PARADE. The Cadets were specially invited to attend Church Parade on October 24th. with the Regiment. Colonel Colquhoun in an address congratulated the boys on their general smartness in both dress and drill. The girls were present as onlookers.

PUPILS DANCE. October 16th. The girls entertained the boys and gave a Box Social which they financed from their own funds. This fund comes from the new system of rewards which has had a marked effect in the tidiness, care of clothing and equipment.

Mrs. Boyce went to Ottawa for two days October 10th.

The assault case of Nettie Clench is causing much trouble and worry and so far little or no progress has been made towards securing conviction.
Wilfred Henry, who has caused much trouble and has been guilty of several petty thefts from officers another boys, absconded in company of a cousin L. Wilson and both are wanted by the police for theft. Ernest Snake has absconded several times being returned each time by the local police. He is absent now.

The girls are now wearing a most becoming set of "tams" made from the blue serge hospital gowns. The necessary issues of warmer clothing and extra blankets have been made and the centre furnace was lit on October 5th.

Sewers. These are a constant source of trouble and require very careful attention in order to keep them effective. Within two weeks recently two portions had to be dug out in order to remove stoppages. Owing to a very small pipe being used in this construction small rags scrub cloths etc cause obstructions.

The white paint recently applied to the outside of the building has greatly improved the appearance; the dome is now an ornament.

The new greenhouse and extensions to potting shed are nearing completion. All the greenhouse construction has been carried out by the staff and is all being painted.

Two hot-plates have been installed in the kitchen and sundry repairs have been carried out by electricians to meet the underwriters standards.

The laundry washing machine and the extractor have been thoroughly overhauled. Our old motor burnt out on September 26th but we have been able to rent another which will operate the machinery until the Hydro connect us to their system. This motor, however, will not work both machines at once as is necessary for efficient work.

The Hydro Electric commenced placing poles October 22nd. In order to keep the cost of this installation down as much as possible we are digging all holes.

Mr Coutts of the G.M.W. commenced a class in telegraphy and has expressed his pleasure at the progress made. The D.S.C.R. Toronto were able to provide us with instruments.

Heavy gales blew down a quantity of apples. This year crop was not good although we seem to be more fortunate than our neighbours. We have not, however, been able to store as many this year as last but the children have been able to enjoy quantities already
Our crops have been good and we have been able to store the following for winter use besides having been plentifully provided during the season.

- 262 bags Potatoes.
- 1,400 lbs Mangolds and turnips.
- 3,000 head Cabbage
- 3,000 " Celery,
and squash, pumpkins, citrons and beets.

We threshed:
- 235 bus. Rye.
- 118 " Wheat.
- 552 " Barley,
- 174 " Buckwheat.
- 1,492 " Oats.

In all, we have 89 tons of good hay and owing to the very excellent corn crop we have a large quantity over and above that necessary to fill the silo. We have already husked 12 loads. The beans yielded well this year.

Having a surplus of straw we baled 18 tons which we intend to sell when the market is favourable.

Although we have been exceptionally busy on the Farm and Garden and have accomplished much, we are glad to be able to report that in no single instance has any boy had to neglect his lessons or miss school in order that so much should be done.

We commenced:
- Milling Silo...........September 14th.
- Second threshing......October 17th.
- Baling straw..........September 2nd.
- Sowing Fall wheat.....September 7th.
- Sowing Rye............September 2nd.

We were able to buy by auction and large quantity of bridg lumber from the County Engineer. There were seven loads in all and their will enable us to re-floor the horse stable, repair or bridges, generally take good and provide the Institute with kindling for the winter.

All the plaster throughout the building was repaired with the exception of the hall (bay-room) which needs a little more than painting to put it in order. The walls of the stairways and hallway at both wings were whitewashed adding greatly to their appearance.

Mr. Asheton went to stay at Grimsby for some months on October 24th.

Is all suffered from poisoning on October 24th. It is thought that some girl put an irritant (possibly lye) in the baking powder and officers and pupils alike suffered. The suspected baking powder was handed over to local chemists and we await their report.
It is our intention to kill our own meat this winter. Already we have enjoyed one home-killed calf and chickens are available when required.

Our first spring chicken to lay laid on October 15th.

The chicken houses and the apple house have been lime sprayed.

Sir,

In answer to your enquiry of November 14th regarding the assault case of Nettie Clench, I regret to report that no progress has been made in securing evidence to warrant a charge being laid. Mrs. Boyce arranged with Nettie to send a letter to Miller requested him to come to the Mohawk to see her and arrangements were made to overhear the conversation in the hope that Miller might make some confession, but he did not answer the letter and did not turn up. It appears to me that he is getting suspicious and is watching his movements. The Crown Attorney informed me that it would be useless to attempt to secure a conviction on the evidence which we now have as there is no corroboration. It is a question which I have been considering whether it would be advisable to lay the information and bring the young man to trial in the hope that admissions might be made by him in Court and it is possible that a prosecution even if it does fail might have a beneficial effect on others as this offence is unfortunately too common on the Reserve.

In my letter of the 5th inst., making a request for the usual grant to assist pupils to attend High School I referred to the case of Helen Bradley who was stated by two young Indians to be the cause of their infection with Venereal Disease, but Dr. Greenwood has informed me that the usual blood test taken in such cases shows that this girl did not have the disease and since then I have not heard anything more in regard to her.

Dear Mrs. Boyce,

I have been giving attention to the case of Nettie Clench. Major Smith informs me that the county Crown Attorney told him it would be useless to attempt to obtain a conviction from the evidence we now have, as there is no corroboration. Major Smith has been considering whether it would be advisable to lay the information and bring the young man to trial in the hope that admissions might be made by him in Court. He thinks it possible that a prosecution even if it does fail might have a beneficial effect on others, as this offense is unfortunately too common on the reserve.

In consulting Mr. Williams, the Departmental Solicitor, he points out that if there were no corroborative evidence in support of the charge, the lawyer for the accused would not put his client in the witness box and there would be accordingly no chance of obtaining any admissions from him.

Madam:

I have to refer to a matter arising out of the report of Mr. Superintendent Smith, dated the 2nd instant. Allow me to quote from Mr. Smith's report:

"Since the terms of the Adolescence Act are to be enforced at the Institute, Mrs. Boyce is somewhat worried as to how the children are to be occupied especially if they pass the entrance examination and attend High School. She now has one girl who will pass the Business College examination before she is 15 and there are others who will pass the Entrance Examination before they reach that age."

The Department believes that any ruling of this type by the Ontario Department of Education does not affect the routine or conduct of an Indian residential school. We have rules and regulations for our Indian wards and for their education, and no programme outlined by the Provincial Department of Education need be adopted unless Ottawa sees fit.

I would like to have a communication from you in connection with the advisability of starting a class for those students who are qualified to take high school work. There has been some doubt on our residential schools in the West where the students before reaching the age of discharge were qualified to take secondary education. I feel that this matter should receive the Department's attention, so that any special training we initiate could be offered this winter.

I had hoped to pay a visit to the Mohawk Institute this calendar year, but I am convinced that, due to the amount of work that has been presented to the School Branch at this time, my trip will have to be postponed.

Your obedient servant,

Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir:

In reply to your letter re the advisability of starting a class in telegraphy among the students who are unable to pursue high school work. As we are so near the city schools - I think it will cost less to send our pupils to the town. We have got the accommodations for another class room - teachers rooms etc.

As we have to keep our children out of idleness we are making every effort to give them variety and entertainments both in and out of school. When qualified - after say six months' months - they can earn eighty a month in normal towns - one hundred and twenty dollars a month in the cities.
The boys are interested in their manual training classes—last week they repaired—in some cases upholstered—a lot of chairs that had been neglected for years.

Next Summer I intend to give the senior girls a short course in knitting, crocheting, embroidery—cooking in small quantities, making them write down the recipes and directions.

Meanwhile we are making a start at an orchestra—we have not found a suitable instructor in the girls—for an advanced orchestra.

Our Christmas entertainment will take place next Friday evening. The school room will be decorated—we will close with a few carols and prayers—as a few are leaving for their holidays.

Dear Mrs. Boyce,

I have yours of the 17th instant, referring to the matter of salary for Miss Cummings and the possibility of a pension for Miss Hardie. I will be pleased to offer for the approval of the Deputy a definite recommendation from you as to an increase for Miss Cummings. If you will indicate to me what you believe is fair and just I will be glad to approach Mr. Scott regarding the matter.

Concerning the possibility of a pension for Miss Hardie, I have to state that at the present time there is no provision made for teachers of our residential or day schools upon their retirement. The desirability of pensioning a teacher of Indian children is not often brought to our attention. Day school teachers seldom remain many years in the employ of the Department, and teachers of residential schools are nominated by the church authorities and their care in later years devolves upon the church missionary society if it is found necessary to provide for old age. In the case of Miss Hardie, might I suggest that you write the New England Company in an effort to enlist their sympathy and their action in connection with their retirement fund.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that on the 20th inst. I made my usual monthly inspection of the Mohawk Institute.

They were making Christmas preparations and arranging for amusements for the children on that day. Tonight they are giving a concert for the girls and on Monday night arrangements are made for a treat for the boys which will probably take the form of a drive in the motor truck which they received from Toronto. On Sunday the special dinner is a concert and a joint roast pork, turkey and plum pudding and for supper the table is to be specially decorated with flowers and ribbon and they are to have figs, dates, nuts, candies, oranges etc., as extras and on Monday hot pork, vegetables and mince pies etc. Mrs. Boyce expects to have all the pupils present and about eight present for the Christmas holidays as so many parents have been asked to keep them during the holidays as times are so hard on the Reserve that they cannot afford any extra expense.

Under the new Instructor which they have for Manual Training a great deal of useful work is accomplished as well as useful instruction given to the boys. All the broken chairs, benches etc., are repaired by the boys, new arms and seats put on the chairs some have been upholstered, all the benches in the new green houses have been built by the Manual training class and after New Years they intend to overhaul all the wagons on the farm.

In the stables there were 19 milking cows, besides 10 calves and the bull. The herd is gradually being improved and brought back to a profit basis. Green houses well filled with vegetables to go to market early when prices are high. Amongst one of the recent purchases of clothing was a quantity of suits purchased from Mr. W. Grant of Montreal, these have to be cut down and altered to fit the boys but Mrs. Boyce cannot get any clothing firm to tender for the work any lower than $750 per suit, the ripping to be done at the school which Mrs. Boyce considers too high, there are about 50 suits required at present. She has now arranged to secure the services of a tailor or tailoress to do the work at the school on a time basis which she thinks would save considerable cost. She expects to have this arrangement made after Christmas.

CONCERT GIVEN AT MOHAWK INSTITUTE

Girls Offered an Excellent Program — The Christmas Celebration

The Mohawk Institute girls' concert was an excellent one. The program was:

- Carol, "We Three Kings of Orient Are."
- Song—Carrie Crowe and Sylvia Jamieson.
- Dance—"Bacon Piper," Helen Frohman, and orchestra.
- Piano Solo—Florenta Elliott.
- Dialogue—"The Ruggles."
- Drill Club Swinging, Senior girls.
- Recitations—"Christmas Doings," Little girls.
- Chorus—"The Bells Are Ringing," VI. Class.
- Dance—Little girls and orchestra—Elliotte.
- Dialogue—"Uncle Joe's Will."
- Dance—Irish Lilt and Jig, Helen Frohman.
- Recitation—Pearl Johnson.
- Drill—"He Be Britannia," Senior girls and flaks.
- Recitation—Cecile Maracle.
- Chorus—"Sing a Song of Christmas," Little girls.
- Chorus—"John Winter," VI. Class.
- Orchestra—Selected.
- School Yell.
- Carols—Accompanied by orchestra.

Major Gordon Smith was chairman and both he and Mr. Standing, teacher, praised the girls for their splendid concert.

All the numbers were worthy of praise; the recitations were spoken very clearly and the choruses were musical. The drill and flag drill were excellent and the little stories were exceptionally good. The acting was carried throughout showing artistic talent.

The school room was decorated with Xmas and Christmas bells and other decorations.

Boys' Concert At Mohawk Institute

On Monday evening at the Mohawk Institute the boys gave a very successful concert that was enjoyed by all in the house and others who came out as visitors. It was long enough to be good and proved to be highly diverting.

The program included the following numbers: Chorus, "O Canada," by school; drill, by six large boys; solo, "Good King Wenceslas," done by Bertie dance, three little Nigerian song, by Mr. Rogers, school jointing in chorus; sketch, "Sale of an Automobile," dance, three little boys; closing exercise.

Mr. Mutter of Hamilton was the chairman. The boys were glad to welcome him back, and were proud to show off the automobile which was bought by the boys for the boys' class. It was a wonderful success. As one girl said at breakfast next morning, "My, I laughed till my side ache!" All others echoed this with loud all over. It certainly was surprising the number of accidents that could happen to a second-hand auto when exhibited for sale.

The dancing done by the three little nurses was excellent. They were amusing.

Mr. Mutter congratulated the house and at the close of the exercises an unfortunate accident happened. An open door caused a candle to set fire to the velvet hangings at the back of the chimney. It was soon in an inferno. The heavy curtains were soon pulled down and the fire put out; buckets of water and fire extinguishers which were rushed in did not reach. Many badly scorched heads and ruined curtains and decorations were the result.

IMPROVEMENTS. A water front was installed in one of the kitchen ranges to heat a boiler that was previously heated by gas.

A new toilet was installed in the boys dormitory to replace one broken.

All glass was inspected and broken glass replaced. The Storm windows were overhauled, repaired, cleaned and put up.

The room usually occupied by the farm hands as a bedroom was re-furnished as a Study room for the senior boys.

The Western Canadian Electric Co. reported that two of our poles were down on November 18th, but they made temporary repairs until the Hydro line was restored. The school is now equipped with a 5 H.P. motor and our troubles so far an insufficient power supply over. The Hydro contract was signed on November 30th the day connections to that service were completed.

The Girls Playground has been levelled and a new fence built around it.

Rough partitions were built up in the attic and a large store-room formed in which can be locked all stores liable to be tampered with. All cupboards containing clothing have been lined with tar paper to insure protection from moths.

The Carpenter's shop has been re-arranged. Stairs were built from the shop to basement which now contains all stores, paints and fittings. The shop itself has been adapted as a Manual Training centre. The electric lights were amended and a stove erected. All this work has been part of the Manual training programme which while it aims to teach the finer work also ensures that the pupils learn such carpentering and fitting as will be most useful to those who follow farming as a vocation.

The Manual Training Class has repaired a number of chairs and benches for the School. The bench for the new greenhouse were built by the boys who also made bob-sleighs and outdoor sports tools and their own enjoyment. Picture framing has also been taught and the boys are now competent to make coat hangers.

Some old man-hole tops have been repaired.

One section of our open drive shed has been partitioned off and extended to accommodate the new truck and the power sprayer. This is fitted with folding doors also made by the boys.

A new road has been made by the new greenhouse and a lower bed put in.

Great fun was taken by the boys who built a "proverb" car which played a great part in the boys' entertainment.

Mr. Rogers went again in the hope of purchasing boys underwear but bought shop soiled garments cheaper in the city.
A candle set fire to the heavy velvet hangings in the chancel which was open for the closing service at one of our concerts. A gentleman visitor pulled down the curtain and badly burned his hands. The Fire Insurance adjuster has examined the damage for which we expect compensation but by dint of much steaming, cleaning and repainting we have been able to re-hang the curtain.

All pupils who went home for holidays returned on Saturday 31st December.

It was reported to us that an Indian living in town has been cutting wood on the Glebe property and that he has been casting off black soil. This report was handed on to the local Indian Office for action.

Andrew Martin, an old pupil who passed his entrance examination when a pupil here visited us in company with his wife who was a Mount Elgin girl. They had with them their baby in whom we see a prospective pupil.

An Indian child named Clarence was buried at the Old Mohawk Church November 29th. Our men prepared the grave.

Our apple house was broken into on December 12th by some person who cut out a Yale lock. An attempt was also made to enter the chicken house. A week later the apple house was again entered but this time the heavy hinges were removed. Owing to hard times there is much petty thieving in the district.

On November the 16th a blizzard put the town in darkness and we were without electricity for some hours. Fortunately, we have a supply of candles and lamps always ready for use and consequently work was not disorganised.

We killed pigs for the pupils Christmas dinners and had fat chickens for the officers and men.

We are grateful for many presents. Mr. Hutchison the local bakers gave us pumpkin pies for Thanksgiving, jelly rolls which were acceptable after the concerts besides contributing to Santa Claus.

Mr. W. F. Cookshutt gave a case of oranges. Mr. E.V. Burnell presented us with two games of indoor golf and a lady sent us a number of children's books.

Miss Cummings, Mrs. Burnett and Mrs. Neals had the first part of the holidays and Miss Hardie and Mrs. Matthews were away for New Year.

Farm and Garden. The fall ploughing was finished and all fence lines were cleansed of weeds. All rubbish and ashes were cleared away before the heavy frosts set in. A quantity of coal which we had to put in a bin removed from the School building was moved into more convenient bins. All the lands that are endangered by spring floods have been taken up.

Good purchases earlier were sorted for various purposes and the culled wood cut up for kindling. We used a cart-load of straw to Toronto. This is the first occasion that we have had the situation to do this.

We have bought two cows recently which are proving good milkers.

Owing to the fact that we shall probably be quarantined so far as corn growing in this district next year we have hired a cutting box and engine to cut up corn stalks and so far we have not had to touch our silo which is full of good ensilage and will feed for next winter.

The barn yards are being kept free from manure this year by removing the manure almost daily. This allows much more exercise room for the animals.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letters of the 30th ultimo and the 1st instant regarding the case of Nettie Clemch, a pupil of the Mohawk Institute.

In reply I beg to say that a communication was received from the principal requesting that authority be given for the discharge of this girl and that she be sent home. In view of your report concerning the house conditions of this girl and the doubt of her receiving proper treatment from them, it is very difficult to decide what should be done in order that she will receive proper treatment. Her discharge from the school is imperative and is approved.

It may be possible for you to have her placed in a hospital where she would receive the necessary medical attention, and I would be pleased if either you or Mrs. Boyce would make the necessary enquiries and arrange, if possible, to have her accepted in some hospital or institution, and the Department will pay the cost of her maintenance and treatment.

You should arrange to see that the expenditure incurred for this purpose is kept down to the lowest possible point, and as soon as the hospital authorities consider that she has sufficiently recovered to prevent infection, she should be sent home.

You should take immediate steps to have her placed in a hospital or elsewhere where she will receive the attention her case requires, as it is necessary that she leave the school as soon as possible. You should consult Mrs. Boyce and together it is hoped that some solution can be made of the problem as to what is best to be done to give this girl the necessary care and attention her case demands.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to the supplies for the Indian day schools on the Six Nations Reserve.

Chapter 50, R.S.C., 1906, "An Act respecting the Department of Public Printing and Stationery," requires that all such supplies be purchased through the Government Stationery Office. Previous to 1918, the supplies for the schools on the Six Nations Reserve were purchased in this manner. About January 1, 1918, several complaints were received regarding inconvenience caused the schools owing to delay in securing supplies ordered through the Government Stationery Office; and, as these supplies were paid from Indian Trust Fund and not from Parliamentary appropriation, the Department decided to allow purchases being made from different local merchants. At that time the Indian Superintendent was instructed to obtain prices for supplies from different dealers and to purchase at the lowest price.

In December, last, the Purchasing Commission of Canada, who must pass on all expenditures either from Indian Trust fund or Parliamentary appropriation, drew the Department's attention to the requirements of the Act above quoted, and pointed out that they could not see their way clear to authorise payment of supplies purchased otherwise than required by the Act. The Department is, therefore, at the present time, purchasing supplies through the Government Stationery Office.

I might point out that the Government Stationery Office purchases all supplies in large quantities and at wholesale rates, and a recent comparison of prices showed that an appreciable saving would result in securing the supplies in this manner.

From the information furnished in this letter, I feel that you will appreciate that supplies can only be purchased in the present manner, and that, in view of the Act and the requirements of the Purchasing Commission of Canada, this Department has no other alternative.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Secretary,

I am writing to you because I don't know any of the men officers and I trust you will help me to make a wrong right. When I was a pupil there at school I went to town one Thursday and while in town a man (a stranger) stopped me in the street, and asked me how many boys were at school. I told him the number there were there and he gave me a dollar ($1.) to buy a present for them. But I kept the money and spent it for myself. And now I am sending you the money to give it to the boys there now. It is the least that I can do. Please give it to them in any way that you see fit.

This is all.

Yours sincerely for the Best,

(Signed) Lewis Laforme

Four dollars was enclosed—which we have contributed to our "Honor Roll" fund.

Yours truly,

My Lord Bishop,

At the last Council Meeting here on the Reserve the question was asked "is it true that a girl of 13, a pupil in the Mohawk Institute, was about to be confined?" The Assistant Principal said it was so, but that the girl was well cared for. After a discussion several of the chiefs advocated the closing up of the school.

I think, My Lord, there should be an investigation as to who is responsible for this state of affairs. I understand this is not the first case of the kind that has occurred.

Several of the children have run away from the Institute the last couple of months and could not be induced to go back. There is something radically wrong in the present management.

Yours respectfully

(signed) James G. White.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Enclosed please find correspondence received by today's mail from the Bishop of Huron. The matter alleged therein is of such importance that I feel confident you will desire to have the information placed directly in your hands. Kindly return the correspondence after perusal.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letters dated,

(1) Feb. 25th, dealing with the future management of the Mohawk and Lytton Industrial Schools.

(2) Feb. 28th, in connection with the difficulties arising out of different religious beliefs when recruiting pupils for Indian Residential Schools.

I will bring the former of these two letters before our Executive Committee for consideration at its next meeting on Thursday, March 30th.

Reports received seem to indicate that the Rev. A.R. Lett is happily and successfully entering upon his duties as Principal of the Lytton School. There is, therefore, no reason for undue hurry in connection with the transfer of that Institute, I hope, however,
that it will be possible to complete arrangements under our usual procedure re estimates in order that the M.S.C.C. may assume administrative responsibility as from Jan. 1st 1923.

The condition of affairs at the Mohawk Institute, if the statements alleged in the enclosed correspondence be true, would indicate the desirability of more immediate action and the early transfer of responsibility to the Missionary Society. We have, I may say, a very experienced and reliable clergyman, with a practical knowledge of farming, who would be willing to assume the Principalship at an early date. Our difficulty arises, as I described to you, from the fact that our financial estimates for the next Calendar year are passed upon and decided by our Board of Management at its annual meeting in September. As an expedient, under the circumstances, I suggest that, in the case of the Mohawk Institute, the Missionary Society should assume administrative responsibility at an early date the Department, however, to guarantee, for this year only, the Society against financial loss in the conducting of the Institute, an obligation which the Department is, of course, carrying.

If you think it desirable to carry out this suggestion we shall of course assume the administrative responsibility without prejudice to subsequent negotiations concerning the financial basis which, after due investigation, may appear to be necessary as a condition of the assumption by the Missionary Society of permanent responsibility for the Institute.

Believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]

Dear Canon Gould,

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with enclosures returned herewith.

I am somewhat surprised at the tone of the letters from His Lordship the Bishop of Huron and the Reverend James White because they seem to take for granted that the report is true. His Lordship says that it is shown that the condition of affairs at the Monseak Institute is by no means satisfactory. I consider that the condition of affairs at the institute is highly satisfactory - we must have a conversation with reference to the staff there; but I trust that His Lordship's letter does not foreshadow a desire to make any change in the management of the institution.

The facts with regard to the case mentioned in Mr. White's letter are as follows: a girl named Bettie Clench claims that a criminal assault was made upon her when she was at home for the holidays. Mrs. B. has reported this to me as soon as she knew of it in the autumn, and we endeavoured to prosecute the guilty party but failed to get any corroborative evidence. The girl was watched carefully and has never been reported to me as anything. However, we have discovered that she had contracted a venereal disease and last month I ordered that she should be discharged from the school and placed in a hospital in order that she might have proper care. From the moment I heard of this case it has been under my own observation. I do not want to make any extended comment on Mr. White's...
Mr. White's letter, further than that the Chiefs of the Six Nations would close up the Mohawk Institute tomorrow if they could do so - not from any reasons of mismanagement or any cause for dissatisfaction but simply from their inextirpate desire to thwart the Department in its best endeavours for their progress. The implied idea that, because two children ran away from the school, there is something radically wrong with the management, shows little appreciation of the difficulties with which we have to contend.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

CHURCH. Rev. Pearson of West Brentford took all the services, administering Holy Communion on the second Sunday of each month. On February 26th he was accompanied by Rev. Aukar from India who addressed the children giving interesting illustrations of Indian life.

HEALTH. We had an outbreak of Grippe three cases of which developed into pneumonia. With one exception all made good recoveries. Several of the boys have also been off duty due to sickness.

Miss Elliott has tonsils and adenoids removed at the hospital. Miss Clausen was very sick for some time with pleurisy.

We have now however a clean bill of health.

Lottie Clench (criminal assault case of last summer) was sent to a women's clinic for examination. At the time we received the Doctor's reports his father died and she went home to his funeral. She is keeping in touch with Dr. Greenwood who reports that she is attending his office regularly for treatment.

STAFF. Miss Cummins' salary was raised to $500.00 per ann. with the approval of the Department of Indian Affairs.

Mr. Burton, farm foreman, and Mrs. Neals, housekeeper, both proved unsatisfactory and were given notice to leave on February 1st.

January 1st. Sunday. For dinner the pupils had roast pork, roast potatoes, pickles and plum pudding and for supper, bread and butter, cheese, jam and tea.

January End. "Cold day." In the morning a party of five went out in the truck while others went skating on the canal. The horses were visited and there was more skating in the afternoon.

The boys spent part of the day hunting and the remainder writing and playing hockey.

January 27th the pupils were invited to a concert given by the Brentford Patriotic Society at the Grand Opera House. The pupils were allowed to go and it was surprising to note how many thoroughly enjoyed the concert.

The boys entertained the girls to a sing-song and dance on February 3rd. The supper was provided by the boys.

It has been installed a series of fire alarms throughout the building connected to a large siren in the entrance hall. We obtained the alarm from the D.S.C.R. Toronto.

The shoe finishing machine has been installed in the Carpenter's shop and the boys are receiving instruction in shoe repairing. They are very interested in the work which is made so much more attractive to them by the installation of the machine.

Both boys and girls lower dormitories have been painted.

The cottages shed and the coal bins in the greenhouse have been completed.

Any farm implements and two farm wagons have been overhauled and painted by the boys in the course of their manual training.

A power drill, broom-making and printing machine received from the D.S.C.R. has been erected here and enables us to manufacture such things as double-trees, neck-yokes, wagon plates and machinery parts.

All these things are being done by the boys under instruction and they are showing great interest.

We have been able to prune a great deal this year and our orchards are greatly improved. The greenhouse lettuce is ranks with the best in town as there has been a steady call for our forced rhubarb. We have had no failures of flowers and have been able to supply the demand.

The boys have been very busy in the garden and have been able to grow a good crop of vegetables. We have been able to supply the market with a good supply of vegetables.

The boys have been very busy in the garden and have been able to grow a good crop of vegetables. We have been able to supply the market with a good supply of vegetables.
She has now recovered and is back in the team again.

The horse Dan is suffering from dropsy and it is feared that he will never be fit for hard work again.

The chickens have been transferred to a section of the calf pen in order that the chicken houses may be thoroughly cleaned and refloored.

We filled our ice-house on January 15th and have laid up supplies on a barn floor. We also built two ice-houses for neighbours.

Mr. Rogers was summoned to the Police Court for carrying without a license but it was proved that no license was necessary and the case was dismissed.

He bought cord-wood in the bush and our teams hauled it home.

Mr. Rogers went to Toronto with truck on January 31st and brought home a miscellaneous load including mirrors, desk, and machinery.

We completed an Annual Report for year ended December 31st, 1921.

Major Smith inspected January 27th and February 16th, and on February 16th, he and Mr. Hill valued stock for the Department.

A representative from the Soldiers Aid called to John Antone and reported to him the name of Charlie Evans and Evelyn Newhouse who are at home ill.

On February 7th, Mr. Rogers accompanied Major Smith to the Six Nations Council.

Brantford is building a large trunk sewer down the Mohawk Road past the Church and through our farm to the river. This has caused a great deal of traffic over our farm roads as part of the road is blocked at times.

Four boys have been giving considerable trouble by absconding. Leonard Wilson who is sixteen has reportedly abandoned us. We have had him returned because we had hopes of doing something with him. He is a lazy fellow who has taken schooling no account at all.

Theodore Joseph is a worthless type and very shiftless. He has a father and relatives who are capable of looking after him and so he lives near a school where he has refused to re-admit him.

Baron Ray was returned very promptly by his parents who find very difficult to handle, but as we have the support of his parents we took him back and will try to make something of him.

Robert Morgan is a constant runner, he not infrequently returns of his own free will, but he is a disappointment to us all. He is bright and very intelligent but very lazy also. He is strong although underfed and he could do well with his studies if he would only try himself.

As he has only an aunt and grandmother who ever take any interest in him we feel that it would be a good idea to take him back although his presence in the school is harmful to the morale. He could try his entrance this year.

We engaged a tailor at $28.00 per week and he re-made the boys uniforms. This was an excellent opportunity for the girls to work at tailoring and some of them did very well. The uniforms have a very nice look and are uniforms which have only cost us $4.00 each.

We kept the tailor an extra week cutting girls coats but as we found we could not possibly complete the coats and dresses by the end of April we decided to discontinue with the tailor until the Fall. This will allow us to have the dresses completed for the spring.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that I made a visit to the Mohawk Institute yesterday as Mrs. Boyce happened to have me there before she left for England on her holiday. I was there this afternoon. She has on the roll 69 girls and 13 boys, being absent at present. The main part of the halls and corridors have been grained and varnished which I believe is the first time this has been done since the building was put up. The upper dormitory on the second floor has been freshly white washed and painted which makes it look very clean and neat. The whole building inside has now been painted and cleaned up.

Amongst the recent army supplies received from Toronto was a large number of red bed covers, all the beds in the boys dormitory are now covered with these goods which gives it a good warm, cozy appearance. They also have enough for the girls beds, but they are not yet in use. One girl was recently discharged as she had a slight case of Tuberculosis following a bad attack of pneumonia. Mrs. Boyce thought she required plenty of fresh air and good food such as eggs, milk and as her father Frank Montour a returned soldier is comfortably well off she should be well looked after at home.

A new chicken house with runways is being built as it is proposed to increase the number of chickens. Seeding started about ten days ago but owing to recent wet weather, rain and floods, it has stopped for the present.

If the present heating system is to be used next winter 140 tons of egg coal and 70 tons of nut will be required, but if a new furnace is put in which is expected, soft coal will be used.

REPORT... CHURCH INSTITUTE, Brantford, Ontario.

March 1st - May 31st and June 1922.

Church: Rev. Mr. Pearson of St. John's Church took the services during March and April. Rev. Mr. Owen the new Pastor of Trinity Church took charge in April. Holy Communion was administered the second Sunday of each month. On Good Friday the children attended the three-hour service in St. Jude Church and on Easter Sunday the church was beautifully decorated by the pupils. On Easter Sunday the boys attended Trinity Church and the girls attended St. Jude's Church for the special afternoon service for children. We opened the Jehovah Church for Sunday services on April 30th. Professor Anderson took the service on May 6th.

Health: We had an epidemic of Grippe in March which developed into pneumonia in some cases. Dorothy Montgomery did not make a good recovery and was consequently allowed to go home on sick leave. We had another epidemic of Grippe in June.

Officials: Mrs. Myers, housekeeper had a bad attack of Grippe and as she did not get strong again she left on April 5th. Mrs. Rogers was engaged in her place.

Mr. Barron, Farm Foreman, left on March 31st.

Mrs. Burnett, Sewing teacher, was ill from time to time, took her holidays and was not well enough to return.

Mr. Singleton, Assistant Gardener, was off duty for about a month on account of an operation for appendicitis.

Activities: In April the boys and girls went to a boy-and-girl show in town. Several evenings have been devoted to dancing for the boys and girls. The boys joined the local School "Aerobics league" and gave a very good account of themselves. We were lucky enough to secure an old mural, Mr. J. Lockhart, as a contribution. On July 24th all the pupils went to Mohawk Park to attend the opening game of the season. Our boys won, the score being 4-0. In their return supper we served on the lawn and games were played. On June 14th, the children all went to a circus presentation and were admitted to the show in the afternoon.

Visiting Inspectors: Major Smith inspected April 19th, May 27th, and June 25th. Mr. Standing, Public Schools Inspector, examined school on March 13th and 14th. Mr. Abrams visited on April 7th and 8th and visited again on June 27th, 28th, and 29th, devoting part of his time to schools on reserve. The Indians were inspected by Col. Piggins May 16th, and Mr. Edwards of M.O.O. visited the school equipment on June 16th. Dr. Wentz, Field Secretary, M.O.O., visited April 22nd. Rev. Ferney called on June 5th re deed of St. John's property.

Rev. Owen, our new clergyman visits frequently and takes evening prayers occasionally. We were some years ago in charge of an Indian school out west. Besides our usual strangers to town we have received visits from the Ontario Bureau Convention, April 1st, Water Works Convention, May 20th, Congregational Convention June 7th, and the British teachers from Toronto on June 20th.

Other: We painted all the old brick white for the girls and grey for the boys. The corridors in the wings have been repainted and varnished. All woodwork and panelings of front hall were repainted. Slate blackboards have been installed in Schoolrooms. The classrooms have been repaired and the girls' upper dormitory has been whitewashed and painted. Miss Smith, our old janitor, who passed away and standard at the Conservatory of Music here, graduated this spring. It is claimed that she is the first Indian in Canada with this degree. Miss Joyce left for England on April 1st.

The floods this spring the second, which was unexpected, was due to heavy rain. We suffered severely from a storm on March 31st. Electric, telephone and telegraph lines were torn down and many of our ornamental trees were badly damaged.

We purchased a large flock here from the imported stock of Mr. F. Shutt.

Incubators were started on March 10th. Our young chickens have done well. We were able to purchase a very fine cow.

We sent our cows to pasture for daytime on May 10th and were able to milk them on the 17th.
The interior of the horse stable has been remodelled and a harness room built in. The pig pens have been overhauled and repaired.

We were fortunate enough to secure some very large tile from the City with which we have made a culvert to replace an old wooden bridge which was becoming unsafe.

The farm is now managed from this office, the farm foreman not being replaced, and we find the arrangement much more satisfactory.

All our crops have done well so far and promise good yields.

We have completed trying and have in our barns 83 tons of choice hay.

We have been able to sell the local markets in the supply of tomatoes, peas, cabbages and cauliflowers from our garden.

Our hot-house cucumbers have been on sale for over a month and are fetching big prices.

SUPPLIES

We have been very fortunate in securing supplies from the H.S.O.R.R., most of which we have been able to haul ourselves from Toronto in the big Kelly truck.

Recently we obtained a Fordson truck which has greatly added to the efficiency of the farm and garden, besides bringing much pleasure to the pupils who are from time to time taken for rides.

We received a large quantity of red counterpanes and pink bedspreads from the A.D.A. Green dresses and material to match from which we have been able to make three sets and four skirts with two waistcoats to match.

We have also been able to supplement our very poor furniture with desks, chairs, cabinets, kitchen utensils and tools. Two typewriters were procured and these are most useful for our advanced pupils who are attending Business College.

Reverend Sir:

I have your communication of the 6th instant, referring to the matter of high school education for the Indian children on the Six Nations Reserve. I have noted your suggestion that we provide accommodation for high school pupils at the Mohawk Institute for children desiring advanced training and, if this is impossible, the establishing of a continuation school at Ohsweken.

In reply I beg to state that at present there are a total of 37 young men and women of the Six Nations reserve doing the high school or college work, and that all are being helped by this department. Four are in residence at the Mohawk Institute and attending classes in Brantford. Also attending are the Hamilton and Hamilton Collegiates and the Caledonia and Ingersoll High Schools, and we pay our share of the net costs at these institutions and in addition give a small grant to the parents of the children attending so that proper clothing can be provided. Further, one pupil from the Six Nations Reserve is, with our help, attending each of the following institutions:—Canada Business College, Toronto; Brantford Business College; Lester Memorial College, Montreal; Upper Canada College, Toronto. In these last mentioned cases we assist with a grant of from $100 to $150 per academic year. The band funds are used for the payment of the tuition and special grants for the 29 Indian children attending the local Collegiates and high schools. The other 8 are receiving assistance from the appropriation for Indian Education.

I have outlined these facts in an effort to show you that we are doing all we can to provide a higher education for the brighter boys and girls on the reserve. If there is any accommodation in the Mohawk Institute we are always pleased to have high school pupils in attendance there, and I wish to assure you that the matter of providing a continuation school right on the reserve is receiving serious consideration.

On July 9th we had our closing service and also celebrated Holy Communion. As most of our pupils left for one month's holiday we discontinued services at the Church and the few remaining attended Trinity Church. Services recommenced in the Old Mohawk Church on August 13th and on September 10th we held a Communion Service. Our Harvest Festival service was conducted by an outside clergyman and the Church was prettily decorated for the occasion by the pupils.

The General Synod met in Brentford about this time and the Primate, Archbishops and clergy were very interested visitors to both the Church and the School. The Rev. Mr. Preuer of the wonderful new school at Chapleau stayed with us and took the services on September 24th.

STAFF. Miss Higginson, a graduate of the O.A.C., was appointed to the Junior School.

Miss Elsie Clausen, one of our own pupils who has just completed a year's course at the Business College has undertaken the duties of sewing teacher.

The pupils returned AUGUST August 12th. The older boys were in many cases kept back on the farms or where they were employed and some have not yet returned. As Miss Hardie did not return for two weeks after the pupils the older girls were given special instruction in Domestic Science, Fancy Sewing and Knitting for which the supplies from the D.S.C.R. were most acceptable. Many girls are wearing scarfs or sweaters of their own make.

The D.S.C.R. supplies have filled many long felt wants. The pupils now have feather pillows. On receiving a supply from the D.S.C.R. we had to empty the feathers into clean cases. Our office is now properly equipped and the typewriters are available for pupils who are taking courses. We feel especially grateful for a number of heavy green V.A.D. greatcoats which fit our older girls and are hoping to obtain a number more in order to make them over for our smaller pupils. The blue dress ingownes have been made over into useful and becoming dresses for our girls. We have just completed making the boys a suit of "teddy-bear" overalls for outside wear this winter. This will enable us to issue the hospital clothing we have received for the boys to wear underneath.
Upon the recommendation of Mr. Orr we pulled down an unsafe chimney and replaced same with galvanized piping.

Mrs. Boyce returned from England July 4th.

Mrs. and Miss Gerrie Smith left for the West on July 5th.

Dr. Westgate, Field Secretary M.S.C.O., wrote July 11th requesting reports, inventories etc., re taking over School.

Major Smith paid his regular monthly visit of inspection.

Jessie MacNaughton, Sylvia Jamieson and Floretta Elliott passed the Entrance Examination to local Collegiate. Jessie is attending the local Collegiate; Sylvia is living at home and attending the continuation School at Omandana; and Floretta is taking a course in telegraphy at the offices of the C.N.R. These pupils, with Hazel Elliott who is accepted for training at the Brantford General Hospital as a nurse, are in receipt of the grant from the Department of $100.

Gerrie Crowe completed her course at the Business College, has a good position in town and is boarding at the Y.W.C.A.

Oscar Hess is taking special course in farming and is leaving in the Spring to commence farming for himself.

Mr. White of the Department, with three assistants spent several days surveying Institutes property.

Mr. Orr and a representative from the Dunham heating firm inspected on July 26th. re alterations and extensions.

Mr. Redermacher of the D.S.C.R., Toronto visited August 5th, and Mr. Keating also of the D.S.C.R., was here August 10th.

Mr. Rogers visited Ottawa September 24th.

Sports. July 12th, our boys played lacrosse at Chawaken.

Amusements. Football and Base-ball are very popular games with the boys. During the holidays the remaining pupils had a very enjoyable time. In fact several who were not called for at closing decided to remain so as not to miss the fun.

The pupils attended several lectures and entertainments in town. We find that local folks are beginning to take an interest in our work and are often issuing invitations for our children to attend happenings in town.

Farms. Crops generally have been good and our farm is beginning to improve but owing to the serious Industrial situation in Brantford prices are very much down and consequently farmers in the district are suffering financially.
we baled twenty nine tons of straw on August 16th.

During the fruit season in Niemara we sent truck loads of baled straw to Grimsby. This we exchanged for fruit on the trees and a party of boys had a good outing to pick same which we brought back to Trentford and sold on the market at a very fair profit in addition to supplying the School with canned fruit for the winter.

We have rebuilt our chicken houses. These houses are of the portable type which will reduce the cost of removal when next necessary.

We commenced cutting corn for silo on September 15th.

Farmers in this locality have for several years discussed the question of buying a community power plant of some kind. Mr. Rogers was able to purchase a 12-24 H.P. Tractor through some friends at a very reasonable figure and this has met a local want and bids fair to becoming a stable source of revenue to the School. This year it has already earned sufficient to pay running expenses and to cover the first installment. We only made this purchase on September 5th.

We have been able to supply the pupils very liberally with small fruits and apples and our preserve cupboards are full.

My dear Mr. Scott,

Many thanks for your kind messages and interest you have taken on behalf of Mr. Rogers and myself.

We both feel that our united efforts can only tend towards a more successful management of school affairs — at the same time having less executive responsibilities, I shall be able to take a greater personal interest in the pupils.

I have forwarded my official resignation, and recommendation that Mr. Rogers be appointed my successor. Previous to entering this work Mr. Rogers had sound business experience and he will I am sure be able to do justice to the administration work.

I will attend to the internal management of such affairs as could not be easily controlled by a man — planning during non-work —; changes of uniforms — clothing and bedding —; supervising dietary buying.
household supplies—training new officers in their work—overlooking the sick and backward children—and general attention to Chamberlin.

Mr. Rogers will continue personal supervision of the boys—from and garden and all outdoor activities—take over the books—records—banking etc.

As to the question of salaries—they stand at $1200—$1000—I would recommend that Mr. Rogers be raised to $1400—and Miss reduced to $600—and that we devote the remaining $200 towards the salary of a playground mistress when we have accommodation for an salaried officer—but of course this question we leave to your judgment.

Yours very sincerely,

A. Royce Rogers.

P.S. Will you kindly instruct back as to changes in regulations.

I have the honour to submit hereby a report on the activities and progress of the work of this Institution.

Church. The usual Sunday services were held in the School-room with Rev. Owen officiating. Special Services were arranged for Thanksgiving and Christmas on each of which occasions the altar and chancel were suitably decorated.

At the end of October Mr Owen commenced training the Confirmation Class. This year we caused all children over twelve years of age to attend the classes but left them to decide whether they would offer themselves for Confirmation. We were pleased to present thirty candidates (24 girls and 6 boys). Among our interests worthy of note is that a boy who was a Diet and had not given any sign or wanting to be confirmed presented himself during the Confirmation Service.

The Bishop held the Confirmation Service on December 11th. For which service the School-room was tastefully decorated with masses of Chrysanthemum blooms.

Prior to the Confirmation Service and baptismal was held on December 3rd.

Clothing. During the quarter we have been able to buy stockings and mits directly from the mills at Paris and were fortunate in securing a jobber's lot of underwear.

The girls have very successfully manufactured sets of one-piece overalls for the boys. These serve a double purpose in that they look tidy and cover up the ill-fitting and bright coloured clothing procured from the D.S.O.C., with which we are able to keep our boys very well clad.

Staff. Miss Higgins, a Graduate of the Ontario Agricultural College has been appointed teacher in the Junior School.

On November 1st we were pleased to welcome Miss Stanley O.A.C., Graduate as housekeeper and Mrs. Haythornthwaite as matron. Mrs. Haythornthwaite was at Moose Factory where her husband was Principal and she has come to us to study the management of a larger institution. She is going to take charge of each department in turn in order to gain an intimate knowledge of detail.

Mrs. Matthews left after being in charge of the laundry for three and quarter years.

Class-room Work. This has been faithfully carried out despite the difficulties due to the presence of workmen.

Amusements. October 25th. 25 girls and Miss Hardie went to Girl Guides Concert at the Collegiate.

October 6th. The girls were taken to Chawken Fair in trucks and the following day the boys attended.

October 30th. Forty pupils attended a Concert at Wellington Street Church to hear Miss Maclean's recital.

October 31st. Halloween Masquerade. We had a lot of fun made all the more enjoyable by a pleasant afternoon of games and races.

November 4th. We held our first Plowing Match on this date and were fortunate to secure as judges two very experienced men who claimed that they had never seen better plowing accomplished by boys. We have to thank the Department for supplying the prizes on this occasion.

Thanksgiving Day it rained but a series of indoor games were played and the girls made a quantity of pretty necklaces from the beads sent by the Department and which we afterwards used as prizes and Christmas
gifts.

Armitage Day. The pupils attended the Community Service held at the Armories.

December 4th. Luckily this was a mild day and we were able to hold our Annual Sports which had somehow been postponed from time to time. The boys' horse and cattle were judged from a cleanliness point of view and such good work was done that there was nothing but praise. The announcement of the wedding of Mr. and Mrs. Rogers was made by Mr. Owen following which the Prizes for Sports day and the Ploughing Matches were distributed. The evening was concluded by a feast of nuts and candy and a dance.

December 19th. The Arcade, a local store, invited our pupils to a reception by Santa Claus and afterwards entertained them to a Punch and Judy show. All pupils had opportunities to visit the local stores before Christmas.

December 23rd. The outdoor rink was made.

December 25th. The Senior School-room was decorated for Christmas.

The Christmas holidays were much enjoyed by all. This year no pupils were allowed to go home. From previous experiences we have found that the small number who do go home usually return with more such trouble as the itch or scabies and this leads to a great deal of trouble. Then there is always a section whose parents disappoint them and they are difficult to satisfy while away. Fortunately that none would go home and consequently all the pupils just looked forward to having a good time at school. We started off by giving every child a present of some kind and as there was a plentiful supply of nuts and candy besides very excellent meals we found that we were able to have a very happy time. Every day some special amusement was planned such as truck rides or sleighing parties.

December 28th. I was able to obtain a free pass for the whole school to the Brant Theatre. Special pictures of interest to children were kindly shown.

Notes. One of our senior girls, Carrie Crowe, graduated from the Business College and has secured a position as stenographer at Bradley, Carrotson.

On October 23rd, work on the extensions was commenced.

During the local Teachers' Conventions no schooltime held and we devoted our attentions to general housecleaning and replacing screens with storm shades.

Irene Edmondson, daughter of one of the farm hands died October 15th and the school was off a number of days.

On October 23rd, we had to locate the clothing rooms, store rooms and men's dining room in basement to allow reconstruction work to proceed.

On October 30th, Mr. Rogers and Mr. Clarke secured a quantity of cooking utensils and oats from the B.S.C.R. at Burlington.

Mr. Orr visited on Nov. 7th and stayed two days during the commencement of the new heating system.

We have had considerable difficulty with the heating arrangements this year. We commenced running with wood only and when the coal arrived we suffered from our old furnaces leaking black smoke into every part of the building. However the new system which is almost complete promises to do away with this unpleasantness.

Mr. Rogers and Mrs. Boyce were married at the Cathedral in Hamilton on December 12th.

Several pupils during this term have applied for admission voluntarily although they were runaways of some time back.

Mrs. Boyce, unfortunately, was quite sick during the whole of Christmas holidays and most of the staff have been down at different times. Colds and sore throats have kept numbers of the children in bed a few days.

Visitors. Hon. O. Stewart, Mr. Raymond and Major Smith visited the School on October 6th.

Old pupils attending the Fair paid visits about that time.

Mr. Standing, Schools Inspector was here October 17th and 18th.

Farm. The farm work has gone on steadily and we are gradually building up a stock. We have not any surplus milk on the whole farm now although we have been killing sufficient to run the Institute for some time. We have threshed over 1200 bushels of late grain and had to leave a quantity of corn in the field for winter feeding as we had no more room in silo. Our mangolds were excellent and our turnips secured prizes at a local show.

We were able to earn a nice sum with the tractor by filling silos during the year we have been unfortunate so far as our horses are concerned but we have now some very fine horses in our barns. We lost one cow through sickness.

Owing to an old bridge across a creek collapsing we secured some...
large tile from the city, free of charge, and have built a permanent culvert with cement wall facing.

One of our boys has been taking a course on farm work and he has become a very useful hand. He expects to run his mother's farm when he leaves so we have given him every opportunity and so far as he is concerned the experiment is a success.

The greenhouses were a steady source of revenue during the Chrysanthemum season and we sold blooms that were without equals in town.

The soft coal we have been compelled to use has been disastrous since we find it difficult to keep steady heat with it. However, we have not suffered any very serious losses of stock but we have been unable to produce our usual winter crops of lettuce etc.

Church. All Sunday services were held in the School-room with the Rev. Mr. Owen in charge. Holy Communion was administered on the second Sunday of each month. Mr. Owen takes a great deal of interest in his work with the children.

Staff. Mrs. Hayworth left on March 13th. We were sorry to have to part with her after her connections with the work but we found that her judgment could not be relied upon.

Miss Higgins left to be married on March 31st.

Miss Hardie left for Easter holidays on March 31st.

Amusements. On January 2nd the children were able to have good skating and truck rides were arranged for the whole school. In the evening the staff and pupils met in the School-room where we had a sing-song and dance with plenty of nuts, dates, candy and biscuits for refreshments.

On January 13th, the boys had a sleighing party and the girls used the boys rink.

We purchased a cheap Victrola and this has been available for the pupils in their spare time. We have found that this and the Books of Knowledge have had a very good effect on the discipline of the children since it has afforded them much pleasure and amusement and kept them well occupied at times when supervision is more or less relaxed.

Notes. The Steam radiation was connected up on January 4th and on the 15th we fired the new boiler for the first time.

January 18th. The new laundry was installed in old laundry from up.

Owing to the plumbers neglecting to plug a pipe leading into the boys clothing room steam escaped into this room for two days and we had to thoroughly overhaul the entire contents of the room which were saturated.

Mr. Ross and Mr. Robertson of the Department of Indian Affairs visited.

Mr. Rogers returned from holiday on February 13th.

We suffered considerable damage in our hot-house during the blizzard on February 14th.

We were able to wash by hand in the new laundry on February 19th.

New Laundry Machinery was installed in the new building on February 19th and credit is due to the Beaver Laundry Machinery Co. for the excellent manner in which they overhauled and installed this machinery.

We have been able to turn out very fine work since.

During the quarter the Dormitories have been thoroughly house-cleaned but we have been unable to do very much in this direction on account of the building and alterations being in process.

The old Laundry building was torn down on March 9th.

Mr. Axford and another representative from the Soldiers Aid Commission visited John Antone and expressed themselves satisfied with conditions.

Mr. Standing inspected the School-room work. March 19th.

During this quarter we have discontinued purchasing meats etc. from retail stores and are now in a position to buy from packing houses and in that manner effect a considerable economy.

Mr. Orr of the Department of Indian Affairs has paid periodical visits of inspection of the building and staff on Health. During the early part of the quarter we suffered from much sickness. The alterations caused the building to be more or less drafty and that together with an epidemic of "la grippe" kept many in bed. At one time there were no less than twenty four girls and eleven boys and three of the staff ill bed at one time. However, we were able to get the sick on their feet in a very short time and all made good recovery.
had one serious case of illness in that of Lena Jamieson who after a complaint for a day or two was discovered to be suffering from appendicitis in a very serious stage and was rushed to the hospital and within two hours of the Doctor's decision she was operated upon. Since the operation she has made a wonderful recovery and is now quite well.

Pupils. This quarter we have experienced considerable trouble with boys absconding. It appears that the children are more or less influenced by the conditions on the Reserve. Just now there is a scarcity of farm help in this quarter the boys are often made tempting offers. The parents are also very keen to remove the boys from school as soon as they are big enough to be useful but realizing the state of morals on the Reserve they are prepared to leave the girls in the safe-keeping of the School until they are old enough.

In one instance the spirit of rebellion was so very pronounced that two boys armed with clubs openly defied the Principal. They were taken before the local Chief of Police who showed them the seriousness of their conduct and were instantly dismissed from the School after having been provided with sufficient funds to reach their respective homes. One boy has since obtained his release and through a friend has sought readmission. Five other pupils have absconded and two boys have absconded for the third time.

On the other hand, we have just heard from three ex-pupils who have secured very good positions. Grace MacNaughton has been appointed head of the sewing-room at the Johnstone's Doorway Company. Eva Curley has been recently re-elected President of the Girls' Conference an organization of about seven hundred members. Carrie Crowe has also taken a position as School teacher on the Kinsey Reserve.

Sir, I have the honour to submit the following report on the activities and progress of the Mohawk Institute.

Your obedient servant,

Principal,

MOHAWK INSTITUTE

CHURCH. Rev. Jnr. Owen was in charge of all services during the quarter except that on April 22nd, when he exchanged pulpits with Mr. Shellgrove of Galtland on May 27th, when the Rector of Ingersoll was in charge. The Communion service was celebrated on the second Sunday in each month. The appearance of the Church has been considerably improved by the renovation of the windows.

OFFICERS. Mrs. Forsall was engaged as sewing teacher. We had been running short staffed during the building operations. Mrs. Knowles has been engaged as junior teacher to replace Miss Higginson who left to be married. Mrs. Knowles is not in possession of certificacies but is capable, enthusiastic and most interested in her work. Mr. Knowles holds a position in a local office and is living in the Institute, in return for which accommodation he takes night duties with the boys and generally relieves the Principal when and where possible.

It was found necessary to replace Mrs. Haythornthwaite with Mrs. Martin. Mrs. Clark and Mr. Hammond left at the end of April and were replaced by Mrs. W. Duffield and Mr. F. Plummer. Owing to the shortage of big boys it was necessary to engage Mr. Hume as an extra man. Mrs. Merlin resigned owing to ill-health and Miss Flith assumed her duties on May 12th.

Miss Clausen was on holidays commencing June 16th and her duties were carried out by Jessie MacNaughten a Collegiate pupil. Miss Elliott was engaged as sub-officer on June 28th.

AMUSEMENTS. On Easter Monday April 2nd, we moved into the new Dining Hall and celebrated the event by a special dinner which was improved by a liberal supply of candies. In the afternoon the girls went to stores and put a show. The boys volunteered to start the work of constructing the new Dining Hall and Assembly play-room and had a great deal of fun tearing out the old partitions. Empire Day was suitably observed. The I.O.D.E. sent representatives to present a prize won by one of our pupils for general efficiency and after an address on the Empire, by the Principal the Victrola Record of the King's speech was played. One interesting feature of this evening was the manner in which every boy responded to attention as soon as the record commenced playing the National Anthem.

On Victoria Day the boys were taken by our truck to Burford and Mr. Brethour, the owner of the largest pure-bred cattle and his farm in this district kindly devoted a couple of hours to the boys and showed them his property. While the boys were out the girls went to a show in town and to the park. After supper the boys team defeated the girls team at base-ball.

We have made arrangements for both boys and girls to swim in the river and during this past quarter we have greatly encouraged sports between the boys and girls. We find that this opportunity for the boys and girls to get together is reducing the passage of letters and the clandestine meetings which were so frequent before.
June 11th. Mr. Orr spent the day inspecting alterations and improvements.

June 19th. Allan Johnson died and Miss Hardie again applied for leave to visit Mrs. Johnson, which was granted.

June 26th. Mary Waswanipi arrived here from the Ontario School for the Blind.

Cassie Arabela, Iraha Longboat, Rita Green and Mary Jacobs were successful in passing the Entrance Examination.

July 1st. With Easter Monday we began to take up our new quarters and to vacate that part of the old building which has to undergo alterations. During the whole term we have been constantly making room for rooms to another and for nearly two months have not been able to even use our office. However, we are beginning to see the end now and are hoping that when next we write our report that we shall be comfortably settled. We have ordered our new purchase a large butcher's refrigerator and we have installed same in the basement to our advantage. With this equipment we can buy meat wholesale and even kill a beast during the hottest of weather without fear of loss.

Our new lavatories and baths are a great aid to health and cleanliness.

July 3rd. During the Quarter we suffered two losses from our stables. One horse had to be shot and another after being constantly attended to night and day for a week became so paralyzed that she had to be shot.

We were able to commence working the land on April 10th, and general farm activities have occupied the male staff since that date.

On April 15th. we had a surprise flood and had to drive teams into the water waist high in order to save fence posts that we had laid out for boundary fencing.

We have discontinued the practice of making butter at the school. There was always considerable leakage in the poundage through carelessness and extravagance and we find that by issuing a stated quantity of butter each day we are getting bigger returns. We now sell our cream to the local creamery and purchase our butter there. This business also provides us with the opportunity of buying large quantities of butter-milk which is invaluable in pig-raising.

We bought a splendid team of mares to replace our losses and one has since given birth to a very fine colt.

Our spare time has been taken up in grading and tidying up after the builders.

One June 20th. we cut hay and we were picking strawberries the following day. It would appear that we are to have good crops this year but the prices of farm products are so low that a big profit can hardly be expected this year.
