MORAHOK INSTITUTION

BRANTFORD, ONT.

Church. The usual services were conducted by Rev. Owen on July 1st, we held patriotic services and the following Sunday we celebrated Holy Communion. During the month's vacation the pupils who remained at school attended Trinity Church where Mr. Bonfield was in charge of our opening service and Mr. Mitchell supplied on August 19th and 26th while Mr. Owen was on holidays. The Rector of Glencoe was preacher for our Harvest Festival service on September 16th.

Hardly a day has passed without a number of visitors to the church and meetings in the Churchyard due to the extra attention has generally found favourable comment.

General. Miss Hardie left for her holiday on June 30th, and Mrs Knowles took the Senior School pupils on a course in elocution and memory training while Mrs Rogers gave instruction in embroidery, crocheting, and fancy work. Our girls greatly enjoyed this and we discovered some very skilful and artistic work done. A student of the type of the Junior School was able to assist in this work.

As a result of Mrs Knowles' training we were able to stage a Closing Concert which was an undoubted success. Larry Wesenepi from the Ontario School for the Blind was very well received and her selections on the piano much enjoyed. The following day the pupils left for their holidays on August 1st.

The pupils who were not fortunate enough to leave for holidays were presented with a bathing suit each and the girls were given a pair of white shoes and two pairs of stockings and every boy had a pair of running shoes.

Leo Kinney was admitted July 10th, and Miss Ford of the local hospital kindly lent us a chair for him. He has since been fitted with appliances which enable him to move around our premises.

Through the kindness of General Ashton our Cadet Corps has been presented with some German war trophies.

While on her holidays Miss Hardie returned to Brantford for medical examination and had to undergo an operation for appendicitis on July 17th. She was given extension of leave until September 15th when she returned, recovering on excellent recovery.

We were very fortunate in securing a good supply teacher in Mr. Wood. His closure last August was succeeded by Mr. Brown an old pupil and a Business College graduate.

On the return of our holidays our pupils returned promptly. In fact the roll call was complete with the exception of those who had for some reason or other not been able to commence their holidays on the right date.

On August 27th, we visited the Paris Kinney Mills and were able to purchase material for repairing our girls' work dresses and also material for next year's summer dresses.

Mr. McVittie visited August 30th.

During the quarter we have made one of our pupils Floretta Elliot a sub-officer, in which position she has greatly relieved our staff generally. She answers the telephone and door, takes charge of girls on walks, teaches music and relates to other officers.

Miss Flora housekeeper left and was relieved by Mrs Woods who arrived with a very bad cold and after a few days broke down entirely.

Miss Elliott and a number of her girls decorated the Church for Harvest Festival.

Health has been excellent.

The pupils had some difficulty in settling down after the holidays especially those who had been berry picking. They were prone to get out of bed early and could be impatient, careless about their dress.
Quarterly Report, Mohawk Institution, September 30th 1923.

Several ran away to be returned very promptly by their relatives.

After a long controversy I have at last succeeded in getting the wholesale houses to fill our orders. The retail houses have been fighting us in this move but at last we have won and are hoping to effect considerable economy as a result of this new method of buying.

Sports & Amusements. We have been able to give more attention to sports this summer and many games have been played between the different divisions in the school. The best ball games have been those between the boys and girls teams. The boys have the stronger team but our girls have been playing very spiritedly. This scheme of mixing the boys and girls on the playing field has had a very desirable influence on the school and such things as the passing of notes from boy to girl or girl to boy has not been heard of for some time. We find that by making the whole school play together they soon divide and the boys begin to play alone and the girls play their own, forgetting entirely of the boys.

Swimming in the Grand River has been good and on occasions the city swimming pool has been visited. Now the cooler weather has set in our new bathes and plentiful supply of hot water are in great demand.

Strawberries were plentiful and the children had their share. One evening we had a strawberry and ice cream feast at the expense of a few others who had been working here.

During the holidays the truck was in use on several occasions taking parties of pupils to the movies.

July 26th, the children were given ice cream as a reward. They had never before volunteered to help with the harvesting operations when we were badly in need of help and they would have been playing at the river or doing something else.

August 5th, Civic Holiday the children went to town for truck rides and dinner. It is raining now.

It seemed like rain all morning but didn't last long. In the afternoon it rained again and shortly after dinner, Mr. Holley was cool enough to build a fire and get the children out of the cold and into the sun. We were able to rent for a little longer so for curiosity's sake we went inside and found the house beautifully reserved. Besides being able to give every child a cool drink.

August 8th, successful corn roast closing our evening with a sing-song round a roaring bon-fire.

Improvements. We are unable to fully express our appreciation of the improvements that we have had carried out. Our staff Dining Room is small and isolated and when the kitchenette is completed will be almost ideal. The new Sewing Room with its large roomy cupboards and big oven is undoubtedly going to be an improvement in this department. We have enlarged the room to accommodate the new sewing machines and also added a closet for the storage of clothes.

The hardwood floors throughout the main floor, with the exception of the dining room, are the same as the rest of the building and are extremely hard wearing. The walls are painted a light color and the floors are polished to a high shine. The rooms are well ventilated and the lighting is excellent.

August 14th, we were visited by a number of influenza cases amongst our horses. To prevent this we had every horse inoculated on August 17th. The terrible thunderstorm that night drenched the streets and killed one of our sheep.

On August 20th, we received a message from Mr. Holley saying that he was coming to see us. We were very pleased to see him and he came on September 1st. He is an excellent worker and we are pleased to secure his services.

Mr. Holley is an honest and hardworking man and owner of a threshing machine which he has used this year and gave him a trial. He did splendid work for us and we are able to thresh at the rate of a thousand bushels a day. We threshed a total of 4,400 bushels this year.

We filled our silo with our own machinery but owing to a series of cutting work we have not been able to fill other silos by contract as we intended.
Quarterly Report, Mohawk Institution, 30th September 1923.

The early potato crop was a failure but due to our irrigation system we had a plentiful supply of cabbage, corn, turnips, carrots, tomatoes, cucumbers, rhubarb, fruits and apples.

Our pure-bred hogs are beginning to attract attention and I have hopes that this is going to be a source of remuneration to no little extent.

Sir,

On closing my Quarterly Report which is now being prepared for forwarding to your office I find that it will be necessary to again ask for an advance from this quarter's grant for $2,000.

There are several reasons for this state of our finances. Only lately have I succeeded in being able to deal with wholesale houses for our supplies. This, naturally, means a great saving but where a retail merchant would allow us to run our accounts quarterly the wholesaler wants his cash monthly and this means that we must have a bigger balance for current expenses. Eventually, I hope to establish the finances of this school in such a fashion that we will be able to meet this.

Unfortunately, this section of the country was seriously affected by a drought this summer which has considerably curtailed the profits from our farm but within this disadvantage our farm and garden receipts for the past quarter are in excess of any similar quarter for a number of years past.

Then, again, the alterations and re-decorations that have taken place this year have made it necessary for us to put in certain improvements that have increased our expenditures. I, however, feel satisfied that the results have more than justified the cost. For instance, last winter in order to light a school-room it was necessary to walk round
and soon light on separately. This, of course shortened the life of the lamps considerably and put a strain on the wiring each time the lights were required. In view of this, I had the wiring altered to that of switch control before the room were decorated, since when I have not had to replace a single lamp. This expenditure will, therefore, be shortly covered by the economy in maintenance.

Another improvement has been carried out in the play-rooms. Every year we have had to spend a considerable sum on glass to replace that broken by pupils. To avoid this I have had substantial frames covered with a very heavy screening placed over all windows in the playrooms and have also guarded all electric lights. Now the children can play ball in their playrooms without doing damage.

As we buy our meat wholesale and have to take delivery weekly it was necessary to increase our cold storage. To do this we were fortunate in securing a butcher's store refrigerator at a very reasonable price.

I also had to furnish a substitute for Miss Hardie during her absence following an operation.

In spite of the foregoing expenditures we have been able to keep a very good standard of efficiency and were able to reduce our last quarter deficit by £200.

I mention these facts for your information and remain,

Your obedient servant,

Angry, Run in Indian Home

Sister of Pauline Johnson Explains Trouble at the Reserve.

SENDS OPEN LETTER

Declares Mohawks Want Chance For Higher Education.

The situation at the Mohawk Indian Reserve near Brantford, which has been the subject of attention for a long time, is now being addressed by Miss Evelyn H. E. Johnson, who seeks to place the responsibility where it belongs.

She says:

"The people of Ontario, and later, the people of the other Provinces as well as Americans, are continually asking 'What is the trouble with the Six Nations Indians?' Even Brantfordians who are contiguous to the Reserve, ask me this question. In Hamilton and Toronto I am asked the same question. No one seems really to know what is going on about, but everyone seeks for information.

"There are many reasons for the present spirit of unrest and rebellion in this Reserve. To-day I wish to draw the attention of the Canadian public to the Mohawk Institution, an educational boarding school near Brantford, for Indian children of both sexes. It is a school similar in nature to an industrial school and is a school for many children who have no parents or for orphan children, whose parents are living in the town. The children of the Reserve, however, are at variance with the system of the institution. The children do not appreciate the conditions in the Reserve and are seeking better treatment for higher and better education.

"The New England Company, which for many years has operated the ten day-schools in the Reserve, together with the Mohawk Institution, has been doing their best to turn out the maximum of educated pupils, whereas, for forty years not one single pupil from these schools passed the entrance examination to the high schools. Furthermore, one annual school conducted by the Six Nations Council had passed a number of scholars into the high schools. At the present time no less than 150 Indian children are attending high school at various places. A school which is badly wanted in our midst.

ASKS INVESTIGATION.

The labor element in Brantford recently asked the Government to investigate the conditions at the Mohawk Institution. Colonel A. T. Taylor, appointed by the Government, came here with an investigation team in the Reserve and it is to be regretted that the Mohawk Institution was not included in the investigation. During the Summer more than 200 children have been running wild in the school. The assertion is made that they are hungry, and the Indians say there is something radically wrong when children abandon wholesome, an institution such as this. The Indian Department contributes generously toward the upkeep of the Mohawk Institution and the New England Company does the same in its support. There are at least two hundred acres of land in connection therewith, plenty of fruit and vegetables, and a large herd of cattle. It is said that no one in Canada that these children runaway in the winter because of their claim of hunger.

Some of the missionaries and bishops who have visited the Reserve met no one in their direct field of work in the Reserve who is the Mohawk Institution. The missionary's wife begged me, with tears in her eyes, to do something to better these conditions. I told her I have no influence; the Indians lie behind me.

"Why not turn the Mohawk Institution into a first-class educational school where boys and girls can be trained in science, by qualified teachers, so that they will be equipped to take up their way in life even if they do not wish to attend school to take up higher education?

Boys Burned Buildings.

The first executive officer, Mr. Hubert Ashton, went out from England by the New England Company to take charge of the Mohawk Institution in this early settlement. During his time many boys ran away from the institution and brought back to the institution they were garbed in clothing similar to that worn by the Indians, the trousers being of blue denim and the shirts of red flannel. The road was easier to color.

In 1930 some of the boys turned and burned down the Mohawk Institution to the ground. The late Rev. James Rogers, missionary and his wife told me it was nothing more than they had expected for a long time. They had complained to him and sentenced to the Ministry for punishment, which Rev. said they thought would be the Mohawk Institution. What a punishment!

Miss Evelyn H. E. Johnson wrote to me that she had not been leaving immediately on a trip to visit friends in British Columbia, she herself, would have taken care of the situation.

The Mohawk Institution was rebuilt by the New England Company. On October 1st, 1930, Mr. Rogers, the Superintendent, his son Mr. Norman Ashton received the appointment. Shortly after this the old building was torn down. When these girls were returned to the institution, their hair was cut off, and they were shut up in the dark rooms. They were given nothing but bread and water. Chief George Hill, who is very sentimental Mr. Nelles Ashton for this treatment of his little daughters. He said was very much against Mohawk Institution.

A Brantford jury of twelve men turned a verdict of four hundred and seventy-five damages against Mr. Nelles Ashton together with the statement that his institution is not a reformatory, it is an industrial school.

Mrs. Horne, now Mrs. Rogers, and who is a daughter of Rev. Rogers, then obtained the appointment of Superintendent of the Mohawk Institution. The province is full of mission workers, especially those who believe in feeding the poor right at their doors.

And the press of the United States is raising the question why the trouble with the Six Nations Indians?"

FISCAL:

In January, 1923, the Mohawk Institute was leased by the New England Company to the Department at a nominal rental for a period of $1 year. The Company grants £1,000 per annum for current expenses and, when they can find funds, they are assisting the Department of Indian Affairs with capital expenses. In the last two years the New England Company has granted £7,015.25, which has been used for alterations and repairs.

The Department of Indian Affairs, before leasing the Mohawk Institute, made per capita grants for current expenditure each fiscal year. For the past few years the per capita grant has amounted to:

| Fiscal Year | Grant Amount |
|-------------|--------------|
| 1914-15     | £12,000.00   |
| 1915-16     | £12,000.00   |
| 1916-17     | £12,000.00   |
| 1917-18     | £12,000.00   |
| 1918-19     | £12,000.00   |
| 1919-20     | £12,000.00   |
| 1920-21     | £12,000.00   |

During these years no grants were made from Parliamentary Appropriation, for buildings or equipment.

Since leasing the institution, the Department has not only paid from Parliamentary Appropriation a per capita grant for current expenses:

| Fiscal Year | Grant Amount |
|-------------|--------------|
| 1921-22     | £20,000.00   |
| 1922-23     | £20,000.00   |
| 1923-24     | £20,000.00 (estimated) |

but also grants for buildings and replacements, as follows:

| Fiscal Year | Grant Amount |
|-------------|--------------|
| 1921-22     | £1,465.00    |
| 1922-23     | £6,068.13    |
| 1923-24     | £5,800.00 (estimated) |

-Since leasing-
Since leasing the Mohawk Institute from the New England Company, the Department has met, roughly, 85% of the current expense and has appropriated, roughly, 95% of the money needed for the alterations and repairs that have been undertaken in the past three years.

**MANAGEMENT:**

Under the terms of the lease, the Department is to maintain the Mohawk as an educational institution for Indian boys, or girls, or for both, and the pupils are to be drawn, as far as possible, from the Six Nation Indians. The religious instruction shall be the teachings and doctrine of the Church of England. It should be noted that the responsibility for the management of the Mohawk Institution is practically entirely with the Department.

**INSPECTION:**

The Brantford representative of the Department visits the Mohawk Institute each month and reports to the Department. The new agent, Col. Morgan, has already paid some eight visits. The Public School Inspector for the County inspects the classroom activities twice each year and reports to the Department, concerning the progress of the pupils and the pedagogy of the instructors. The date of the last inspection by the Public School Inspector was the 7th instant. The Superintendent of Indian Education has paid two official visits to the Mohawk Institute during the past two years. The Department Architect has visited the school at frequent intervals during the alterations and additions to the buildings.

**RELIGIOUS:**

Church services are conducted regularly each week by an Anglican Clergyman, communion services being held each quarter. The Bishop of Huron is the official church visitor.

**INSTRUCTION:**

The Department requires each pupil in residence to be in the classroom at least five half days per week. The elder boys and girls spend the other school hours in one of the departments, for the purpose of assisting with the domestic duties and the farm and garden activities and to receive instruction along vocational lines. The Department expects the younger pupils to be in the classroom during the whole of each school day.
TRUANCY:

A study of the reports sent in by the Mohawk Institute shows that during the quarter ended September 30th, last, two boys and one girl truanted. The Principal states in his written report that "several pupils ran away, but were promptly returned by their parents." The returns for the same quarter a year ago show that six boys and two girls absconded and two years ago, a like number.

This year three boys and seven girls did not return promptly after the annual vacation. A year ago seven boys and two girls had not reported one month after the school opened. Three girls did not return following the holidays of 1921.

As mentioned in my last report the attendance of the larger boys has, in many cases been unsatisfactory. After staying a while they run away to their homes and often no action is taken to send them back. The result is that in the senior school there are three times as many girls as boys.

I note that while the girls are given some good practical training in sewing, cooking and general housework, and the boys with some work with the gardener and on the farm, there is, nevertheless, no provision for systematic instruction in the principles, either of household science, manual training or agriculture. It would, I think, be most desirable in a school of this kind if the heads of the various industrial departments were also qualified to teach the principles of these subjects. The following invited attention of the press on an important meeting of public interest. It must be free from personal attacks and accusations.

INDIAN AFFAIRS.

Sir, I have been told that at the time of the last council meeting of the Six Nations Indians at Ohsweken, on November 4th there was a rumor that instructions had been received by me from the Indian Department to announce an important decision which would affect the affairs of the Mohawk. Other chiefs for those not holding that position. As this rumor appeared to have caused great excitement, and perhaps some misunderstanding, I would take advantage of your valuable columns to say definitely that no such instruction has been given or that I know nothing whatever about it.

There who have followed the attacks against the Indian Department and the Mohawk Institute, which have been found in the press of Canada, the United States and Great Britain will realize that there is a deliberate campaign of calumny in papers and newspapers directed against the Mohawk people for their own ends, led by a lawyer in Rochester, N.Y., who remains beyond the jurisdiction of the Dominion.

As this is one of the schools which comes within my jurisdiction as Superintendent of the Six Nations, I have occasion to be constantly exposed to various and unexpected slanders and can, therefore, say from my personal knowledge that there is no truth whatever in these allegations.

It is the policy of the Government of Canada to uncover children's obstructions of personal spite appearing in publications which have attacked themselves of slanderous, but I am convinced that the situation cannot be worse than it is now, and I should ask you to publish a detailed report on this column of half-truths, distortions and suppositions of fact.

In conclusion, I would emphasize the importance of having an accurate statement of such reports.

Your obedient servant,

THE MOHAWK INSTITUTION

To the Editor: The people of Ontario and other provinces, as well as Canadians, are continually asking: "What is the trouble with the Six Nations Indians?" Mr. Bradfield, who is contiguous to the reserve, asked me this question. In Hamilton and Toronto I am asked the same question. No one seems to know what the unrest is about; but everyone seeks for information.

The Mohawk Institution is a school for the present spirit of unrest and rebellion on the reserve. Some of them have already touched upon it in my personal experience. Yesterday I wish to draw the attention of the Canadian public to the Mohawk Institution as an educational institution, near Brantford, for Indian children of both sexes. The school is intended to be an industrial school and is a home for many orphaned boys and girls, as well as for other children whose parents are living.

Practically the whole Indian population in the reserve, however, is at variance with the present existing situation and its executive head. The Indians of both opposing factions in the reserve are seeking and begging the Indian department for better education. The New England company, which for many decades controlled the ten schools in the reserve, together with the Mohawk Institution, no doubt believed that they could secure a maximum of educated pupils, whereas, as far as I know, not one single pupil from these schools passed the entrance examination into the high schools; yet, the one single school conducted by the Six Nations council has been more successful than any of the high schools. At the present time no less than 35 Indian children are attending high school very well placed. A high school is badly wanted in our reserve.

The labour union in Brantford recently passed a resolution suggesting that the government makes a thorough investigation of the conditions and the conduct of the institutions. Col. A. T. Thompson, appointed by the government, in September, found such an investigation in the reserve, and it is to be regretted that the Mohawk Institution was included in the investigation. During the summer more than 10 children have run away from the home-school. All of them claim that they are hungry, and the Indians are angered.

There is something radically wrong with the way we are wholesale an institution such as this is supposed to be. The Indian department has spent many thousands of dollars towards the upkeep of the Mohawk Institution and the New England company also reside in it. They have at least two hundred acres of productive farm land in connection therewith planted in fruit trees, orchards, and a large herd of cows, and it is a crying shame to Canada, that these children run away in such numbers because of hunger.

One of the missionaries and wife declared to me that they had met no one in their direct field of labor in the reserve who liked the school or thought it was desirable. This is suggestive of something rotten in the state of Denmark. The missionary's wife begged me to help her in her endeavor to influence to better these conditions. I told her I have no influence; the influence lies with the Canadian government.

Why not clean up this sore in the reserve and put the Mohawk Institution in the hands of educated Indians? Why not make the school teaching trades, nursing and domestic science by qualified teachers? Why not take out boys and girls fitted to make their way in life, even if they do not own fields abroad, whereas this work affords them the opportunity to attend higher education?

Members of the family who have been sent to the Mohawk Institution have returned to the reserve. What is the trouble with the Six Nations Indians? EVELYN H. C. JOHNSON

November 1st, 1923.

Services were held at the church throughout October with the exception of Sunday, 13th, when our children were invited to join the choir and Sunday School Classes of Trinity Church in a Children's Service. We closed the Church for the winter at the end of October and held our classes in the School Room. Owing to the limited space in this room we are unable to allow the whole school to remain throughout the service and consequently only twenty pupils was sent to the Junior school after the opening of the service. On December 15th the pupils attended the unveiling of the Christmas tree at 10:40 and a well attended Carol Service at 6:15.

Christmas morning was a very delightful Carol Service. Some of our older girls were able to join in the service. The children learnt a number of carols for the Christmas Concert and the Christmas tree festivities. Our senior girls were specially invited to the Carol Service at St. Luke's Church on the 24th before Christmas.

In addition to the services we have singing practice and exercises at 9 a.m. and 2 p.m., and Sunday School at 11 o'clock.

There has been considerable trouble with the Housekeeper on October 1st. She is an English school-teacher on leave of absence and due to her enthusiasm and energy we have been able to re-organise the kitchen department with very good results.

On October 15th, we lent Miss Crowe to Col. Vernon for a week to assist him in his office work.

Miss Crowe had been acting as handy-woman on October 1st. Mrs. Ludmore has been out in charge of the boiler room for the winter in addition to acting as cattle-maid. She had to take up on October 1st.

All the beds in the house were turned over and leaves at third floor. Due, no doubt, to the improved sanitary conditions and better heating we have had a variety of sickness among the children which have not been in need of a doctor. Several children have had trouble with their teeth which have received attention.

On October 1st, we filled neighbour's silo.

On October 15th, we killed five pigs for sale. Commenced lifting bulbs for winter on November 1st. We converted the basement of the old Playhouse into a very effective apple and root store-room. During the alterations one of the soft water boilers on the North end of the Institute fell into the house so we have run a pipe from it into the greenhouse and now use this water instead of the city water. Full advantage was taken of the mild fall weather and fields were ploughed, hedges trimmed, fence lines cleaned and fruit bushes pruned.

On November 27th and 28th, the boys and girls were issued with new shoes and socks or stockings, while the girls had further issues of bloomers and combinations. Our girls are wearing the blue serge dresses for school and most of the boys are wearing their blue uniforms. Owing to the warm clothing we have been able to make use of the E.S.O.C. supplies we have allowed the girls to wear the grey pyjamas for play as the weather becomes colder for best.

This is the first opportunity we have had of allowing our girls coats for
to wear in the playground and they look most comfortable in them.

We have made a new issue of aprons for the girls but during the winter we do not propose to put them into use. It is our custom to patch and darn the aprons when necessary to save our new clothing for Spring. A new set of blue uniforms has been ordered for the girls.

Oct. 1st. Mr. Rogers met Mr. G.J. Parker and Colonel Morgan at the Inn Office. Colonel Morgan stood with us until he and his family could locate a house and move to Brantford.

Oct. 3rd & 4th. Our girls went by the truck to Chawaken Fair and the boys went the 6th & 7th. We took our lunches with them and being relieved of the milking by volunteer girls. It is also pleasing to note that the girls brought back Lucinda Henry, a girl who had run away the day before and had already repented. She has done well since her return.

Our truck made several trips to Burlington during this month where the school was closing down and we were able to get a good supply of chairs, lockers for girls' playroom, cinematograph and cabinet, kitchen and dining hall supplies, rugs, bath mats, furniture, an organ and some plants and shrubs.

Oct. 5th. Several British teachers made an extensive visit and Mary Jacobs and her brother, old pupils, arrived in two fine cars one morning bringing their respective families to see their old school. They both speak high-Isle of the White men in the villages.

Colonel Morgan presented the pupils with four baskets of very fine grapes.

Oct. 14th. Mr. and Mrs. Rogers went Grimby and brought back a quantity of peaches which the children enjoyed for several suppers.

Oct. 12th. Leo Winnie was foiled in an attempt to make three other boys become with him one night. He had persuaded them to wheel him about fifteen miles on a wheel chair. One boy, William Snake, did get away and we have not been able to locate his whereabouts.

Oct. 23rd. We contracted with the B.T.T. Bakery to supply home-made bread for the school and we were able to reduce the cost by one cent per loaf.

Oct. 28th. Mr. Rogers left for Ottawa and England.

Oct. 29th. The pupils dismissed and taken home by Mr. Gudmore.

Oct. 30th. Mr. Rogers returned celebrated by the children supplying taffy and lemonade while the school supplied apples and bananas. During the evening the girls were allowed and the boys thoroughly enjoyed or in the girls' shriek with their chest parades.

Nov. 1st. Connected up radiator in senior school that was in old channel. The Western Electric Commission altered our service to take care of the new wing passenger lamp.

Nov. 7th. Mr. Standing inspected classroom work. Although he expressed approval and satisfaction on the progress here he reported to the Department of Indian Affairs that we too frequently change our junior teacher until that we needed a qualified teacher in that position. In this connection he said that the last four changes have been out of our hands entirely; two sent on account of ill-health and two to get married. Our present teacher, Mr. Monk, is a very intelligent and most enthusiastic. He finds the qualified teacher too rigid to our liking and interests solely to the class whereas the type of teacher is required to take part in the general life of the pupils. Mr. Monk is also our clerk guide, etc.

Nov. 8th & 9th. Teachers' Convention held and no Junior School. The weather was very cold and two legs out of doors in the flower beds a great mistake.

Nov. 11th. Captain Howorth of the local Fire Brigade examined the boys' fire teams and gave all very fine marks.

Nov. 12th. Christmas tree was decorated by a group of parents and lam and boxes for dinner and gifts were purchased for the children.

Nov. 13th. The weather was very mild and we were able to plant the orange trees.

Nov. 14th & 15th. We devoted these two days to sewing for our own church needs. We removed the church curtains and were very happily set and received the best of thanks.

Nov. 16th. Mr. Monk received a special message from Mr. Johnson, Secretary of Education.

Nov. 17th. Colonel Morgan wrote to the Department and Colonel Johnson in this connection.
Rev. Col. Colonel Morgan inspected.
Nov. 29th. Started winter routine.
Nov. 30th. The boys' house chimney fell in. Fortunately it did little damage and our men were able to repair it.
A reporter from the Toronto Star visited the school in connection with Miss Johnson's letter. He spent several hours here and returned the next day to see the children at their meals.
Nov. 27th. Archdeacon Jones Bedford visited the school with Mr. Bishop and was most interested.
Nov. 28th. Colonel Morgan unexpectedly paid a visit of inspection for the Department. He took sworn statements from the members of the inside staff and thoroughly investigated every phase of the school work. He expressed his approval.
Nov. 29th. Fire Alarm Drill. Our Boys team were playing water on the library roof when the minutes of the sounding of alarm. We found our alarm gong batteries run down and had them replaced.
Miss Knowles and Miss Elliott with several of the girls commenced a course for Girl Guides.
After the issue of Miss Johnson's letter we experienced a trying time with the pupils. They showed resistance to discipline and one girl became most disobedient and defiant. This girl was in the second year at the Brantford Collegiate Institute and was dismissed but the effect was immediately shown in the improvement of the general conduct.
Dec. 5th & 6th. The Hydro Electric workers put in a new transformer and altered the interior distribution of services.
Dec. 5th. The pupils went to town to see Santa Claus and to see the Community Christmas tree on the market square.
All the girls went in charge of officers to town during the weeks preceding Christmas to see the stores and to buy their Christmas presents. In addition pieces of orange, cords silk and crochet were given to each girl for making into presents for relatives.
Some very novel and excellent work was turned out.
December 14th. The pupils of Toronto and Mrs. Watts, Captain of Brant and Norfolk's colonies organized our Girl Guide Corps, No. 6 Brantford. All over twelve years were accepted on four months probation and were formed into the following patrols, Blue Bird, Canary, Oriole, Pheasant and Robin. Colonel and Mrs. Morgan were present and their daughter Betty with her gardener two daughters joined our Corps.
The following two days our guides went to the Y.W.C.A. and the Collegiate for drill.
December 21st. We decorated our Dining Hall and Entrance with boughs and colours and in the evening we staged our Christmas Concert in the Dining Hall. This was an undoubted success and we felt very grateful to Miss Knowles for the successful manner in which she had trained the pupils. Colonel Morgan took the chair and many friends and old pupils were present.
Dec. 23rd. We called two days for the finest and the weather was so mild that we were able to send the truck to town with flowers and plants. Many pupils went to town with friends and those who were less fortunate were taken out by officers.
Dec. 24th. We had a wonderful Christmas Tree in the Dining Hall. All pupils were present and they brought their families to swell the number. We purchased an enormous bunch of apples to supply every child with a present and a candy bar. Mr. Thompson sent a crate of oranges and Mr. and Mrs. Knowles gave every child a small owse. One of the tall-staffed ladies in the latter was the number of trees in the hall placed on the tree for one another.
The pupils had very enjoyable holidays. There was sufficient snow for sleighing on the hills and the building snow forts yet it was mild. Each evening the whole school gathered in the Dining Hall for games and fun of all kinds.
Dr. Souls of the Brant Museums Ltd. gave each pupil an invitation to the local cinema and a box of chocolates.
Dec. 27th. Mr. B. Bishop called to see the school and to get some particulars. He said an old friend of his felt he ought to reply to Miss Johnson. His father, he was sure, never made any statement as represented in the article. He freely stated that the enemies of the school were to be found almost entirely in the ranks of the Baptists. On referring to the list of runaways immediately before Colonel Thompson's enquiry on the Reserve we discovered that they were all children of Baptists with the
exception of a family of Whites who have an aunt who is very bitter in her attitude towards the school. Although she is an old pupil the reason of her antagonism is that years ago Miss Hardie refused to allow her sisters to take an entrance examination for which she was entirely too stupid to write.

We killed another pig for the New Years Day dinner and gave all our men ham for a Christmas present.

The whole school was gathered for prayer Sunday morning at 9 o'clock and another service was held after the smaller children had been dismissed.

On Sunday evenings we have had a series of social talks by the principal some of which were illustrated either by lantern slides or by the microscope. Once we had a Radio service from the Buffalo Studio.

Five of our older girls have taken turns in playing the organ for the services.

Health. With the exception of a slight epidemic of chicken pox we have had little or no trouble this quarter other than a few thousand colds. This is all the more remarkable since most of our boys were seriously affected by outbreaks of several infectious diseases including smallpox. We had only one visit from the doctor this quarter and that was to examine a child who had been kept in bed for three days out of bed and who had it was stated had received some internal treatment.

Staff. Miss Browning (now Matilda teacher on leave) has returned to the country. She had been splendidly well in recent weeks and looked lovely. Miss Allen took her place and we find her very efficient.

We have had our usual skating parties and very active work in the organized Guides and Soldiers bringing our girls to the front in the affairs of the camp. We had snow all the quarter in fact so much so that we could not be able to keep our skating rink in good order. However, we sent all pupils out frequently for sleigh rides until the roads became too badly drifted. The boys sometimes came here for playing on their sledges we had to send them out for walks to keep them exercised. Our pupils have had a great deal of enjoyment this winter out of the vehicle and a radio set which we were able to borrow for them.

January 1st, we had a tea-party with the tables daintily decorated.
with red bow s containing candles and so on. The evening programme included games and singing.

January 23rd and 26th. The Girl Guides went in sleighs to the Armouries to practice for the Trentford Parade at which they were inspected by the Lieutenant Governor. This was on the 26th January and our troupe were splendid. Each Guide wore a uniform made from the Blue Dressing gowns we obtained from the D.S.C.R., by themselves since the first of January and a pink kerchief and scout hat completed their outfit. There were visitors from all parts of Ontario and our girls secured the first prize for their display of needle-work and second prize for first aid work. The drill display by our troupe was second to none.

In the same afternoon our boys were guests of the Kiwanis Club at their annual Christmas Show.

Miss Turnbull, our sewing teacher, was so pleased with the nice work on the uniforms and their display that she gave them a party at which all the female officers helped to give the girls a good time. On March the 4th, the girls all gave a party to the boys school in the dining room. Small boxing contests between the boys and the girls took place but it looked so simple that they asked to be allowed to box. We all found their efforts very amusing.

On March 16th, a Bible class from the school attended a play for the pupils and it was very much enjoyed.

Improvements. During the re-decorations we have tried to keep all wiring and plumbing in such condition that we shall not be compelled to nor floors walls or ceilings in the near future by repairing. In this connection we have wired the officers' pantry to take care of an electric stove although at the present time we are using a hot-plate. Wall switches have been installed in playrooms and clothing rooms in order to protect the residents.

The second staff bath-room has been completed and small alterations made to the lighting.

During the quarter we had several days during which a blizzard blew steadily on the front of the house and although we were running the boiler hard two radiators were frozen. We thawed them out without any difficulty and discovered the cause to be ill-fitting doors and windows which allowed a direct draft of cold air to blow on to the returns from the radiators. To prevent a recurrence of this we had a new storm door made for the upper verandah and had all windows fitted with weather strip pine. Since doing this we have had very severe weather and been quite comfortable. In fact it was only necessary to keep a man on duty at night to care for the boiler on three occasions.

Mr. Peters commenced work on January 15th, and with pupils help has painted several of the rooms on the principal's flat, refinished stairways, stripped several old floors and re-decorated the new bath-room.

The pupils have also painted the dormitories which we had previously had white-washed. The men's Dining Room was also plastered and painted.

Clothing. During this quarter our girls have made great headway in their sewing. Beyond keeping every article of clothing in repair they have made a complete issue of new serge dresses and aprons ready for Spring wear. They have in addition to this completed two issues of boys shirts.

For the winter months the boys were outfitted with rubber shoes, heavy stockings and new sweaters.

Notes. Miss Hardie was away for three days in January owing to the death of her friend Miss Davis.

Colonel McCrimmon of the Cadet Corps visited on January 18th.

Colonel Morgan and an officer of the R.C.M.P. visited on January 21st.

Two boys, possibly old pupils, climbed the fire escape and knocked at the
Girls Dormitory window on February 19th. The police were notified
that we are keeping a close guard.

Inspecting inspected March 5th.

On March 11th, we held a staff dinner in the Principal's Dining Room.
This is an innovation that was so successful that we purpose to repeat
it from time to time. It serves to bring the whole staff into closer
touch with one another and tends to a more uniform standard for the
pupils. The table was effectively arranged by Mrs. Rogers and three
of the senior girls waited at table in a very smart manner.

The Orange Convention was held this year in Brantford and we were visited
by nearly every delegate. They were quite interested in every depart-
ment of the school's activities.

Mrs Colonel Morgan, who has been ill, and whose daughter was taken to
the local Sanitarium, came on a visit to recuperate.

Discipline. The disturbing effects of Miss Eva Johnson's newspaper
propaganda are no longer noticeable. The introduction of Girl Guides
has had the tendency to improve the general discipline of the girls
although we had one rather serious case to deal with during the quarter.
A number of girls banded themselves together under the name "Jesse James
Gang" and they started out on a regular reign of tyranny over the other
girls. However, we became acquainted with the "gangs" activities and
were able to break it up. There is a splendid spirit amongst the
boys now. Although at times I had feared the honour system was imprac-
tical amongst them I am glad to say that at last, I am finding very good
results. The senior boy in the school had for some little time been
bullying the small boys but the intermediates took the matter up and
after severely thrashing him brought him to me and made their report as
to his conduct. This is the first instance of its kind to my knowledge.

Farm. In common with all farmers in this locality we have had a very
trying winter so far as hogs are concerned. The litters were small and
weak and we had considerable difficulty in wintering them over.
We had the horses thoroughly examined and were able to control another
outbreak of influenza. The horses teeth have been filled.

We converted an old brick building that had gone into disuse into an
ice-house by excavating floors.

The old carpenter shop, the foundations of which were collapsing has been
moved to a new location and will be converted into a tool room and farm
office.

Owing to very heavy snow on the greenhouse roof a small section of same
gave way but we suffered no loss with the stock on that account and temp-
orary repairs were soon made. We had to keep our snow plough out nearly
every day in order to keep the roads open to town.

As our bull had become unsafe he was sold to a butcher and another to
replace him was purchased from the Duncan Farm at an auction sale.
An old horse that had been raised on this farm had to be shot as she had
become unable to digest her food.

Having a number of very good poles on the farm we sent them to a saw mill
and the boys are converting the lumber we got out of them into double-tree
single-trees and other farm necessaries.

We purchased an ice plough as we had difficulty in borrowing one this year.
The ice harvest had to be made quickly this year and everybody was rushing
their work this year.

We had several suspected cases tested for tuberculosis in the cow barn and
one milk cow had to be destroyed.

The incubators were set early in March and we have had excellent results
from them.

The Farm has been able to contribute well to the upkeep of the school by
sending in plentiful supplies of milk, potatoes, cabbage, other vegetables.
an abundance of apples.

We killed a pig, a calf and several chickens for home consumption.

The farm teams have kept the small coal bin filled and have been making pool roads with the cinders which they have kept cleared from the buildings.

7th April 1924.
ASKS Federal Government to Fight Chicago Scheme to the Finish—Premier and F. H. Keefer Show How Ontario Faces Real Peril—Many Interests Are Affected

TORONTO, April 5.—With unanimity which submerged all party differences in the recognition of an issue of outstanding importance, the members of the Ontario Legislature yesterday adopted a resolution protesting against the diversion of water through the Chicago drainage canal and urging that the Dominion Government should act in behalf of the province. The question had been discussed by members of all three parties in the House. What the amount of water involved was more than that which goes over the American Falls at Niagara and that the loss would have been occasioned is $500,000, and this was perhaps seldom realised, which the debate stressed and which influenced the members to lend it their unequivocal support.

The question was raised by F. H. Keefer, member for Port Arthur and Under-Secretary for Agriculture, who pointed out the magnitude of the question and who strongly suggested that the Chicago sanitary district should be treated as "an enemy child" by Washington and made to observe the country's obligations in its water treaties. He pointed out that for the sewage sludge proposed Chicago required only 600 to 1000 feet per second flow, not the 10,000 feet which it was taking now. He strenuously argued that Chicago should be made to pay for the erection of a sewage disposal plant, even if the completion of such a plant would require six times as engineers had computed.

AFFECTS MANY INTERESTS.

Premier Ferguson followed and emphasized the intimate relation of the Chicago diversion to the serious problems which the Province was facing. An amount of water equal to that generated at Niagara was being used in the province in the case of the scarcity which was inevitable in the immediate future. Fishing, navigation, and hydro-electric power were severely affected by the diversion.

DICKSON: Under this heading I am very pleased to report that there is a spirit of thrift among the pupils. They are beginning to develop an "esprit de corps" and that certainly tends to make better discipline.

On April 1st, Mr. Conley and Miss Elliott attended the course held in Brantford for training Girl Guide Officers. They were enrolled on April 4th, when all Girl Guides and officers were present.

Mr. Conley was discharged April 5th, and Miss Elliott returned to her place. Miss Elliott living in the Farm Tent Room until his cottage is ready for occupation.

Mr. Taylor arrived from England on April 1st, and was taken on the staff to assist in supervision of boys and to take care of animals, which are minor responsibilities.

Miss Taylor left on April 15th, for one month's holiday.

On June 7th, the girls, again together, left for one week's holiday.

On April 2nd, the girls returned to their homes, i.e., to their families. Miss Elliott visited by the principal but no traces could be found in the girls. The girls were notified that they have not been reported on.

April 13th, we got our first snow and had our first snowstorm.

April 16th, the snows came up but there was no serious damage.

Miss Elliott is now well following the treatment. Our small girls are quite normal and the older girls ready to their activities at school.

On Thursday afternoon, the Girl Guides met every Friday evening under the instruction of Miss Elliott and Mr. Elliott in the Family Hall. These activities include games, country dances, singing, and story telling stories in addition to drill and we attribute the improvement in the girl discipline to the largely due to this training.

On April 13th, the Royal Foresters Chapter of I.O.O.F. presented the school with a picture entitled "The Forester's Gift" to the school. Colonel and Mrs. Murray were present at the ceremony of presentation and were most effectively married.

On April 17th, Mr. Yale of the Great Lakes Institute visited us on April 17th.

The girls who are on the verge of becoming adults have been for about three weeks. They looked so well with each other that they did not want to leave on April 27th, which proved to be a rest.

On May 3rd, we had a meeting of parents and invited them until June 7th.

On May 10th, the pupils were called back and all have made good recoveries.

On May 17th, the boys' windows and doors and school closed because of this. This is not a month later than usual.

On May 18th, Miss Elliott and Miss Conley came and lunch here. The Bishop was unable to visit the whole school and expressed his satisfaction.

May 19th, Mr. Conley, who is to visit Canada yesterday or the League of Nations and make a visit. We told of last year to Chief Levi Gabriel at Teewa and I think he was very impressed with what he heard. Needless to say, he was convinced that the Normal Institute was far from being neglected.

And everything in the school and I to this spring the girls have shown several days of the flowers to be in very great improvement.

June 12th, Messrs. Foster, Vincent, and Mr. Dorso attended the Farmers Demonstrations at the Ontario Agricultural College.

On June 16th, Miss Foster and Miss Conley through Mr. Dorso to attend the Convention at Toronto, visited the school and Church.

Miss Waswanipi from Ontario School for the Blind came June 17th.
June 18th. The Delegates to a Convention Of the Daughters of England visited the school. There were twenty-three full of delegates and it took practically two hours to show them everything they wanted to see. June 25th. Mrs. Rotariu who had heard of us from other visitors came to see us on their own house.

June 26th. Mr. and Mrs. Rogers with Mrs. Knowles and Mrs. Howarth visited our Elgin Institute. It was a most interesting day and all members of the party felt the trip worth while.

June 27th. Our new boiler heated a car of coal in seven and a half hours. Strawberries were picked for the first time.

June 30th. A garden party for the Girl Guides was held at the Johnson family house. We contributed four gallons of ice-cream and our guides danced and helped with the visitors.

July 1st. We painted all the beds, the girls white and the boys grey enamel.

The girls painted and varnished the burlap in the new wing which had discoloured badly owing to the dampness.

The farm cottages at the church were thoroughly re-decorated and the roof repaired. This cottage was in a bad condition as it had not been able to do any work for years.

The attics have all been varnished and the verandah floors painted.

All the wood in furniture has been painted and the polish renewed.

We have had little to ordinary farm work as we have filled the woodshed with wood cut with our own tractor, all roads have been graded and re-filled.

Our poultry have kept us well supplied with eggs for setting and the pupils have been plentifully supplied with eggs.

The old carpenters shop has been removed from its old site where it was too close to the new wing and is now conveniently situated near the farm building where it has been converted into store rooms for tools with a large room for use by the men.

On April 21st, we had the first fine weather and all the crops at our feet. We needed the first fall with rain on April 18th.

April 21st was rather cold over night for several days.

All the fences on the place have been erected early in May.

All our fruit trees are in good order.

We have been very busy with our work.

My attention has been drawn to the financial condition of the Mohawk Institute and I note, with regret, that during the 15 months ended June 30th, last, there has been a loss of approximately $4,000 in current financing.

The quarterly statements for the period in question show balances as follows:

This is a serious situation and demands thoughtful consideration, so that remedial measures may be taken. It is particularly disturbing when one compares the grants which the Mohawk Institute has received with those paid to other Indian residential schools in your area, where the Department endeavours to care for replacements and repairs to buildings. The regular grant for these schools is $150 per capita per annum. In the case of the Mohawk Institute the per capita grant for the period under consideration has been at the rate of $160. In addition, you have received during the 15 months payments from the New England Company amounting to approximately $7100. Divide this amount by the average pupils of 115.6, and the amount of the New England Company grant has been approximately $50 per pupil per annum. The Mohawk Institute has therefore received grants totalling $110 per pupil. Compare this with the regular grant of $150, and the seriousness of the retrogression is apparent.

The weather has been quite good recently, although there have been some showers. The crops are doing well, but we need more rain to ensure a good harvest. We have started harvesting our wheat and are making progress. The silos are almost full, and we are preparing to store the grain. The government has provided us with some equipment to help with the harvesting process. We are grateful for their support.

We are also working on improving our irrigation system to ensure better crop yields. The government has allocated funds for this project, and we are confident that it will be successful.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

On the 24th and 26th ultimo Mr. Phelan audited the books of the Mohawk Indian Residential School and made a study of the expenditure for a period of fifteen months ended June 30th, last. He prepared a comprehensive report, which is hereunder, and I was able to discuss with Mr. Rogers, upon the occasion of my visit to the school last Wednesday, the best methods of placing the institution on a sounder financial basis.

I am convinced that the deficit of approximately $3,000 in current financing is accounted for largely by (1) the replacements and additions to stock and agricultural machinery, (2) interior decorating of the main building. The replacements and additions were necessary if the farm was to be put on a paying basis and the decorating was advisable for general reasons and particularly because of the large number of visitors to the institution. I know of no Indian residential school in Canada, that is subjected to the same continuous stream of visitors as the Mohawk.

The tuition period in the case of the boys of the Mohawk Institute is short. The reasons for this are truancy and delinquency following holidays. When pupils did not return and could not be brought back without considerable difficulty and perhaps unpleasantness, they were struck off the roll. This all results in few large boys for the farm and garden activity, which in turn affects the financing of the institution. The principal promised to report to Superintendent Morgan cases of delinquency when it was considered advisable to have the pupils returned. In view of the unsettled conditions at present on the Six Nations Reserve, no drastic action will be taken. If the R. O. M. P. can quietly assist, they will be asked to cooperate.

The principal has a good chance to improve the financial condition of the school, as practically $4,000 expenditure during the past fifteen months will not have to be repeated for some years. Further, the barns are filled with feed and the natural increase of the stock will be a source of revenue. Besides, I have made arrangements with the principal to requisition for drugs and classroom supplies. The expenditure in this connection has in the past been provided by the management from current funds.
I wish to point out that all bills have been paid promptly and the reputation of the institution is not suffering in the business world because of any outstanding accounts.

Mr. Rogers welcomed any scheme that would assist him in the general financing in the future and I promised that favourable consideration would be given to the necessary replacements and repairs to plant. Further, special expenditures only should be met from the New England Company grant and the principal welcomed the assistance of the Department in the administration of this money. I advised him to write to the Charter Clerk, informing him that the Department would fund the money in a special trust account and would assist in the administration in the future. The Department also should correspond with the New England Company in this connection.

The principal expressed his willingness to carry on with advances on the per capita grant from time to time for a further period and to make a determined effort to get on a sounder financial basis. He will receive, as heretofore, the $160 per capita grant and will use this entirely for regular current expenditure. Special requirements will be referred to the Department for decision.

Certain small accounts for interior decorating and repairs will be paid from appropriation during the next few weeks and will not be charged to the present school funds.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, October 23, 1924.

Dear Mr. Bush:

The best method of financing the Mohawk Institute has been given considerable thought by the principal and the officers of the Department. Mr. Rogers would like our active cooperation and this can best be given if we advise him concerning all expenditures other than those of a purely current nature.

The school is paid $150 per child per year from Parliamentary Appropriation and is also allowed from the same source grants for replacements, repairs and additions to plant and equipment when funds can be found for the purpose. The principal and I agree that the New England Company grant of £1000 per annum should be used for special expenditures which are necessary from time to time, if the school is to continue to be a point of interest and satisfaction to the hundreds who visit it every year. I know of no Indian residential school in Canada that is subjected to the same continual stream of tourists and visitors as the Mohawk Institute. I am pleased to inform you that the Superintendent of Indian Education has lately visited the school and he reports that not only is splendid work being done, but that the buildings, the grounds and farm are in fine condition.

Mohawk Indian Institute Was Founded Nearly 100 Years Ago

The Mohawk Institute was founded in 1826, nearly a hundred years ago, by the New England Company who, it will be remembered, aided greatly in the work of the old Mohawk Church, one of the original first places of worship in this locality. In recent years, however, much more money has been given by the Department of Indian Affairs, which has had the result of making the school more prosperous.

The best possible facilities have been provided for the propagation of Christian knowledge among the Mohawk Indians and their children. The school was opened in 1826, and has been in operation ever since. It is now under the management of the Mohawk Institute Board, and is conducted by a staff of teachers who are thoroughly trained in the methods of education.

The school offers a wide range of courses, including English, History, Geography, Mathematics, Science, Music, Art, and Physical Education. The students are encouraged to participate in various extracurricular activities, such as sports, drama, and music.

The school also provides a variety of vocational training programs, including carpentry, sewing, and cooking. These programs are designed to equip the students with the skills they need to succeed in their future careers.

In addition to its academic and vocational programs, the school offers a strong emphasis on religious education. The students are taught about the principles of Christianity, and are encouraged to develop a personal relationship with God.

The school is located in a beautiful setting, surrounded by trees and fields. The campus is well-maintained, and provides a peaceful environment for learning.

The school is open to all students, regardless of race or religion. It is a place where students can come together to learn, grow, and succeed.

A CHRISTMAS TALK

By Robert Power, Author of the widely read "Two-Minute Talks."

Christmas is not the word festive with a fine spirit of jollity and good cheer, the suggestion of reunion, and the time when we call "True" to dull care and carking worries.

That day that is these modern days "Christmas" is dying out as a festival. All the time there are kiddles in the homes and sometimes in the hearts of fathers and mothers. Learned professors and those who give amid ancient customs and time-worn ceremonies, tell us that Christmas is but a pagan survival, an improvisation of Woden's Jule. Modern writers say there is a deeper meaning in the Festival than can be explained away by myth or legend.

If we Jo but gorge and gusset at Christmas we enter into the grave aspect and miss the spiritual significance of the Festival. Or if our Christmas experience has been phlegmatic, drowsy, or prosaic expression, it is but a barren season. A Christmas word is better than a Christmas card and a hearty shake more effective than a stilted letter of "good wishes," which, after all, may mean nothing.

The story of the Nativity is often that goes down to the roots of human life. The star raised in the East, and the Magi hastened to the stable where the angels sang in the Highest. Peace! Goodwill toward men for an old world. And we are poor spirits and children in imagination if we cannot catch something of the glory of the Christmas season. A festival! A season of good cheer! A trace of divinity, a time to remember the poor. Come, let us wascall his neighbor.

Christmas in the time of God's Remembrance. The Nativity blends earth with heaven, the past and the present made One. It is the day when we should take wings and fly away and find it means another mile down in the journey of our life. To some it is the first Christmas; to others it will be the last. How memory flies back to other seasons when times we have been were with us and whom we knew are far away or whom we think we have thrown behind the clouds of the valley." In the last silence, when we assemble for our Christmas festival, shall we be able to bring to those who have kept their feet wide awake and show so sweetly true the words of imagination, the gentle poet of everyday life: "The spirits of the lovely dead, whisper the story of old times."

What is the special message for this Christmas? One of patience and hope. Some say the times are very hard. Many point to great and overwhelming evidences that the nation is burdened almost beyond endurance. The pessimistic signs that there are no signs of the return of the old-style Christmas. Things are not what they were—they roam.

No, I am thankful they are not. For while it is true that we are burdened with many problems, and Life is very hard to-day, it is just this trouble that we have no cause to despise. A new spirit is abroad among the people. More understanding, larger tolerance, a greater disposition to see the best in man, and that much finer afforded by birth, that matters. We shall be patient, and the situation means that discontent of change. The war has brought its aftermath of settlement, but it has also produced a greater understanding. Patience—Home needs a full day, and social changes, upheavals of what seemed so fixed, and fresh adjustments of value, all this surges on.

Peace!...and Peace! Yet the peace of interregnum, or of slumber, but the peace which comes from the clear consciousness and the consciousness of work done. If I had to wish a Christmas greeting upon those I love, I can think of no better than to desire for them a settled contentment. I love those words of dear, warm-hearted Addison, when keeping his diary Christmas in his circle of friends, all of whom are gathered 'round the stars of Old London in its literary home. He says: "I've never seen such a Christmas. 'T give you my best respects; I salute you in the name of Charity and Friendship; may the Peace of the Magier rest upon you in all your days."

A good Christmas is not a riotous one. It may be quiet, but it should be full of those who love rocks and excitement. But if it is to be with your dear ones and promotes the fellowship of the family—why there can be no better way of keeping the day hallowed in the Christian Calendar. Let it have its place, relative, half in life, a time for consideration, a Christmas at the end of one year, the threshold of another.

"Watchman, what of the night?" was the question asked in ancient days. Yes, there has been cloud and gloom. The memories of the war are still with us even at this Festival of Joy. How many a broken household does the war leave behind in the springtime of life, and whom does shoulders in a forlorn land? Yet there who mourn, be patient with the mothers and the wives who grow thoughtful and fall into a reverie. Perhaps their hearts are sad over in the human life joy is mingled with sorrow, and smiling is heard even in the hour of rejoicing.

Let us think, too, of those brave ones who fought and suffered and who are still with us. In many a home, pitiful tragedies of the war still linger. Silent sufferers, lonely and despairing, seek them out. Help them. Let your Christmas mission be to render thanks for past benefits by affording practical assistance to those who are in need.

Comfort the lonely. There are those who realize to the full the bitterness of being solitary when Christmas comes and most homes are filled with joy of reunions. Perhaps an opportune invitation, or a cheery word showing that after all somebody has remembered them—this is the real Christmas spirit in practical expression.

Time steals on, and as the minutes tick away, the fingers in the belfry of the old church prepare to wake the music of the chimes. I know of no more inspiring and memory-awakening sound than the toll of the church bells ringing for the joy of Christmas-tide. As I listen, there is a vague seem to be repeating the age-old message of God to man:

"Glory to God in the Highest; and on earth Peace, Goodwill toward Men."

Ring on, brave bells! Times change, and generations come and go. But as long as the years endure, the message shall awaken the Christmas season. Goodwill, Peace, and Fellowship among the sons of men!

BY DR. STANLEY CLEMONS,

Human milk is the ideal food for the baby. Not only does it contain fat, sugar, protein, salts and water in the proper proportions for the infant's needs, but it also contains other substances which provide the baby with immunity against disease. The superiority of breast milk to any other food is strikingly demonstrated by the fact that only four out of every hundred babies die among those who are breast fed.

These figures furnish irrefutable proof that no mother can afford to deprive her baby of breast milk if she is capable of supplying it unless her own physical condition is such that her physician forbids her nursing the baby.

Even though she may not be able to supply a sufficient amount of milk, the baby that receives a portion of his food from the mother has a better chance than the one who is wholly bottle fed.

STAY LATE, FOLKS!

The mother's milk does not appear in the breast until three or four days after the baby is born. Nevertheless, the baby should be put to the breast at regular intervals both to accustom him to nursing and to stimulate the flow of milk. It is also important during these first few days to give the infant water frequently.

When the mother's milk supply is established, the nursing intervals should usually be either three or four hours. In general the mother will produce more milk if the baby is on a three rather than four-hour schedule.

When the mother has plenty of milk, and the baby is strong and vigorous, the four hour feeding is to be preferred. By so doing the mother has longer intervals both to save time and the infant is less likely to suffer from vomiting and colic.

Whether the three or four hour interval be adopted, one feeding can usually be omitted at night.

Sir,

I have the honour to submit the following report on the activities and progress of the work of this Institution,

Your obedient servant,

Rev. C. H. Owen was in charge of all services which were conducted in the Senior School-room. He administered Holy Communion once each month. Owing to the lack of space in School-room a number of the Primary children meet in the Boys School-room and receive religious instruction. The School is divided under the teachers for Sunday school which is conducted every Sunday at 10.45 a.m. In the evening all attend prayers and after the younger children are dismissed choir practice is held. Twice a month the Principal gives a talk on current events or Lantern slides are shown with suitable readings.

Staff. There was no change of staff during the quarter. Mrs Knowles, who is a very energetic officer, was poorly and as a nervous breakdown was feared she was granted a weeks rest commencing March End.

Mrs Rogers left for holiday on February 7th.

Discipline. On the whole we have had very good discipline which has made the work much easier and has enabled the pupils to obtain greater benefits from their school-life. It is most gratifying to note absence of insolence which used to be so common and the children are constantly showing evidence of greater confidence in their teachers. It is felt that the restoration of law and order on the local Reserve has helped a great deal to bring this condition about.

While our ordinary pupils are showing improvement, it is regrettable that our students attending the Collegiate and Business College are not so satisfactory. They take no interest in the tasks allotted them at the school and are inclined to be impertinent to the staff. They are frequently quite late in returning from their classes and appear to think that other pupils should be detailed to wait on them. Possibly the lack of discipline in the Collegiate and Business College accounts for their attitude.

Amusements. On January 1st, sleigh-riding and skating were the order of the day and a special dinner of Roast pork, baked potatoes, mashed turnip and mince pies. During the evening all the school met in the Dining hall for games and competitions.

On January the seventeenth the girls went for a sleigh ride and took eggs to Reuben Fox at the hospital they then called for Mary Waswanipi at the Blind School. Mrs Knowles has kept the Girl Guide and Brownie movement active and has had good success despite the fact that the local Commissioner has been out of town and has therefore conducted no Rallies, which always serve to stimulate our girls' interest.

Outside competition always serves to increase our girls' enthusiasm. The boys had a good rink and were allowed to water hill near the school on which they had some very fine sleighing. A number of boys were given opportunity to build their own sleighs. They used old
packing cases and barrel staves for lumber and made some very novel mischief.

HEALTH. We commenced the quarter with a fairly clean bill of health but in January we had an epidemic of colds with nasty sore throats and in February we had another spell of the flu. It was necessary to call Dr. Brown and Dr. Macdonald and many children who had had ear complications left by the measles were again troubled during the flu epidemic. However, good care resulted in the restoration of our usual freedom from sickness.

Reuben Fox, who was taken to hospital last quarter to be operated upon for mastoid after a recovery, developed subarachnoid meningitis with fatal results on 17th February. Mr. Fox's kindness and co-operation on record his appreciation of the kindness of both the hospital staff and the Doctors of this town. On one occasion when Reuben's condition was puzzling our Doctor no less than four other Doctors came and held free consultations.

NOTES. School re-opened on January 2nd, with a full staff. During the quarter Rev. Jones of Chawesen visited the school often. His visits keep him in touch with the pupils from his Parish and it is felt that this has a good effect.

January 8th. Frank Fox visited his brother at hospital who had taken a sudden turn for the worse. We also telegraphed Mr. Macdonald to inform father of the latter's arrival and pleaded poverty so we boarded him for several days for which we got credit but not payment.

January 12th. We brought Lizzie Snake home from hospital.

January 13th. A neighbour, Mr. G. Good, suffered the loss of his house from fire. Our men and boys helped to free and care for stock and we started the cottage to him until such time as he can rebuild.

January 16th. Mrs. Dunlop, the former housekeeper here, visited us. She is connected with Children's Amalgamation and has experience in that work both in England and here and she says that our standard of living and accommodation is far better than the average home she visits.

On February the seventh we commenced upon a spell of very mild weather February the Thirteenth took Reuben Fox's body to Middlemiss.

February 19th. A large convention from Hamilton visited the School. The mild weather and rain caused floods on 24th, February.

February 26th. The temperature dropped suddenly and a very high wind caused two radiators to freeze during the night. This made it very difficult to heat the building.

February 28th at 7.30 p.m. we felt an earthquake shock.

March 2nd. Mrs Knowles took sick leave.

Colonel Morgan inspected monthly.

INDUSTRIES. The Girls have altered Cadet Marine uniforms to fit our boys and made suits for the small boys from jersey cloth purchased at the Paris Mills. They have also made two issues of shirts for boys and one of aprons and combinations for the girls. Besides this they have made new kitchen and Dining Room aprons and kept all clothing being worn in repair.

We have commenced a new work with our girls. All scraps of cloth now are being saved and made into very attractive rag rugs. The boys have renovated the Girls playroom and painted it.

This is a great improvement.

Farm and Garden. We have carried out the usual work for this quarter in a very satisfactory fashion and in addition we have painted all the farm wagons, made new double-trees and single-trees and over-hauled our machinery. The hospital, which was touching the new wing has been moved to a new site and is now attractively situated on the side of the tennis lawn with row of spruce trees for a back-ground. After removing the hospital the ground was graded several hundreds loads of earth being necessary for this work.

We shall commence this year's farming operations better prepared than has been the case for several years.
