June 5th 1925.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I regret to say that the attitude of Mr. Rogers of the Mohawk Institute towards myself, as Superintendent, is such as to leave me no alternative other than to either dissolve me from responsibility regarding him or to definitely notify him that it is your wish that I should continue upon the same lines as my predecessor, Major Smith, and that he must not commit actions, without first consulting me, which may lead to complications in the relations between the Department and the Six Nations.

I have previously told you that since I came to office there has been a systematic attempt by the Indians to influence between the Institute and this Office. First, the Indians wrote to the Indians until you yourself notify me today that his returns should be closely watched before sending out, and that it was your wish that a friendly investigation should be made by me.

To avoid unpleasantness I have, therefore, been resigning these duties and have done my utmost to avoid any further complications in any way possible.

Yesterday I was recently met by Mr. Frank Lortner who asked me whether his daughter, Dorothy, could leave the Institute to attend the Sun Dance, and I gave him a letter to Rogers, of which I attach a copy(A). I also attach one of Major Smith's letters of a similar
nature, and other facts. His Missive (B) to show that no letter was written so courteous or unusual.

On May 27th Rogers told me that he had asked the Bishop of Huron to unveil a new memorial to fallen Indians in the Church early this month.

I had heard nothing of this officially from the Department I thought it odd and, knowing that the Council was on the look out for any excuse to accuse the Department of ignoring it, in the case of the statement of Mr. J. C., not merely written over, I wrote Rogers my letter back marked (C).

This was the height of folly. When he called me a liar, "I'm writing to tell you that the Institute has nothing whatever to do with the children. If you receive instructions only from Mr. Rogers and you", in reply to this I wrote:

On June 1st, Johnson returned over to Mr. Hill's, who is now Chief of the Ojibwa Band, and on the 3rd day of the Colored People, the Ojibwa Band, a missionary service, so I could not go. On the 4th day I went there and "He said he had nothing to do with the race".

The Council, as you know, is divided into two parties, one loyal to Mr. J. C., the other, its representatives, as to the Chief Counsellor Mr. J. C., and by Councilor Johnson, Mr. J. C., which loses an opportunity which offers to covertly
defy the Department and spread the seeds of dissention amongst the loyal section of the Council whenever possible.

It was Johnson who reintroduced the question of "Status" into the new Council. Johnson opposed the Kitchener Oil Vote. Johnson raised the controversy that the Department had slighted the dignity of the Council by erecting No 6 School by hired labour, instead of calling for contracts. In his chagrin that he could not sell the Department nails at 7¢ a pound which were being bought elsewhere for 5¢, and it is Johnson who poses in the Council as the arbitrator between it and the Department. Don't I am told he says, bother about the Indian Office, I will see Dr Scott about it the next time I go to Ottawa.

I was informed that Rogers flung an apple of discord by a direct invitation to be present at the unveiling of a memorial of which no one had previously heard.

Several Councillors and members of the School Board asked me why the Department had not invited them to deliver a speech on the nature of a war memorial to fall on Six Nations soldiers to be erected in the Six Nations Church.

I was obliged to admit that I knew nothing about it, and to say that I did not think that the Department did either, and that not only had I, as representative of the Department received no notice but that also I had received no notice to be present, so I concluded that it had been done by Mr Rogers upon his own authority.

My omission from the list was, as obviously, in the eyes of the "loyal flock," an attempt by this employee of the Department to do what they are constantly themselves striving for, get away from local supervision, that they called it with each election or vote to listen, and some no doubt ill, but the loyal element, being the stronger, voted against

Mr Rogers called at Colby's house or may have explained something
attention, on the grounds that they considered that if the Department had any knowledge of the matter they would first have been consulted before the memorial was erected in their church to their dead, and that the information and invitations to attend would have reached them from the Department through the Official channel of the Indian Office.

Some were favoring to you to stop it but finally they consented themselves with refusing the invitation.

In conclusion may I repeat what I have previously written you that far from wishing to exercise any authority or officiousness with the Rogers I would far sooner have nothing whatever to do with the Institute.

If the Department feels that Rogers can be trusted to be freed from all local supervision and control by the Indians, it will give me considerable relief to me, although I cannot see how my responsibilities for the Indians can be likely confined to those who are grown up and residing on the Reserve.

In any case I trust that steps will be taken to prevent any recurrence of this episode and that if Mr. Rogers finds it necessary to communicate in future with the Council or others on the Reserve that he may be told to do so through me.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

S. H. Burgess
June 9th, 1925.

Dear Colonel Morgan,

I have your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to your relationship to the Mohawk Institute and the Principal, Mr. Rogers. I regret to learn that there has been some unpleasantness.

I cannot see that there should be any doubt in your mind concerning your duties in connection with the school. If you will read my 32-0-1 of November 28th, last, you will note that you are not asked to supervise school activity or accept any responsibility. I requested a monthly inspection and report. Further, you are required to make an independent check of the school's quarterly financial statements.

I have noted your letter to the Principal, relative to special leave for Dorothy Monture, one of the pupils. I think it would have been more considerate if you had suggested or recommended to the Principal that the girl be allowed to go home with her father.

Your communication concerning a Memorial to pupils of the Mohawk Institute was couched in language which would be sure to cause offense. The Memorial is not a Six Nations matter—it is for pupils of the school and is to be placed
in the Mohawk Chapel, for which the Principal of the Institute is responsible to the Department. I am sure Mr. Rogers intended to send invitations to you and to the members and organizations of the Indian band. It is probable that your peremptory letter to him on this subject halted any cooperation with your office that was originally intended.

I do not know what contribution Mr. Rogers has made to the present unpleasantness in your personal relations, but I wish to state that you are not responsible for him. Further, I am not prepared to criticize his actions in connection with the Memorial to former school pupils.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Indian Superintendent,

Sir,

I have the honour to submit the following report on the activities and progress of the work of this Institution.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Church. Owing to the coldness of the weather we did not commence holding services in the Church until May 10th, when Rev. Soudamore was in charge. Rev. G.H. Owen conducted all other services with the exception of that held on June 28th by Rev. Smith. The children decorated the school-room most tastefully for the Easter service.

Staff. During the quarter Miss Crowe resigned and her place was taken by Miss Allen who promises to develop into a very efficient officer. Miss Hardie has not enjoyed very good health but otherwise our staff has worked most satisfactorily. Miss Jackson and Miss Hardie attending Business College have had a great deal of trouble and I am glad to find that they have in the habit of absenting themselves from classes. They failed in their first examinations and although given an opportunity of an extra month's tuition only Effie Montour passed. Maggie Jackson and Helen Froman continued to trifle and were consequently dismissed after trying their examination for the second time. Dorothy Montour who is attending the Gold Plate passed her first year and has shown a very marked improvement lately.

News. A party of teachers from Hamilton visited the school early in April and showed much interest.

April 6th. Thirty children were outfitted for Chapleau. These children were forbidden to enter the school and slept in a cottage nearby. Some were in very filthy condition and although we took utmost precautions we had quite a lot of cleaning up to do after they left.

The boys had some good fishing on Good Friday and Easter Monday. Mrs Rogers returned on the 2nd.

On May 1st, our pupils were invited to a Band Concert at the local Armouries and we were encouraged by the kindly comments made as to their appearance and behaviour.

May 23rd. Mr. Ferrier visited and matters pertaining to school advancement were discussed.

May 22nd. The Remembrance Chapter of the I.O.D.E., of which Miss Hardie is a member, presented a prize for the best paper on Hygiene. This was won by Beulah Stonefish.

May 24th, being Bob Rogers birthday was the occasion of a party. We had a large birthday cake and all the staff and pupils shared it.
June 1st. Commenced preparations for unveiling Roll of Honour in Church. The pulpit has been removed and was presented to St. Peters Church at Onawaken.

June 5th. A Garden Party was held at St. Peters Onawaken and several of our pupils attended by Mrs. Rogers took part in the programme. In this connection it should be mentioned that due largely to the cooperation of Rev. Jones of that church there is a much more friendly spirit shown towards the school.

June 11th. Bishop Williams unveiled the Roll of Honour in the Mohawk Church. He was assisted by the Reverends Lee, White and Owen. The Town Band from Gananoque offered their services and paraded our children to and from the Church. So large was the crowd that many of the pupils had to remain outside the Church. After the service the visitors were entertained on the School Lawn to ice cream and cakes while the band played. Mrs. Pearson was absent for ten days holiday in June.

Mary Macdonald from the local Blind Institute commenced her annual visit on June 15th.

During the quarter the girls were issued with new low shoes and aprons while the boys received two new shirts, new overalls, caps and hats.

Buildings and grounds. In an attempt to add to the beauty of the school grounds we have reorganized our activities in that direction. Mrs. Rogers has taken charge of the flower borders and with a number of girls is giving them the care they need. This relieves the gardener who can now bend every effort to production. Large white stones have been placed along the drive and our verandah is in very fine condition.

A new wall has been placed under the verandah and paint is being applied as opportunity occurs.

We have built a garage to house the new truck and to make room in the old drive shed for our implements.

The new hog pen is well under way and in the course of a week or so will be ready to occupy.

Farm and Garden. We have suffered a very severe disappointment in these activities. For nearly two months prior to June 24th, we had no rain and practically the whole of the farm crops in this area threaten to be a failure. We have one field of about forty acres in hay and it is impossible to cut it. Nowhere is the grass as tall as it was last year in height. Some of our crops which showed so much promise has ripened at a height of about ten inches. However, due to having a fair acreage of alfalfa which are in a better position than most farmers.

For the same reason there were no small fruits this year and our lawns are scorched.

SPECIAL NOTE. On June 30th, we had to call the Doctor to Batay Isando a recent admission who had become quite ill. It was discovered that she had been injured by a fall and had been in bed a week before she came here. She is up and appears to be well.

I have the honour to submit the following report on the activities and progress of the work of this Institution.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Church. During the holidays the Church was not used for services but every Sunday a short service was held in the School-room at 9.30 a.m. by the Principal and most of the remaining pupils attended Trinity Church for the morning service afterwards. Many Tourists visited the Church throughout the summer and those who have memories of the pulpit expressed themselves as delighted to see the interior of the Church as it had been for so many years. We had to hold the services at home on several occasions on account of rain. Rev. Mr Owen has been in charge and on September 12th he celebrated Holy Communion.

Staff. There have been no changes in the staff during the quarter. Miss Hardie and Mrs Knowles had six weeks holiday and on their return Miss Wilson, the housekeeper had two weeks leave. Mr Knowles took two weeks holiday and Mr Thurlow attended the Dufferin Rifles Camp.

Discipline. There has been a decided improvement in the general discipline since the holidays. We have two pupils attending Collegiate and very definite rules have been laid down for their guidance, with quite severe punishments for misdemeanours. As a result they are only too anxious to do their share in maintaining their place in the school. We were also able to dismiss a number of older girls who were not a good influence. We are now, for the first time, able to maintain a Waiting List and as all the parents and pupils know this, there is a very decided effort on everyone's part to retain a place in the school.

Works. During the holidays the plaster throughout the school was patched and repaired and the girls re-varnished the stairs, wainscoting and linoleum.

Rev. N. Lee visited and borrowed the Principal's car to visit his old parish on the Reserve.

Mrs Watts, Commissioner, and Girl Guide Officers from England visited our Corps on September 1st.

September 16th. Nugent Bardy, one of our boys, was kicked in the shoulder by a horse in the pasture. First aid was rendered and the Doctor summoned. Upon examination it was found that only a painful bruise was the outcome.

We were also visited by Miss Bauslaugh whose father was the Principal here some sixty years ago. It was quite interesting...
to hear her discourse upon school life in those early days.

Reverend Westgate and Canon Fotheringham visited the school on September 20th.

On the 24th September the members of the Rotary Club Convention were here.

After the holidays the pupils returned promptly and early in the term we were in the fortunate position of starting our waiting list. We are very pleased to report that we have not approached any person with a view to inducing pupils to enter the school. Our pupils went home and apparently compared so favourably with other children on the Reserve that before the close of the holidays we were having applications for children that we could not accommodate.

Amusements. On July 1st, the girls visited the stores in the morning and played soft-ball. In the afternoon they went in a body to Mohawk Park. The boys spent a good day at the river with the Principal.

A Closing Concert was held on July 3rd, when Miss Hardie left for Victoria and Mrs Knowles for the Girl Guide Camp.

July 4th. Closing Day. The day passed very quietly and we were left with 30 girls and 20 boys. We gave these children a more liberal diet in the way of fancy articles and generally speaking made it possible for them to have a good time at the school. Once or twice a week they went to Mohawk Pleasure Park where the management were most kind. Our pupils were allowed to ride the ponies and the merry-go-round free and they made good use of the other amusements there.

On two occasions we took a number to Grimsby where they picked fruit in the mornings. We provided picnic lunches and in the afternoons they visited the pleasure Park there and enjoyed spending the money they had earned.

One afternoon as a reward for some extra help the girls had given they were taken for a round trip on the town street car. The boys were very willing whenever volunteers were called to help handle a crop and on the whole the summer holiday passed most pleasantly. During the last week all pupils were paid a small sum in proportion to the help they had given and they went to town to spend the same.

On the 17th August, the Monday following School Opening, all the staff and pupils held a Gala at Mohawk Park. This served to settle them all back to school life after which steady work was the order of the day.

Our annual Corn Roast was held on the 24th September.

Farm and Garden. Despite a very backward spring and severe drought our crops were quite good, on the whole. Apart from ordinary farm activities we have completed our new pig pen, laid the cement floor and sprayed it ready for use. We have also unloaded all the coal for the coming winter and stored it away. In preparing our Fall wheat ground we had a most interesting and instructive time. Members of the Verity Plough Company brought several ploughs here and tests were carried out. The Company's expert was here and we all felt that we had learned a great deal about ploughing and ploughing when they left.

Our second crop of Alfalfa was exceedingly good and a hay field, that at one time appeared as though it were ruined, revived after the heavy rains and we were able to cut a huge crop off it.

On September 8th, we threshed our grain and had over 1700 bushels in our granary as a result.

The long flower borders on either side of our drive have been thoroughly cultivated and we are in hopes that next year we shall have that more beautiful than ever before. Every plant was lifted out and the whole manured and plowed. After the girls under Mrs Rogers had replaced the plants we obtained several hundred fresh plants to fill in the many bare places.

Sir,

May I respectfully make the following proposal for the betterment of this Institution.

For some time I have been discussing the advisability of increasing my inside staff by one female officer. At the present time the members of our housekeeping department are called upon to take care of more work than can be effectively accomplished. Whilst the work is always done it is felt that the training of our girls is necessarily neglected along certain lines.

I feel that as an Industrial School it should be our first object to teach our pupils the correct methods of labour and not merely regard each pupil as a unit of labour. With this in view it is easy to see that unless the housekeeping officers have sufficient time to teach the various domestic sciences we are falling short of that high standard of efficiency that is desirable.

Many of our girls have to take positions as maids when they leave the School and whilst they have quite a good idea of cooking for large numbers they are absolutely incapable of cooking for a family. This is quite naturally the case since there is no opportunity given them under existing conditions, to acquire the necessary knowledge and experience. Then, again, they are not well instructed in the care and cleaning of furniture, carpets and floors, and whilst we are always particular as to cleanliness we are of the opinion that better results would be obtained could more time be given to instruction.

In view of the foregoing could I be authorised to engage another officer. I believe I could get the type of person I want for about $25.00 per month.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal

CHRISTMAS TREE.

The following evening, Christmas eve, the whole school and staff gathered in the dining hall where there was a light show that shone by hundreds of coloured lights on the giant Christmas tree. One member of the staff had an unfortunate thing that Principal S. Rogers was too busy to attend the party. The staff had made his visit and departed.

Santa Claus, however, did arrive. Two red planks were placed across the floor and down these he slid with a sleigh and a bag full of presents. He said he had so many presents and such a large sack that he could not have put all the gifts on before and after dinner. He was very glad to make the presentation. Then a very funny game was played. A piece of board was hanging from the bottom of the tree and as a result the whole contents dropped out. From a gun the whole school pounced upon them. The board had been so strangely scattered. After dinner was served, each class came in and out of the one hundred and ninety-five rooms. Every one had a present, an orange. The remainder of the evening was spent in a period of fun and frolics off their previous work and playing.

Christmas Day.

On Christmas Day the staff and pupils met in the school room for a special celebration. The children, Christmas Lunch, at 9 o'clock, and the remainder of the morning was spent in various activities. The pupils played games, sang songs, and danced. After lunch, the boys went out to play football while the girls remained inside. In the afternoon, the pupils attended to their chores in a more leisurely manner. And because of the Christmas spirit, they worked hard.

New Year's Day.

New Year's Day was the occasion for much fun and frolics. It was also the final day of the holiday. The pupils returned to school for the re-opening of school lessons, and a normal routine.

During the whole of the holiday the girls have carried on with the usual routine. They have attended to their chores in a more leisurely manner. And because of the Christmas spirit, they worked hard.

As the boys were suffering from the cold, they volunteered to clear the snow away for the girls. The space was flooded and now they have a right fine place to play in. During the two weeks preceding Christmas all the pupils were given an opportunity of visiting town and seeing the window displays and stores. Many of them were fortunate enough to see Santa Claus. The Trinity Dramatic Club very kindly came to the school on 17th December and played Pollyanna for the benefit of the pupils.

To describe our activities during the Christmas recess would fill a press volume. The little girls under Miss McKeown made three rag rugs whilst the senior girls made the officers a complete set of linen luncheon doylays, trimmed with crochet work. To match this there was also a side table and sideboard runner made in the same fashion.

We tried to interest the girls in knitting themselves scarfs and mittens as soon as the pupils were expected to do this in their own time we failed to get very much work done in this direction.

Notes. Girl Guides were re-organized on October 1st, and went for a hike during which they gathered wild flowers and plumes for Harvest Home decorations.

Mr. and Mrs. Rogers went to Toronto to make wholesale purchases Oct. 7th.

On October 8th we had to commence heating the building and on the tenth we had to issue heavy underwear to the boys on account of the sudden cold weather.

By October 12th, all the girls' summer clothing had been replaced by heavier wear for winter, and all store windows were in position.

On October 13th Miss Chamberlin was assigned. She has a second class certificate and teaches the kindergarten children during work hours. Among other duties she has assumed are those of instructing junior pupils in making rag rugs, elementary sewing, supervision of cleaning and play director.

Miss Knowles was taken ill on the 26th. October so we had Miss Chamberlin assist her in her duties until Miss McKeown arrived.

The Stamford Laundry issued a public invitation for inspection of its plant so Miss Allen who is responsible for the laundry work here and Miss Chamberlin took twenty-five of the senior girls who were welcomed by the President of the Company who kindly acted as guide throughout the whole of the plant. In addition to this highly instructive inspection the girls were presented with five dollars which they placed in the Radio Fund.

We have now a powerful receiving set with one loud speaker operated in one of the classrooms and we are now trying to sell our fund sufficiently to install a loud speaker in both classrooms. We find the talks to children broadcasted from the various stations are most attractive and the older children enjoy the good music. Of course, the jazz is always popular.

On November 7th, three girls who had absented themselves after the holidays without sending any word applied for re-admission. They and their parents were quite surprised and indignant when we could not accept them on account of the school being over-full. We are hoping that this action will ensure prompt return from holidays in future.

Irene Isaac, a very naughty small girl, and Betsey Isaac, who is sub-normal, absconded on November 25th in their work dresses with no coats. After searching all morning for them I informed the Mounted Police and the girls were returned the next day. They were ordered that no one should shelter them and that they were reported to the police as Mohawk Institute pupils. This shows a very welcome change of attitude on the Reserve.

We were offered a piano very cheaply and as we were in need of another instrument we purchased same on November 27th. Our music classes are growing rapidly.

On the 12th December we fetched a wagon load of evergreens and bring the Saturday before Christmas most of the pupils were visited by friends or relatives and went to town with them.

During the week preceding Christmas everyone was busy. Girls were decorating and boys killing pork and poultry and getting ready for Christmas inspection.

We were able to arrange for the inside staff to have five days either at Christmas or New Years.

Mr. Elmer Jamieson was given the classrooms for carrying out intelli-
tests with the pupils on the 19th and 24th December.

Clothing. In addition to making the necessary seasonal changes in clothing, the girls were issued with new high shoes; they made twenty heavy coats and altered thirty-five heavy green coats in addition to re-making some old grey coats; an issue of new stockings was also made. The boys received new shoes, socks, heavy underwear, overall sweaters and were re-fitted with winter uniforms.

Health. Whilst the general health of the pupils has been very good we have suffered one or two severances and there has been an epidemic of accidents. Missie Snake had a very trying time with pneumonia and as she began to recover another little girl named Powless contracted the same complaint. There were also a few bad colds with indications of pleurisy but by careful attention there were no serious results. As far as the pupils are aware there were no serious results.

In the matter of accidents investigation showed that the cause was either purely accidental or else directly due to the carelessness of the victim. Myles Isaac left his shoe lace undone and this tripped him as he was entering the greenhouse with the result that he fell and broke his clavicle bone. George Oba came down on his shoes and clipped whilst carrying a plank. This broke his forearm. Another boy walked in front of some wood that was being pitch and was struck in the forehead causing a cut an inch and a half long which bared the bone. Another boy slipped whilst skating and cut his lip on a skate. All these cases were promptly attended to and no ill-effects seem yet be evident.

Farm and Garden. Speaking generally this has been the most successful year in both these departments during the period I have had the honour to control them. Whilst there were drawbacks due to the early drought our ultimate crops compare most favourably with some of the best farms in this locality. Our barns were filled with live-stock and savings were thus made.

On October 13th, I inspected the farm and our fall crops were all ready to harvest. As the weather was mild I decided to discontinue classroom work until we had the work of harvesting well in hand. As a consequence we were able to commence operations all over the farm. The school teachers took the very small children out to pick beans, a large number of boys assisted in gathering apples in the orchard and as they picked a number of larger girls sorted and packed away the fruit in the cellar; other squads were busy pulling the manure and picking up potatoes. Every morning I called for more effort and I have never witnessed such enthusiasm as the pupils and staff displayed. In about a week we had the work well in hand and school was resumed. We had only a few hours' work before the harvest was in hand and when the weather broke we had very severe frosts which spelt ruin to so many farmers. We had to have all our cattle in winter quarters by October 26th. After the frost we dug the potatoes that were left and picked what few apples there were unpicked and found them quite good if used immediately. In this way we did not lose anything.

Our obysenthamums this year were exceptionally good and were in great demand. Out of the thousands of blooms I do not think we had a dozen in the school as buyers were here daily taking everything they could buy. In this connection great credit is due to our gardener Mr Henderson. We are also indebted to Major General H.C. Ashton G.M.C. for the many choice species he has secured for us from the Experimental Farm.

We had several cows tested for tuberculosis and have had to dispose of several that reacted badly.

Owing to our boar failing to breed we had to purchase a new one which was obtained from the Ontario Hospital, Hamilton.

By arrangement with the Canadian Poultry Company our older boys are visiting that plant chiefly to learn the hog industry. They are allowed to accompany the Government Grader who explains to them all the various features that control his grading. This work is most interesting and the boys are quite enthusiastic. On December 30th, one of our boys was within ten pounds of the correct weight of any pig he saw when estimating prices.

Owing to a very uncertain market in feeds I was advised to buy a carload in October during a dreary spell in the markets.
I acted upon this advice and by the time the car was delivered the price locally was $5 per ton higher than that which I had paid. We are steadily building a reputation as breeders of the bacon type hog and as our name improves so we find the demand for our stock increasing. I am indebted to Messrs J. B. Brethour and Nephews for much assistance in this direction, and to Mr. R. A. Thompson, miller for information regarding the Feed Markets.

5th January 1926.
Ottawa, January 8, 1926.

Sir,

It is with great regret that I have to report a very serious breach of discipline on the part of a number of the senior boys and girls of this school. For a period of two or three weeks a number of boys and girls found means of meeting in different parts of this Institute and in fact a party of boys on several occasions made a trip to the Girls dormitory. This was discovered by myself when investigating a report by a junior officer who had occasion to correct the girls for noisy conduct in the dormitory about 5 a.m. on January 9th, 1926.

I made a very extensive enquiry and caused every pupil implicated to write me a full confession of the whole proceedings and it would appear that serious as I at first thought the matter to be, it was more in the nature of a series of wild escapades. During the period that has elapsed since this occurrence I have had every officer co-operate in obtaining information concerning this affair and today I find them of the opinion that the affair was in the nature of a "lark".

Needless to say great care has since been exercised to prevent any possible recurrence and an system of alarms has been worked out to warn of any movement during the night. The culprits have been punished by having leave cancelled and they have also an hour extra work daily.

Should any information reach me that would alter opinion of this affair I will immediately report to you.

Your obedient servant,

Church all services were held in the Senior School-room under the direction of Rev. C. H. Owen. A number of junior pupils have had extra Bible instruction under the junior school teacher during service hour as they would cause the senior school-room to be overcrowded. During February Mr. Owen commenced a Confirmation class. Holy Communion was celebrated each month.

Staff. There have been no changes in the staff during the quarter.

Parents. Whenever possible the girls the girls have had two walks on fine days. Sleighbidding and skating were enjoyed by both boys and girls. During stormy days the children were able to listen to all kinds of radio programmes. We have found the boys very active in entertaining the girls in former times it was necessary to keep them out of mischief. We have now a lot more space in our school-room.

New Year's Day was celebrated in the usual way. All the girls went sleigh-riding and after a supper very well decorated, we met in the Dining Hall for games and frolics.

January. Mr. Elmer Jamieson tested those pupils in the Training Room. Fire Drill and all equipment tested.

February. A breakage occurred in the steam pipe in the Girl's Dormitory. This was quickly repaired with material we had on hand.

January. This was a very fine day and we had a great number of visitors.

January 27th. As we were unable to purchase chestnut coal we were in great difficulty with the cooking arrangements. The local dealers were asking $14 per ton for coke and consequently were being put to considerable expense. After careful consideration we decided that the installation of the electric stove would help us considerably. Our electrician gave us very reasonable terms and the range was installed on this date. Since its installation we have been giving senior girls who will be entering Year training in its operation and so it serves a double purpose.

Mr. Jamieson has spent most week ends with us conducting his intelligence tests and we have been most interested in the results. In the case of one girl who has always been very troublesome, it was discovered that although only eleven and in the senior class she really has the mentality of a child of five. It is Mr. Jamieson's intention to put her through further tests.

Rev. Mr. MacKenzie who several years ago was closely in touch with the school paid us a visit and greatly admired the additions and alterations in the buildings.

During the quarter the largest department store in Brantford closed and we were able to buy quantities of equipment at very reduced prices. Mr. Ford and Co., who have been our grocers for so many years also closed down and after their sale we bought quantities of their "dead" stock at ridiculously low figures.

March Mr. Standing inspected.

Sir,

I have the honour to submit the following report on the activities and progress of this Institute.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Church. The weekly services have been held under the charge of Rev. G. H. Owen. Good Friday morning service was led by the Principal and the girls went to partake of the three hour services in town. For Easter we had special decorations and on April 11th we had Easter Communion. We could not attend the Church until May 9th. Three pupils were baptised and the Bishop confirmed twenty-two pupils on June 12th. We were able to complete a flag-stone path into the Church before the Bishop's visit. The Board of Works of the City of Brentford kindly gave us some flag-stones and the farm staff and boys laid the walk in about six days. We have also built a stone barrier at the foot of the Church hill to prevent thoughtless motorists from damaging the turf. On June 6th, Rev. O. Rodinon came to pray with the children.

Staff. On April 1st, engaged Mr. Foster as teacher but as he was not satisfactory he was allowed to leave at the end of one month. We were fortunate enough to get the services of Mr. Thurlow for the spring work. During the quarter Mr. and Mrs. Rogers, Mrs. Persall, Miss Chambers and Miss Allan had each eight days' holiday. Mr. Persall was quite off for two weeks with lumbago and Miss Wilson had to lay up with an injured leg for three weeks. Mr. Thurlow was given an opportunity to resign as he was not proving satisfactory.

Mrs. Persall has on the doctor's advice resigned but we are not anxious to lose her and have only made temporary arrangements in the hope that she will recover and return to us. We were able to get Miss Mason, daughter of Rev. R. Mason to take her place.

I have Miss Chambers resignation as she has secured a position near her home.

Health. During the quarter the general health of the pupils has been excellent, apart from a slight epidemic of croup. Several pupils have been to visit the dentist and optician. On June 11th Dr. Selby visited the school and examined a number of girls who were giving us a little concern and he pronounced Gladys Watts as tubercular.

Discipline. There has been a marked improvement in the conduct of the children and a very pleasing spirit is evident.

Nursery. Elmar Jamieson held tests on April 8th and 9th.

During the quarter we have painted the beds and the woodwork in the dormitories. Early in May we were able to have a spring clean-up outside the building and it is generally remarked that the grounds have never looked so trim.
On May 6th, this district was visited by sneak thieves and we lost five tires from the school truck during the night.

They've been fitted out with new overalls, shirts, shoes and at times and the girls have new summer dresses, underwear, stockings and kitchen aprons.

May 16th. Zion Church girls called at school whist hiking.

May 17th. The Bishop of Huron and friends were entertained after Service of Confirmation. Mr. Johnson the famous New York tenor was in town on that day and called to see the Church during the service. It was delightful to see him enter in the singing with the pupils and he was very complimentary in his remarks afterwards.

May 18th. Mr. and Mrs Rogers visited wholesale houses in Toronto in search of clothing for boys next winter.

From May 18th to 20th we had two delegates of the Women's Auxiliary billeted with us. The Bishop asked if the Queen Anne Silver could be loaned as they had to add to the Communion Plate at Grace Church for the Delegates service. As the delegates do so much work for Indian Missions I thought it was very fitting that they should on this occasion have the use of the service so I made the necessary arrangements for its safe keeping much to every person's delight. During the time the delegates were in town we were constantly visited.

June 10th. Mr. and Mrs. Hundfland, German journalists, visited the school to collect data for a book they are writing.

June 14th. We fetched Rev. and Mrs. Lee who spent a few days with us.

June 21st. Large hot water boiler sprung a leak and we had to have it replaced.

June 22nd. Irene and Betsy Isaac again absconded but we had them back in a few hours. Neither of these girls are normal and they give us quite a lot of trouble.

June 25th. Mr. and Mrs. Peters from No. 6 School on the Reserve spent week end here.

Three girls and three boys wrote their entrance examination. Two girls dropped out of class, one was sick and the other did not wish to continue.

June 29th. Visited Mills in Paris and purchased blankets and stockings.

Amusements. Easter Monday the girls went to the stores and to a show whilst the boys had a good day fishing.

Our pupils attended Miss Frances Nickawa's recital at a city church.

May 24th. Girls went to Mohawk Park and the following day the Remembrance Chapter presented a prize for general efficiency to Norman Lickers. The pupils held a short patriotic concert and the Chapter made a presentation of library books.

June 8th. We had a general holiday and Mr. Rogers took four senior boys to the Agricultural College.

June 22nd. Miss Hardie took a party of girls to help at a concert at a Reserve Church.

June 29th. Circus Day and all those who had the money were taken in the afternoon.

Farm and Garden Work generally was slow this spring and our garden suffered considerably from cutworms. However, crops are very promising and I hope we have very full barns this fall. Boys have been attending the pork factory to receive instruction in hog farming.

We have installed a new lawn water service and laid the water into the new pig pen. All the trees on the property have been trimmed and the hedges have been pruned to control the borders. We have planted all the farm buildings and they present a very smart appearance. We have laid a new cement driveway in one of the farms to replace one of the paths. The wells have been cleaned.

The fences are in good order and one other after staining. Our vegetable garden looks very nice and we are planning a very bountiful harvest.

3rd July 1926.

Sir,

I have the honour to submit the following report of the activities and progress of the work of this Institute.

Your obedient servant,

S. Rogers

Church. Services were held at the Church on July 4th and 11th. The Church was closed for six weeks during the holiday period. During holidays and short service was held each Sunday morning at 9:15 and pupils were allowed to attend the Churches in town for morning and evening services. The girls went in charge of an officer and the boys were allowed to go unattended.

The Church was re-opened on August 26th under Rev. C.H.Owen. Holy Communion was celebrated September 26th.

Staff. Mr. Thurlow resigned and his services terminated July 15th. Mrs. Smith was engaged to fill the vacancy and was on duty July 12th. On July 31st Miss Chambers, Domestic Science teacher, left to take a position she had secured near her home which was much better paid. Miss Mason, a temporary officer left on the same date and Mrs. Forsell who had had a month's leave of absence, returned to duty.

Mr. Hughes, a farm instructor, went to Hospital on August 31st and was away three weeks.

Miss Wilson resigned on September 1st. She was a very efficient officer but since an automobile accident a year ago her nerves had gradually become worse until they rendered her undesirable. We replaced her with Miss Bates but she showed no signs of becoming a good officer and so was allowed to leave at the end of one week.

On September 5th Mr. and Mrs. Rogers left for a short motor trip which included Ottawa in its itinerary. They returned to duty September 13th.

September 15th, Mr. Howarth took material for boys suits to Greene Swifts of London.

Discipline. On the whole this has been good especially amongst the boys but we have had several unpleasant cases of theft and petty stealing amongst the girls.

Notes. On July 1st the girls went to the River to bathe and to Mohawk Park while most of the boys found work at neighbours.

Gladys Staats went to the Sanitarium, Hamilton with Mr. and Mrs. Rogers. On July 8th all boys were kept from School. Owing to the cool wet weather, weeds were making much more rapid growth than our corn and roots and it was considered advisable to devote a day or two's work to saving the crop. By comparing our corn crop with our neighbours it is easy to see that we were wise in doing this. At the same time the girls tidied the playgrounds under the supervision of the school teachers and some silver spoons and fountain pens that had been stolen were found cached.

The Shrine Club entertained our pupils at a Circus on July 10th. On July 14th we ventured a Garden Party and Closing Concert. The grounds were beautiful. This being the result of the work Miss Rogers and the girls in the flower beds. The weather was ideal and we had a
The Tennis lawn was gaily lighted and there were booths for the sale of ice cream sodas, drinks and specimens of the children's handiwork. We used the front veranda as a stage for the concert and seats were placed on the lawn. The school electrician very kindly loaned us string lights and the building was very attractively decorated. We had the early evening parade of visitors who proceeded through the school buildings by officers. During the Concert prizes were given to the pupils who had made most consistent progress during the year and we were able to announce the results of the Entrance Examinations. We had three girls and three boys write this examination and all passed, one boy with honours.

July 26th. The school closed for holidays but we had 42 girls and 28 boys remain. Several were able to leave later when their relatives assured sufficient money to outfit them.

Miss Hardie and Miss McKeown also left for their holidays. During the vacation the girls were required to work each morning and the afternoons were devoted to amusements such as bathing, visiting parks, taking round trips on the street cars and going to shows. We spent the sum of $25 upon these outings.

With the boys it was necessary to hire a number of the older in order to keep the farm work in hand. These boys, however, were allowed to attend the moving pictures and sports meetings at night with an officer.

On July 28th. James Macdonald was suddenly taken very ill and on the following day was taken to hospital and Morrison rushed him to hospital after consultation and operated for appendicitis. He did very well and returned home at the end of two weeks.

On August 9th. Rev. H. Lee who used to be a missionary on the Reserve spent a few days with us and on the 12th. we motored him to Dr. Davis at Brantford where he was treated for his complaint.

The Manager of the local theatre entertained our children on 16th.

On August 22nd. the water front in the kitchen stove burst and we found water all over the basement floor.

Friday August 27th. the last day of the holidays we had a big night ice cream and games on the lawn. During the holidays we varied the diet as much as possible and served ice cream several times for supper.

August 28th. the pupils returned from holidays; they were prompt and in good spirits. Some new pupils arrived two and three weeks ahead of time. Some children were even left without papers and had to be sent home.

Monday August 30th. all departments of school work were re-opened in proper order.

August 31st. Mr. Rogers took 12 boys by truck to Toronto Exhibition. These boys had done particularly well during the holidays and spent a very happy and instructive day, witnessing the Grand Stand Performance at its close.

1st. September a car of coal was unloaded on this day and two others were delivered during the month.

Labour Day on September 5th. was a school holiday.

September 9th. Mr. Williams of the Department and Colonel Morgan visited the school.

September 25th. Major Rogers and Mr. Smith attended Great War Veterans' Dedication at Brantford and were able to take a delightful spray-bouquet of flowers from the school Farm and Garden. This section of the country has been very ill-favoured by the weather this year. Hundreds of farmers have scarcely saved any hay or grain but we have been particularly fortunate. There remain about five acres of hay uncut and we have garnered all the grain except about 100 bushels of rye which is sprouting badly. Our wheat yielded forty bushels to the acre and our other crops were correspondingly good. It was necessary to hire extra help as we had one man in hospital and whenever it was possible to draw in the grain we made a point of crowding as much work as possible into a day to avoid the grain being left out for more rain.

On rainy days we have worked around the barns and greenhouses and have accomplished a great deal of repair and constructive work. We have replaced one rotten wood barn floor with another of cement. Torn out
benches in greenhouses that were on the verge of collapse and replaced them with cement of a permanent nature. We have built cement cold frames and have generally improved our buildings. There is much favorable comment locally over the improved appearances of our buildings in their new coat of paint.

A store house on the farm has been moved about four feet from its old location where it obstructed the light entering several windows of the new pig pen.

We have over-hauled our tractor and owing to collapse of our old cutting box we had to purchase a new one for silo filling.

All glass in buildings and greenhouses has been re-set.

Holiday Improvements—All plaster throughout the building has been patched and the school-rooms and sewing room re-painted.

A room in the basement that had previously been used as a refrigerator and store-room was refitted as a clothing room to accommodate forty senior girls. The old clothing room was refitted to accommodate the smaller girls. Boot-racks were placed in all clothing rooms and an addition made to that of the boys. The girls' lavatory and dressing-room was whitewashed and repainted. Most of this work was done by the girls; men, of course attending to the ceiling and other high work.

The stairs and main hall were re-varnished.

The lockers in the girls' playroom were repaired.

The large refrigerator was rebuilt in the Dining Hall in a convenient corner.

2nd October 1926.
Ottawa, October 6th, 1926.

Sir,

I have the honour to submit the following report of the activities and progress of this Institute.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Rev. Mr. H. Owen has been in charge of the weekly service. On October 11th we celebrated our Harvest Festival and the Church was very prettily decorated by the senior girls for this event. The pupils attended a Social Children's Service at Trinity Church on October 17th. Holy Communion was administered on the last Sunday in each month. It was arranged to hold Thanksgiving Services in the Church but we have not held them there since. The Christmas Services were very prettily arranged but on Christmas morning we had a special Carol Service.

Health. On the whole this has been particularly good with but two exceptions. Miss Skye has sent several weeks in bed. She has been ill for about two years and but the doctor cannot find out his own ailment although he has had repeated examinations. She developed dysentery. This has been good but we found it necessary to discipline Miss Skye and Miss Martin as they were guilty of several serious breaches of discipline although they were senior girls they were actually younger girls to stand and behave disobediently.

Notes. Miss Macdonald's grandmother died and she came home for a short time.

The children of the wards present pictures of normal life. They make many excursions of various kinds in their daily life.

Patriotic songs.

October 11th. Harvest Festival services were held. We had a special prayer and sang a "Thanksgiving" song.

General Assembly visited the school for a day in order to inspect the general work.

October 25th. Miss Macdonald visited.

The boys and girls were given a lesson on the Royal Navy.

November 2nd. Mr. James visited and made a special inspection of the children.

The Teachers' Convention was on November 4th and 5th. On these two days the boys cleaned up the farm buildings and the girls worked on the lawns and in the flower beds.

November 5th. Miss O'Leary and Mr. Owen visited.

November 9th. Mr. Standing inspected the Class-room work.

November 15th. Mr. Rogers went to Toronto and visited the Royal Navy. On the following day Misses Swarth and Henderson were in Toronto. They attended a show and had to attend Hospital for a day.

November 18th. Mr. and Mrs. Rogers with Pauline visited her sister Gladys at the Hamilton Sanatorium.

On Armistice Day our Girl Guides and the boys were present at the Remembrance Service. At that time we had some lovely Chrysanthemums and two lovely arrays were placed on the memorial.
November 22nd hot water boiler burst and had to be replaced; this was done within twenty-four hours.

November 25th. The contractors commenced re-roofing the Institute.

November 30th. The Principal visited Paris mills to make purchases of socks and scarves.

December 1st. Made repairs to base of large heating boiler.

December 3rd. Mr. and Mrs. Rogers to Toronto wholesale houses to make purchases for Christmas.

Mr. Orr visited on December 9th.

All the indoor staff were given four days holiday at Christmas.

On December 27th, Miss Hardie and Pauline visited Gladys Steats in Hamilton.

December 31st. Discharged Mr. Smith and engaged Mr. Thurlow temporarily.

The boys have new heavy serge uniforms and caps to match. Both boys and girls have received a new issue of winter shoes, underwear and socks or stockings.

The Dining Hall equipment has been partly renewed.

Amusements. October 1st. Twenty-eight of the senior boys went to Oshawa fair by motor truck.

Halloween was celebrated in the usual way and on Thanksgiving Day most of the boys were out.

During the Christmas Shopping season all the pupils visited town and saw the various displays under the supervision of officers.

We held our Christmas concert on 22nd December and the pupils were grateful to those responsible for their training.

Many gifts were received for Christmas from the local stores and friends. Santa Claus arrived in time on the 24th, and everyone had a very happy time. Special meals were prepared for the Christmas dinner. Pretty effects were obtained by using red candy hearts and smiling for the tables. The weather during the following week was ideal and we had good sleighing and skating.

All the children were entertained and the local picture theatre.

Farm and Garden. We were very fortunate in the gathering of our root crops. We had a good crop and were able to store them with a minimum loss. All branches of the work were well ahead when the frosts came and we started this winter with the fall work well done.

On November 8th the boys had a special holiday to acknowledge their very good work in handling the harvest.

We have had to place new benches in the Greenhouses.

Sir,

I have the honour to submit the following report of the activities and progress of this Institute.

Your obedient servant,

Church, citing the fact that Mrs. Green, wife of our school doctor, has been ill for several days, I am obliged to contrast the services of our former doctor, Mr. Smith, who was very efficient in his duties.

Health conditions have been most satisfactory. In examining several cases of sore throat which occurred in December, there have been no serious cases except a few sore throats and colds. The only exception was that of Miss King who stayed in bed for a period without the doctor discovering any cause. The boy Mr. Holman also had a slight cold.

Discipline has been excellent throughout the term. However, the boys have been very restless during the Christmas recess, which reflects badly upon their spirits. No new discipline has been introduced since the position of boys' master on January 1st.

Mr. Thurlow replaced Mr. Smith on January 1st. Mr. Thurlow has been very successful in his dealings with the boys and has managed to maintain discipline. However, I am unable to secure a very good record from him. He has been very attentive to the boys' needs and has been very successful in keeping them busy.

With the mild weather this spring three girls absconded but were promptly returned by their parents. We are glad to re-assign one girl as she had a very bad record and we found that she was a ringleader in many of our troubles.

Staff: Mr. Thurlow replaced Mr. Smith on January 1st. Mr. Thurlow has been very successful in his dealings with the boys and has managed to maintain discipline. However, I am unable to secure a very good record from him. He has been very attentive to the boys' needs and has been very successful in keeping them busy.

With the mild weather this spring three girls absconded but were promptly returned by their parents. We are glad to re-assign one girl as she had a very bad record and we found that she was a ringleader in many of our troubles.

School re-opened January 3rd.

January 12th: Mr. Rogers, Mrs. Smith and several girl chums visited Gladys State at the invitation of Miss Smith.

January 25th: Mr. Rogers, Mrs. Smith and three girls attended funeral of Gladys State. The school wreath was the only floral token.

January 29th: Miss Smith took a large party of girls to the local cinema.

February 10th: Miss Smith, Mrs. Smith and several girl chums visited Gladys State at the invitation of Miss Smith.

March 6th: Mr. Standing inspected the class-rooms.

March 18th: The kitchen stove collapsed but the officers remain...
for that department rose to the emergency and kept the meals on time in a most satisfactory manner.

Farm. All departments of the farm and garden have shown progress although business conditions have been adverse. Owing to the hog market falling we have not had as large returns from that department as we expected, and the fact that the local fruiters are importing rhubarb from California has reduced our income from its production here. Despite these conditions we have increased our supplies and have been able to keep the school very liberally supplied with apples and all kinds of vegetables.

During January all the farm implements were overhauled. In February we harvested our ice and the farm men were used to carry out some of the improvements inside the building. We had a very high flood early in March and as the ground became fit to work upon we commenced grading and levelling the playgrounds.

Improvements. As the floors in three small rooms were in very bad repair we took advantage of a price war in Brantford and secured some flooring and other lumber. For about $17.00 we were able to place hardwood floors in these rooms. The floors were laid by Mr. Rogers. In several parts of the building we made permanent broom cupboards. All the paint work was thoroughly done over and any retouching necessary was done. We placed a marble slab in position in the kitchenette for pastry making.

The laundry machinery was giving trouble so we overhauled it and made several replacements.

We have also sheeted over the boys play-room ceiling.

The small girls have been busy making rag-rugs for bed-rooms and we were able to sell one or two for the benefit of the radio fund.

Church. Owing to the fact that Mrs Owen, wife of our Chaplain was seriously ill at the beginning of the quarter the services were conducted by the Principal. On Good Friday many of the older pupils attended the three hour service at St. Jude's Easter Sunday with Rev. Owen in charge Holy Communion was celebrated. The first service to be held this year in the Mohawk Church was on May 22nd. On this occasion the Thayendanegea Chapter I.O.D.E. placed a wreath on the tomb of Joseph Brant.

The remaining services were conducted by Rev. C. H. P. Owen.

Health. We have had very few cases of sickness. In April there was a slight epidemic of Chicken-pox but this was confined to the girls.

Discipline. On the whole this has been very good but early in the term we had a few cases of truancy as is usual at that time of the year. Two of the pupils who tried their Entrance Examinations have been troublesome during their term at the School so their parents were told that they would have to assume responsibility for them should they be successful.

Notes. April 6th. Mr. and Mrs Eccleston, Miss Hardie and Mr. Rogers to Mrs Owen's funeral.

Mrs Persall returned to duty after an absence of seven weeks during which time she underwent two serious operations.

The Salvation Army Band visited the school and rendered a delightful concert after which the senior boys entertained them to light refreshments.

April 10th. Sir Alfred Stewpot, Dominion Meteorologist visited the School and found much of interest.

April 18th. The weather was very mild and being Easter Monday was spent in fishing and outdoor sports.

Miss Allen and Miss Hooper both had a week's vacation in April.

May 4th. In response to an urgent telegram two boys Montour were allowed to visit their dying father they returned after the funeral and have since tried their Entrance Examination.

May 10th. Miss Hardie fell and badly sprained her ankle. She was very lame for some weeks.

About this time we were able to successfully bid on the uniforms of the Cadet Corps of the Brantford Collegiate and were thus enabled for a very small sum to purchase next winter's clothing for our boys.

May 16th. We had a very serious stoppage of the sewers. After some trouble we discovered some small girls had dropped a book into a toilet.

The pictures of the Confederation period were very much appreciated by the Staff and pupils. They have been put away and are to be framed by the boys next winter.

May 25th. The Remembrance Chapter I.O.D.E. paid their yearly visit and presented prizes.
June 14th. Mr Phelan of Schools Branch arrived to audit accounts.
June 15th. Mr. Orr visited to inspect the barn in bad condition.
14 girls and two boys wrote their Entrance Examination.
On June 29th we held our Closing Exercises and the prizes were distributed. Each pupil received a Confederation Medal on this occasion.
June 30th. School closed leaving 36 girls and 31 boys.

Improvements. As soon as possible the teams were put to work ploughing and regrading both playgrounds. This work was necessary to clear the playgrounds quickly of water after rains and they both present a much more attractive appearance as a result.
The boys' playroom ceiling was sheeted after the old damaged plaster had been removed.
All the plaster throughout the building was repaired and a new ceiling put up in the officers bath-room. Three small rooms were redecorated.
The drying tumbler was installed in the laundry.
Built-in sundry cupboards and linen closets.
The bridge across the Canal became unsafe and had to be almost rebuilt.
Cement steps and approach were laid to cottages near the Church.
The Gardener's Cottage was painted and the verandahs of the school were repainted.

Farm and Garden. Work started on the land fairly early but owing to rains and cold weather the seeding season was unduly long. However, this weather made for very fine hay and wheat crops and these crops are still most promising. Work was kept well in hand in the garden and we shall be amongst the first to place our produce on the market. The plants which were wintered in the new frames were in excellent condition and the potatoes pitted last fall will carry us well through the summer. Hay stored four years ago was baled in order to make a thorough inspection of the cow barn which was found to be in a very unsafe condition.

Grounds. As these are cared for by Mrs Rogers and the girls I feel they should be dealt with under a separate heading. Our grounds are a continual source of comment and congratulations as they have been a blaze of colour since the earliest blooms. The hard work of the last three years is showing to perfection this year.

August 10th. We visited school with regard to new boys.

Farm and Garden. We have had a very busy season on the farm. The abundant hay crop required a tremendous amount of labour on account of the rain spell that occurred just when it was ready to harvest. The grain crops were successfully harvested during the drought which followed the heavy rains but the ground was left extremely hard for ploughing. In fact the ground was too hard for a boy to plough.

In addition to the routine farm work we have had to devote a large part of our staff and labours to moving barns and preparing land before erecting the new Dairy Barn. The potatoes, roots and late crops suffered badly from the late drought but fortunately we withheld from selling a large part of the early potatoes when the price fell. This will help us greatly with our fall short.

Church. The services have been conducted by Rev. C. H. P. Owen and Holy Communion was celebrated monthly. When the principal and Mrs. Rogers were presented His Excellency decided to visit the Old Mohawk Church. Arrangements were quickly made and when the party arrived a number of our girls were on guard as a guard of honour. Our Girl Guides were delighted to present to Lord Killineon a gift from their Canadian Chief.

Mrs. Harry Scott visited the school on November 8th. In company with Mr. and Mrs. ... on December 1st, Mr. and Mrs. Rogers visited Toronto College.

December 1st. Mr. and Mrs. Rogers visited Toronto College.

November 11th. We had our annual Sports Day on October 11th. It was a very full day and the children had a great deal of fun.

On November 7th, the children held a barn dance in the New Barn. The Radio was moved into the barn and five loud speakers were attached. As reception was particularly good the children were well provided with music.
Our electrician kindly loaned us two or three hundred feet of wire with coloured globes attached and the barn was a very gay affair. A large number of neighbours came in and all helped to make the evening a riot of pleasure for the children.

Thanksgiving Day was bright and cold and nineteen of the boys were granted leave for the day. Most of them visited the scene of the local militia manoeuvres. The fact that the Principal was commanding the local artillery Brigade added quite a deal to their interest.

On December 23rd, the Trinity Church Choir presented a delightful concert after which the Principal attired as Santa Claus officiated at the Christmas Tree. Owing to the fact that kind friends had sent sufficient gifts all the smaller and poorer children awoke on Christmas morning to find that Santa Claus had visited their homes. The Grand Theatre very kindly entertained the whole school on the 24th, to a showing of "Pinocchio."

On December 25th, the Dining Room was very handsomely decorated and the dinner was quite a function for the staff had arranged the table with new runners, coloured candy baskets, fruit and so on.

The usual Christmas Dinner was served on Monday. During the first half of the holiday the pupils had much fun here with their sleighing but unfortunately I knew some of them had to resort to their own indoor amusements.

By and by, owing to delightful weather in October we were able to complete the harvest work to get all the work well in hand. Many of the girls were out daily gathering leaves and putting them into beds for winter. Our tomato plants are very poor this year and our apple crop is not as large as usual.

We built a new supply shed to the barns and have linked up all outside pipes to this supply. The new barn is occupied and work has been commenced on making the dormitories there.

The Charles Reid Co., who have very fine premises, have a large lot of old lumber which they are willing to sell us. We have completed installing cement sheds in place of the rotten woodwork between the two parts of our greenhouse. Improvements. At a very small cost we have built a workroom in the attic which is most useful since all minor repairs can be effected there and hobby instruction can be given.

Mohawk Institute

While not a civic institution, one which is closely linked with Brantford and which, in point of history, extends to the earliest days of this city named after the famous Six Nations chief, the Mohawk Indian Institute, founded in 1831 by the New England Company, London, England, is one which meets the specific needs of the Six Nations Indians. It is a boarding school for children from the nearby Tuscarora reserve and is located on 300 acres of excellent land. This enables the carrying out of the dual instruction system based on theoretical and practical work in the school room and practical work on the farm itself, for the boys, and domestic life for the girls.

For many years the head of the institution and the rector of His Majesty's

Mohawk Institute—(Inset) Major Sidney Rogers, Principal.

Chapel Royal of the Mohawks (familiarly known as Mohawk church), was Rev Robert Ashton, who was succeeded by Major A. Nelles Ashton, and he by Rev C. M. Turnell. The present heads are Major and Mrs. Sidney Rodgers. The choir of Mohawk church, it should be noted, is formed from the pupils of the Mohawk Institute, who this term numbered 125.

The pupils were transferred to the Lady Willingdon Hospital where they are still patients. It was noted that the hospital was in need of help as there was an unexpectedly rush of patients and so we left Marjorie Hill, who has passed the Entrance and is taking special training.
April 14th, 1928.

Dear Sir:

"Visit of Directors, New England Company to Brantford".

I understand that the Directors of the New England propose to visit Brantford on or about the 24th of May.

I have received a visit from the Rev. Mr. White, one of the Missionaries on the Reserve, who tells me that a meeting was held last night on the Reserve of the Anglican Indians who desire to interview the Directors when they are here to lay certain matters before them in connection with the Churches upon the Reserve.

Mr. White tells me there is an impression that the Directors may stay at the Mohawk Institute and merely drive through the Reserve without giving the Indians an opportunity to see them, and as I have no knowledge as to the actual date that these Gentlemen are expected or where they may be staying.
I would ask you to ask them when they visit Ottawa to make an appointment for a deputation of Indians to meet through the medium of the Rev. Mr. White at Sour Springs on the reserve.

Your obedient servant,

Lt. Col. C. E. Morgan,
Supt. Six Nations.

Sir,

I have the honour to submit the following report of the activities of this Institute.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Church. During the early part of the quarter the services were conducted at the Institute and it was not until May 20th that we were able to attend the Mohawk Church, at which service there were a number of Baptisms. On May 27th His Grace the Archbishop of Huron conducted a Confirmation Service, the candidates having previously been prepared by Rev. C. H. P. Owen. The Church was very prettily decorated for this occasion.

Discipline. This has been quite up to standard during the quarter.

Health. The health of the pupils has been exceptionally good. There have been, however, a number of spring colds which have been difficult to control.

Staff. Mr. Thurlow left April 2nd, and Mr. Raynor, a returned man who has spent some years in Hospital, was engaged in his place. The officers gave Mr. Thurlow a very good send off from Hamilton.

On April 29th, Mrs Hamilton, junior housekeeper, was taken seriously ill and it was necessary to send her to hospital. She was unable to return and Miss Smith who was engaged in her place collapsed at the end of a week. Mrs Harrington was engaged on May 5th, and is proving quite satisfactory.

Clothing. The usual changes in clothing for this season were carried out. The boys receiving new overalls and the girls made themselves new issues of aprons.

Notes. On April 4th, the kitchen stove collapsed. We had had considerable trouble and expense with this stove for some time and the quickest replacement was by gas. We have had great satisfaction since replacement and are able to cook all meals for fifty eight cents per diem.

April 5th. Major and Mrs Rogers went to Toronto making purchases.

April 26th. A Class from Wesley Church Sunday school gave the pupils a very interesting evening in the Dining Hall.

May 6th. We had two pupils who had been inmates of Hamilton Sanitarium and as we had to go to Hamilton on business we took them to visit there.

May 17th. All pupils were taken to witness circus procession and a number of pupils went to the afternoon performance.

Pupils had holiday after service on Good Friday and Easter Monday. The boys were all busy fishing and made some fine catches. Good Friday was exceptionally hot and a large number of the senior girls attended the three hour service held at St. Giles.

May 24th was a holiday for the pupils and some of the staff. At 9.30 a.m. Karl Doellittle broke his finger whilst playing. This had to be X-rayed.
and was very difficult case to set. Daily visits to the Doctor were necessary but the finger is now healed and doing well.

In the spring of the same year, Bishop and Mrs. Chubb arrived and stayed several days, making a very thorough inspection.

May 25th. The Archbishop of Huron arrived for Confirmations the following day on the Reserve and here.

Activities. On April 10th the girls were able to uncover flower beds and generally clean them up. The following day the storm windows were removed and cleaning commenced. During April the girls made a number of rag rugs.

May 4th, the lawn water service was connected.

The City of Brantford have been relaying a number of sidewalks and have put broken sidewalks in their place. These have been laid across factories from the school to the shops to make better going during the muddy weather and to avoid the lawns being ruined. This has also made a great improvement in appearances.

Notes continued. May 28th. Rev. H. Lee visited. Members Chubb, Bush, Lee and Rogers attended a meeting at Kanawagah organized by Rev. White.

June 3rd. Mr. Davis visited. We were also visited by the United Church and Commercial Travellers Annual Conventions. These visitors were most interested and inspected the whole school in addition to seeing the Bible, Plate and Church.

June End. The Queen Anne Silver was used for Communion in the Church and kept out for the visit the following day of the Canadian Historical Society to see.

June 6th. Rev. Owen left for England and the services have since been conducted by a student.

June 15th. Mrs Stanley of the Stoney Mission and School spent the afternoon here.

June 19th. Pupils attended the Brantford Industrial Exhibit, as guests of the local Board of Trade.

June 20th. The Elected Six Nations Council visited in a body and had a most interesting time.

Farm and Garden. The work was commenced late this year owing to weather conditions and the sale of garden produce was very slow owing to late frosts and wet weather. However, as we had ploughed every available piece of land last fall we were able to get our crops in in better time than the average farmer of the district, and prospects are quite good. We are growing five acres of tomatoes this year as a cash crop for sale to the Canning factory newly opened in Brantford.

We took the gardener and some boys to plant up the flower beds at the Lady Willingdon Hospital.

14th. July 1928.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Last week, I received a letter from the New England Company in which they stated that they have been allocating £100 a year for the services of a Chaplain at the Mohawk Institute and Mohawk Chapel. I was not aware that they did it. The present Chaplain for his services receives only $5.00 per Sunday and not £100 a year. I have written to Mr. Rogers, the Principal of the Mohawk Institute, and he states that the Chaplain has been paid out of the School funds at the rate of $5.00 per Sunday. Can you tell me who has the remainder of the £100 allocated by the New England Company? I think that £100 should go to the Chaplain as intended by the Company. It is the intention of the Company to have the Chaplain do certain work both in the School and in the Church, for which they set aside £100. If the Chaplain does his work properly the £100 will not be too liberal a remuneration.

I would be very much obliged if you would let me know if the £100 is paid to the Department, and if so what becomes of the balance after paying $5.00 per service for the Chaplain.

Believe me Yours faithfully,

D.H./B.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 13th instant, addressed to the Governor of the Company, I do not think that the word "allocated" was used by us in our letter to the Archbishop. Actually no portion of the Company's grant of £1000 is or can properly be allocated by the Company for any particular purpose. But when we were staying at Brantford Mr Chubb and I understood from Mrs Rogers that £100 was the stipend allowed to the chaplain who takes the services for the Mohawk Institute. We may have misunderstood her, but that was the figure that we reported to the Court, and it was a fair presumption, that as one of the stipulations contained in the Lease of the Institute to the Department concerns the religious training of the pupils in the doctrine and teaching of the Church of England, payment for such instruction would be considered part of the annual grant made by the Company.

You may rest assured that the Company has no wish to restrict the Department in any matter concerning the details of management of the Institute.

I am, dear Sir,

Yours very truly,

Dear Archbishop Williams,

Upon receipt of Your Grace's letter of August 16th, last, with reference to the stipend for the chaplain at the Mohawk Institute and the Mohawk Chapel, the Department made enquiries, and I have now to inform you that there is no special grant from the New England Company for this purpose. Payment for religious instruction is considered part of the annual grant of £1,000, which is made to the Department by the Company. I presume that Mr. Rogers, the Principal, has made what he considers a fair arrangement with the chaplain.
