Sir,

I have the honour to submit the following report on the activities of this Institute.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Church. July 1st. Dominion Day services were held at the School and during the holidays services were discontinued at the Mohawk Church and the pupils allowed to visit the local Churches. Rev. Owen who had been away in England reopened the School term with service at the Mohawk Church on August 25th.

Staff. Mr. F. Hughes who has been with us as cattleman for some years left to manage a farm near Oakville and Mr. Howard was engaged to fill the vacancy.

Owing to the small number of boys remaining here for the holidays and the pressure of work it was necessary to engage Mr. Lindsay as extra help.

Mr. Raynor was ill for several days.

Miss Hardie and Miss Hooper were both away for six weeks and R. Howart had one weeks holiday.

Discipline. On the whole this has been very satisfactory. This is due in part to the fact that the parents and friends of the pupils are showing a much more friendly attitude towards the school. We find much more co-operation now than we had before.

Holidays. School closed on July 14th. for six weeks and we had only forty pupils remain. Most of these were small and it was necessary to hire some of the bigger boys in order to maintain the farm work. All pupils remaining were able to have an enjoyable holiday. It was necessary for all to work part of the time but this work was interspersed with visits to the Cinema, to the Park and the River. While at other times they were given truck rides and minor treats.

School opened in a most disappointing fashion. Had all returned who were expected and the new pupils reported promptly we should have had a full school, but this year there seemed to be a shortage of money amongst the Indians and only those who were near at hand were able to send the children in at the proper time. Several pupils were in the States, five asked for sick leave and others were kept in the berry fields until such time as sufficient money could be earned to pay the return fares.

Major Rocker went with his battery to Pettawawa Camp for Annual Firing practice on August 26th. July.

Mr. Sisson called August 2nd. and the matter of arranging the graves of the Johnson family was discussed.

On August 27th. the Principal and Mrs. Persall took a party of pupils who had behaved so splendidly during the holidays to Niagara Falls. This was a most pleasant and instructive day and in addition to the natural sights arrangements were made for the whole party to be shown over the big Chippawa Hydro plant. Lunch was served in Victoria Park and although we had a very strenuous day we all returned home.
August 29th. Mrs Rogers took four girls to the Lady Willington Hospital for examination.

September 4th. Three boys started the Fall term at the Collegiate and we were able to find homes for several girls who had passed the Entrance Examination. In the case of the girls we find it much more satisfactory to place them in homes where they may earn a little pocket money than to keep them here and allow them to attend the Collegiate. They have to leave the School early and cannot possibly return before 4:30 or 5:00 p.m., and we find better results are obtained when a girl is so placed that she has to spend her noon hours occupied.

On September 7th. Major and Mrs Rogers left for a holiday during which eight schools were visited.

On September 27th. and 28th. the school for the first time placed some work on exhibit at the Chewaten Fair. Our boys were very proud of the results and we were glad to notice the good effect on the school morale. The classroom exhibits were also of a very fine quality.

On September 28th. Isobel Hill was taken to Hamilton to appear in Court in connection with an assault committed against her during the holidays and whilst in her Mother's care. We lent every assistance in the prosecution of this case and a conviction was secured. It was a matter of satisfaction to us to find the girl's mother so willing to take action in this case as unfortunately the Indian mother is inclined to be callous on the question of the daughter's morals.

September 29th. Mr MacKenzie, Colonel and Mr. Fairchild visited. The Newport Women's Institute visited the school and were entertained to tea. This organisation has been very actively interested in some neglected Indian Children in the school.

Clothing. The girls have been issued with smart new caps of blue, piped with black, with the school badge.

Improvements. During the holidays we completed the painting of the school-rooms and the sewing rooms. These rooms and the small corridors were also Calcomined. These rooms now present a very fine appearance. The flower beds were very attractive this year and have called for very complimentary remarks from nearly every visitor. This work is done by the girls under the supervision of Mrs Rogers.

Farm and Garden. We have a very trying season but have had good results. Owing to the wet spring crops were tremendously heavy to handle and the grain looked badly. It was necessary to purchase a new binder in order to harvest the grain which we managed to harvest in good condition. We have not completely threshed yet but very satisfactory yields are expected. The garden crops were good although delayed by the wet weather and we had a good yield of tomatoes which were grown for the Canning Factory.

Sir,

I have the honour to submit the following report on the activities of this Institute.

Your obedient servant,

Church. During the quarter the usual religious training was carried out. Rev. C. H. F. Owen was in charge of the weekly services. We held our Harvest Home on the 1st October and have held no services in the Church since October 14th. On October 31st, the pupils attended the Children's Special Service at Trinity Church. Holy Communion was celebrated monthly.

Discipline. There have been no serious breaches of discipline during the quarter and the fact that our boys have attained some prominence and distinction locally as runners has had a very marked effect upon the boys' general attitude. The girls worked some very nice badges for the boys running suits and every boy running under the school colours is very proud of the ovation the crowd always gives them. Naturally, this has a most desirable effect in fostering school pride.

Health. Although Brantford has had several bad epidemics we have escaped with only minor sickness. Several of the staff, however, have been sick.

Staff. There have been no changes in the staff. Mrs Perall and Miss Allen have had holidays.

Clothing. The usual seasonable changes have been made and new shoes issued.

Notes. We received a report from the mother of Isobel Hill, a pupil that she had been assaulted during the summer holidays and had her medically examined. The mother prosecuted and the man was sentenced by the Hamilton Court.

October 1st. Mr. MacKenzie visited.

October 2nd. Two pupils were taken to Chawaken Hospital and were operated upon for abscesses and tonsils. Several others who had slight symptoms for concern were examined and treatments given.

On October 4th, the Church was decorated by the girls for the Harvest Thanksgiving service.

During the quarter we had many visitors, including English teachers, here on Exchange; School inspectors from South Africa and New Zealand; the Church Army workers; the Principal from Alert Bay; Clergyman from Hamilton; the Stratford on Avon Festival Company; and the Public School teachers from St. Catherine's.

October 19th. Major and Mrs Rogers visited Toronto to purchase supplies.

The School Inspector was here October 25th.
October 20th. The fire alarm system was overhauled.

November 1st. All Hallows Eve was celebrated by the pupils with the usual pranks and fun.

His Excellency the Governor General visited officially on November 3rd, and he pronounced the following Monday to be a school holiday.

November 6th. Mr. Phelan visited and conducted an audit.

November 9th and 10th. The local teachers held convention; on those two days they threaded.

November 11th. A Community Service was held at the Centotaph. This was attended by all the Militia Units and every organisation in Brantford. Our pupils were also present and made a very creditable appearance.

November 23rd. The Douglas Seed Company presented the school with a large quantity of imported bulbs which Mrs. Rossiter and the girls were able to plant in time for Spring flowering.

December 7th. All hands were busy unloading a car of coal.

December 8th. This was a notable day for the boys. The local newspaper sponsored a Road Race for Indians and there were five prizes. Present pupils secured three of these and a boy who has recently left school won another. This race run over a seven half mile course against fifty-two competitors, of which only 27 finished. Of our thirteen entries there were none who did not finish.

Since the Race, the proprietor has presented each entrant with a medal as an appreciation of their efforts.

December 12th. The boiler was removed from the water heater.

December 14th. An Electric service switch-box was found to be out of order and immediately repaired.

December 16th. Mr. Raynor's mother died.

December 21st. The children began to decorate for Christmas.

On the 22nd, we had very few relatives visit owing to the bad condition of the roads. All the pupils were taken to town at least once before Christmas.

Santa Claus arrived as usual and every child had a gift.

On Christmas Day a special service was conducted by the Principal and a most happy day followed. The Dining Hall was very gay and a special feast was prepared for every meal. In the evening we had a huge masquerade party and there were many weird costumes improvised.

The pupils were guests of Mr. Ernie Moul of the local theatre during Christmas week.

Owing to the kindness of several merchants and friends we were well supplied with fruit and candles.

All the teachers had four days holiday arranged to include either Christmas or New Year's Day and most of them have been off duty since with the prevalent influenza.

Farm and Garden.

We had very fine crops this year and harvested every one in good condition. The only failure was with the apple crop which was practically nil. We sold our wheat immediately.

Every portion of ground that it was possible to plough was ploughed and the whole farm is well prepared for next year.

Improvements. A brick out-building was converted into a forge. The forge had previously been housed in an old wooden building and the fire hazard was too great. Some disused pavement was given us and laid as a side walk to the green-house.

The Gardener's cottage kitchen was put on a cement foundation and the walls lined to prevent freezing. A long wanted rail was placed on the front steps to be of assistance in wintry weather.

Paroch. All the services were conducted at the school except in February when the pupils attended Trinity Church for the morning service and those confirmed attended St. Jude's Church in the afternoon. In which service Archbishop David Williams preached. Rev. G. H. P. Owen conducted the musical service on Good Friday and Holy Communion was celebrated on Easter Sunday.

As we restricted visiting the pupils, fortunately, were not exposed and we had very few cases amongst them. Marie Hill suffered from a bad abscess which required medical attention. Marjorie Hill was badly attacked by the Collegeate and midwife position in town broke her wrist. We have had her in residence but arranged for her to enter services during the Easter Holidays.

Eva Liokas, a diabetic case, complained of a cold and was ordered to bed on January 24th. She was found in a state of coma the following day and treatment was administered pending the arrival of the Doctor. On his instructions she was removed to the hospital and died there.

Four pupils attended the dentist and two received treatment from an acupuncturist.

Staff. Miss Harrington did not recover from the attack of "flu" and resigned. Her post was filled by Miss Gilmore. Mr. John Hetherington joined as an active member of the staff at the beginning of the quarter. Mr. R. Howarth resigned in order to take a course in field engineering.

Notes. Owing to fouling we pumped the soft water cistern and discovered we had been using water from a cistern of which there was no record. All necessary safety precautions were taken.

All plaster in the building was repaired and the upper girls dormitory was whitewashed. The floors were renovated and all woodwork and beds painted. The boys dormitory was completely painted and the beds put into good order whilst the girls lower dormitory was toned up where necessary.

The Laundry machine broke down and was overhauled by the staff. A new switch box was installed.

The Principal, Miss Hardie and Mr. R. Howarth attend...
attended Eva Lickers funeral. Ten pupils were in attendance as pall bearers.

February 20th, Mr. Schuyler who inspected the school farm when Mrs. Rogers returned here in 1915 called on business. He was very much impressed with the improvements in all departments connected with the farm.

March 4th, Mr. Truefitt, private secretary to Lord Rothmere and business manager of the Continental Edition of the Daily Mail visited the school and was most interested.

Mr. Standing, County public school inspector, spent a day in the class-rooms.

March 19th, a visitor sketched the Royal Coat of Arms in the Mohawk Church.

A new organ was bought for the services out of contributions received for displaying the Queen Anne bible and silver.

Amusements. January 1st, Miles Isaacs ran sixth in a ten mile road race against the pick of Ontario. March 20th, the 91st Highlanders of Hamilton staged an indoor track meet and for our special benefit a race for Indian boys was run. Miles again led his school chums and was only a few seconds longer in covering the two miles than Pavlo Nurni. We secured every prize offered in this meet.

March 29th, The principal and two of the staff took Miles and Norman Lickers to Toronto where Miles ran second in a six miles race and Norman secured the first junior in a three mile run.

On February 8th, the pupils were the guests of the Kiwanis Club at a matinee performance.

Our senior girls have joined the Lady Willingdon Hospital Auxiliary and devote an evening once bi-weekly to making necessaries for the hospital. They entered a competition sponsored by the W.C.T.U. and we secured several good prizes.

Farm and Garden.

We have hauled all the coal off cars this year.

A sanitary house has been built for storing the milk pails and separator.

A slide was built for the girls.

Ice was harvested on February 15th.

All possible work has been done and much manure hauled to fields in preparation for the spring work.

All roads have been graded.

Wagons and implements have been painted and gate posts have been built for the school entrance.

Dear Dr. Scott,

As directed by you, I visited the Mohawk Institute at Brantford on the 20th and 21st instant.

Immediately upon my arrival at the school, I interviewed Mr. Rogers with a view to eliciting information regarding the reports that had reached the Department in connection with (a) purchase of farm by Principal and (b) rumours regarding Principal's intemperance.

(a) Purchase of Farm by Principal.

Mr. Rogers informed me that, about six weeks ago, he purchased a farm adjoining the Mohawk Institute farm. There are eighty-eight (88) acres of land with a good house and barn. He has already purchased eleven (11) saddle horses and it is his intention to conduct a riding school - as a matter of fact, he has already started and several residents of Brantford have arranged with him to receive riding instruction regularly. On the second day of my visit, (May 21st), he hired a man to conduct the riding school.

About fifty (50) acres of this farm is being cultivated - the seed for this, Mr. Rogers states, has been supplied by himself while the labour from the school (both employees and pupils), as well as school farm machinery and tools, has been used. Mr. Rogers further stated that it was his intention to allow the school one half the proceeds of the crop raised on the acreage cultivated on his farm. He appeared to be of the opinion that this was a profitable arrangement for the school.

From a departmental point of view, I believe that the ownership and the cultivation of the Principal's farm in the manner stated presents very serious difficulty - (1) Principal not devoting his whole time to supervision of school; (2) use of school equipment and school labour especially the Indian boys, on land owned by the Principal is likely to cause unfavourable criticism and (3) possible profits very problematical. I pointed out this attitude to Mr. Rogers and, while he agreed with me that the proposition is open to the objections just stated, he still seemed convinced that the financial benefit accruing to the school would offset the disadvantages of the scheme.
We discussed the whole matter for some time and visited the farm and I informed Mr. Rogers that the matter would be placed before you for your decision.

(b) Rumours regarding Principal's intemperance.

Mr. Rogers stated quite candidly that he had been arrested on May 3rd on a charge of being under the influence of liquor while in charge of a car. The case has not yet come to trial owing to the absence of Mr. Rogers' doctor, but Mr. Rogers was very emphatic in assuring me that there was no doubt about his innocence. His explanation of the incident is that he had been under the influence for some time and was troubled with insomnia. On the day in question, he had been around the country with two friends in connection with the purchase of horses for his farm. At about three o'clock in the afternoon, they reached a certain farm where the horses had got out of hand. Mr. Rogers, presumably to look at horses, Mr. Rogers remained in the car and says he fell asleep. The County Constable came along and arrested him and Mr. Rogers claims that personal animosity on the part of the Constable prompted this action. He was taken to the police station but was allowed out within two hours.

The Indian Superintendent, Colonel Morgan, appears convinced that Mr. Rogers is frequently using liquor to excess and, as consequence, is not a proper person to be in charge of the school. Colonel Morgan's request I had a short talk with (1) Rev. Mr. Owens, (2) County Constable Blakeley and (3) Chief of Police of Brantford. Mr. Owens is the Anglican clergyman who attends the Mohawk Institute and he was of the same opinion as Colonel Morgan. The County Constable claimed that Mr. Rogers was drinking to excess. I must say that I am not very favourably impressed with this man. The Chief of Police stated that, while he had never seen Mr. Rogers under the influence of liquor nor had any charge been previously laid against him, still many rumours had reached him and he felt that Mr. Rogers was not altogether the proper person for the position of Principal of the Mohawk Institute. I had a confidential talk with the Librarian of the Bank of Montreal, where the school account is kept, and he had not heard any serious reports regarding Mr. Rogers' drinking and was unaware of the fact that he had been arrested on May 3rd. I did not inform Mr. Rogers of the above interview.

Sir—

I have before me the report of the officer whom I sent to investigate certain matters pertaining to your conduct as Principal of the Mohawk Institute.

In this report it is stated that some six weeks ago you purchased a farm of 38 acres adjoining the Institute farm, and further that you have undertaken the establishment of a riding school. I need hardly say that these activities are quite incompatible with your status as a full time employee of the department as the responsible head and principal of one of our most important Indian Residential schools.

You did not think it necessary to advise me of your intention to engage in other employment so that I feel quite free to make arrangements for the future conduct of the Mohawk Institute, as the duties and responsibilities of the position which you occupy require the entire attention of the incumbent.

I note, moreover, that you have been using school equipment and school labour on your own farm land and that you actually utilized the services of employees and Indian pupils for this purpose. I must ask you to let me have a statement of these transactions showing the time spent and the value of the labour at a reasonable rate of wage in order that you may make compensation. You must cease immediately the employment of any equipment or manual labour from the Institute.

I have to advise you that it will be necessary to arrange for the appointment of a new Principal and Assistant Principal at an early date.

Yours very truly,

Dear Archbishop Williams,

I find that it will be necessary to appoint a new principal and matron for the Mohawk Institute at Brantford and I would take it as a favour if you would give the matter consideration.

As you are no doubt aware the present principal and matron are husband and wife and I would be inclined to continue such an arrangement if persons well qualified could be selected. I think it is essential that the incumbent should be a good business man with knowledge of farming and stock-raising. It might be advisable to select someone in Holy Orders. It is our understanding with the New England Company that the pupils of the institution shall be trained in the teachings and doctrines of the Church of England.

The salaries of the present incumbents are $1,400.00 and $600.00 respectively, with residence and maintenance. I am desirous of carrying out this change as soon as possible and I know that I can expect valuable advice from Your Grace.

Yours faithfully,

May 29th 1929

Dear Dr. Scott,

We received your letter today with deep regret. Mr. Rogers has put his personal interest at risk to save the school, and I have done two persons' work for years.

I regret very much the attitude you have taken - with me the Mohawk always comes first and I have put in many years of untiring labor and thought to build up the school. As it is I can be proud to hand it over to a new staff. Don't think I want to take all the credit, but I must take all the blame.

Buying the farm was not premeditated - several English families have settled in the neighborhood - and we were looking for a location for another friend to start their own and it looked to me to be an opportunity to mine. One reason the Mohawk farm does not pay is that there is no land surplus. After my purchase in April, the flood covered the property for some weeks. A good deal of the farm is in fall wheat and hay - the Rockwood Plow Company's wheeling nephew is sales manager - plowed by tractor the greater part of the remaining land. The middle of May...
The school ploughed, tenanted and sowed oats. The school has not touched the fencing. The foreman has kept strict account of all labor - the school to have half the crop which is more than the usual rate. Fall report of actions taken will be in the next quarterly return.

When General Asheton was here last we told him our plan and asked him to take the initiative over with you - he thought it might do much with your approval - John's death I'm sure made him forget our little plan.

We have also moved the old people to the farm - and a man is managing the care and setting out of the ponies and horses. It is possible a limited stock company will be formed to manage the herd when it is built.

When we first bought the farm Mr. Rogers thought I should be in his occupation at once - but I thought as the properties adjoin we would be more in the place than usual - we will not be taking afternoons away on any holidays. Our trip west last fall gave
As many pointers as to the management of other schools—we do not think the Red Indian took second place to any of the sights we visited. In fact we do more in the way of painting woodwork, and beds and keeping furniture repaired than any school we saw.

I'm sure the Palace found the school and grounds in good order—the stables and yard have been better the pupils' health good and everything running smoothly.

I am sorry I did not write you earlier, but Mr. Rogers' ladies office work and letter writing—and I'm only under how to explain our views partly as I'm sure he will not—I would have liked to remain here a few years longer—yes, I lost most of my money during the war—and we could have gradually altered stables—put in electric lights—firewood, plumbing etc., that the house requires—but please be assured that while Sir. we will carry on—and do our best to help our successor—

Yours very sincerely,

Ann Rogers

Report of the Quarter Ended June 30, 1829

Church:
Rev. Owen took the services until April 14th when he had to go to the hospital for some weeks—neighboring clergy took the services. May 26th we were able to attend service at the church for the first time this year. The organ was unusable. The girls wore their new blue cloth uniforms and caps and looked very smart.

Mr. Owen was able to take service June 9th, and administered Holy Communion in the 30th ward.

Discipline:
Very little trouble. Tom Logg absconded twice—brought back each time by the Mounted Police. Two girls also ran away—the third in years—were rounded up the same day in Hamilton and returned to the institute.

Health:
Good—several minor accidents—and seven eye cases.

Staff:
Mrs. Robert Hawthorne left April 15th and Mr. Alexander engaged—Mr. Howard left April 30th and Mr. Hopkins formerly
on the staff was engaged—living in the shop.

June 8th—Miss Selwyn sick

10th—Mrs. Terrall sick—very ill for several days—doctor sometimes coming twice a day. Allowed up but not to work on June 24th.

Miss Allen's day holiday—a back debt.

Notes—

April 1st—Easter Monday—holiday—very windy and floods were high. Fortunately we had plenty of magazines and games.

April 5th—flood very high.

6th—... at six o'clock—had to throw reserve hay into cows—horses and chickens.

April 6th—Artist and wood carver—interested in Inuit Art. Cook & Arrows—had to go to the church by boat.

April 9th—Mrs. Murray Smith gave children an interesting lecture on bird growing.

April 14th—Sea, Aviation and Flying visited in their way home from Idleworth.

May 2nd—Dr. Palmer vaccinated 80.

May 3rd—Doctor finished vaccinating 108 in all of which 99 successfully took; the others showed old marks—but no reaction.
May 17th - Inspection of Burnished Police medals.

May 20th - Mr. Thielman arrived - brought new piano and books and left next day.

May 24th - Holiday.

During May we had all the pianos and organs overhauled - the church organ examined, and sent an organ to the church.

May 30th - Board of Trade bought a large card of American tickets.

June 3rd - School division had holidays.

June 6th - Sent truck full plants and furniture to Okanagan hospital.

June 8th - Commenced erection of large ornamental posts at front entrance - took several days to erect and paint. They were made during the winter.

During May and June made repairs to cottages near the Church - repaired roof and ridge board. Had cottages painted - purchased and painted.

The Ladies' congregation Chaplet had a picnic at Fairview Park - twenty-five girls and two teachers attended taking sandwiches.

June 11th - New bus and bus driver brought over school, is taking over the management.

June 12th - Inspection of Toronto Public Schools was most interested visited every department.
June 23rd - Mr. Bunnell and Mr. Scott brought important mail from Australia and England.

June 24th - pupils were able to wear summer uniforms which had all been refitted.

School Activities -

- Locating and storing away winter clothing - blankets etc.
- Washing summer clothes
- Altering and making summer uniforms

Girls had new shoes & hats from England - two coats, 1 new apron, 1 new underwear, and new school shoes. Boys have work shoes - two pairs of slippers, veranda and belts.

June 27th - Mr. Rogers' house burned - boys helped父亲 find it out only brick walls & solo remaining - slower clock and manure pile burned in days.

June 27th - Mr. Bunnell left - his luggage taken around - work unloading & original clothing - slippers etc.

A picnic was given by the Council at Oshawa in honor of Miss Hardy and we sent twenty packages by truck and received the Rogers' kindness. Miss Hardy was presented with a silver watch - also we gave the park refreshments and a chair. The pupils enjoyed the day - playing ball games and horse racing. They were well treated.
to sandwiches, cake and lemonade.

The Ontario Historical Society visited June 2nd. Mr. Maclean left June 29th—having taken inventory & farm buildings—stock implements and greenhouse.

Farm & Garden—

April 2nd—Such a horrid—gone lame and blind.

It's been a hard season—flood prevented work on school farm—then drought—but were able to seed oats across the canal on April 25th.

Early in April Mr. Rogers bought a farm 7 & 8 acres adjoining the school intending to farm in half shares with the school. There was little ploughing to do and most of that was done by the Cockshutt Plow Co. The school ploughed about six acres—did some harvesting and seeding. MR. FERRIER.

To the Governor and Gentlemen,
New England Co.

Dear Sirs:

We are severing - with regret - our connections with the Mohawk Institute, at the end of July.

May I beg to be placed on your pensions list. For many years I helped my parents with the management - care of the sick - class rook work etc., without any salary. Then I took charge for one year when my brother had leave of absence.

During the war I lost most of my money in a railroad investment - so was glad to return to the school in 1918 as I could continue the care of my parents. I could have commanded a much larger salary in a hospital but that would have taken me away from Brantford. The school was in such a neglected condition that for four years it was work under a dreadful strain. Now I am proud to say we can hand the school over in as perfect condition as our funds would allow - a competent and contented staff - and healthy and happy children.

The school grounds and flower beds have never looked better. The Government Inspector who in 1918 said it would take at least ten years to build the farm up was here the other day and said he did not think we could have attained so much - he was sure there were not horses or cattle better cared for anywhere - and was full of praises for conditions all over the place.

Hoping that you can grant my request -

Trustfully yours,

(Signed) ALICE M. ROGERS.

In going over the building, I found that there is a considerable amount of old desks, etc., stored in the attic. I feel that the new Principal should be instructed to clean out the attic and destroy any articles that would not likely be of further use.

You will note that the fire equipment does not appear adequate.

I noticed that there was considerable mustard in the large field near the road. I was informed that it is practically impossible to keep mustard out of this field as the field is generally flooded every spring. I feel, however, that a determined effort should be made to eradicate this weed and it might be well to direct the new Principal's attention to the matter.

Before the new Principal takes charge, the Bank of Montreal requires (a) authority for Rev. Mr. Snell to sign cheques against the school account and (b) a new letter of authority with reference to the amount of overdraft to be allowed.

Dear Dr. Scott,

Your letter to me of the 24th June was placed before a Court of the Company today.

The Court greatly regrets to learn of the motion which Mr. Rogers has taken and feels that you had no course open to you but to call for his resignation. Incidentally, the Court are of opinion that it is in the best interest of the School and the objects of the Company that the Principal should be in Holy Orders.

It is a great satisfaction to the Court to realise that under the lease granted to your Department you are enabled to take prompt action without the delay of reference to the Court. And I was authorized to suggest to you that a sale of the Mohawk Institute to your Department on the same basis as that of the Lytton Institute would be a further simplification of our common responsibilities. I should be glad if you could, at your convenience, let us hear your views on this suggestion which was brought up in conversation between you and the representatives of the Company when they met you a year ago.

Mrs. Rogers has written a letter of which I enclose a copy. The Court could not entertain any grant of a pension. But as she was in the first instance a servant of the Company it might be prepared to make her a small grant - if you approved.

With kind regards,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Mathews:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, with reference to the Mohawk Institute. I am very pleased that the Court concurs in the action that has been taken. I am very hopeful that the Reverend Mr. Snell will make a good principal. The Superintendent of Indian Education is proceeding to Brantford today, to install him in his new position.

Boys' Master, H.E. Jones. The engaging of a man who is a mechanic who can also assist on the farm and act as Boys' Master has abundantly justified itself in the saving of expensive visits of mechanics from the city. He has more than saved his salary for us in this way. As I had to give Mr Hughes a Month's notice, we had 8 women & 5 men on the staff during September. The Senior & Junior Housekeepers are both graduates in Dietetics with practical experience.

NOTES:
A great many visitors have called to see the Institute and Queen Anne Plate, among them was Dr. Guiness who spoke very appreciatively of the School and its work.

The children, 20 in number, who got no holidays were taken to Sprinbank Park for a holiday. They were specially interested in Zoo. The picnic was in the nature of a reward for good behaviour and compensation for the loss of holiday.

A great deal of cleaning and painting has been done so that the building presents a very spick-and-span appearance inside.

A change in the diet from skimmed milk to whole was much appreciated by the pupils and should be good for their physical development.

A number of our boys competed in the races at Cheweken Fair. Norman Lickers ran first in the five-mile race with Harry Lickers third. Jesse Cayusa came first in the five-mile bicycle race. A four-year-old colt from the farm prepared and exhibited by Harry Lickers was awarded second prize in the general purpose class.

Four prizes were awarded to garden stuff from here exhibited at the school fair. The whole school were guests at the Ohs. Fair.

We have 6 boys and 1 girl attending Collegiate from here. One other girl, Helen Miller, was removed by her parents after spending 16 days. They brought an order from Col. Morgan for her release. I was rather pleased as her removal made room for a needy case.

FARM AND GARDEN:
Harvesting is all completed and thrashing done. The yield was good considering the season. Our oats were particularly good. I sold the wheat soon after thrashing, realizing $522.62 @ 1.30 per bushel.

The garden has paid well, but we suffered a severe loss in tomatoes and peppers from the early frost which was most unusual. We estimate that we lost about $400.00. The late potatoes will be very poor owing to the very dry summer.

We have been unable to sell any of the horses. There seems to be no demand at present. The old brood mare died a few days ago. The loss was small as she was too old to be of any use. Another old horse will have to be got rid of this fall. If I cannot sell him I shall have him killed. Two or three old cows will have to be sold.

Services have been held each Sunday at His Majesty's Chapel of The Mohawks. The historical interest of the Church attracts a considerable number of visitors. This is good for the pupils as it tends to add importance to their service. The visitors, too, invariably comment most favorably on the reverent attitude of the pupils and the beauty of the service. Chapel Services are held each day in the senior class-room, and the children seem to enjoy them. The readiness with which they respond to the call to chapel is very gratifying. Simple Bible talks are given by the Principal at each evening chapel. The only drawback is the lack of a suitable Chapel. The school-room lacks atmosphere and one hundred and thirty-five pupils and teachers crowd the room very much.

DISCIPLINE.

On the whole the pupils have been good. There was quite an epidemic of running away when I first took over but they seem to have settled down now that they have found out the reaction of the new Principal. A gratifying development has been the readiness of the pupils to cooperate in the prevention of absconding. Breaches of this rule are making the offender distinctly unpopular.

The most serious breach of discipline has been also a moral offense. There have been several instances of theft, most of them by two boys and one girl. Here, too, I have emphasized the harm done to their school and race. The scholars as a whole seem to have responded to this appeal, so that I was able to bring the last culprit, who happened to be the most persistent offender, to trial before his peers. He admitted his guilt and as a punishment was "put through the lines" and deprived of the trip to Oshweken Fair.

HEALTH.

The health of the school has been good. There was a mild epidemic of influenza. Three of the girls, the Curly sisters and Certie Hill were taken to Lady Willington Hospital for tonsillectomies. There are three pupils, Ambrose and Horne Cayuga and Mary Batista receiving treatments for eye trouble. The two boys began them before holidays. George Hill and Lorne Cayuga suffered fractures of the forearm but are doing well.

STAFF.

There have been several changes in the staff. Mr. Raynor and Miss Bellwood left Aug. 30, Miss Hooper had resigned on June 1, Miss Allan left Sept. 30, as did also Mr. Hughes. All of them resigned to take other positions except Mr. Hughes, whom I had to let go in pursuance of the policy of reducing the male staff.

But first let me say how much I appreciate the co-operation of many of the parents in encouraging the children to work hard and interest in their studies. Parents thus add much to the smooth running of the school and often save the school the trouble which must follow heedless.

There are at present 37 pupils in the School, the largest attendance I believe in our history. There are 18 boys and 19 girls. There is some possibility that the dormitory may be enlarged to accommodate the boys' dormitory, giving room for about 30 more.

The conduct of the pupils shows a distinct improvement, and I am convinced favorably with that of any other school for boys and girls. The Public School Inspector has visited several times and has been pleased with the school's condition.

The work of the teachers is very good, and I am sure they will be pleased to hear from you at any time. I shall be especially glad to have your report to me regarding your children's progress. We want them to be happy and contented here and if I know I can often remove a difficulty or show them how to improve the conditions. Of course, children often make mistakes and sometimes you know, but I hope I see that they are not repeated.

I am glad to hear anything you may have to say in praise of our efforts to give the children a good education and to develop in them good, honest Christian character.

Wishing you a Very Happy Christmas and a Happy New Year,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir,

I have to submit herein a report of the activities of this Institution for the quarter ending Dec. 31, 1929.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.

CHURCH. There have been no services held in His Majesty's Chapel owing to there being no way of heating the building. However, there have been regular services at the Institute, morning and evening prayer being held each Sunday by the principal, and chapel services were held each evening.

DISCIPLINE. There cannot be said to be an improvement in the general conduct of the pupils. Misconduct notably decreased, probably owing to the unfavourable season of the year. Five boys left one morning, Nov. 5, but three of them returned of their own accord the same evening while the rest were brought back the same night. One new girl tried to run away but was brought back by the other girls. Cooperation for this sort of part of the pupils is very gratifying. The boys have not been disrespectful, and although there is a petty thieving than in last quarter, we still believe, to our satisfaction, strong public feeling against such offenses among the pupils.

HEALTH. The health of the pupils has been excellent. There has not been a single case of sickness. Twenty-two of the girls who were diagnosed as having diseased tonsils have been taken to Lady Elgin Hospital for consultation. Phoebe Clausen, who prior to her operation had discharging glands, has been greatly improved since her operation. There are still several pupils who need similar treatment.

I do not speak too highly of the hearty co-operation of the staff. I only hope I may be able to retain them all indefinitely. There have been no changes during the quarter. It is worth mentioning that I have not required the services of a mechanic from the city once during the quarter. Mr. Jones has been able to make all necessary repairs. This means considerable savings to us.

FOOTBALL. The Institute is still well to the fore in sports. In a team contest between Brantford and Osgoode, the first two to finish in a five-mile race were Ingram Lickers and Miller Lewis, both pupils of the Institute. These two boys also won good places at the New Year's Meet at Hamilton. Norman was second in the three-mile race, Junior, being beaten by a step only by the champion mile runner. For the first time in many years, the open ten-mile. Other boys also ran well in both these events.

A very enjoyable Christmas was spent by all. The festivities included a Christmas concert which would have done credit to any group of children, a Christmas tree on Christmas Eve, a comedy and a dance put on by friends from the city, as well as sleigh rides for the girls and skating parties for the boys. One result of the skating parties was that all the children were treated to a rabbit dinner on New Year's Day.

I am glad to report too, that, for the first time in its history, I believe, the Church is taking an interest in the Institute. We have had a few visits, and Christmas presents candy store with some quilts and clothing. Our Circle W.A., or Grace Church here came down with 14 woollen blankets for pupils' beds. The Secretary

Dear Dr. Scott,

Mohawk Institute

Referring to your letter of July 31st last, I am authorised by the Court of the Company to submit to you the following proposals.

The New England Company are willing to ask H.M. Charity Commissioners to sanction the sale of their Mohawk Institute property to the Indian Department of the Government of Canada for the sum of £9,000 (nine thousand pounds), subject to certain conditions as follows:

For so long as the Institute is continued as an educational establishment the Company covenant to pay an adequate sum as stipend either to a resident Principal ordained in the Church of England or to a non-resident Principal ordained in the Church of England. For so long as the Institute is continued as an educational establishment the Department shall covenant to train the pupils in the teachings and doctrines of the Church of England. The Court of the Company, however anxious they may be to provide for the continuance of that religious education which is the main object of their Trusts, do not feel that they would be justified in attempting to bind the Department to continue the Mohawk Institute as a school should it be desired to convert it to any other use.

As regards the actual sale, the Company are prepared to accept similar terms of payment to those agreed in the case of St. George's School, Lytton, viz., the payment to be spread over a period of years bearing interest at 5% per annum on such of the purchase money as is unpaid. The existing lease would ipso facto be determined.
January 30, 1930.

Dear Mr. Matthews:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to a proposal to sell the Mohawk Institute to the Department. While I am glad to hear from the Company in this connection, I regret that the Department is not in a position at present to make an offer. I wish to give the matter careful consideration and to discuss it with the Honourable Mr. Stewart. I am not sure that he would be justified in asking Parliament for an Appropriation for the purpose for the next year or two, as we have many pressing claims.

I presume the Company's offer to pay the stipend of the Principal is in addition to the regular £1,000 per annum, which is payable under the current arrangement.

I am glad to state that, this year, the Department hopes to complete the top storey on the boys' side and to take in twenty more pupils. The Reverend Mr. Small, the new incumbent, has had a very auspicious winter season and I am hopeful time will prove that we have been very fortunate in securing his services. Next year, if an item can be provided in the Estimates, I propose to complete the rear wing by the addition of a chapel, etc.

Yours very truly,

The Mohawk Institute having, last year, completed one hundred years of usefulness, the Superintendent of Indian Education, Mr. Russell Ferrier, is writing its history which is to be embodied in next year's annual report when issued by the Department.

Dear Sir,

Mr. Frank Cookshutt called on me recently on behalf of the Farrindon Church. They are temporarily without a minister. They have applied to the United Church but cannot be supplied for some time. In the meantime, they would like me to take charge. As there is only one service a Sunday afternoon, I thought it would be only a neighbourly act to accede to their request. Further it should contribute something to the feeling of goodwill toward the Institute among a very fine type of people in the community. However, as it may possibly last for some little time, I thought I should report the matter for your approval.

I may say the Farrindons are an Independent congregation here in the city, of which the late Hon. Mr. Patterson was one of many outstanding members. They are few in numbers but very influential. In the old days they did their own preaching but the younger men have not kept up the tradition completely, hence the desire for someone to help out in this way.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Dr. Scott,

Your letter of the 14th January was before a Court of the Company held on the 19th instant.

The Court notes that you will consider the suggestions made in my letter of the 14th January and that there is a probability of your taking up the matter before very long.

With regard to the second paragraph of your letter, I might explain, to avoid misunderstanding, that the primary object of the third paragraph of my letter of the 14th January was to accentuate the view held by this Court that any grant by the Company should be allocated to religious rather than secular education. It was not in the mind of the Court that they should definitely bind themselves to provide the whole amount of their present grant in addition to the stipend of the ordained Principal or Chaplain.

You will realise that this decision leaves the Company in a freer position to aid in religious education in other parts of the dominion as occasion may arise.

MOHAWK INSTITUTE

The first building of the Mohawk Institute was situated just east of the cottage, opposite the Church "His Majesty's Chapel of the Mohawks." The present site was chosen in 1869 when a square white brick building was erected. Sometime before 1872 when Mr. R. Ashton became the Principal, a wing at the back of the building had been added, where the Sr. School, the pupils' dining hall and the boys' dormitory were located. In 1886 a wing for the Principal's residence was added to the north-west of the main building. In 1891 a larger wing was added to the south-east of the main building, where the Jr. School, the girls' dormitories and the girls' play-room were located.

This whole building was destroyed by fire in April 19, 1903. It was set on fire by the following boys: Isaiah Antone, Roy Wilson, Jesse Debo and Frank Winnie. On May 7, they also set fire to the barns, and on June 19 the boys' play house. Numbers of the pupils were reduced, leaving about 40 boys and 45 girls. Temporary buildings were put up on the place for the accommodation of the boys. But the building which had been the Ladies College in the city was rented for the girls where they and some of the staff lived for two months. Then they were removed to the old Parsonage, where temporary additions had been made.

Members of the New England Company, Mr. Wigram and Lord Stamford visited the place and decided that the new Institution should be built on the old site. The new building was completed in the autumn of 1904 and we moved into it on Oct. 20, 1904. To the rear of this building a large wing was added in 1922, in which the pupils' dining hall, the kitchen, the laundry and boiler room are located.

All these buildings were put up by the New England Co. with the exception of the wing erected in 1922.

The Prince of Wales made his visit to "His Majesty's Chapel of the Mohawk" on Oct. 20, 1919. He was attended by Major Gordon Smith and received at the church by Mrs. A. M. Boyce, the Principal of the Mohawk Institute. The boys of the school acted as guard of honour and the girls curtsied as His Royal Highness walked between the lines.

He entered the Church where he signed the Queen Anne Bible and where the missionaries to the Indians—Reverend Strong, Lee, Paget and Filkey—were presented to him. Sometime after this visit he sent an autographed photograph of himself to the Mohawk Institute, which now hangs in the front hall of the Institution.

In Oct. 1917 the Duke of Devonshire, who was Governor General at the time and Professor Graham Bell, the inventor of the Telephone paid a visit to the Mohawk Church, where they were shown the Queen Bible and Communion Silver—the pupils of the Mohawk Institution were present at the time.

The Duke of Connaught made a visit to the Mohawk Institute the day he visited the Six Nations at Cawkerk. Lord and Lady Willingdon visited the Mohawk Church on the day they opened the Lady Willingdon Hospital. Pupils of the Mohawk Institute were present at the church.

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit the following report of the activities of this Institution for the quarter ending March 31, 1920.

Your Obedient servant,

Horace W. Swell,
Principal.

CHURCH. The services have been conducted regularly morning and evening on Sundays as well as the chapel services daily. We have not been able to use the Church as services have been held in the Senior schoolroom. Mr. T. G. Goldsmith has been coming weekly to train the children in singing and there is a noticeable improvement in the musical parts of the services. Our thanks are due to Mr. Goldsmith for his labour of love.

DISCIPLINE. The conduct of the pupils as a whole has been good. A few have been in need of punishment, some of them several times, but the great body of them have behaved extremely well. The warm weather brought three or four cases of groups abounding but only one group were away over night. We had one case of a number of girls stealing food and one case of a boy stealing from another boy. He was dealt with by the boys themselves after trial and I doubt if he will repeat the offense. Several boys had to be punished for having data-pulse after being forbidden and the practice seems to be, at least, in abeyance.

HEALTH. The pupils have been in excellent health excepting two little girls who have swollen glands in the neck. It is hoped they will improve as soon as they can be taken to Lady Willington Hospital for tonsillectomy.

Staff. There have been no changes in the staff and all are co-operating splendidly.

FARM AND GARDEN. The stock all looks exceedingly well. We have had a request from the Provincial Agriculture Department for some young brood sows which are to be delivered in the near future. This very gratifying and we hope will open up a new market for a number of our pure bred hogs. Prices have been good and we have had good returns from our hogs this quarter.

NOTES. The principal has been asked to address several organizations on the work of the Institute. He has spoken to the Rotary Clubs of Brantford and of Preston, to several church organizations in the city to the Ladies' Club, the I.O.D.E., and also to a Men's organization in Windsor. Many of these have made or are to make contributions of books for the Children's library. They are also given to understand something of what the Department is doing for their Indian wards and how worthwhile it is.

Myles Isaac again brought honour to the school when he stood second in a half-mile race at the Hamilton meet in competition with 42 entrants.

The Public School Inspector visited and spoke favourably of the work being done.

A number of most enjoyable concerts were given for the children by city artists. They were also the guests on two occasions of the manager of the Temple Theatre.

A corps of Girl Guides has been organized under the leadership of Miss McCurney, the junior teacher and a keen interest is manifest. It should be a strong force for character building.

THE MOHAWK INSTITUTE

By Rev. H. W. Snell, B.A.

The City of Brantford may well be proud of its educational institutions. The oldest of them, and by no means the least valuable, is the Mohawk Institute. The idea of an institution goes back to the beginning of things in Brantford. A day school was carried there as early as 1828. But it was in 1841 that we find the first mention of the residential school, when the Mohawk Institute was opened with an attendance of ten boys. The object of the New England Company, who founded the institute, was to give the Indian boys a good education, to teach them to become useful members of society, and to provide them with good Christian habits and building. This has been kept steadily before the public ever since.

The Institute had become so much appreciated that work was extended to take in both boys and girls. It was built by the Company, and this, with a large endowment, insured the pupils until it was burned by fire in 1875. The present school was built on the same site, and a wing for the pupils' dining-room, kitchen, laundry, and new heating plant were added in 1922. Additional space is to be added this year and a Chapel in the new Institute is also provided with excellent barns, the latter built in 1877 at a cost of over $30,000. As garden space is limited, two small houses have been built and land has been bought for a third. A small revenue is derived from this source from sales of the market garden.

At present 134 pupils in residence; 78 boys and 56 girls are still ages, from 6 years to 18 years of age. Eight of them reside at the school while attending the Collegiate Institute in the city.

The pupils are drawn mainly from the Six Nations, but there are a number from Moraviantown, near Highgate; from Muncey Reserve, near Lorneville; from the Bay of Quinte Reserve, near Belleville; and from Caughnawaga, near Montreal.

In order to be admitted, a child must be an unenfranchised Indian. If he is of the Six Nations, the Principal has authority to accept him, but all other tribes and children not on the list must have their applications approved by the Department of Indian Affairs. The first claim upon the school is felt to be that of those who have no parents or guardians. These are probably as few as these. After that pupils are admitted in order of applications as a rule. The financial position of the parents, unless they are very poor, is not taken into consideration. The parents of several of the children are quite well off.

The course taught is partly academic, and partly industrial, the aim being to give them a good practical equipment for making a good living. The scholars are divided into two divisions, "A" and "B". Each division is in school for one-half of each day, which is divided into periods of the house, farm, and garden. For purposes of instruction and management there is a staff of twelve besides the Principal. The two school teachers are North American. One of them, Miss Harlow, is herself an Indian, who received her education at the Institute, and has almost completed her second year of teaching. She has a thorough knowledge of the pupils and her own language.

The Indians are divided into two classes. The other classes are: Nurse, Sewing Teacher, two Dietitians, both of whom are graduates of Macdonald Institute, Guelph the other of an English school, the Boys' Master and Mechanic, Farmer Teamster and Gardener. All the officers are employed within the pupils in their respective departments of work. In order to make the students realize how thoroughly practically trained our department to another. One half chance each week. This gives each pupil two weeks at each kind of work at a time. In the course of a number of years they have been many times through the whole round, but at no time are they kept at one thing until it becomes monotonous. The work is light, as many hands make light work, and the exercise is such that each miler has to milk and clean the cows, and his task is done.

In temperament and disposition the Indian differs very little, if any, from the white. In school they progress almost as rapidly as the whites in the Public School in spite of the fact that they attend school only half of the day.

Finally, every effort is made to develop good Christian character among the pupils. It is said that the attempt has been successful. The graduates may be found taking up the old occupation of farming, some are leading farmers on the Reserve, others are in business or industry, while many are making good wives and mothers. While it would be impossible to over estimate the good that has been rendered these hundred years to the Indians and, through them, to the whole community.

I have pleasure in submitting the following report of the Mohawk Institute for the quarter ending June 30-30. The report has been delayed owing to the fact that I have been ill from the effects of trench mouth ever since returning from my holiday two weeks ago.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

CHURCH. Services have been held regularly in His Majesty's Chapel ever since the weather has been warm enough. We were fortunate in having as special preachers several distinguished visitors to the city among whom were Reverend Canon Gower-Rees of Montreal, Ven.R.F.Fleming, Archdeacon of the Arctic, and Reverend Mr. Sampson a young Indian graduate from Trinity University who has been recently ordained. A Confirmation class was presented to Archbishop Williams for Confirmation in the Chapel on the Sunday after Ascension Day. There were 21 girls and 18 boys and the Archbishop commented very favourably on the class. Chapel services are held daily in the senior school room.

DISCIPLINE.

I am very pleased with the improvement in the conduct of the pupils this quarter. There was one instance of two boys climbing to the girls dormitory but the girls gave the alarm immediately and the boys were scared off. I regret to say that the leader was a Collegiate boy who should have been an example to the rest as he comes from a good home. Both boys absconded before I had completed the investigation. The reaction of the pupils, both boys and girls was gratifying. Neither of the boys will be returning after holidays. Another encouraging feature has been the marked decrease in corporal punishment and the readiness of the pupils to respond to the appeal to their sense of right and fairness. Altogether I am very much encouraged as to the conduct of the pupils.

HEALTH.

The health of the pupils has been excellent. We have been free from epidemics and have not had a single case of a pupil being ill enough to be sent to the sick room.

STAFF.

I cannot speak too highly of the staff. We are having to make one change. Miss Johnston the junior dietitian has to go home to help her mother. Miss Lydia Smith is succeeding her at the same salary. She is an older woman and should be a very efficient officer.

NOTES.

The buildings and grounds present a very pleasing appearance and are the admiration of the many visitors. All the interior of the building except the dormitories has been painted or varnished and almost all of the exterior has been painted so that the building looks very spick and span. All the work has been done by the pupils and staff.

A difficulty will present itself when the school reopens with more pupils. The senior school room is crowded at chapel now. It will be exceedingly difficult to find room anywhere for the larger number which we shall have next term. I hope, therefore, that the new Chapel will not be delayed a moment longer than necessary.

FARM AND GARDEN. Everything looks well and with a favourable season we should have good returns. The reduction in staff here has not done any harm.
REV. R. ASHTON
PASSES AWAY AT
CRIMSBY HOME

For a Lengthy Period He
Was Head of the Mohawk
Institute

His Interests Included
Many Widespread
Activities

There passed away yesterday at the
home of his son, Major A. Neles Ashton,
Grimsby, Rev. Robert Ashton, who died
after a long illness. He was head of the
Mohawk Institute from October, 1872
until 1910, and incumbent of "Saint
Peter His Majesty's Church" at the
Mohawk Institute, formerly known as
the "Mohawk Church," from 1865 to
1915. Born in England January 13,
1845, he came to Canada with Mrs. Charles
Ashton, he had attained the ripe age
of 87 years. In his early life he was
connected with the staff of the Mid-
dlessex Industrial school, and came to
Canada where still quite a young man
he assumed charge of the Mohawk In-
stitute, then under the auspices of the
New England Company, and he
remained there representing in Canada
until 1910.

He speedily won most effectively
confidence in the position and for
nearly half a century discharged the
many difficult duties of the post with
ability and zeal, devoting his super-
vision over the education of pupils of
both sexes, in the school rooms, and
in the various departments of the
institution, manifested great skill, and his
advice was frequently sought and his
judgment highly valued by the leading
institutions, not alone in Canada but
also in the United States. His love
for nature was evident in his constant
care of the grounds so that they became
one of the local show places, and the
provision of a large greenhouse for
growing flowers was also another most
successful hobby. Indeed, his all round
management of the institution was
such as to secure a handsome annual
revenue, applied to the expenses of
the school, and thus enabled him to
secure the wants of the pupils. He took holy
orders on June 11, 1901, and his ser-
mons, delivered in the Mohawk
church, were models of reason-
able brevity and sound reasoning.

Mr. Ashton was a many-sided man
exceptionally well informed upon a
great variety of subjects, and the
possession of a most logical mind. The
military life made a strong appeal
to him, and as chaplain with rank of
Major and member of the officer's
club, he has always been interested
in participation in the welfare of
the British Empire.

His favorite sport was the grand
old game of cricket, and many years
ago he had a playing field and ex-
cellently equipped cricket club on
the Mohawk Institute property, fac-
ing the canal. This was done entire-
ly at his own expense and was his
own personal cricket club, and the
club of which he was the honorary
president. During the Wednesday after-
noon matches for many years and
considerable period, he took a very
deep interest and frequently acted
as umpire; his profound knowledge
of the sport rendering him a most
efficient official in this respect. He
always said that cricket was a game
he enjoyed and that the numerous visi-
tors at these events were most hon-
estly treated. It may be said too
much to say that it was through
this kindly concern that the sport
was so much more retained in
Brantford at a period when other
more modern games threatened to
engulf it. He was also one of the
early officers of the Brantford
Masonic lodge and enjoyed his very
deep interest. He was a member and
Past Master of Masonic Lodge No.
12 and A.M., District Deputy Grand
Master for a long period, and had
occupied the chair of Provincial
Arch Masonry. Meteorological obser-
vations likewise constituted another
of his interests, and for a lengthy
period he had charge of the Brant-
ford station, making the records
when the observations were always
characterized as something of unusual
accuracy.

To the numerous visitors at the In-
stitute his great knowledge of In-
dian lore was also an attrac-
tive, and he had the pleasure of
being a host to members of the
British Royal family and other
notable people whose signa-
tures were always secured in the
famous guest book, now visible,
preserved to the Six Nations in
Brantford.

He was British to the core, and
to his memory in the Empire
was a very dear individual.

Mrs. Ashton predeceased him some
years ago and two sons and three
daughters survive: Lieut.-Colonel
R. C. Ashton, Toronto; Major Ash-
ton, Grimsby; Mrs. Sydney Rogers,
Mohawk Road; Mrs. F. C. Con-
shutt, Brantford, and Mrs. C. D.
Cocks, Virginia; also one sister, Miss
Emma Ashton.

The funeral will take place on
Saturday afternoon from the home
of Major A. Rogers, Mohawk road,
on Mohawk church.

Rev. Sir:

As you are aware, the Department has experienced considerable concern during the last year in connection with the many cases of truancy at the Mohawk Institute. As a result of Mr. Phelan's recent visit, I am inclined to feel that the supervision of the boys during their leisure time is not as effective as it might be. While Mr. Pengelley may be well qualified along certain lines, it is doubtful if he is capable of exerting the desired influence over the boys. As an instance of this, I may say that Mr. Phelan's report showed that the boys' washroom was allowed to remain in a dirty condition. For the next month or so, you should carefully supervise Mr. Pengelley's work, and, if there is not a decided improvement in the conduct of the boys, the Department considers that it would be in the best interests of the school to dispense with his services.

The Department also understands that it has been the practice to allow the boys to go into town and look for odd jobs, such as cutting grass, etc. The Department sees no reason for allowing this privilege, and it should be discontinued immediately.

Except in the case of the older pupils on whom you can place absolute reliance, no pupil should be allowed to go into Brantford without the supervision of some member of the staff. I think you will agree with me that it is necessary for all parties concerned to take every precaution to see that the actions of the boys and girls attending the Mohawk Institute are such as to reflect credit on the school and not be a cause of complaint on the part of residents living close to the school.

I trust that you have already arranged for the installation of the electric bell from the doors leading to the fire escapes to the supervisor's bedroom.

Dear Sir,

I am indeed surprised at the reports referred to in your letter No. 32-0-1, 14th inst. It is true that some boys were at the dump. This is a habit that we have been combating for some time and which recurs at intervals even with the most careful watching. The boys referred were detected by us and were thoroughly punished. But it is certainly not a regular occurrence.

As to the boys being seen at all hours in the city I am certain there is no foundation for the statement. The doors are locked at eight o'clock each night and the boys are all sent to bed at nine o'clock, the juniors at eight immediately after chapel. The dormitories are inspected to see that all are in bed at intervals during the evening. The electric bell with switches controlled by the fire-escape doors was installed immediately after Mr. Phelan visited us and as the bell is in the bedroom of the boys' master, it would be impossible for any boy to leave the building without arousing him. I am inclined to think that any Indian boy seen on the street is from Mohawk Institute and there are many Indians living in the city.

I have made inquiries from several people living near the Institute as to whether our boys ever gave them any trouble and they have all stated that the boys gave them no trouble. One lady remarked that they were likely to be blamed for much that was done by other boys.

The only times any boys have not been in the dormitory were cases of truancy. In one case the four boys returned voluntarily the next day. In the other we found them near Norwich.

I am glad to report that I am having the fullest cooperation from Mr. Pengelley. He could not give more supervision than he does without leaving undone the mechanical repairs that are part of his duties.

I should be pleased to know who are the people who make these complaints. No one has said anything to me.

Dear Major Bush:

Miss Susan Hardie, an Indian, was admitted as a pupil of the Mohawk Institute on March 20, 1878. She was at that time 11 years of age. In 1886, she was appointed as teacher in one of the classrooms and has taught at the school continuously since that time, with the exception of one year, which she spent at Normal School (a training school for teachers) in Toronto.

You will note, from the information contained in the preceding paragraph, that she is now 60 years of age, and, while she is still quite active, the Department considers that it would be in the best interests of the school to dispense with her services.

Unfortunately, we have no provision for superannuating teachers of Indian schools, even though they have given such long service as Miss Hardie.

As you are aware, you allow this Department an annual amount to assist in the maintenance of the Mohawk Institute. Would the New England Company have any objection to this Department using $500 or $600 a year from the amount which you pay us to provide an annuity for Miss Hardie, in the event of our finally deciding to dispense with her services within the next year? I trust that you will give this letter your kind consideration and advise me.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

I regret to note the recommendation to discontinue the greenhouse here. It would mean the loss of so much revenue that the difficulties of keeping accounts balanced would be very materially increased. In fact I cannot see how I could possibly make ends meet without the revenue received from this source. During the last fifteen years the cash revenue from the garden has averaged $1800.00 and about ninety per cent of this has come from the greenhouse. The lowest year was 1933 when the cash receipts dropped to $740. But there has been a steady increase since, $534.53 in 1934 and $187.32 in 1935. With further improvements in the economic conditions this may be expected to continue to rise to the average. The current cost of running the greenhouse is very small, the only expenses being coal, about $170, seeds about $90 and a few hoes, pots etc amounting to less than $100.00 per year. This leaves, in a normal year, several hundred dollars more than enough cash received to pay the gardener whom we should need in any case. To these receipts would be added about $1000 per year for vegetables sent into the house and also the cost of vegetable and flower plants that would amount to nearly $500.00 if we had to purchase them on the market.

Owing to the large amount of work by the gardener, the plant itself is now in excellent condition and will need no permanent repairs worth mentioning for years to come. All this, together with the new heating equipment recently installed, would be useless and necessarily fall into decay for lack of use.

I trust, therefore, that the Department will not insist on the closing up of the greenhouse.

The suggestion in paragraph 4 has been attended to and we shall have 200 chickens on May 1st.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM

Dr. McGill,

Miss Susan Hardie, teacher of the senior room at the Mohawk Institute, began duties there in 1886 and has taught continuously since that time, with the exception of one year which was spent at Normal School in Toronto.

The records at the school show that Miss Hardie is now sixty-nine years of age. She is an Indian and a member of the Six Nations Band.

As you know, we have no provision for superannuating teachers of Indian schools, even though they have given such long service as Miss Hardie. The New England Company allows us the sum of £1000 a year towards the cost of the operation of the Mohawk Institute. The Company was written an official letter on March 2nd, last, and a reply has just been received stating that they would have no objection to our using $500 or $600 of the amount they allow us in order to provide a yearly pension for Miss Hardie.

In view of Miss Hardie's age and reports that we have received in connection with the Mohawk Institute, I feel that it would be in the best interests of the school to retire her.

I would, therefore, recommend that Miss Hardie be notified that her services at the Mohawk Institute will not be required after the end of August, 1936, and that, from September 1st, 1936, she will be allowed a retiring pension at the rate of $50.00 a month.

Dear Madam:

After giving the matter very careful consideration, the Department has decided to discontinue your services as teacher at the Mohawk Institute. The principal, Reverend Mr. Snell, is being so advised and is being instructed to allow you to remain at the school, if you so desire, until the end of August. He is, also, being instructed to allow you your salary until that date.

There is no provision for superannuation of teachers at Indian residential schools or Indian day schools and, as a consequence, teachers in these schools do not contribute to any Superannuation Fund. However, the New England Company makes a yearly grant to assist the Department in the maintenance of the Mohawk Institute and the Company has given its permission to the Department to use part of this amount for payment to you of a retiring allowance. As a result, you will be allowed, from September 1st, 1936, a retiring allowance at the rate of $500 a year. This amount will be paid on the basis of $50.00 a month.

Dear Sirs:

Some time ago, I queried through the local Indian Office (Six Nations) as to whether the Mohawk Indian Institute, located in Brantford Township, just outside the city limit, were a government institution, and was informed that it was not, that the only government connection was that the government contributed on a per diem basis for the pupils trained there.

Last week, a Muncey Indian girl, Effie Smith, was killed when a Maypole gave way, and the auto wheel which formed the top of the equipment crushed the little girl, causing internal hemorrhages. At the inquest held on Friday night, Rev. H.W. Snell, Principal of the Institute, who, as far as I can find out, is an appointee of the Bishop of Huron, stated in giving his evidence:

"There was no special grant made by the Government for recreational equipment. The Institute was conducted by the Dominion Government and came under the jurisdiction of the Department of Indian Affairs."

As this puts the onus on the Indian Department and therefore on the Government, and as this is distinctly contradictory to the information given to me officially as President of the Brantford Liberal Association, I thought it should be drawn to your attention, hence this letter. I will be glad to receive from your Department any information which may arise out of this unfortunate affair, as to the actual jurisdiction of the Indian Department in the affairs of the Mohawk Indian Institute.

Believe me to be,

Your humble servant,

(Sgd.) A. T. Whitaker,

A. T. Whitaker,
The Expositor, Brantford, Ont.

As you are aware, the Mohawk Institute was established over one hundred years ago and, until 1928, was conducted under the auspices of "The Company for the Propagation of the Gospel in New England and the parts adjacent in America", commonly called "The New England Company". Dear Sir,

The newspaper report of the inquest re the death of Effie Smith, while perfectly fair, hardly gives the right impression of the part of my testimony which you quote. The Crown Attorney asked me "Does the Department make a grant for playground equipment?" and, of course, I answered "NO" but added that the Department did furnish us with equipment such as balls, bats etc. He then asked if our equipment was sometimes homemade as in the case of the Giant Stride and I answered that it was. No one who heard the evidence could possibly have inferred that the Department was niggardly in its provision for the pupils.

The court did not think Mr. Lager was remiss, inasmuch as he explained that he took it that the ring around the pole had been placed there to strengthen the pole where it was checked. The check, as was shown to the coroner and jury, did not reach completely to the top of the pole. Had the ring been nearer to the top of the pole it would have effectually prevented the split that caused the accident.

I may say that the mother attached no blame to the management. In fact she made the request that her little boy might be admitted next term if there is room for him. I have received a very kind letter written on her behalf, thanking us for our kindness in connection with the sad occurrence.

I shall be glad to furnish any further information desired.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

The boys do get a good deal of manual training under the Boys' Master and Mechanic. All repairs to equipment and plant that can be done by ourselves are almost entirely done by the boys under the direction of the boys Master. This involves considerable training in carpentry, plumbing, painting and repairs to machinery. As an example, the new metallic ceiling in the senior school room last year was done entirely by boys, the boys master merely giving the directions and instructions necessary. I may say that it compares more than favourably with the ceiling in the junior room installed by regular workmen some years ago. In addition to this, the boys are given instruction in the making of models of various kinds, bird houses etc. The excellence of their work is shown by the fact that four of the five prizes awarded at Oshawken Fair were won by our boys. I am convinced that the boys here get a better training in manual work than they could get in any of our public Schools where Manual Training is given.

Mr. Phelan of the School to the Department regarding his recent visit to the Mohawk Institute in company with Major E. P. Randle, Superintendent at Brantford.
