Dear Sir:

I have been consulted by Mrs. Edna Chrysler of 101 Euclid Avenue, Toronto, concerning injuries sustained by her son, Ross Chrysler, who was a pupil in your school in June last. My client informs me that one of the teachers on your staff called Mr. Logan mistreated her son to such an extent that his body was covered with bruises when her sister, Mrs. Harold Carter, of Hamilton, obtained the boy from your school for the summer holidays.

I hope you understand that I appreciate that there is a certain proper form of punishment in case a pupil misbehaves, but such punishment does not allow a teacher to take a pupil into a henhouse, as I am informed happened in this case, and flay him with a belt.

I have advised Mrs. Chrysler to let me know if there is any further mistreatment and in that case I will communicate directly with the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa. I also advised Mrs. Chrysler that she is to tell her son that in case of further mistreatment the boy is to go direct to you and also go to a physician for an examination.

I quite understand the difficulties which there may be in a school such as yours is, so far as the pupils are concerned, but feel that under the circumstances some explanation should be made to the boy's Mother.

Yours truly,

H.H., CRAIG

Dear Sir,

Mr. Snell informs me that you desire a signed statement regarding the reprimand and punishment administered to a pupil, Ross Chrysler some two weeks before the holidays by myself. This I am pleased to submit for your satisfaction.

On the particular day I was supervising some work at the poultry building when I heard a terrifying scream and one of the boys outside directed my attention to Ross throwing stones at a little fellow around five years of age by the name of Hubie Hill. I immediately went out of the building and called to the Chrysler boy to stop but he ignored me and continued to stone the Hill child. I distinctly heard two of the stones thud against the child's body and I was roughly one hundred and fifty feet away.

I ran up to the boys and asked what Ross was thinking about throwing stones with such violence at so small a boy and also explained the serious consequences that may result from this method. I found he was not repentant so I gave him four straps on the palm of each hand to which he smiled so I again spoke to the boy and asked him how he would feel had he placed Hubie in a world of complete darkness for the rest of his life by blinding him, and to this end I was successful in making the boy feel sorry, also gaining his assurance that he would not throw stones again.

Dear Sir,

I have pleasure in submitting a report of activities in
the Mohawk Institute for the past year, as requested by the
New England Company.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.

CHURCH. Sunday services have been conducted regularly during
the year, in His Majesty's Chapel during the warm months and in
the school at other times. We also have daily chapel services
in the school at which Biblical instruction is given. In addition
a period of religious instruction is given to each class during
school hours and Sunday School is held each Sunday. Confirmation
classes in preparation for that rite, attended by all the senior
pupils, were carried on for three months and thirty-eight pupils
were confirmed. Three of these came to the school from Iagen homes.
No attempt is made to proselytise children of other denominations
but occasionally they ask for Confirmation and, with the consent o
their parents, are presented. There can be no doubt that the em-
phasis placed upon Religious instruction has much to do with the
marked improvement in the character of the pupils.

DISCIPLINE. The conduct of the pupils has been most gratifyingly
exemplary. Truancy has almost entirely ceased and there is evident
a steadily growing desire on the part of the pupils to follow right
because it is right and to co-operate with the staff in maintaining
a high standard of behaviour and industry. This is so much the cas
that I have to resort to corporal punishment only on very rare oc-
casions.

STAFF. Too much credit cannot be given to the very efficient and
sympathetic staff of teachers and officers. I feel that it would
be very difficult to improve its personnel. We have now thirteen
members: Principal, Matron, Nurse, Senior teacher, Junior teacher,
Sewing teacher, Manual Training teacher, Senior dietitian, Junior
dietitian, Boys' Master, Farm Superintendent, Gardener and Teamster.

It is worthy of special mention that, through the kindness of the
Superintendent of Training and Welfare, we have been able to add a
teacher specially qualified for Manual Training. About $1100.00
has been spent in equipping the shop for teaching carpentry, forging,
woodwork, farm mechanics etc., and our pupils will now have the opp-
ortunity of a much better practical training than heretofore.

PUPILS. The enrolment has been slightly under our quota of 150.
We had 64 boys and 81 girls. The progress was normal. Eight pupi
passed the Entrance examination for a mission to Collegiate Insti
and the other classes advanced steadily. Five pupils are attend
College from here and are doing a uniformly high standing.

Improvements have been made
in the plumbing and
other matters.

Dear Mr. Snell:

On the occasion of my recent visit to the Mohawk Institute Indian Superintendent Randle and myself went over the whole school with a view to examining the work that has been recently done.

On entering the wash rooms used by the girls in the basement I was extremely disappointed to notice papers scattered over the floor and in spite of the newly decorated walls and ceilings the rooms appeared as if no supervision was being given to the girls.

I feel it is almost unnecessary for me to point out that the Department expects the staff of the Mohawk Institute to see that all rooms in the building are kept in a cleanly condition.

The Indian Superintendent, Major H.F. Randle, is being requested to visit the Mohawk Institute within the next month and to report to the Department any room that is not in the condition in which it should be.

I was especially sorry to see the condition of these rooms in the basement on the day on which I was there because I understand that later in the afternoon a member of your staff accompanied one of the leading members of the American Delegation through the basement. Certainly this gentleman could not have obtained a very good opinion of the training given the girls in the matter of cleanliness of the rooms which they are occupying.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

On July 31st, 1929, we were informed of the appointment of the Rev. H. W. Snell, B.A., as Principal of the Mohawk Institute, with power to sign against the Bank account operated in the name of the Institute. We were asked to extend "the usual overdraft courtesies, if necessary, up to $3,000."

On a subsequent occasion we were told that arrangements were being made whereby overdrafts should not be necessary, but from time to time we have been requested by Mr. Snell to allow some special overdrafts pending the receipt of delayed funds from Ottawa, and to some extent we have complied.

On May 7th, 1940, the account was placed in funds with a deposit of $4,805, but we notice today that cheques since paid have created an overdraft, which amounts this evening to $697.50. We have hesitated to refuse payment of cheques issued for the expenses of the School, when requested to do so by the Rev. Mr. Snell.

Our relations with the Principal in the operation of the account have been entirely pleasant, but at the same time we are desirous of carrying out the wishes of the Department. If it is your wish that we allow overdrafts we shall do so, and we shall not hesitate to permit them from time to time to such amount as you may set. If, however, we are expected to refuse any cheques which, if paid, would create an overdraft, perhaps you will be good enough to so inform us.
The Deputy Superintendent General (2)

The purpose of this letter is to let you know that there is at this writing an overdraft of $879.50, and to ask for instructions for our future guidance. We think you might consider it convenient to authorize some overdraft privilege, but perhaps less than $3,000.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

DOCTOR LOGILL

Brantford

We visited and make an inspection of the Mohawk Institute. The Principal of the school, the Reverend H.W. Snell, was absent, making certain purchases from wholesale houses in Hamilton. Despite the substantial sums spent from year to year on the upkeep and repair of this building, the structure is by no means in first-class shape. The whole atmosphere in the school appears to be somewhat depressing and the rooms, particularly the bedrooms, rather bleak and unattractive. We were particularly interested, however, in his farming operations and in his live stock, he appears to have a good farming instructor, Mr. Arnell and I questioned him closely in respect of his dairy herd, which appears to be somewhat depleted, and to the number of Yorkshire hogs that he is feeding this winter. When we expressed surprise at the small number of hogs in the piggery, he intimated that it was exceedingly difficult to secure the funds necessary to multiply the number of hogs at the school. I did not question him closely but came away with the impression that the cattle and hogs produced at this school during the last two or three years have not been equal to the number consumed at the premises. Mr. Snell is an old man and has never been a good administrator at any time. He never appears to have a good grip on his finances. If this school is to be kept open and in operation, it might very well become a government-operated institution, following the withdrawal of the annual grant now made by the New England Company.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Minister,

I fear that it has taken some time to reply to your letter of December 23rd 1942 about the future of the Mohawk Institute, but it was necessary for the New England Company to take legal advice, and to ascertain the views of the Charity Commission as to how far the proposition in your letter was consistent with the Company's Charter.

The Court of the Company are advised that they are not at liberty under their Charter to transfer the freehold of the Institute to your Department as you propose without consideration. On the other hand the Company have every wish to facilitate the general scheme which you have proposed. The Company must, however, stipulate that the teachings of the Church of England should continue to be available for those pupils whose parents desire it.

With the purpose in view of continuing the objects of the Company within the terms of their Charter the Company wish to suggest to you the following alternative arrangement:

The Company would be willing to grant a Lease of the Mohawk Institute, apart from the Mohawk Chapel, for a nominal rent, for a term of 21 years, your Department being responsible for maintenance and repairs and for the insurance of the property. The Company would retain the freehold of the Chapel and would be responsible for its upkeep.

In the altered circumstances the Company would not propose to maintain their annual grant of £1000 beyond the end of the current year, but they would pay a salary to a Church of England clergyman nominated by the Bishop of the Diocese and appointed by the Company, to give religious instruction in the school and to serve the Chapel. The Company would wish to consider

Dear Sir,

Re: Gasoline - Special Category Applications.

On February 14, 1944 instructions were received in this branch from our Deputy Minister's office that all applications for special categories for gasoline for the operation of motor cars should be submitted to the Administrative Branch for approval and the signature required of Certificate Number 1 on Page 2 of the application form. It would appear that arrangements were made with your office that these applications would bear the signature of Mr. C. W. Jackson, Chief Executive Assistant.

It was not the intention, when this arrangement was made, that this should apply to the Principals of Indian Schools, who, although engaged in what might be described as government business are definitely not Civil Servants or employees of the Dominion Government. It would appear that when Principals of Indian Schools apply, from time to time, for special category gasoline they are informed by the Regional Oil Controllers that their applications must be sent to Ottawa for the signature of the official above mentioned. The official, Mr. C. W. Jackson, however, is not prepared to sign these applications as he is not sufficiently informed as to the work these gentlemen are engaged in, and consequently is not in a position to pass judgment as to the amount of gasoline they should be authorized to use.

As an example of what has been occurring I give you the following information:

Rev. H. B. Small, Principal, Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ontario, applied early in the year (about May, 1944) for a Special Category for gasoline for the operation of the Mohawk Institute car. The Regional Oil Controller returned the application to Mr. Small with the notation - "Must be certified by Ottawa Department". The application was forwarded to Mr. Jackson with the advice received from the Regional Oil Controller. Mr. Jackson returned it to this branch with the notation - "Unless Mr. Small is engaged and paid by the Department, I have no authority to certify this application".

From the above you will see that under the present arrangements Principals of Indian Schools cannot secure additional gasoline to carry on the school operations. The Regional Oil Controllers will not grant it claiming that the applications must be signed by the department at Ottawa, and the department at Ottawa will not sign as they are not in our employ.
The particular case cited is not an isolated one, as many such instances have occurred. It would be appreciated if you would issue instructions to your Regional Oil Controllers to deal directly with applications presented to them by persons conducting semi-government business for this department, but who are not paid by this department nor receive from this department any allowance for travelling.

Yours very truly,

Director.

Memorandum:

I inspected the Mohawk Institute on Thursday, October 12. Accompanied by the Principal, I visited all parts of the building and I found everything in good condition, with the possible exception of the boys' playroom. Although the conditions in this room are not perfect, they are much better than I have seen them on former occasions.

Two qualified teachers are employed. This is the second year during which these teachers have been at Mohawk. While the girls are given considerable training in housework, sewing etc., the boys evidently receive little vocational training. The Principal stated that it was impossible for him to secure a qualified vocational teacher this year. At the present time he is employing a man by the name of Bricker. This gentleman is 67 years of age, but appears quite vigorous.

The Principal brought to my attention the necessity for the supplying of a new gas stove in the kitchen at an early date. New tables are also necessary in the children's dining room. Neither of these requires immediate attention, but as soon as such articles are available after the war they should be supplied.

At the time of my visit there were 110 pupils enrolled. The authorised pupilage at this school is 130. The Principal stated that he expected to obtain another 10 or 15 pupils within the next month.

Mr. and Mrs. Snell introduced the question of whether the Department would insist on Mr. Snell's retiring at the end of June, 1945. I pointed out to them that by this time Mr. Snell would be over 65 years of age and that the original decision of the Department to retire him at that time was still in effect. Mrs. Snell expressed the opinion that other members of the staff were doubtful regarding their future. I pointed out to her that, as far as we were concerned at the present time, we had no intention of dispensing with the services of any other members of the staff.

Dear Sir,

I am writing to you with regard to the Mohawk Institute at Brantford, Ontario.

I am informed that the Department is considering the idea of radically changing the whole character of the School by putting it under a layman as Principal and merely allowing the services of a Chaplain for our own children.

I was very much shocked when I heard of this proposal to bring to an end a religious and educational tradition which had been established for so long, and I am sure that Anglicans generally throughout Canada would hear of this decision with regret and amazement.

I trust that those in charge of Indian affairs will take over this school on the same terms as it takes over other Indian residential Schools. In fact there seems to be no reason why an exception should be made in the case of our oldest school.

Ottawa, November 6, 1944.

My dear Archbishop Carrington:

I have for acknowledgment Your Grace's letter of November 6, in which you express surprise that this Department is considering the idea of radically changing the whole character of the Mohawk Indian Residential School, by putting it under a layman as Principal and merely allowing the services of a Chaplain for the Anglican children.

I may state briefly that this expression of opinion is based either on a misunderstanding of the actual facts or a misinterpretation by someone of the negotiations that have taken place and are still taking place between the representative of the Bishop of Huron, the General Secretary of the M.S.C.C., and this Department, with respect to the future of the Mohawk Institute.

In September, 1942, the Governor of the New England Company informed the Chief of our Training Division that it was not the intention of the New England Company to continue its annual grant of $5,000.00 for the operation of the Mohawk Institute. The Governor did suggest, however, at that time, that the Company would be glad to lease the property to the Government, should the members of the Government feel that the school should be kept open and in operation. A great deal of consideration was given to the remarks of the Governor of the New England Company, by the Minister of this Department and the officials of this Branch. It was finally decided that a representative commission should thoroughly

Most Reverend P. Carrington, K.A., P.C.L., Litt. D., D.D.,
Archbishop of Quebec and Metropolitan of Canada,

investigate the educational needs of the Indian population of southwestern Ontario. This commission reported to the Minister in due course.

In the meantime, however, the Governor of the New England Company sent forward, for our consideration, a draft 21 year lease. This lease, with certain minor adjustments, was returned to the Governor of the Company with a covering letter dated August 1, 1944. The lease has not been executed, nor have we been in communication with the Company at any time since the afore-mentioned date. A number of conferences have been held, however, between representatives of the M.S.C.C. and this Branch, and arrangements have been made whereby I shall interview Canon Dixon on Friday, November 24, and interview Canon Dixon and Canon Townshend on November 30. It will thus be seen that we are putting forth a sincere and earnest attempt to adjust what appears to us to be a very delicate and somewhat complicated matter. In all fairness to the Government and to this Department, it should be stated, however, that the proposals now under consideration are the proposals, not of this Government, but of the New England Company. Dear Sir:

As one of the Bishops of the Church of England in Canada, I am deeply interested in the welfare of our native peoples and have given the best part of my life in order to help them towards the time when they shall take their full and proper place in this great Canada of ours, of which they are first citizens.

I write to express my deep concern regarding the proposal to change the whole character of the ancient and historic Residential School for Indians on the Reserve at Brantford, known as the Mohawk Institute and it is not clear to me what lies behind the recent government proposal.

May I point out that no one who has any intimate knowledge of our native people could fail to realize that it is of first rate importance that the children shall not only be taught those things which are important so that they may have such knowledge as will fit them for the life they will be called upon to live but also they should be trained in a religious atmosphere. This is necessary in order that they may have that moral stamina without which they would go down to defeat.

In the past the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources, hitherto known as the Department of Indian Affairs, has done a most valuable work in connection with the education of our native people.
and I trust that there will be no weakening on the part of the Department now. Greater efforts should be put forward to see that, in the face of the present pressure being brought upon these people by our civilization, more help and not less should be given for their mental and spiritual upbuilding.

As I understand the situation in connection with the Mohawk Institute, the government is being asked by the Church simply to put this Institute on the same basis as other Indian Residential Schools. Surely this is a very simple and natural proposal void of any grounds for controversy.

I would like to hear from you, Sir, if I understand the situation properly or not. I would also hope to have an assurance from you that the rumour of a proposal to turn it into a home for orphans and perhaps delinquent children is inaccurate. It seems to me this second idea has nothing whatsoever to do with the Mohawk Institute as such. I should be entirely in favour of establishing an Orphanage or a Home for delinquent Indian children if that be deemed necessary but I deplore very much any suggestion that either of these should take the place of the Mohawk Institute.

Awaiting your reply, believe me, dear Sir,

[Signature]

Bishop of the Arctic.

Re: Operation of Mohawk Institute.

My dear Bishop Fleming:

I have for acknowledgment Your Lordship's letter of November 7, in which you discuss the marginally-noted subject.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Canon Townshend and I greatly appreciated our interview with you this morning and your courtesy and frankness in discussing with us, as you did, the future of the Mohawk Institute. We were sorry that Dr. Alderwood was unable to be with us.

I am writing now to record our understanding of the matter discussed and the agreement reached.

In my letter to you of May 29th I summarized our interview of that date. A copy of that letter, together with your reply of June 3rd are before me as I write. Since my letter of May 29th I have written you on August 21st and October 19th telling of cables received from the New England Company enquiring as to the progress of negotiations and my replies, and again on November 8th stating, as already reported to you, that our Board of Management at its annual meeting had agreed to take over the administration of the Mohawk Institute. Your letters of August 23rd, October 19th, and October 23rd relating to these subjects were duly received.

Our conference this morning helped greatly to clear away misunderstandings and enable us to see the real issue more clearly. This would seem now to narrow down to an alternative which you stated and which, at our request, you kindly agreed to put in writing. Our understanding of that alternative is:

1. That Government, by the terms of the new agreement with the New England Company, continue the Institute under its direct administration; that the appointment of a Principal, acceptable to the Bishop of Huron, and a Chaplain nominated by him and the setting up of an Advisory Committee be provided for as outlined in my letter of May 29th and yours of June 3rd; and that this be regarded as an experiment for three - or possibly four - years, at the end of which time the whole matter would be reconsidered.
2. That the Institute be placed under the administration of the Church of England through either the M.S.C.C. or the Diocese of Huron. In that case it was your opinion

a. That the agreement now under consideration between the New England Company and Government would need to be replaced by an agreement between the Company and M.S.C.C. or the Diocese of Huron.

b. That Government would continue its per capita grants as paid in 1944.

c. That with the discontinuance of the New England Company's annual grant, this would likely involve additional expenditure for M.S.C.C. - or the Diocese - of from $5,000 to $12,000 per annum.

I feel sure it will help greatly in arriving at a definite decision to have the issue thus defined in the form of an alternative. I hope that such a decision may be reached when our Executive Committee next meets, which will be in February.

Meanwhile, as agreed, I shall write to the New England Company telling them that the negotiations are proceeding, and that we hope to arrive at a definite and amicable agreement before the end of February.

With kind regards,

Yours sincerely,

My dear Sir:

The matter of the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, being taken over by our Missionary Society was discussed on Tuesday of this week in Toronto by the Executive of our Society.

I may say that the definite and authoritative step to the above end was taken last September by the parent body of our missionary work which we call the Board of Management. The Committee which met on Tuesday last in Toronto was only the Executive of this parent body and is therefore charged only with the carrying out of the directions of the Board of Management.

In undertaking this task the Executive Committee found itself in need of some further information on certain points with regard to the Mohawk Institution management, and it therefore deferred taking the necessary steps until its meeting next May.

If I understand the situation correctly there is a desire on the part of your Department to clear up the matter of the Principalship of the School. I may say that I see no obstacle to your Department taking whatever action you may think necessary in this important matter whenever it seems advisable to you. Any delay which has been caused on our part by deferring action until next May will not, in my opinion, seriously affect the question of the Principalship.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Since I wrote to you on February 18th our Executive Committee has met. I had hoped to be able to write and report definite action regarding the Mohawk Institute. Unfortunately I cannot. The two alternatives, as set out in my letter to you of November 30th last, were presented and given most careful consideration. Ottawa, March 1, 1945.

My dear Archbishop Seager:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 23rd instant and have noted with interest the information contained therein.

In view of the fact that we have not yet received from the New England Company for execution by the Crown, the lease forwarded to them in July of last year, it is difficult for me to see how we can keep the Mohawk Institute open and in operation after the close of the present school year. I have not had an opportunity to give the matter the study to which it is, undoubtedly, entitled, but I doubt very much if we could use Parliamentary appropriations for the repair of a building that is not owned by the Government and is not under lease by the Government. I am definitely of the opinion also that we are not likely to receive this lease of which I speak from the New England Company until the Governor of that Company has an assurance from the Church of England authorities in Canada that the differences between them and the Government on the operating of the school have been amicably settled.

Yours very truly,

Most Reverend Charles Seager, M.A., D.D., LL.D.,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Your letter of the 18th received. I suggest for appointment to the Principalship of the Mohawk Institute the names of the Rev. J. Billingsley, now Rector of Holy Trinity Church, Chatham, and the Rev. J. R. Thompson, now Rector of Trinity Church, St. Thomas. I note your intention to select three of our officials to investigate the men suggested. Dear Archbishop Seager:

I am in receipt of Your Grace's letter of the 13th instant, in which you advise that you hope to be in a position to suggest the names of two or three Anglican Clergymen, who could be interviewed with a view to ascertaining if any of them would be suitable as Principal of the Mohawk Institute. Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am in receipt of a letter from the Rev. Canon Dixon, General Secretary of our Missionary Society, under date of 10th April, confirming a telephone conversation with me the same morning with regard to the retirement of the Rev. H. W. Snell of the Mohawk School.

Canon Dixon informs me that you wish me to suggest to you the names of two or three Anglican Clergymen whom you, or members of your staff, might interview with a view to ascertaining if any of them would be suitable for carrying on the work of the Institute. He informs me that your idea is that the new Principal should be between thirty and forty years of age with some teaching experience and also reasonably good knowledge of farming.

I have now that I have carefully considered the matter and find that I have at least three men here in the Diocese of whom, so far as can be expected, fit in with the qualifications here mentioned. I think before sending you their names I should interview them as to whether they would be interested in such a proposal. This I can do in the next day or two. I will then be in a position to write you definitely.

In considering the whole situation of the administration of the Mohawk Institute, particularly in view of the possibility of the Church taking it over, it has occurred to us that it might be very helpful if we set up a kind of administrative Board consisting of able and experienced men, particularly in farming and in business. This body, say three or four in number, could look after the administration of the business interests of the concern, and would likely be of great assistance to the Principal. I thought you might be interested to know of such an arrangement.

If you can give me any information as to the amount of salary to be paid the new Principal together with any other financial advantages the position carries with it, it would assist me in placing the matter before the men I have in mind. At present I can of course only go upon present arrangements. I understand that Mrs. Snell has acted as Matron of the Institution and has received
compensation for this service. I suppose the same would apply in the future.

I am,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

CHANGES DISCUSSED

A crisis which has arisen in the history of the Mohawk Institute in Brantford, the Anglican Indian Residential School, is now being discussed by all parties interested in the purpose of removing the school from the auspices of the Church of England.

The agreement between the New England Company and the Indian Department at Ottawa has expired and a new one proposed "of a nature to so radically change the character of the school as virtually to destroy it as it is now constituted."

Changes Sought

Certain proposals to reorganize the school and change its character from a religious foundation to an exclusively educational one have been made. Through the help of the bishops throughout Canada the Indian Department has stated that it is prepared to continue its per capita grants to the school as soon as arrangements are made with the New England Company, if the M.S.C.'s of the Diocese of London will become responsible for its administration. It is expected that this question will be settled on May 23, Archbishop Seager stated.

Then an agreement with the New England Company, whose interests in the school are material, will be sought.

A delegation from the Indian Department at Ottawa and the United Church of Canada visited the school recently in view of considering changes by which the pupilage of the United School at Mount Elgin might be transferred to the Mohawk Institute. It was proposed that the purpose of the institution should be primarily an educational one and one with special equipment in agriculture. Dear Colonel Randle:

This will confirm the decision reached at a conference held in my office this morning (June 1, 1945) that Joseph C. Hill, new Principal of the two-room Indian Day School (No. II) in the Six Nations Agency, be offered the Principalship of the Mohawk Institute at Brantford. It was decided that Mr. Hill should be paid a salary at the rate of $1500.00 per annum, and that his wife, who has the qualifications necessary to act as Matron, be paid at the rate of $50.00 per month.

It is the feeling of the officials here that, while Mr. Hill is a capable, fully qualified and experienced teacher, he may nevertheless feel the additional administrative duties and responsibilities at the Institute somewhat exacting. This position is, as you know, an important one. The Mohawk Institute has always occupied a prominent place in the educational program of this Department. It has been decided, therefore, that Mr. Hill should be assisted in his work by the creation of an advisory board, the members of which board should meet at least quarterly - this board to consist of yourself as Chairman, the Public School Inspector of the district, the Clergyman in charge of the Mohawk Chapel and responsible for religious instruction at the school, the Chief of the Six Nations Band and the Principal of the School, Mr. Hill, as Secretary. It is our intention that this advisory committee should have general supervision of the work of the school and of the farming operations carried on as part of the regular school program. We are anxious that no radical change in the school program or in the operation of the farm or in the work of general administration should be undertaken without first being submitted for review to the advisory committee. While the Principal will be responsible for the employment and dismissal of the members of the staff, nevertheless staff matters might, with advantage to all parties concerned, also be reviewed by the members of the advisory board.

......This school
This school, as you are no doubt aware, has been operated since its inception, with two exceptions, under the direction and guidance of Clergymen of the Anglican Church in Canada. The appointment of Mr. Hill, therefore, constitutes a somewhat radical change in policy, but one for which provision is made in the lease sent forward for execution to the New England Company. We do feel, however, that before the offer of the Principalship is made to Mr. Hill, the matter should be discussed with the Archbishop of Huron, and his consent, if at all possible, to the arrangement obtained. While we are under no legal obligation to consult the Archbishop in this regard, it is, in our judgment, of the utmost importance for the success of the school that he should sanction this change in policy, and that the closest possible cooperation should exist between the Archbishop and the Anglican Church authorities in the operation of this Residential School. Indeed, it would appear to us that under the new arrangement cooperation in the future should be as close, or perhaps closer, than it has been at any time in the past. Provision has been made in the new lease, copy of which is no doubt in the possession of the Archbishop, whereby an Anglican Clergyman will be employed to take charge of the Mohawk Chapel and this Clergyman also be responsible for providing religious instruction to the pupils enrolled at the school. This point should be emphasized by you in your interview with Archbishop Seager.

In view of these facts, it would be appreciated if you could make arrangements to interview Archbishop Seager at the earliest possible date. It would be appreciated also if you would let us have a report on the interview in due course.

We are asking Mr. Phelan to visit Brantford at a suitable date in the immediate future. Mr. Phelan will be in a position to supply you and Mr. Hill with full and complete information on the history of the school and the financial obligations assumed by this Department with respect to the maintenance and operation of the Institute. It will be highly desirable also, at the time of Mr. Phelan's visit, that the task of preparing a complete inventory of the assets of the school and the farm be undertaken.

I have referred to the creation of an advisory board which, in our judgment, should be organized prior to the opening of the school on September 1st. In this connection, it is unnecessary to add that the decisions reached by the

......school
school management and by the members of this board from time to time, must, of necessity, be subject to Departmental sanction and approval.

My dear Archbishop Seager:

I have received your letter of June 15th, and have noted with interest the suggestions contained therein.

I found myself unable to reply to your telegram of May 15th for several reasons. First of all, I had no officials here with the time at their disposal necessary to return to Brantford with the object of interviewing the Clergymen nominated by you for the Principalship of the Mohawk Institute. Inspector Arnell is at present engaged in field work at Port Arthur. The Chief of the Training Division is, for the time being, responsible not only for his own work, but responsible also for the work of the Superintendent, and could not possibly leave Ottawa.

I have found it difficult to reply also for the reason that we have not, in my judgment, the legal or indeed any authority to administer the Mohawk Institute in the absence of a duly executed lease. The revised lease was sent forward to the New England Company almost a year ago, but has not been returned. I did feel, however, and still feel that rather than close the school an attempt should be made to carry on until the Governor of the New England Company either returns the lease or until he informs us definitely that the Company is not prepared to renew it.

In the interval, the suggestion has been made that Joseph C. Hill, an experienced teacher, should be placed for the time being at least in charge of

......the school,
the school, under the direction of an advisory committee. In view of all the circumstances and the uncertainty surrounding the appointment, the suggestion appeared to me to be a reasonable one; but before taking definite action, or indeed action of any kind, I asked Lt.-Col. Randle to discuss the matter with you personally. I feel sure the Government would not be prepared to proceed with this appointment even on a temporary basis unless Mr. Hill could have the active cooperation of the Anglican Church authorities.

I might add that Mr. Hill has an outstanding record as a teacher. It is my understanding that he has had two attractive offers within the last couple of months - one from the City of Hamilton and the other from the City of Kingston. It is not at all likely, in view of these offers, that we shall be able to retain him in the two-room Indian Day School on the Reserve, of which he has been Principal for a number of years. In addition to Mr. Hill's qualifications, his wife seems particularly well qualified for the position of Matron. She is a graduate of Home Economics and has no family obligations. The fact that Mr. Hill has been suggested for this position is in itself a great tribute to the work undertaken and accomplished by the Church on the Reserve over a long period of years. I feel confident the selection of Mr. Hill would prove popular not only on the Six Nations Reserve, but would prove popular with the Indians throughout the country. You might, therefore, just as soon as you can conveniently do so, communicate either with Lt.-Col. Randle or myself with respect to this latest suggestion. The time, as you state, is short and action should be taken immediately if the school is to be kept open and in operation.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Following your letter of 18th June, I called a meeting of our Committee to discuss the matter. The Committee asked me to state first how this matter stands, particularly as to the revised lease to which you refer as having been forwarded to the Company "almost a year ago, but has not been returned".

We had not been informed by the New England Company of this revised lease, the fact of which was brought to our attention accidentally. To the terms of this revised lease we offered strong objection, as the effect of them was to radically alter the whole religious character, atmosphere and purpose of the School. For this reason I cabled the New England Company under date of April 15th, 1944 to delay signature as it appeared altogether probable that the Church of England in Canada would be willing to assume responsibility for the School.

The fact is that the proposal stirred practically the whole Church of England in Canada into disapproval which was clearly expressed, and your Department withdrew it, substituting a second and much more favourable one. I am under the impression that this latter understanding was not communicated to the New England Company but awaited action here. I need not refer to its details which are, of course, known to you.

Under this new proposal the Bishop of Huron was to nominate a Priest of the Church of England properly qualified as Principal of the School, and the Department undertook to continue to pay the per capita grants. In the meantime, the assumption of the administrative responsibility for the School by the Church of England in Canada was still under consideration.

Pursuant to this new proposal I was asked to nominate three Priests of the Church of England to your Department from whom, after an interview by your officials, you might appoint a Principal. I complied with this, your own request, as soon as I could contact three such men. Unfortunately none was able to meet your officials on May 7th as arranged because the Clergy were all directed to be in their parishes awaiting the German surrender. Dear Mr. Hoey:

Your letter of 28th June received, enclosing a copy of your cablegram to the New England Company. I note the steps you propose to take this week with regard to the Mohawk Institute.

Since your letter was written, however, the following cable has been received by me from the Company, and I understand one was by you received to a similar effect, your letter being dated 28th June and the cable 29th June:

"Reference your letter of 21 June. New England Company intends grant lease of Mohawk Institute. Only form of lease known to us is that sent to Hoey a year ago. If you and Hoey have agreed together and suggest new form of lease we as landlords must know new form before agreeing. If you and Hoey are not agreed as to variation we are prepared to grant lease to Canadian Government in original form. We have cabled Hoey today to this effect.

Cochrane Governor."

Since receiving your letter and the cable, our Committee here has discussed the matter of the Mohawk Institute, and to facilitate the settlement of it makes the following suggestion. That the proposals suggested as amendments to the original ones made by your Department be the basis of a new lease between the New England Company and your Department.

The terms of the revised proposal in outline are:

1. That the Principal of the Mohawk Institute be a Clergyman of the Church of England nominated by the Bishop of Huron and appointed by your Department.

2. That an advisory committee be set up consisting of the Principal, the Indian Agent and a nominee of the Bishop of the Diocese.

3. That this arrangement be tried out for three years and if any adjustments are found to be advisable they should be made at
Mr. R. A. Hoey,

the end of that time.

The main reason for this suggestion by our committee is that The New England Company was informed about a year ago of this revised proposal and is therefore in a position to draft a form of lease in accordance with it without delay.

Our Committee had felt when these proposals were first made that there are drawbacks to them, namely two in number. First that the period of three years is hardly long enough for a successful experiment. Secondly that it might be difficult to secure the right man as Principal if he should feel that his position should be in question after so short a period. Our Committee feels that a period of five years might be better.

I took the opportunity yesterday of meeting Colonel Randle and informed him of the action of our Committee, merely with a view of his knowing what is in mind, particularly as your representative was to meet him in Brantford sometime this week.

I very earnestly hope that this suggestion will meet with your approval so that this somewhat vexatious matter may be satisfactorily settled.

Memorandum:

In accordance with your instructions,
Mr. W. S. Arneil, Inspector of Indian Agencies for Ontario;
Lt.-Colonel E. P. Nandle, Superintendent of the Six Nations Agency; and myself interviewed the under-mentioned gentlemen, recommended by His Grace the Archbishop of Huron as suitable candidates for the position of Principal of the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ont.:

1. Rev. W. J. Zimmerman:

Mr. Zimmerman is 39 years of age and was ordained to the Priesthood of the Church of England in 1936. Since that date he has held two or three parishes and, in addition, has spent some months with Canon Paul, who is the Anglican Missionary on the Big Island Lake Indian Reserve, Onion Lake Agency, Saskatchewan. Mr. Zimmerman possesses a B.A. Degree from Toronto University and an M.A. Degree from Columbia.

Mr. Zimmerman has conducted Children's Camps for three years during the summer months and has always had very close connection with the Young People's Organizations of the Church of England. He was born on a farm and has a background of rural experience, which he claims to have increased by serving entirely in rural areas. He has one child and it is stated that his wife would be capable of carrying out the duties of Matron.

2. Rev. J. Billingsley:

Mr. Billingsley has served in four different parishes for the past 15 years. He is 56 years of age and has one child. He holds a B.A. Degree from Western University. He has a pleasing personality and made a good impression. He is reasonably familiar with farming conditions, as he has served almost exclusively in country parishes.

3. L. J. Patterson:

Mr. Patterson is at present Rector of Church of England in Sarnia. He served for the past six years in rural parishes. He is 31 years of age and has two children.

Mr. Patterson holds a B.A. Degree from Western University. His wife is 26 years of age and before her
marriage she taught school, being a Normal-trained teacher. Mr. Patterson has considerable knowledge of farming, as he was born and raised on a farm and during his university course spent his summers at farm work.

All three of the above-named gentlemen made a very excellent impression on the Committee, and while none of them can be said to have any actual knowledge of Indian work or the work in an Indian residential school, at the same time their educational qualifications and general knowledge appear sufficient to justify the belief that any one of them would probably make a reasonably good principal. However, if a choice was being made, the Committee was unanimous in agreeing that Rev. Mr. Zimmerman should receive first consideration as, while the other two had some advantages, he appeared to be the best qualified.

Before making a decision on the principalship of this school, the committee felt that we should again bring to your attention the suggestion to appoint Mr. J. C. Hill, a member of the Six Nations Band, as principal. Mr. Hill, as you know, has given several years of splendid service on the Six Nations Reserve, as teacher at two or three of the Indian day schools. Mr. Hill is a Normal-trained teacher, 31 years of age. In addition to his Normal training, he possesses the following special certificates: Manual Training; Agriculture and Horticulture, Physical Training; Recreational Leadership and Religious Instruction. Obtaining the agricultural and horticultural certificates necessitated his attending Ontario Agricultural College, Guelph, for 2 years. He also spent two years at the Teachers' Training College at Hamilton. While attending O. A. C. and college, he devoted a great deal of his spare time and the holiday periods in working for a large grocery firm in the vicinity. For the last three years he did all the purchasing. This work necessarily gave him considerable business experience. Mr. Hill's wife is 26 years of age and spent two years at Macdonald College, where she took the Home Economics course. Later, and previous to her marriage, she was employed by the Department for some time at the Lady Willingdon Hospital.

As you are aware, we have approved Mr. Hill's conducting social gatherings for the younger people on the Six Nations Reserve during the past three years. These gatherings were both recreational and educational and Mr. Hill has always had a very large attendance of Indian youth, both male and female. It is reasonable to infer, from their interest in Mr. Hill's courses, that he has the sympathy of his own people, and, if he were appointed principal, the committee believe that he would be strongly supported by the members of the Six Nations Band.

The committee feel, from their knowledge of Mr. and Mrs. Hill, that they are capable of carrying out the duties of Principal and Matron of the Mohawk Institute. In addition, such an appointment would definitely indicate
that the Department is prepared to recognize Indians who have ability and training for positions.

Since 1929, Rev. Mr. Snell, who is just retiring as Principal, has been in charge of this school. He, of course, is an Anglican Minister. Previous to his appointment, however, the principalship of this school had been in charge of lay people for many years.

In brief, the conclusions of the committee comprising Mr. Arneil, Colonel Randle and myself, are:

(1) If the Department feels that the recommendation of His Grace, the Bishop of Huron is to be accepted, we recommend the appointment of Rev. Mr. Zimmerman, effective August 1, 1948; (2) for the reasons stated above, we feel that it would be preferable to give favourable consideration to the appointment of Mr. J. C. Hill.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

26th June 1945.

Dear Sir,

MOHAWK INSTITUTE.

At a meeting of the Court of the New England Company held on the 13th June 1945 the Court had before it the following telegram from the Archbishop of Huron dated 25th May 1945:

"Huron Synod prepared assume full administrative and financial responsibility Mohawk Institute Department agree continue capita grants advise me acceptance such agreement".

You will remember that the lease of the Mohawk Institute granted by the Company to your Department expired on the 1st January 1943 and on its expiry the Company's obligation to pay £1000 p.a. towards the stipend of the Principal of the Institute and its maintenance ceased. In these circumstances it was our intention at first to grant your Department a new lease of the Institute (excepting the Chapel) for a period of 21 years, under the terms of which your Department would be responsible for maintenance, repairs and insurance, and our Company would be responsible for the upkeep of the Chapel and the payment of the Chaplain's stipend.

At this stage the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada (hereinafter called "the Missionary Society") intervened and requested that the Institute instead of being under the supervision of the Diocese of Huron (as heretofore) should be placed under the supervision of the Missionary Society, adding that the Diocese of Huron favoured this change. In view of the Missionary Society's intervention we decided not to execute the proposed lease in your favour at that time, but to await the outcome of negotiations which we understood were progressing between your Department and the Missionary Society. We have now heard from the Missionary Society that in their opinion the historic connection of the Church of England with the Mohawk Institute is sufficiently safeguarded by the draft agreement between your Department and our Company.

The Archbishop of Huron, on the other hand, writes in confirmation of his telegram urging that the Synod of his Diocese should assume responsibility for the administration of the School.
As our negotiations were originally conducted with you we would be glad to hear from you as to whether the Archbishop's proposals meet with your approval. If they do, we assume that we should grant a lease of the Institute in favour of the Diocese of Huron rather than in favour of your Department. If the lease is to be in favour of the Diocese of Huron, we should require to be informed of the name of the trustees or of the trust corporation which holds their property.

Presumably, the Chapel should be included in such a lease. In this connection we wish to set on record that we are still willing and desire to pay the stipend of the Chaplain and to pay for the upkeep of the Chapel, but that we are unable to make further financial provision towards the Institute.

We assume that it will not be necessary for your Department to be parties to a lease in favour of the Diocese of Huron, and that any arrangements reached between that Diocese and your Department (such as for example those relating to per capita grants) will be dealt with separately in some document to which our Company need not be a party. If, however, this assumption is wrong, perhaps you would be good enough to inform us of any terms you would like included in the lease.

We shall be very grateful for any assistance you can give us in this matter, which we should like to see settled at an early date on terms satisfactory to all parties. We are sending a copy of this letter to the Archbishop of Huron, who will no doubt answer our query as to the name of the body or persons who normally hold as trustees the property of the Diocese.

We are, dear Sir,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Governor,
NEW ENGLAND COMPANY.

Ottawa, July 10, 1948.

My dear Archbishop Bourne:

I have received your letter of July 3rd and have noted with interest the suggestions contained therein.

In this connection, I am sending forward for your personal information copy of a memorandum received by me from the Chief of the Training Division immediately following Mr. Phelan's return from Brantford. It occurred to me that it was only fair to Your Grace and to the members of your committee that you should have, before making a final decision, these recommendations before you.

I still find the proposals now before me for the operation and management of the Mohawk Institute somewhat disturbing and I am anxious to do everything humanly possible to make the position of the Minister and the Government clear and unassailable, in case this matter becomes a subject of public discussion. Indications at present are that the Minister will be called upon to defend his position in the House of Commons, regardless of what action we are likely to take at this time.

The agreements reached between the Government and the New England Company have been over a long period of years amicably satisfactory. The financial burden, however, of maintaining this institution has been borne almost wholly by the Canadian taxpayers. The records indicate that during the last twenty-year period we have spent approximately $50,000.00 on the repair and upkeep of the school. These figures do not include the $5,000.00 received annually from the

...New England Company.
New England Company. In addition to this, our per capita grants have amounted to approximately $4,000.00 annually. It will thus be seen that the Government is deeply interested in the school from the standpoint of public expenditure.

The Government too must assume a measure of responsibility for the administration of the school farm. This land is, as you are no doubt aware, the property of the Six Nations Indians and is steadily increasing in value from year to year. Just what position the school would be in if the Six Nations Council decided to have this land subdivided and sold for the construction of houses, I am not, of course, in a position to state. Am I correct in assuming that the Diocese of Huron has never at any time contributed to the upkeep or operation of this particular school?

The proposal that came to me first from Lt.-Colonel Mandle, that Mr. J. C. Hill be appointed principal of the school with the cooperation of an advisory committee—one member of which would be nominated by you—seemed at the time it was made, a rather happy solution to a somewhat involved and perplexing problem. I make this statement remembering that the members of the Six Nations Council, at an interview with me a couple of months ago, were very critical of the institution and particularly of the training in farming and agricultural operations provided for the senior boys. Indeed, one member of the Council expressed the view that the time had come when serious consideration should be given by the Council to the withdrawal of the farm lands, which were not, in his judgment, being used to the advantage of the Indians. It is significant that no formal agreement appears to exist between the New England Company and the Six Nations Council, or between the Six Nations Council and the Government, with respect to the use of the school farm.

I am personally disposed to think that our failure to appoint Mr. Hill to the principalship, in view of his outstanding qualifications and the offers he has received from other schools, will create an unfavourable reaction on the part of the Indians and one that is not likely to contribute to the success of the Institute. Indeed, I feel so strongly on this that I consider at the moment that the matter is one that

........might well
might well be discussed with the Council before the appointment is announced.

While I have no desire to comment upon the action of the Missionary Society of the Church of England, nevertheless in fairness to the Government the position taken by them, namely, that the original lease sent forward to the New England Company for execution sufficiently safeguarded the historic connection of the Church of England in Canada with the Mohawk Institute - will, I feel sure, make the position somewhat embarrassing for the Government when this fact becomes known to the Six Nations Councils. In addition to this, the records disclose that for a period of years the principalship of this school was occupied by a layman, and the Indians are likely to interpret the appointment of a clergyman at this time as discrimination against a man who is exceedingly popular on the Reserve and who has displayed rare gifts of leadership.

The final decision must, of course, rest with the Minister; but before submitting the matter to him for his consideration, I am anxious that conditions at the school and the future of the Institution and its relationship to the Indian population - particularly the Six Nations Indians, with whom the Church of England has been associated in missionary effort for a century or more, should be carefully reviewed by your committee, and a reply sent forward which I can, in due course, submit to the Minister of this Department for consideration.

Yours very truly,

Most Reverend Charles Cesar, M.A., D.D., LL.D.,
Archbishop of Huron,
Bishop Cronyn Hall,
Director.
LON.-N., Ontario.

Ottawa, July 14, 1945.

Memorandum:

In addition to interviewing the applicants for the position of Principal of the Mohawk Institute, I carefully inspected the buildings during my trip to Brantford on July 6 and 7. While visiting the school I was accompanied by Indian Superintendent Randle and we had several discussions, both with the Principal, Mr. Snell, and with the Matron, Mrs. Snell.

Attached to this memorandum is an inventory of the government property on hand at the Mohawk Institute on July 7, 1945. I wish to bring the following matters to your attention:

1. All the farm machinery is in serviceable condition and has received careful attention by the farmer; when not in use, it is stored at all times in sheds for the purpose.

2. We found that while there is a reasonably adequate quantity of clothing on hand for the girls, the supply of clothing for the boys for the coming academic year, including shoes and rubbers, is very limited, and a considerable quantity of the articles mentioned will have to be purchased before September 1.

3. Generally speaking, the school is in reasonably good condition, although some of the rooms require painting. The Principal assured us that the plumbing and heating were now perfectly satisfactory and there should not be any heavy expenditure required in the immediate future.

The south side of the roof of the main barn requires immediate repairs in order to prevent future possible damage. The repairs required should not involve any heavy expenditure.

4. When Mr. Snell became Principal he brought his own car. Later this car was turned in when purchasing a new car. At that time the turn-in value of the car owned by Mr. Snell was $1,000.00. The car at present in use has only a turn-in value of $89.00. Mr. Snell felt that he should be allowed to take this old car, in view of the fact that he had supplied the first car. I thought this was reasonable and approved of such action. As a matter of fact, he has always carried the licence of the car in his own name. When the new Principal is appointed the question will arise about
the purchase of a car for him and I feel that we should purchase the car outright and have it licensed in the name of the School.

6. The truck that we purchased several years ago was completely worn out about 8 or 9 months ago and was sold by the Principal for $150.00, which amount Indian Superintendent Randle considered reasonable. The school actually needs a small truck for carrying garden produce and the greenhouse plants, etc., to the Brantford market. Early consideration should be given to the purchase of this vehicle.

7. I also attach to this report a statement prepared by Mr. Bertho, Departmental Auditor, with reference to the farming operations for the fiscal years 1943-44 and 1944-45. Colonel Randle and I reviewed these and the former considered them reasonably satisfactory, but he feels that a new principal could make a better showing by keeping a stricter supervision on the operations of the farm and greenhouse. The farmer, Mr. Haworth, has been in our employ for several years and has an excellent knowledge of farming. He is a splendid worker. As stated above, the machinery is kept in excellent condition and the farming operations are carried out efficiently. However, there is no doubt that if the Principal gave more personal attention to this phase of the school's work, it would be an encouragement both to the farmer and the gardener to put forth extra effort.

8. In visiting the dormitories it was found that practically all the mattresses are in very poor condition, and I strongly recommend that before the school reopens in September new mattresses be purchased. There is approximately $4,500.00 still remaining in the Trust Fund where we deposited the payments made by the New England Company, and when the new principal is appointed, I suggest that we allow him funds from this account to purchase the new clothing and also use part of this fund for the purchase of mattresses and for other repairs and purchases previously mentioned.

As you are aware, Reverend Mr. Snell and Mrs. Snell have been instructed to vacate the building on July 31, 1945.

Mrs. Smith, who has been acting as assistant matron, is willing to stay until September 1, at which time she will have to be replaced, as she does not wish to return to the school.

Mrs. Thorpe is only acting temporarily as senior dietitian and another appointment will have to be made to this position by September 1.

With the exception of the positions mentioned above, all other members of the staff have intimated that they are willing to remain.

10. By an old agreement between the New England Company and Dr. R. F. Palmer, of Brantford, the latter has been the medical officer for the school for a great many years. He has been allowed only $100.00 a year—which amount has been paid from school funds—for his services. In case of serious illness, pupils are either sent to the Lady Willingdon Hospital on the Reserve or placed in the Brantford City Hospital. In the latter case, accounts are rendered to this Branch for payment. Dr. Palmer is advancing in age and has not enjoyed good health and, when illness occurs, it is frequently impossible to obtain his services. I feel that the medical services at this school should be handled by our Medical Division and the cost of doctor's services should be paid from the Medical Appropriation, in the same manner as at other Indian residential schools. It may not be possible to effect this change immediately, as, from the information I received, it is evident that Dr. Palmer regards the Mohawk Institute as one of his special duties and when he was in good health he visited the school at every possible opportunity.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of 10th July re the Mohawk Institute. When it arrived I hopefully assumed that it would contain your appointment of one of my nominees as Principal. It was therefore a matter of deep regret that such was not the case.

It is hardly necessary to recall the fact that as a result of a conference between yourself, Canon Townshend and Canon Dixon, and of subsequent negotiation with the latter, the "original lease" proposed between the New England Company and your Department was amended. The main amendment was that the Bishop of Huron should nominate Clergy of the Church of England from whom your Department might make a selection of Principal.

Pursuant upon this understanding, you wrote asking me to nominate such Clergy between thirty and forty years of age. The Archbishop made up yourself, I believe, in accord with the above understanding. I followed literally, even to the ages of the men nominated. We here fail to see why this clear arrangement has been followed by a suggestion that a Mr. Hill, whom I did not nominate, should be appointed, which we regard as not in accord with the terms of our understanding. We have, of course, no criticism to make of Mr. Hill who has certain qualifications which I nominated; however, particularly the Rev. W. J. Zimmerman, are as well qualified academically as Mr. Hill, and in other vitally important respects have qualifications which he cannot be expected to possess.

Frankly the reason alleged in favour of Mr. Hill, namely that it would please the Six Nations Council but that failure might result in hostile feeling on the part of the latter, while of course reasonably strong, does not begin to weigh with another fact of which we are thoroughly aware. It is that among the Church of England people in this Diocese, and in
proportionate measure throughout the Dominion of Canada at large, is a rising tide of concern over this matter which at any moment might turn into resentment which without doubt would express itself actively. I beg you to accept this assurance as a matter of fact. Only prompt action along the lines of our understanding will allay this. We are deeply concerned about this aspect of the matter. We should greatly regret if any embarrassment were caused the Minister through this business but if it drags on we are of the opinion that it is likely to be inevitable in any case.

We are surprised that the Resolution of the Executive Committee of our Missionary Society sent you by Canon Dixon should have been interpreted as referring to the "original lease" as "sufficiently safeguarding the historic connection of the Church of England with the Mohawk Institute." The reference in the Resolution is to the "original lease" as amended at the conference above referred to. It was precisely because the "original lease" was wholly unsatisfactory that Canons Townshend and Dixon interviewed you with the result that it was amended. We telephoned Canon Dixon Friday morning asking him to make this clear to you.

It is not surprising that the Six Nations Council should have been concerned over the management of the farm. It is exactly because we recognized this fact and believe that the farm can be made to pay that the Synod of Huron was prepared to assume financial responsibility. Under any of the men I nominated, assisted by the advisory committee, undoubtedly this would be the result.

May I again point out that we have endeavoured to assist you and your Department in every way in this matter. The cable recently received from the New England Company we interpreted as implying a preference for a lease between that body and the Government. We therefore dropped our suggestion that the Synod of Huron should assume responsibility, doing so in the hope that it would facilitate matters.

We also understood that your Department had in mind the name of the Rev. Gilbert Thompson as Principal, until recently head of the Moose Factory School. Assuming this to be true, I conceded this point as well in a postscript to my letter to you dated 3rd July, 1945. Our Committee would be glad to co-operate in any way further but we know of nothing we can do.

It is true that the Synod of Huron has never been called upon to make any contribution to the up-keep and management
Mr. R. A. Hoey,

of the Institute but it has built Churches and maintained Missionaries on the Six Nations Reserve at heavy annual costs, the work of whom has had behind it the influence of the School as one of its most important assets.

As a result of this renewed negotiation I urgently suggest that your Department act at once in making an appointment to this position out of the men interviewed by your official on the 7th of this month. I suggest that if you do not see your way clear to take this action that you receive a deputation from the Synod of Huron to discuss the matter further for which we shall be glad to be informed as to the date and time. The appointment of the Rev. G. Thompson will also be acceptable to us.

The only real danger in this situation is that if it is allowed to drag on we apprehend unsatisfactory results.

I am, with kind regards,

Yours sincerely,

My dear Archbishop Benson:

I am sending forward herewith for your information copy of a telegram sent under date of July 24, 1945, by the Minister to Doctor Isaac Jones, Secretary of the New England Company. The subject matter of this telegram, you will note, is self-explanatory.

In view of the decision reached by the Government and assuming that the New England Company will lease the Mohawk Institute to the Diocese of Huron, as suggested by the Minister, it will be necessary for you to take immediate steps to select a Principal to take charge of the Institute immediately following the resignation of Mr. Small on July 31st. In case, however, you find this task impossible, we shall be glad to have Lt.-Col. Hurdle, with the assistance of the staff now employed at the school, carry on for a month. In this connection, it is unnecessary to state that we shall be glad to do everything humanly possible to cooperate with you in a manner that will enable the classroom work and the farm operations to proceed without interruption.

May we embrace this opportunity to express regret that your representatives and the representatives of the department, including the Minister himself, failed to reach an amicable agreement at the conference held at Ottawa yesterday. There seemed to be throughout the course of the discussions honest differences of opinion that were simply irreconcilable.

We are anxious also to clear up one or two misunderstandings that have arisen during the course of these negotiations, which have been conducted over a period of two or three years. These misunderstandings were inevitable,

......in view
In view of the fact that the limited time at my disposal prevented me from discussing the matter with you personally, in your letter of July 16, 1948, you state:

"It is hardly necessary to recall the fact that as a result of a conference between yourself, Canon Townshend and Canon Dixon, and of subsequent negotiation with the latter, the "original lease" proposed between the New England Company and your Department was amended. The main amendment was that the Bishop of Huron should nominate clergy of the Church of England from whom your Department might make a selection of Principal."

I have already discussed this particular paragraph of your letter with the members of the delegation and intimated to them that the view expressed was completely at variance with the facts. There was no such understanding at any time, nor was the lease ever before the New England Company for execution amended, either by the Government or the New England Company. Such amendments, of course, could only be introduced by the Governors of the Company. The position of the Government from the outset was made clear and we felt, unmistakable. The position was that the Principal of the school should be an agricultural college graduate with pedagogical training and experience both in classroom work and farm management. We did intimate, however, that no such man would be appointed to the position unless he was acceptable to you. A number of tentative proposals were discussed and reviewed from time to time, such as the operation of the school by the M.S.C.C., the operation of the school by the Archbishop of Huron, the creation of an advisory board, etc. These proposals were in their initial stages, not introduced by the Government but by the Church representatives. They were accepted for discussion with the feeling that it was our duty and responsibility to explore every alternative in the hope that a satisfactory agreement might be reached. At the end of our second last conference, Canon Dixon suggested to me that you would appreciate the opportunity of nominating three or four men for the Principalship - any one of whom might be selected. He may have had, in making that suggestion, clergymen in mind, though he did not say so, and inasmuch as the name of Mr. Middleton has been mentioned by Canon Townshend, I concluded that there was a possibility that he might be nominated. I deeply regret that this misunderstanding has arisen. I particularly regret that it has caused you annoyance.

.......The second
The second misunderstanding that appears to have existed from the outset centered around the impression entertained by the Church representatives, that the Government somehow was responsible for this change of policy; whereas, as a matter of fact, such is not the case. The proposal with respect to the new lease came from the New England Company. While, strictly speaking, I have no authority to release copies of correspondence of an official character, I am nevertheless sending forward a copy of the first letter written on the subject received by the Minister from the Company, for your personal information. You will, I feel sure, in the light of later negotiations be deeply interested in the subject matter of this communication. It would be, in my judgment, unfair to the Minister then in charge of the department, the Honourable T. A. Orser, to suggest that he, of his own initiative, at any time advocated a change of policy with respect to the operation of this particular school. Here again, I accept full responsibility. The time at the disposal of the Minister and the senior officials was so limited, the whole responsibility for the negotiations fell upon me. It is just possible that I had neither the experience nor the tact to carry them through successfully, although I made a sincere and conscientious attempt to do so.

An additional misunderstanding arose toward the close of the negotiations. A number of the individuals interested in the matter and, it is just possible the Church representatives - though they did not say so - had a feeling that the department was anxious to appoint Mr. Hill to this position. Mr. Hill, I may state, is unknown to the senior officials of this department and no attempt was made by the Government at any time, directly or indirectly, to place him at the head of the school. In view of his record, however, as a teacher and leader amongst his people, we felt it was only fair that his case should be very carefully and very sympathetically reviewed and his claims discussed with you by Lt.-Col. Handley. It was pointed out that our failure to appoint Mr. Hill without valid reasons would create unfavourable reactions on the part of the Indian population. Our attitude with respect to Mr. Hill was made clear at our last conference, during the course of which I suggested to Canon Townshend that he communicate by phone with Mr. Middleton, with the object of securing, if at all possible, his services for the school. The officials of this branch and particularly myself, have been given a perfectly free
hand in the conduct of the negotiations. No pressure of any kind has been exercised upon us and no attempt was made at any time to build up a case on behalf of any particular individual. The success of the Institution and the welfare of the Indian population was at all times uppermost in our minds.

Apart from these misunderstandings, however, it was a real pleasure to conduct these negotiations with men who seem to be eminently fair, whose courtesy was always in evidence at our meetings, and whose patience appeared inexhaustible. It would be deeply appreciated if you conveyed to Canon Dixon and Canon Townsend, insofar as a sense of appreciation can be conveyed, our gratitude and appreciation for all the help they have rendered us in handling a somewhat difficult and involved problem.

Should the lease be granted, the management and control of the Institution will pass into your hands, whether an advisory board should or should not be created is a matter you, in your wisdom, will decide. The school will, of course, be subject in the future as in the past to an annual audit by an auditor appointed by the Treasury Division of this department and will be subject also to inspection by the Indian Superintendent, Lt.-Col. Randle, and by other departmental officials who may have occasion to visit Brantford in the transaction of departmental business. This is exactly the procedure followed in the schools operated under the auspices of the M.S.O.C., and will, I feel sure, be acceptable to Your Grace.

I must apologize to you for the length of this letter, but I did feel, in fairness to all parties concerned, that these views should be expressed.

With kind personal regards,

Most Reverend Charles Seeger, M.A., D.D., LL.D.,
Archbishop of Huron,
Bishop Grosvenor Hall,
London, Ontario.

I remain,

Sincerely yours,

Director.
