Thank you for your letter of the 25th following
the conference with you of Archdeacon Townshend, Canon Dixon
and Mr. A. B. Lucas. I and they appreciate deeply your kind
reference to them in your letter, which I conveyed to them.

May I refer first to the misunderstandings men-
tioned in your letter. I regret if the expression "original lease"
which occurs in a quotation from my letter to you of 16th July,
should have misled you. Perhaps I should not have used the
expression.

What I referred to was the draft lease sent
to you by the New England Company over a year ago but which has
not been executed. This draft lease was amended or changed, what-
ever the right word is, following a conference of Canons Dixon
and Townshend with you in November, 1944. The particular points
changed or added to it were; first, that any Principal appointed
to the Mohawk Institute should be acceptable to the Bishop of
Huron; secondly that there should be an advisory committee; and
thirdly that the situation should be reviewed at the end of three
years. As a result, however, of negotiation later with Canon
Dixon, the first alteration was again changed to the effect that
the appointment of a Principal should be made out of nominations
of one or more Clergy of the Church of England by the Bishop of
Huron.

This information was conveyed to me by a letter
dated 10th April, 1945 from Canon Dixon in which the following
occurs:

"I have telephoned you this morning at the request of Mr.
Hoey of the Indian Affairs Branch in Ottawa.----------Mr.
Hoey asked that I ask you if you would be good enough to
suggest to him the names of two or three Anglican clergymen
whom he, or members of his staff, might interview with a
view to ascertaining if any of them would be suitable to
carry on the work of the Mohawk Institute.----------Mr.
Hoey would be very grateful if you would send the two or

I enclose a full copy of Canon Dixon's letter.
I responded by nominating men who were to meet your officials in Brantford on May 7th, which, however, turned out to be V.E.Day, and the men could not attend. In response to your telegram, however, of 5th July, I arranged again to have three of my nominees meet your officials in Brantford. Your telegram reads as follows:

"Please arrange to have Reverend W. J. Zimmerman, Reverend L. J. Patterson and Reverend J. Billingsley at Indian Office, Brantford, on Saturday, 7th July at 10.00 a.m. where they will be interviewed by Departmental officials in connection with principalship of Mohawk Institute."

It was regrettable that we could not make any contact with the Rev. Gilbert Thompson so as to have him, as your other telegram of 5th July requested, present with the others. The report of the interviewing committee was most favourable, particularly as to the Rev. W. J. Zimmerman. I trust this clears up any misunderstanding under this head.

As to any misunderstanding that the Department was desirous to appoint Mr. Hill, the only information that I possess on the point is that in your letter to me of 16th July, in which the following occurs:

"In the interval the suggestion has been made that Joseph C. Hill, an experienced teacher, should be placed, for the time being at least, in charge of the School, under the direction of an advisory committee."

My impression is that Lt.Col. Randle, not anyone in Ottawa, was anxious for Mr. Hill's appointment. I take it therefore that there is no serious misunderstanding on this point.

I note the reversion in your letter to the offer of the Synod of Huron to assume financial and administrative responsibility for the Mohawk Institute, provided that the Government continue the per capita grants, and your cable in this connection to the New England Company, a copy of which you kindly enclosed. The outcome of this cable to the Company we shall await of course with interest. It is necessary, however, to state that when the New England Company, in a cable dated 29th June, 1945, to me virtually declined the offer of the Synod of Huron, the matter, so far as we are concerned, was closed, and without further authority from our Synod can not now be re-opened. I am, however, perfectly willing to refer consideration of any communication from the New England Company to the Executive Committee of our Synod which meets in September. What action that body may take I cannot of course predict.

In the meantime I am perfectly willing and able, as suggested in your letter, to select a competent Clergyman to
be appointed Principal, and I nominate the Rev. W. J. Zimmerman, in accordance with the unanimous recommendation of your officials who interviewed my nominees in Brantford on 7th July. They unanimously placed Mr. Zimmerman's name first in their recommendation. Mr. Zimmerman can in all probability take charge of the Institute in a fort-night.

It will be clearly understood by you, however, that obviously the Synod of Huron can not be responsible for his salary or any other financial obligations of the Institute, as we are necessarily unaware of the mind of the New England Company in the matter, particularly as our offer to them was virtually declined, and as in addition to this I have no authority now from the Synod to assume such financial responsibility.

Further, if a competent man is to be offered the Principalship it is only reasonable that he should be assured of the security of his position for at least the three year period mentioned above.

Will you kindly accept my expression of regret that you and we also should be put to so much trouble about this matter, but we are all acting, needless to say, in perfect good faith and with the sole desire for the educational and spiritual advantage of the pupils of the School.

For your information I should add that under date of 28th July I wrote to the Minister of Mines and Resources, expressing appreciation of the considerate reception of my representatives on Tuesday last.

With kind regards,

Yours sincerely,

My dear Archbishop Seager:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 27th and to thank you for the information contained therein.

It is my intention to deal in this letter only with the problems confronting us with respect to the operation of the Mohawk Institute during the period immediately ahead of us. In this connection, it is our hope that Mr. Zimmerman will be free to take charge at the earliest possible date. The Chief of the Training Division will be prepared to go to Brantford on August 10th and 11th to discuss with him, in a general way, the whole administrative set-up, the enrolment of the pupils for the coming academic year, the operation of the farm, the payment of per capita grants, etc. It is my hope that Mr. Zimmerman will be able to visit Brantford for this purpose on the dates suggested.

As I see matters at the moment, neither the Diocese of Huron nor the Government has a legal right to operate the school and certainly no right to incur financial obligations. In view of all the circumstances, however, we would be prepared to continue the payment of the per capita grants, which payment would enable Mr. Zimmerman to draw his monthly salary until a final settlement is reached.

The Minister, with whom this matter has been discussed, is definitely of the opinion that the school should be administered either by the Diocese of Huron or by the Government and has issued instructions to this effect. He is opposed to dual responsibility and dual control and feels that the newly-appointed

.........Principal
Principal should be under the immediate direction of either the Government, on the one hand, or the Diocese, on the other. It is not at all likely that the New England Company will refuse to lease the property to the Diocese. Should they do so, however, or should the Diocese refuse to assume this responsibility, the Minister will then be called upon to decide what action, if any, the Government should take. I am particularly anxious that the classroom work should proceed without interruption and that a final settlement should be reached at the earliest possible date.

With kind personal regards,

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Director.

Honourable and Dear Sir:

Re The Mohawk Institute

This is to express my great appreciation of your kind and considerate reception of the deputation, consisting of the Venerable Archdeacon W. A. Townshend, the Reverend Canon L. A. Dixon and Mr. A. B. Lucas, the former and latter of whom represented me at their conference with you on Tuesday last. We are grateful particularly for the time and attention you gave personally to their representations.

It is regrettable that this matter has been unavoidably prolonged, but you will readily understand our deep concern regarding it. This you will the more readily do since the affairs of its Indian wards in Canada have always elicited an equal and active concern on the part of the Government of this Dominion.

Our delegation made it amply clear no doubt to you and your officials that the Mohawk Institute has always been a religious foundation under the auspices of the Church of England, though not administered by that Church here.

The teaching and influence of the School upon the pupils have been of enormous value in our Missionary work on the Mohawk Reserve which, as in the case of the Institute, has been carried on for more than one hundred years. While the School has always held an open door to pupils of all religious denominations, yet the fact that last school year 75% of the pupils were members of the Church of England is significant showing as it does the successful character on the whole of the Church's work upon parents and forbears of the children. Under such circumstances you will understand fully our deep desire that the School shall be continued as heretofore. Should parents of any children who are not members of the Church of England wish it, we are always willing to set upon what may be called a "conscience clause".
It was therefore a matter of great satisfaction to us when we understood that a proposal which, as we interpreted it, would radically alter the character of the School, was altered in the following particulars briefly stated. First, that the Principal of the Institute shall be one acceptable to the Bishop of Huron. Secondly that the Principal should be assisted by an advisory committee, and thirdly that the arrangements should be reviewed at the end of three years.

As a result, however, of a conference in Nov., 1944 with the Acting Director of Indian Affairs by the Reverend Canon Dixon, General Secretary of our Missionary Society, and the Reverend Canon W. A. Townshend from this Diocese, this proposal was further altered in respect with the first provision. Instead of the Principal being "one acceptable to the Bishop of Huron" it was agreed that the Principal should be appointed by the Department from nominations made by the Bishop of Huron or ordained Clergy of the Church of England. This alteration was communicated to me by Canon Dixon in a letter dated April 16th, 1945, in which the following occurs:

"I have telephoned you this morning at the request of Mr. Hoey of the Indian Affairs Branch in Ottawa, .............Mr. Hoey asked that I ask you if you would be good enough to suggest to him the names of two or three Anglican Clergymen whom he or members of his staff might interview with a view to ascertaining if any of them would be suitable to carry on the work of the Mohawk Institute...........Mr. Hoey would be very grateful if you would send the two or three names to him direct."

This information was further corroborated by a request from Mr. Hoey that I arrange to send three Clergy to Brantford to be interviewed by his officials with the above object. This meeting was unfortunately arranged to take place on May 7th. At that moment we were expecting the unconditional surrender of Germany and all Clergy were directed to be in their parishes to meet any announcement of this sort. My three nominees therefore were unable to attend. Later, however, under date of July 8th, 1945, Mr. Hoey telegraphed me to have my nominees meet his officials in Brantford on July 9th. This was done and I have before me the report to the Acting Director of the interviewing officials with regard to my three nominees as follows:

"All three of the above named gentlemen made a very excellent impression upon the committee and while none of them can be said to have any actual knowledge of Indian work or

......the work
"the work in an Indian Residential School, at the same time their educational qualifications and general knowledge appears sufficient to justify the belief that any of them would probably make a reasonably good Principal. However, if a choice was being made the Committee is unanimous in agreeing that the Rev. W. J. Zimmerman should receive the first consideration".

I may add that Mr. Zimmerman is a specialist in Religious Education with an M.A. degree in that field, and that he was born on a farm and worked as a farmer in his early days. He also possesses outstanding administrative abilities. I am sure you will agree that it was not unreasonable that I should expect one of my nominees to have been appointed at once. This, however, has not yet been done.

At one point in the lengthy negotiations the Synod of Huron offered to assume financial and administrative responsibility for the Mohawk Institute, on the understanding that the Government should continue the per capita grants. The Synod took this action hoping that the suggestion might facilitate action already long delayed. I need hardly say that such an offer is of a highly generous character as the Synod of Huron was prepared to accept a serious financial risk though we believe that the business side of the Institution can be made to pay. This suggestion, however, did not appear to be acceptable to the New England Company and was therefore dropped, and without further authority of our Synod must remain closed. Our understanding, in consequence, of the present status of the matter is reverent to the three-fold proposal quoted above.

I trust that this somewhat vexatious matter may now very soon be closed satisfactorily. Again expression appreciation for your great consideration, I am,

Faithfully yours,

(Sgd.) Charles Huron
Archbishop of Huron.

My dear Archbishop Seager:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 26th, in which you discuss the decision reached at a conference on the Principalship and operation of the Mohawk Institute held at Ottawa on Tuesday, the 24th instant.

For reasons that will readily occur to Your Grace, I am naturally anxious that no misunderstanding should arise with respect to this decision and the cablegram sent forward by me to the New England Company, copy of which, I understand, is already in your possession.

The information before me indicates that the Mohawk Institute and a small parcel of land, approximately nine acres, is the property of the New England Company and that the larger farm, usually referred to as the school farm, is the property of the Six Nations Band of Indians. It would appear that this school has been leased by the Government over a long period of years and that the entire costs of operation and maintenance, with the exception of an annual grant made by the New England Company, now discontinued, were borne by the Government. The selection of a suitable Principal with the necessary tact and experience is, therefore, in my judgment, an exceedingly difficult and exacting task. The Principal in this case occupies a unique position, in that he is not only responsible for the operation and management of the farm, but is responsible as well for the employment of the staff, the organization of the classroom work and the religious instruction provided for the pupils.

It is true
It is true, the classroom work is inspected by the Public School Inspector for the County, but the control exercised until now by the Diocese of Huron and by this Department appears to have been more or less nominal. The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch feel that in view of the large annual expenditures involved, and in this regard I am wholly in agreement with them, the administration of the Institution should be more closely knit and that the Principal should be constantly subject to direction either by the Government or by the Diocese.

The Department would be prepared to undertake this direction immediately, but only on the understanding that an experienced agricultural college graduate with pedagogical training were selected for the Principalship. This proposal, however, did not appear at all acceptable to your representatives. Consideration was then given to the operation of the school under your own immediate direction, extending to you full freedom of choice in the selection of the Principal on the understanding that this Department would continue to pay, in the future as in the past, the regular per capita grants.

It is altogether likely that the New England Company will be prepared to enter into an agreement with Your Grace for the operation and management of the school. I do feel that in view of all the circumstances the Diocese of Huron should assume this responsibility. The work accomplished at the Institute has not been satisfactory in recent years. The change of policy now suggested, that is, operation either by the Government or by the Diocese would, I feel sure, result in more efficient administrative effort and prove more satisfactory to all parties concerned.

May I embrace this opportunity to thank you very heartily for your personal interest in this matter and for the appreciation expressed in your communication.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

Your letter of 1st August received. I at once had Mr. Zimmerman communicated with who is now prepared to meet your Chief of the Training Division on 10th August as you suggest. As you know, I telegraphed you asking for the hour. Mr. Zimmerman can take charge almost at any time. I expect him in to see me today.

Certainly neither the Department nor the Diocese has a legal right to operate the School, but it must be carried on and I appreciate the action of your Department in the matter.

I note your statement that the Minister is of the opinion that the School should be administered either by the Diocese of Huron or the Government, and has issued instructions to this effect, and is opposed to dual responsibility and dual control. Certainly we heartily agree with this opinion. It has been our sole desire from the beginning of this negotiation that the Government should administer the Mohawk Institute under the terms arranged for, the chief of which is that I should nominate Clergy of the Church of England for appointment as Principal but that the appointment should be with your Department.

It is true that at a certain point of the negotiations the Synod of this Diocese offered to assume responsibility for its administration and financing, but this was done only in the hope that it might facilitate the conclusion of the matter. It was a very generous action on the part of the Synod and the assumption on its part of a very serious responsibility. The reply of the New England Company to this offer was not favourable. Therefore the matter was dropped and it reverts to the original suggestion referred to.

I share your anxiety that the class room work particularly should proceed without interruption. When Mr. Zimmerman is appointed, as no doubt he will be shortly by the Minister, all other details can be happily worked out I am sure. I take it from your letter that the formal appointment of Mr. Zimmerman as Principal of the Mohawk Institute will be received by me and him at an early date.

With kind regards,

Memorandum:

MR. HOLT,

As directed, I again visited the Mohawk Institute on August 10 and 11.

On the latter date, accompanied by Indian Superintendent Randle, I interviewed Reverend Mr. Zimmerman, who has been nominated by His Grace the Archbishop of Huron as Principal of the Mohawk Institute.

At the outset of our conversation, I realized that Mr. Zimmerman was not thoroughly aware of the situation as it exists at the present time. Consequently, acting on your approval, I showed him a copy of the letter written by the minister to Archbishop Seager. The purpose of this letter is that the Department is willing to have the Diocese take over the Mohawk Institute, on the understanding that the only financial responsibility on the part of the Department will be the payment of the per capita allowance, and if there are any deficits on management, these will be paid by the Diocese of Huron. Mr. Zimmerman stated that he was not aware of this condition and after considerable discussion he advised Colonel Randle and myself that it was his intention to immediately interview His Grace the Archbishop of Huron with a view to having his own (Mr. Zimmerman's) position fully clarified. He intended to see the Archbishop either Saturday or early this week.

Colonel Randle and I discussed the past, present and future situation at the Mohawk Institute with Rev. Mr. Zimmerman in a very complete manner. I feel that if he receives the assurance that he personally desires from His Grace the Archbishop, regarding the financial situation, he should make a capable Principal. He appears to be anxious to come into our work and gave us several very constructive ideas, regarding the improvement of the school management in the interests of the Indian pupils. We agreed with these and offered him certain other suggestions. If he decides to remain it is also his intention to recommend to His Grace the appointment of the advisory committee which has been previously discussed. Mr. Zimmerman stated that in the event of such a committee being appointed by His Grace, he considered that it should include both the Indian Superintendent - Colonel Randle - and the Chief of the Six Nations Council. During the course of the day we visited all parts of the building. Colonel Randle and I believe that before turning over the building to the Diocese of Huron we should redecorate the children's dining room, the boys' playroom and the Principal's living room and dining room. There are also some minor repairs required to the electric wiring in the boys'
playroom and the plumbing in the kitchen. We estimate that all this work can be done for an amount not exceeding $1,500.00. At the present time there is approximately $1,400.00 left from the funds provided by the New England Company; consequently, this expenditure can be taken from that amount. This would leave a balance of approximately $1,900.00 on hand, from which we could handle the monthly payments of Miss Hardie's superannuation, until such time as we receive special funds for the purpose from the New England Company, as promised by the Governor of the New England Company in a letter dated June 16, 1943. In view of new instructions this afternoon, I have written to Colonel Randle, authorizing him to proceed immediately with the improvements just mentioned, at a total expenditure not exceeding $2,500.00. It was arranged that the future monthly payments to Miss Hardie would be made through the office of Colonel Randle, instead of through the office of the Mohawk Institute.

Philip Nolan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In pursuance to a telegram, dated 4th August, from Mr. P. Phelan, reading as follows:

"Please have Rev. Mr. Zimmerman report at Indian Office, Brantford, at 2 P.M., August 10th."

Mr. Zimmerman was there as requested.

On that day, Friday the 10th, Mr. Zimmerman met Colonel Randall and discussed with him the matter of the Principalship of the Mohawk Institute. According to Mr. Zimmerman's report to me, the discussion was held on the basis and assumptions of previous discussions at which a general understanding was arrived at. At the interview it was assumed that Mr. Zimmerman was to be appointed Principal by the Government on the basis of previous discussions.

The next day, August 11th, Mr. Zimmerman interviewed Mr. P. Phelan in Brantford on the same subject. The discussions took place on the same assumptions as with Colonel Randall on the previous day, and included those involved in the management of the School by Mr. Zimmerman as Principal. He was given the keys of the place, introduced to members of the Staff as the new Principal and the matter was apparently finally settled.

At the close of the interview, Mr. Zimmerman naturally inquired as to his position in the matter, for example, by whom was he to be appointed, from what source would he get his salary, who was to be responsible for expenditures, etc., etc. Much to his astonishment, he was told by Mr. Phelan that he was to look to the Archbishop of Huron for all these things since the Synod of Huron was taking over the responsibility of financing and managing the School. To my amazement, Mr. Zimmerman so reported to me later.

It will at once be perceived by you that the above statement was made in the face of the facts set forth in my letter to you dated July 27th in which I stated, in the clearest possible terms, that we have no authority from the Synod of Huron to assume any financial responsibility whatever. Similar statements were made in my letter to the Minister on other matters dated July 26th.
It may well be, of course, that Mr. Phelan was unaware of the facts of the case, for example that no communication has been received from The New England Company regarding the Lease to us, and that, even if this had been the case, we have no authority from our Synod to negotiate with them.

You will at once perceive that it is absolutely impossible for me to transact business in the face of a contradiction such as the above.

I am bound to add also, that I consider that both Mr. Zimmerman and myself have been placed, as a result, in an entirely false position, and, in addition, the former has been put to considerable expense and personal anxiety.

I am, with kind regards,

Yours sincerely

Ottawa, August 20, 1945.

My dear Archdeacon Townshend:

I am today in receipt of a letter from His Grace, the Archbishop of Huron, the last paragraph of which reads as follows:

"As Chief Executive Officer of the Diocese of Huron, I therefore find it impossible to continue direct communication with the Department in this matter. I have appointed the Ven. Archdeacon Townshend of this office to represent me. Archdeacon Townshend will no doubt be glad to receive and attend to any further communication and arrangements in the matter."

The Archbishop in this letter refers to Mr. Phelan's interview with Mr. Zimmerman at Brantford on August 10, and to an apparent misunderstanding, not the first of course which has arisen with respect to the operation of the Mohawk Institution. Mr. Phelan, I may state, had explicit instructions with regard to the policy of the Government prior to his visit to Brantford and took with him a copy of the Minister's letter to the Archbishop dated July 31, 1945. If you will read this letter, I feel confident you will experience no difficulty in understanding clearly the exact stand the Minister has taken.

In a strictly legal sense, neither the Government nor the Archbishop has a right to operate the Mohawk Institute in the absence of a duly executed lease. In as much, however, as per capita grants for the operation of this school have already been voted by Parliament, the officials here took the position and the Minister agreed with them the school should reopen on September 1, under the guidance and direction of the

...........
Archbishop of Huron and on the understanding that the per capita grants would be paid by this Department. This is the only position the Minister could legally or consistently take, and this is the point we have reached as the result of prolonged discussions and negotiations covering a period of two years or more. The present Minister appears to be determined that dual control of the Institution should cease; that the Principal should work under the immediate direction of either the Archbishop on the one hand, or this Department on the other.

If I have made the position at all clear, would it be possible for you to visit Brantford on Thursday next, August 24, and discuss the matter again with Mr. Phelan and Colonel Randle. If the school is to open on September 1, an attempt should be made to persuade either Mr. Zimmerman or Mr. Hill to take charge of the school on a temporary basis. None of the parties concerned are in a position, at this date, to guarantee permanent employment, and I feel sure the Archbishop appreciates this fact.

You might ask Mr. Phelan to wire me from Brantford immediately following your negotiations.

Yours sincerely,

Honourable and Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge your letter of 8th July in reply to mine of the 25th. Vacation time has made it impossible readily to summon the proper committee to discuss the matter of the Mohawk Institute.

I have taken the liberty of making this letter a personal one in order to speak more freely, particularly as we have shared fully your anxiety that no misunderstanding shall arise as to the Principalship of the School.

As I wrote in interpreting your letter as conveying a virtual ultimatum in this matter. As it appears, you offer us a choice between running the Institute ourselves or having the Indian Department do so along the lines originally proposed. There can be an ultimatum however only in appearance, as we have no authority from our Synod to accept responsibility as I said in my letter to you of 8th July.

In any case your letter makes it clear that the information on which you have based any decision in the matter is inadequate and in some respects inaccurate and I am sure you would not wish this to be the case. For example, your statement that

"the entire costs of operation and maintenance, with the exception of an annual grant made by the New England Company, now discontinued, were borne by the Government" and later in your letter "in view of the large annual expenditure involved"

is not correct. I have the most definite information from the former Principal in a report to me that the fact is the exact opposite of this statement. The following are some extracts from that report:

"I cannot be definite concerning the first two or three years of my tenure of office but I do know that for the last twelve or thirteen years all repairs, improvements, additional equipment, machinery, and the hambushes and boys' Master's cottage were paid from New England Company grant. All the stoves (heating etc.) and equipment as well as the building behind the schoolhouse included in these repairs is the new boiler which was installed fairly recently as well as the one which it replaced."

I am further informed that the Department now has on hand a considerable sum of money contributed by the New England Company for the Mohawk Institute. It is, of course, most important that you should be in possession of this information.

The second inaccuracy in the information you have received is contained in your statement that

"The control exercised until now by the Diocese of Huron and by this Department appears to have been more or less nominal. The officials of the Indian Affairs Department feel that —— the administration of the Institute should be more closely knit and that the Principal should be constantly subject to direction either by the Government or by the Diocese."

.....The fact is
The fact is that very close knit control over the administration of the School has always existed. The Principal has been constantly subject to the control of the Indian Department. The only power to which the Diocese of Huron has possessed any control, at any rate for the greater part of a quarter of a century, has been the nomination of the Principal. Once appointed, however, the Diocese has had no control over him as Principal whatever; the Government has had complete control. It is precisely this position which we so strongly advocate should be continued. As far as we understand the matter no good reason exists to the contrary. After all, the Indians of this Dominion are wards of the Government, not of the Church.

A third inaccuracy in your information may be stated as follows. The original proposal of the Department (to which I understand the New England Company assented) was that an experienced agriculturist and College graduate with pedagogical training be selected as Principal. We did object to this proposal on the ground that it would have radically and completely altered the whole character of the School, which for one hundred and fourteen years has been on a religious foundation and the system of doctrine and worship of the Church of England. Surely such a proposal is utterly unreasonable and unjust unless the most urgent facts and considerations should compel it. None such exist.

The inaccuracy in your information in this reference lies in the fact that in your letter you pass immediately from this proposal to refer to the suggestion that the Church of England in Canada become responsible for the School, without any reference to the several conferences and much correspondence which took place in the interim.

The proposal was made that the Church of England in Canada, through its Missionary Society, should undertake this responsibility. The Society, however, through its Executive Committee, refused to do this. Upon this fresh negotiations were opened with the Department, the last of which was on 26th July when Mr. Zimmerman met myself and the officials of your Department and yourself. As reported to you, the result of this consultation was a complete understanding in the matter, with the sole exception of the question of the appointment of the Principal. Since then, however, the Acting Director requested me to send Mr. Zimmerman to Brantford to consult with Colonel Randle and Mr. Phelan with a view to his appointment.

At one point in previous discussions the Synod of Huron did offer to become responsible for the School, and asked the New England Company to this effect. That body did not accept the offer, and, as I informed you in my letter of 26th July, five days previous to yours of the 31st,

"This suggestion, however, did not appear to be acceptable to the New England Company and was therefore dropped and without further authority of our Synod must remain closed."

I regret the length of this letter but it is necessary to refer to your cable to the New England Company dated 26th July as follows:

"Impossible for Government to reach agreement with Archbishop of Huron with respect to Principalship and operation of Mohawk Institute. Suggest you enter into agreement with the Diocese of Huron for operation of school on understanding Government will continue to pay the regular per capita grants but will assume no additional financial responsibility."

This message was sent by you after a lengthy conference with my representatives on 26th July. During the conference my representatives made it perfectly clear that the Synod of Huron has given me no authority whatever to assume such responsibility again as I wrote you on 26th July. As no reply to your cable that I know of has been received from the New England Company with regard to the matter, there is nothing for us to consider from that source.

I am afraid I must object to the wording of the cable which states that:

..... "Impossible for
Impossible for Government to reach agreement with Archbishop of Huron with respect to Principalship and operation of Mohawk Institute.

The first part of this statement with respect to the Principalship is substantially correct; the reference to "operation of Mohawk Institute" is surely inaccurate. As stated above, a complete understanding appeared to be arrived at in the course of the conference on 24th July as to this aspect of the matter, the only question left being the appointment of the Principal.

With the exception of the original radical proposals already referred to and to which we objected we have followed every direction of the officials of the Department literally and faithfully. Delays and changes have been caused solely by the officials of the Department.

As an instance of this I enclose a copy of a letter written by me to the Acting Director of Indian Affairs under date of 17th July which I trust you will be good enough to peruse. It is but one instance of several. The latest instance of this sort of thing occurred last Thursday when two representatives of myself were asked to go to Brantford to consult with Mr. Phelan. They did so and spent the day in vain in that City since Mr. Phelan did not put in an appearance.

In conclusion I earnestly urge, though I know, from my own experience, how great the claims must be upon your time and energy, that you take occasion to possess yourself of the actual facts of the case.

All we ask is that the School be continued as heretofore, the Principal being appointed by the Department out of whatever number of nominees by the Bishop of this Diocese the Department may desire. We ask, and have a right to ask, that we receive at least the same consideration in respect of the Mohawk Institute as is accorded to the United Church of Canada in its Indian Institute at Mount Elgin and to the Roman Catholic School in Nova Scotia. I again respectfully urge that you give this matter some close attention and that it be settled along reasonable lines at once.

I am apprehensive that it may become an issue, not only between the Synod of Huron and the Department, but between the whole Canadian Protestant organization and the Department. Such a prospect is to me utterly distasteful to say the least of it, and the last thing to be allowed to develop.

I appreciate the attention you have given to this matter and trust that it may soon be settled along reasonable lines.

I am, with kind regards,

Sincerely yours,

(Sgd.) Charles Huron

According to Mr. Zimmerman's report to me, the discussion was held on the basis and assumptions of previous discussions at which a general understanding was arrived at. At the interview it was assumed that Mr. Zimmerman was to be appointed Principal by the Government on the basis of previous discussions.

My dear Archbishop Seager:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of August 25th and have carefully reviewed the information contained therein.

In this connection, may I quote from a telegram dated August 25th, received by me from the New England Company. This telegram reads in part as follows:

"Would be grateful if status quo could be continued for interim period till end of year when we hope to send out representative of company to interview all parties and settle matter."

It is my understanding that a clergyman, the Reverend Mr. Zimmerman, nominated by you, has been temporarily placed in charge of the school and will, as doubtless, act as Principal until a representative of the New England Company visits Canada toward the end of the present calendar year. In view of this arrangement, which appears to be satisfactory, no useful purpose could be served by a lengthy discussion of the matter at this time. May I, however, offer one or two comments on certain statements contained in your last communication.

You refer to my statement that the entire costs of operation and maintenance, with the exception of an annual grant made by the New England Company, now discontinued, were borne by the Government and you express the opinion that this statement is incorrect. A careful review of the records here, including the statements of the auditors, indicates that this statement is true in every particular. If, however, you can inform me of any organization other than the Government and the New England Company which contributed to the upkeep and maintenance...
of this school, I shall, of course, be glad to have the information.

I still feel that the control of this Institute by the Government and by the Diocese of Huron in recent years has been in a very real sense nominal. A clergyman nominated by the Archbishop of Huron is not likely to take kindly to instructions issued to him by the Department and certainly is apt to resent such instructions when issued by our officials. The reports on the work of this school, including farming operations, now on file, are far from satisfactory.

You refer to two men representing yourself who visited Brantford to consult with Mr. Phelan, Chief of the Training Division, but who did not succeed in meeting him. You will readily appreciate that the negotiations with respect to the operation of the Huron Institute, conducted with you by the Department for a period of two years or more, have made serious encroachments on the time of our staff. Mr. Phelan was visiting western Ontario on a brief holiday when the Director of Indian Affairs asked him to proceed to Brantford in an attempt to secure a Principal prior to the reopening of the school on September 4th. This, Mr. Phelan did, using his holiday period for this purpose and without cost to the Department, and later proceeded to London, where he discussed the matter with Canon Townshend. I am particularly anxious that no misunderstanding should arise with respect to Mr. Phelan's action on this occasion. In view of the fact that he was under no obligation during his holiday period to undertake this work, his action was, in my judgment, commendable in every sense.

May I state that I have little to add to the views expressed by me in my letter to you dated July 31st. I find it difficult to understand how any misunderstanding can arise with regard to the position I have taken and the views I have expressed with respect to the administration of this school since the matter was first brought to my attention.

Yours sincerely,

I write to confirm the despatch on the 25th August 1945 of a cable which we sent to you in the following terms:

"Your cable received and considered by our Company. Position still obscure since you suggest lease in favour of Huron Diocese and Archbishop suggests lease in your favour. Would be grateful if status quo could be continued for interim period till end of year when we hope to send out representative of Company to interview all parties and settle matter."

This cable was sent after a meeting of the Court of the New England Company at which your cable and a letter from the Archbishop of Huron dated the 11th July 1945 had been considered. It was in this letter that the Archbishop had suggested that the lease of the Mohawk Institute should be in favour of the Dominion Government. He considered that this course would be satisfactory to him because the Dominion Government, the Missionary Society and he had agreed to certain proposals one of which was that the Principal of the Institute would be appointed by your Government on his recommendation. We gather from your cable that the proposals particularly on this point have broken down in practice.

This matter has now been proceeding for a very long time and we are anxious that it should be settled at an early date, if possible to the complete satisfaction of your Government, the Missionary Society, the Archbishop and our Company. At present, however, the matter does not appear to be approaching a solution rapidly, and we think that the best way to overcome the delays caused by the slow post and the difficulty caused by our lack of knowledge of the problems which have so far prevented your Government, the Missionary Society, and the Archbishop from reaching agreement is by personal action. In particular, we feel insufficiently instructed as to the various advantages and disadvantages and the financial consequences which would result from the lease being granted (a) to the Dominion Government or (b) to the Diocese of Huron.

In these circumstances we consider that our best course would be to send out a representative of the Company to interview all parties and settle the matter. This we hope to do at Christmas.

My dear Archbishop Beager:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 26th, in which you discuss the decision reached at a conference on the Principalship and operation of the Mohawk Institute held at Ottawa on Tuesday, the 24th instant.

For reasons that will readily occur to Your Grace, I am naturally anxious that no misunderstanding should arise with respect to this decision and the telegram sent forward by me to the New England Company, copy of which, I understand, is already in your possession.

The information before me indicates that the Mohawk Institute and a small parcel of land, approximately nine acres, is the property of the New England Company and that the larger farm, usually referred to as the school farm, is the property of the Six Nations Band of Indians. It would appear that this school has been leased by the Government over a long period of years and that the entire costs of operation and maintenance, with the exception of an annual grant made by the New England Company, now discontinued, were borne by the Government. The selection of a suitable Principal with the necessary tact and experience is, therefore, in my judgment, an exceedingly difficult and exacting task. The Principal in this case occupies a unique position, in that he is not only responsible for the operation and management of the farm, but is responsible as well for the employment of the staff, the organization of the classroom work and the religious instruction provided for the pupils. It is true, the classroom work is inspected by the Public School Inspector for the County, but the control exercised until now by the Diocese of Huron and by this Department appears to have been more or less nominal. The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch feel that in view of the large annual expenditures involved, and in this regard I am wholly in agreement with them, the administration of the Institution should be more closely knit and that the

NOV 13 1945
Vice-Regal Couple Sign Historic Queen Anne Bible

The signatures of the Earl of Athlone, soon to end his term as governor-general of Canada, and Princess Alice have been affixed to the historic Queen Anne Bible belonging to the Six Nations Indians of the Grand River Reserve near Brantford, Ont.

The Bible, printed in England in 1709 during the reign of William of Orange, bears the signatures of all the governors-general since 1867 and those of all members of the royal family who have visited Canada.

Due to the war, the Governor-General and Princess Alice were unable to visit the reserve, and Lt.-Col. E. F. Randle, superintendent of the Six Nations Indians, brought the Bible to the capital on behalf of the Iroquois tribes which form the Six Nations.

During the American Revolution, the Six Nations remained loyal to the Crown and fought with the British. For safety, the Bible and plate were buried in the woods.

When American independence was recognized, the Iroquois joined the "Empire Loyalists" in the exodus to Canada and were given title to the lands which make up the Grand River Reserve as compensation for the loss of their territories in New York.

Chapel Replaced.

King George III decided to replace the chapel Queen Anne had given the Indians. Shortly after the revolution, a party of the Indians returned to the forest cache, retrieved the Bible and plate and smuggled it across the border for the new chapel known as "His Majesty's Chapel of the Mohawks."

Among the signatures are those of King Edward VII, then Prince of Wales, 1860; the Duke of Connaught, 1887; King George V and Queen Mary, 1931; Princess Patricia of Connaught, 1944; Prince Albert, Duke of Windsor, then Prince of Wales, 1919; Prince George, later Duke of Kent, whose signature is undated, and King George VI and Queen Elizabeth, during the royal tour of 1939.

EDITORIAL AS FEB. 1946

Mohawk Institute

The Local Council of Women has recently made a worthwhile community service by drawing public attention to conditions at the Mohawk Institute here and obtaining constructive recommendations for their improvement.

The school for Indian children is housed in an old building which for many years has been in need of some renovation. The present state of affairs has been good and there has been considerable need for modernization among several lines.

This proposal to add home economics and manual training specialists, as well as music and art teachers to the staff is well worth consideration. Not least among the other suggestions, particularly those calling for better physical culture and recreational provisions, library, study, and required classroom equipment. It would appear, in addition, that the question of health supervision should receive more attention.

None of the advice offered by the Local Council of Women reflects adversely upon any particular upon the competence of the Principal of the Institute or her staff, but as a whole the situation is described as making good bricks without straw, making it possible to run a good school without essential physical plant, equipment, and educational accommodation.

It is to be observed, also, that the so-called religious and parochial feeling in the Church of England in Canada has been superseded in recent years by the Federal Department. Upon the latter, therefore, must fall the main responsibility for correction. It should not have been tacitly admitted by the local Member of Parliament, Mr. Macdonald, who, unfortunately, has directed attention to the matter and has taken it to the proper offices.

The results in this connection have been immediate and gratifying, and Mr. Macdonald has been able to announce that an official of the Indian Affairs Department will be here early next week to make an inquiry into the matter.

Particular care of the youngsters attending the Institute is a matter of prime concern, and it is to be anticipated that the Ottawa authorities, once the case has been fully reviewed, will proceed to remedy any deficiencies as promptly and completely as possible.
L.C.W. Urges Action To Better Conditions At Mohawk Institute

Recommendations for improvement and better educational and recreation building improvements at the Mohawk Institute's school for Indians aged 14 and under were approved by members of the L.C.W., M.P.A., at the meeting held Thursday afternoon in the Canadian Red Cross, William St.

A report was read out of reports which were presented by members of the L.C.W. Executive Committee. They had made an inspection tour of the institute and had been conveyed to the general meeting the conditions under which the Indians lived, including insufficient clothing and other facilities.

NO BLAME PLACED

It was made abundantly clear, however, through the reports presented by the members and through the clarifying addresses of Ven. Archdeacon A.J. Clarke, Bishop of the Anglican Church, and Mr. Macdonald, that the conditions did not lay upon the shoulders of the Anglican Church, but had surrounded the religious aspects of the school for many other ways for years; nor of the New England Company in providing land and buildings and which has been foreclosed, and would cease to exist for a time, pending annual grants from the Department of Indian Affairs of the Dominion Government.

The Council seemed to agree, as it was stated, from the condition of the school and from the entirely insufficient grants which were given by the Government, for the upkeep of the school.

RECOMMENDATIONS

The recommendations made by the Council were as follows:

(1) The addition of highly trained instructors so that boys might be taught woodworking, mechanics, and other trades, and the basic principles of trades.

(2) The addition of music staff.

(3) The installation of physical education facilities, a recreation room, and a library.

(4) The addition of a well-equipped library.

(5) The addition of a quiet, supervised study room.

(6) The addition of proper equipment for the school.

The above recommendations were made by Mrs. George Williams, the Education Convenor, who inspected the school and presented a detailed report.

Miss M. Milne, R.N., Health Convenor, also reported on the conditions at the school. She pointed out that though there were no regular clinics conducted among the young Indians, sufficient dental and medical care would be soon inaugurated.

FOREIGN PRESSMENT

Members of the present staff of the Mohawk Institute and the past staff members were highly commended for their fine efforts despite the dire conditions under which they had to work and it was emphasized that in no way were they being criticized for the situation.

Archdeacon Clarke told the L.C.W. on the manner in which the investigation had been made and the importance for taking such keen interest in a matter which appeared to have been overlooked because it was so close, and apparently unimportant.

He stated that he would take up the affair with the proper authorities in Ottawa. But, he pointed out, to improve the situation, funds would be required from the Government, and months would be needed before such a request could be granted.

Mr. Macdonald asked that the findings be put in a detailed report and, if possible, an estimate of cost be included.

"NOBODY'S BABY"

Archdeacon Clarke said he wished to make it plain to members of the Council that the situation was definitely not the responsibility of the Church. He named the three responsible parties who were responsible for the care of the school, but stated the main responsibility for the situation "seemed to be nobody's baby."

Mrs. Willoughby told the members that there was dire need for bedsteads, blankets, towels and wash cloths, tablecloths, furniture and various other things.

"To bring the situation before the proper authorities," she said, Mrs. Cogswell, who stated she realized obtaining sufficient funds to give the school an overhaul the school from the basement up, would take considerable time.

The matter was left in the hands of Miss Macdonald to confer with the Department of Indian Affairs and the Anglican Church, and that drastic measures were necessary to alleviate conditions in the shortest possible time.

Meanwhile, it was stated, contributions would be gratefully received by Miss W. Macdonald Works Convenor, and her committee.

Mohawk Institute Conditions Are To Be Investigated

Quick action has followed the meeting of the Local Council of the L.C.W., M.P.A., to investigate prevailing at the Mohawk Institute and a plan was brought to light. This morning Mr. Macdonald, President of the Board and Honorary Speaker of the Mohawk Assembly, presented the matter to the government. The question was to be put before the Board of Directors at its next meeting to Mr. A. Hovey, Director of Indian Affairs, and requested his cooperation.

Mr. Hovey stated that Mr. Macdonald's plans for the school would be sent to Brantford the early part of next week. Plans will be made and the Inspector will consult with members of the Executive of the L.C.W. and others concerned," he stated.
R. A. Hoey, Esq., Director,
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

There are attached for your information, local press reports and comment in connection with the Local Council of Women's action over the Mohawk Institute, - which from press reports you are already advised of.

In case you feel something has recently gone wrong, this office would assure you that everything is in normal good order at the Institute. The Principal and his staff have been attending to their duties, and the care, comfort and well being of the children has received first consideration, as far as circumstances and facilities permit. In fact the energy and interest shown by the Principal has resulted in probably the children receiving the best all-round feeding and care in years.

So this office can only express regret that it is not possible to advise you what is behind this added interest by an organization who have never previously shown the slightest interest - or why they should have placed the spotlight on the Mohawk Institute in rather an unfair manner.

What is known is that members of the Local Council of Women made a very cursory visit to the school a few weeks ago on the pretence they wished to supply some recreational equipment for the children - but instead spent the brief period of their visit questioning Mrs. Zimmerman on various matters and features concerning the school's administration.

One member also visited this office in my absence and asked for Mr. Moses - and there was a long discussion over the school - but what was said is not known, though Mr. Moses states he said little, as Mr. Hilton Hill, the former Chief Clerk, happened in at that time and did the talking.
On hearing of this incident I informed the Local Council of Women that they wanted any information from my office it would be preferable if they consulted the responsible person - and they did apologize.

The President also called here, but I was on the reserve, so finally we only had an unsatisfactory telephone conversation from which it was obvious they had a wrong picture, but were determined to make it public. I suggested they send a written report and recommendation to the Department direct, and see what resulted, - but I was informed that the local Member was attending their meeting and they would accept his advice.

You might also wish to know, Mr. Zimmerman was in the hospital on the occasion of their brief visit to the Institute - but the Local Council of Women never had the courtesy to discuss the matter at any time since with him.

The recommendations made by the Local Council of Women are highly desirable and commendable, and are all likely to have been discussed among us and planned to some degree, but are dependent largely on increased grants by Parliament - and by all-round good management by the Principal.

Had the Local Council of Women taken this action in past years it would have been more understandable, as the then Principal was sadly lacking in every quality to make the Institute a happy home for children,- but to do it at this time when it should be obvious to everyone that the Department is changing; the Principal was intent on an all-round improvement, seems rather like an attempt to be sensational and gain publicity rather than be helpful and just, with their case built up on a somewhat limited knowledge and one-sided viewpoint of the Institution.

Yours truly,

Lt.-Col. E.F. Handle,
Indian Superintendent.

Mohawk Institute Investigated By Division Chief

Brantford, Feb. 26 (Special) — Philip Phalen, chief of the Training Division of the Department of Indian Affairs, has arrived here to investigate conditions at the Mohawk Institute, where members of the Local Council of Women have charged Indian children are living under unsatisfactory conditions.

Recommendations for improvements in physical and academic lines were made by the Local Council of Women following a report by J. M. Anguish, secretary of the Council for Social Agencies, on his report on conditions at the Indian children's school. Mr. Anguish said children eat off "sadly battered and filthy" enamelware, have no decent room for recreation nor enough clothing to give them a change of underwear each week.

"Wastefully Inadequate"

Mrs. George T. Cockshutt, president of the women's council, read the report to Mr. Phalen at a meeting here today. The report said the building, as a whole, is sound, but dingy and drab. Facilities are woefully inadequate, and tables and benches in the dining hall are unpainted.

"The sleeping quarters at the time when Anguish visited the Institute consisted of large narrow rooms into which cats were crowded," the report said. "Toilet facilities, which were inadequate for the number in each dormitory, were situated in one corner and surrounded only by cats. The rooms were devoid of lockers or shelves for keeping personal belongings."

The report added that recreation rooms were almost unfurnished and were damp, cold and cheerless. All rooms, it said, were spotlessly clean, but the staff was inadequate. As a result no manual training is given here and there is no capable housemaid, according to the report. There is no provision for a medical checkup of the children.

No Blame Attached

No blame was attached in the report to Rev. Mr. Zimmerman, principal, or his wife. Appeals have been made to Brantford churches for clothing and bedding for the children.

Need for health protection for Six Nations Indians was stressed by Dr. W. L. Hutton, M.O.H., head of Brant County health unit, in a letter to Miss Cockshutt.

"The Brant County Health Unit," the letter said, "was set up within the Township of Tuscarora, in which the reservation is located. For the protection of the rest of the county the reservation should receive the same kind of treatment as the rest of the county. However, local authorities on the reservation are in favor of it. The consent, cooperation and financial aid of the Dominion Government is necessary."

The city and county pay $1.50 per head for such treatment. Coal on the reservation would be perhaps $2 per head, $3 if dental treatment was included, because of conditions there now.

Memorandum:

Mr. HUNT,

Acting on your instructions, I went to Brantford this week and spent Tuesday and Wednesday, February 26 and 27, investigating charges made by the Brantford Local Council of Women regarding the Mohawk Institute.

As you will recall, the action of the Brantford Local Council of Women was first brought to your attention in a telephone message from Mr. E. Ross Macdonald, M.P., and you informed him, in reply, that I would go to Brantford.

Immediately on arrival in Brantford on Tuesday morning, I phoned Mr. Macdonald, and he stated that the Local Council of Women had arranged a meeting for 2:30 P.M. on Tuesday in the Red Cross Room. He further advised me that it was their intention to have a newspaper reporter present at the meeting. Following our conversation, I discussed the situation with Mr. Macdonald, and he agreed to communicate with the President, pointing out my position. Mr. Macdonald and I arrived at the meeting at 2:30 and a reporter from the Brantford Reporter was present. I told him that I would not agree to make any statement to him or to the members of the Women's Council who were present. He said that under these circumstances he would withdraw, and he did so. The only publicity that the meeting obtained was an account of the charges the Local Council of Women consider should be made in the conduct of the Mohawk Institute.

The President of the Brantford Local Council of Women is Mrs. George T. Doakshutt and she called on the chairmen of the various committees to report their findings.

It appears that the Acting Principal, Reverend J. J. Zimmerman, was ill in the hospital for a period of approximately 3 weeks in the month of January. During that period a group of members of the Brantford Local Council of Women went to the Mohawk Institute and interviewed Mrs. Zimmerman. They told her that they had approximately $1,000.00 to spend and expressed a desire to assist the Mohawk Institute. In order to do so, they asked Mrs. Zimmerman what was required. It is evident from what later newspapers wrote, that Mrs. Zimmerman considered the ladies were friendly towards the Institute and consequently she pointed out to them several things that could be improved. However, in subsequent newspaper articles they either accidentally or deliberately changed the tenor of her remarks. For instance, she evidently told the ladies that the school was short of clothing and blankets. This statement was apparently reported by the
Ladies to the effect that the children had no clothing and no blankets. These latter statements are certainly incorrect. It is true that the school has no large surplus stock of either clothing or blankets, but from personal observations of Colonel Randle and myself, I can assure you that the children are comfortably clad and that sufficient blankets are available for all the children in residence.

During the course of the meeting I pointed out to the members of the Local Council of Women that the observations contained in newspaper reports and which apparently emanated from them did not convey a true picture of conditions at the Mohawk Institute, but it was practically impossible to have them recede from the position they had taken.

The Council of Women expressed the definite opinion that the children were not receiving sufficient medical and dental care. One of the members stated that in her opinion the school should be visited by a doctor daily. I pointed out to them that a doctor is on call at all times, that there is a trained nurse on the staff of the school and that in the event of any child becoming ill outside side such child is removed either to Lady Williston Hospital, or to the Sir Robert McLaughlin Hospital in Brantford. I also mentioned that we hold dental clinics at regular intervals and in the event of any child developing sudden dental trouble such child is immediately taken to one of the local dentists in Brantford.

In spite of the very definite statement that I made in this regard, they still expressed the opinion that additional medical care was necessary.

The statement was also made that a member of the staff should sleep close to the dormitories. I pointed out to the Local Council of Women that the bedroom of one of the male members of the staff is directly beside the boys' dormitory and that the sleeping quarters occupied by the Principal and his wife are immediately outside the girls' dormitory. It would appear, from the statements they made in this particular regard, that they did not inspect the building very carefully.

The Local Council of Women consider that the following additions should be made to the staff (a) a highly trained domestic science teacher, so that young girls might receive training in home-making, child-training, house nursing and kindred subjects; (b) a manual training instructor; and (c) a music and art teacher. In regard to these recommendations I pointed out to them that all the girls are taught cooking and sewing under the direction of a member of the staff. It is true that this staff member is not always a trained domestic science teacher but is a person well qualified to teach cooking. We had a manual training teacher at this school two years ago. Since then we have been unable to engage a qualified manual training teacher, owing to circumstances beyond our control. The appointment of music and art teachers to the staff is a matter of opinion. Certainly, such teachers are engaged at few, if any, of our schools.

The Council of Women complained regarding the general condition of the school. It is true that the building was erected
many years ago, but it was rebuilt in 1923. The playrooms available for the children are not as spacious as they might be. The complaint of the Council of Women regarding the size of the dormitories is unfounded, as these are sufficiently large to provide the necessary air space for the number of children enrolled.

As you are aware, the 21-year lease of the Mohawk Institute, given to the Department by the New England Company, expired in 1943. One provision of that lease was that the Principal should be a Minister of the Anglican Church. When that lease expired in 1943, the New England Company agreed to re-lease the building, but in their new lease made no mention of the necessity of appointing a Minister as Principal. You will recall that His Grace the Archbishop of Huron took exception to this clause and stated that in his opinion an Anglican Minister should be appointed in view of the long association of the Anglican Church with the Mohawk Institute. As a result of the stand taken by His Grace, the lease has not been renewed by the New England Company, either with the Department or with the Diocese of Huron. In view of this position, I pointed out to the Council of Women that in my opinion the Department could not legally spend any money on the Mohawk Institute. I further pointed out that if the lease was eventually concluded between the Department and the New England Company, the Department would then be responsible for repairs and improvements required to the building. On the other hand, if the lease was concluded between the New England Company and the Diocese of Huron, this Department would only be responsible for payment of the per capita grant. Archdeacon Clarke, of Brantford, had given an interview to the paper, pointing out that the Church of England was in no way responsible for any situation that might arise at the Mohawk Institute. In view of his statement I thought it advisable to have an interview with him, and the Indian Superintendent, Colonel Randle, and I called on Archdeacon Clarke at 11.30 on Wednesday, February 27th. We discussed the whole matter and pointed out to him the situation and expressed regret that he had seen fit to express the position of the Anglican Church. I told him politely that I thought it would have been preferable to make no statement to the press on the matter unless it was made by either Archdeacon Townshend or Mr. Lucas, who were the gentlemen originally appointed by His Grace the Archbishop of Huron to conduct negotiations with the Department. I pointed out to Archdeacon Clarke the amount which we have expended on the building since the beginning of the lease in 1922 and reminded him that general conditions at the Mohawk Institute had deteriorated, due to the neglect of the former Principal, Reverend H. E. Small, whose services were dispensed with in July last year. Archdeacon Clarke agreed with me that Mr. Small's services had not been satisfactory. I also reminded the Archdeacon that the present Principal, Rev. S. J. Zimmerman, had been acting Principal, nominated by His Grace Archbishop Leger. In view of this, it is hardly fair for the Church to divest itself of all responsibility.

Colonel Randle accompanied me on a complete tour of all sections of the Mohawk Institute. As stated previously in this report, the building is not modern but is comfortable. It is kept in a very cleanly manner. Probably the worst fault is that the recreation rooms for both boys and girls are in the basement, and while an effort is being made to do so, it is difficult to make these rooms as attractive as all concerned would like to have them. However, Mr. Zimmerman is making an earnest endeavour to improve conditions in this regard. The toilet facilities adjacent to the
dormitories are not as extensive as they should be, but owing to the construction of the building, improvements in this particular regard could not be made without very heavy expenditure. Adequate toilet and bathroom facilities are provided in the basement for the girls and adequate toilets and shower baths are provided in the basement for the boys.

In going over the building, we found that the doors to the fire escapes were closed with panic bolts, which could be easily opened. The fire escapes are iron steps, protected by iron railings, and were free from snow and ice.

Colonel Handley and myself suggested to the Principal certain improvements that could be made at once in the playrooms in order to make them more attractive. The Principal promised to have this matter receive immediate attention.

The public school inspector was interviewed but he did not know any qualified vocational teacher whose services could be obtained at present. It may be impossible to secure such a teacher before September 1st. I instructed both Colonel Handley and the Principal to continue their efforts to secure a manual training teacher, there is a building suitable for manual training and we have sufficient supply of tools in it. When I told the Local Council of Women that the school was equipped in this manner, they expressed surprise as they had not been shown this particular building. It is a separate building from the main building.

Conditions generally at the Mohawk Institute have improved since Nov. 8th, Zimmerman took charge. Many of the complaints made by the Local Council of Women are the result of the unsatisfactory services of Rev. H. W. Bell during the last two or three years of his term as principal.

A peculiar feature of the whole affair is that Mrs. Cookshutt, President of the Local Council of Women, has never interviewed Mrs. Zimmerman at any time. She visited the school during the Principal's absence in hospital owing to illness and interviewed Mrs. Zimmerman who happens to be new to the work and probably said more than she should have done. She did not interview our Indian Superintendent but instead rushed into print and had the opinions of the Local Council of Women broadcast over the local radio station. Mrs. Cookshutt is a very determined lady and will probably keep up the agitation if she can continue to obtain the support of the other members of the Council. At the conclusion of the meeting, since the ladies met Cookshutt's request and that a committee (presumably including herself) should be allowed to visit the Mohawk Institute at periodic intervals in order to ascertain if the improvements they had suggested are being put into effect, I told her very definitely that we were not prepared to give her any such privilege. I pointed out that the school is visited two or three times a week by Indian Superintendent Handley and that other government officials inspected at regular intervals. I trust my decision in this regard meets with your approval.

Philip [signature]
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Zimmerman:

This gesture on their part is a very kindly one, but, as I intimated to you when I was in Brantford, it is felt that you should decline it, with thanks.

The greater portion of the land surrounding the school is the property of the Six Nations band. Actually the Department is not in a position to make any financial contribution to the school until the situation is fully clarified. We are still hopeful that a representative of the New England Company will visit Canada shortly, at which time we hope to adjust matters on a permanent basis.
