MEMORANDUM:

- THE ACTING DEPUTY MINISTER -

I am enclosing herewith for your information copy of a report received by me from Mr. Phelan following his inspection of the Mohawk Institute at Brantford, Ontario.

Director.
Say Criticism of Institute Unfounded

For the first time in history, a Supreme Court Grand Jury Tuesday made a thorough inspection of the Mohawk Institute, local Indian School, and, according to the presentment, handed to the presiding judge, Hon. Mr. Justice Urquhart, noted that "considerable criticism has been made against this institution. In our opinion, we did not find any evidence to warrant such criticism."

The report also referred to the present Principal, Rev. W. J. Zahniser, saying, "The Principal showed us through the building and appears to have everything in smooth running order. We wish to commend him on his capable management."

The report recommended, however, that "the playroom floor be repaired and that chairs be provided for use in the girls' and boys' dormitories. It would be a nice feature if some public-spirited organization supplied the chairs."

The Grand Jury visited the County jail and found everything in first-class condition. The report recommended that a new defecator be purchased for the jail kitchen and that a toilet be installed in a more convenient place for use of jail guards and staff. New caving throughout was recommended for the jail house and that a new porch be placed over the outside entrance to the jail kitchen to prevent formation of ice and other hindrances.

CHILDREN'S SHELTER

The Children's Aid Society building was visited and the jurymen were escorted through the building by Superintendent J. P. Temple. Everything was found to be in "excellent shape," but the heating system in the children's sleeping quarters was recommended. In view of the fact that recent Grand Juries had examined or visited the hospital and Home for the Aged and Indians, no visit was made today to these institutions. The report was presented under signature of the Foreman, Clark Merritt. His Lordship lauded the sentiment.
L.C.W. REPLY
RE FINDINGS OF GRAND JURY

In view of the press report Wednesday of the resignation of the Supreme Court Grand Jury of Mohawk Institute and the report that it was said that "considerable criticism has been directed against the School but in our opinion we did not find it necessary to justify such criticism," Mrs. George Cockburn, Chairman of the Investigating Committee of the Local Council of Women who previously submitted the criticisms and recommendations, told The Star.

"The L.C.W. Investigation Committee reported conditions as found at the Mohawk Institute, having in mind the welfare of the children and bringing the School up to present standards. Some two months of consideration preceded the drawing up of the recommendations now before the Indian Branch of the League of Women Voters' sources in Ottawa.

"Members of the Committee appointed by the L.C.W. to make the report on the Institute included the following investigators: Three former school teachers; a woman who is a specialist in child psychology; two nurses from the Mohawk Institute and who specialized in dormitory management and family welfare workers; a member of the Children's Aid Society for 29 years; a member of the Board of the Victorian Order of Nurses; and a woman of the Institute who is a registered nurse."

The recommendations made were as follows:

1. The addition of trained domestic science teachers in homemaking, cooking, home nursing, dietetics and sanitation.
2. The addition of trained instructors in sewing so that they might learn woodworking, hand crafts, knitting and crochet.
3. The teaching of music and art.
4. The installation of a well-equipped library.
5. The addition of a quiet, supervised study room.
6. Providing of adequate room equipment and laundry facilities for the boys and girls.
7. The addition of a supervised recreation room for boys and girls.
8. The installation of better lighting facilities for all children.
9. The addition of more accommodation and teacher supervision in the dormitories.
10. A trained dietician to plan and supervise balanced diets for the children.

The committee also pointed out that the lack of regular dental and regular medical check ups, especially for tuberculosis, typhoid and diphtheria were extremely hazardous. They suggested that the Institution be brought under the Canadian Health unit so that these services could be more effectively provided.

It was stated that an infirmary to segregate the children who were ill from the others, was also needed. Clothing for all children, bedding, dishes and cutlery were found to be in need. They suggested that the Indian Affairs Department be asked to turn over to the Institute the surplus blankets and mattresses to remedy the bedding situation.

Barber shops were installed in two of the dormitory factories to save workers' time.
Jury Foreman Defends Stand on Institute

The inspection of the Mor- eau Institute by a Grand Jury selected some weeks ago by the bar of the Spring Ad- visors of the Supreme Court of Ontario was not in any way a "pre-arranged affair" and there was no politics in it at all, said Jury Foreman, interviewed by The Expositor at the Institute Thursday night. He said he had been told to make a report on the institution made.

In his presentation to the presiding Judge, Hon. Justice Murray, the Grand Jury noted there had been considerable criticism of the Mor- eau Institute in view of the publicity recently given to the welfare of the children in the Institute and the children in the Children's Shelter, and you won't find much criti- cism," he concluded.

Mr. Merritt stated that the classroom work was conducted in the forenoon, and practical work in the afternoon. The boys work in the outside and the girls helped in the business end whenever they were needed. "The teaching being best when I am doing best," he added.

The boys are expected to do their work and furniture is a con- stant threat. A large amount of redecor- ation needs to be done and that action needs to be taken so that the building will be fit to do its job from basement to roof.

MEDICAL SERVICES

He also stated that the hospital is run by a jury that will stand to medical service a great deal.

MAKES DEFENSE OF MOHAWK INSTITUTE

Ven. Archdeacon A. L. G. Clarke, Rector of Grace Church, speaking Tuesday at the meeting of the Synod of Huron in London, Ont., defended the Mohawk Institute, similar as the Anglican Church was concerned.

He told the Synod that the Institute was in good shape, excellently run and thoroughly clean, with a better and larger staff than ever before although it needed some repairs and equipment. He said there was nothing wrong with the Institute and that it had never been closed down. It had been attacked through a small group of well-meaning women who had circulated stories which had most unfairly reflected on the Anglican Church.

My dear Sir Francis,

I am sending forward herewith a copy of the revised lease, which I trust you will find reasonably satisfactory.

The amendments inserted by me have been prepared hurriedly, without legal advice. It is just possible that the solicitors of the New England Company may want to revise the phraseology I have used, and I want them to feel free to do so.

May I direct your attention particularly to paragraph (1) on page (2), with respect to the appointment of the Principal. I have also deleted the last paragraph of the lease already approved by the Company, for the simple reason that I can see no purpose in this reference to the Mohawk Chapel, and it seems to me that this paragraph is somewhat inconsistent with the reference to the Mohawk Chapel in section (1) of the lease; in any event, this is simply my own opinion and should the legal advisers of the New England Company feel that this particular paragraph should form part of the lease, we shall have no objection.

May I embrace this opportunity to thank you very heartily and very sincerely for the courtesy and sympathetic understanding of this problem displayed by you at the time of your visit. The Minister would, I feel sure, expect me to thank you on his behalf for the work you have accomplished and for what appears to be a very satisfactory solution to a problem that was at times rather perplexing and always more or less delicate.

My dear Archbishop,

I am much obliged for your letter of the 31st August, which sets out fully your point of view regarding the Mohawk Institute.

The Institute has certain special features which differentiate it from the other residential schools for Indians in that the Institute itself and some ten acres of land together with the Chapel are the property of the New England Company and have been leased to the Canadian Government, while the farm, which has been worked with the Institute, is the property of the Six Nations Band of Indians.

The New England Company has felt, therefore, that the Indian Department is the proper authority to be responsible for the administration of the Institute, provided that the historic connection of the Church of England with the Institute is sufficiently safeguarded.

It appears, however, that difficulties have arisen in recent years in that Mr. Snell regarded himself as primarily responsible to the Bishop, who had appointed him to the Principalship; and that he was disinclined to act on the instructions of the Indian department, who felt that his administration of the Institute was far from satisfactory.

It was in view of this situation that the Minister expressed the view stated in his letter of 31st July, 1945, which you quote, that the administration of the Institute should be more closely knit and that the Principal should be constantly subject to direction either by the Government or by the Diocese, so as to avoid any danger of a dual control.

I am

My dear Sir:

May I trouble you with a letter as brief as possible with regard to our Mohawk Institute School for children on the Reserve at Brantford.

It has been a deep satisfaction to note the great improvement of conditions which is going on there, but which is not by any means yet complete. We are particularly gratified and grateful for the active co-operation of your Department in building up this School. We see no reason why it should not be an example to all such institutions in the course of the next year or two.

May I, however, draw your attention to the fact that when the School at Muncey under the United Church was closed, forty children were sent to the Mohawk and are now there. No extra provision, however, appears to have been made for them except of course in regard to per capita grants. No provision was made for example for extra blankets, sheets and towels, the provision of which is quite beyond the present finances of the institution. With the Autumn and Winter drawing on the matter is of great importance.

May I also draw your attention to another fact; that until the Agreement between The New England Company and the Indian Department has been executed, and so far we have no word that this is the case, it is impossible for us to apply to our Women's Missionary Society to provide their share of the children's clothing as we have undertaken to do. This aspect of the matter is, of course, obvious. In the meantime we are informed that there is immediate need for one hundred suits of underwear for boys and seventy-five assorted sweaters on account of the approaching cold weather. There is, of course, urgency in this matter therefore and we should be grateful for some financial assistance in this connection. Once the Agreement, however, is executed, I will be in a position to write to the President of our Women's Missionary Organization with regard to clothing for the children.

I am, with kind regards,

Yours faithfully,

Dear Mr. Cochrane:

In a letter dated June 16th, 1943 addressed to Mr. Phelan of the Welfare and Training Service, you stated that the New England Company was prepared to provide the existing pension of £150 per year for Miss Hardie.

Following a personal interview with me last summer, Sir Francis Flood wrote to me on August 24th, 1946. His letter reads in part as follows:

"I feel sure that the New England Company will be very glad to continue its long association with the Mohawk Institute by providing funds for the grant of scholarships to deserving Indian pupils to enable them to proceed with high school studies, and I have no doubt that the Company will wish your Department to undertake the administration of such funds as we can provide."

I would appreciate it if you would let me know if you have found it possible to give further consideration to the above proposal and if so, what scholarships you are prepared to allow. We would like to commence these as soon as possible so that the first scholarships granted in this manner may be awarded at the end of June, 1948, the close of the coming academic year.

Memorandum:

Re: Mohawk Institute.

On the occasion of my recent visit to this school, Indian Superintendent Randle and myself discussed with Rev. Mr. Zimmerman, the application that he has received from a number of the members of the staff for increased salary. We went over the finances of the school very carefully and at the present time it appears that the school is in a reasonably satisfactory financial condition.

For instance, all disbursements incurred during the quarter ended September 30th, 1947 were paid and when the principal received his per capita allowance for that quarter, it meant he had funds on hand to pay his expenses during the December quarter. In other words, he was practically working on the basis of one quarter ahead.

Mr. Zimmerman appeared to be very satisfied with his present staff with the exception of Mr. Coates who was being let out. In view of the increases in wages which is general throughout the country, I feel that it is necessary for him to make some increases at least and I, therefore, prepared the letter appearing on this file authorizing certain increases. At the present time these increases will not affect the financial condition of the school to any great extent as Mr. Coates, who has been the gardener, will not be replaced until March or April, 1948.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Mrs. Davies is trying to give the children a balanced diet. One of the boys said the other day that one of the things which keeps him at the school is the good food. He plainly stated that if there was a return to the former meals as served a number of years ago he would not stay.
He is the type of boy who would take to the road. I am concerned about whether if we could make any savings whether we would run into more truancy or not. I am spending a great deal of time on this matter of food.

Last year I bought a number of bags of potatoes at 50 cents per bag. The other day Mr. Haworth was offered $3.00 for all the potatoes per bag. We did not sell any since I do not know what we shall have left over. The bread cost us $50.00 per month alone extra. We use about 1 bag of potatoes alone each day. When you add the extra cost for these few items alone you can see what a difference it makes.

To illustrate again our problem. According to the Mohawk creamery butter sold to customers cost on March 25/46 39 cents per pound. On November 25/47 butter cost 64 cents per pound. That same month we used 100 pounds of butter and it cost $2.68 as against $29.00 for 100 pounds in March of 46. The school used the same amount 100 pounds but the cost had risen $25.68 while the amount used shows no change. My records illustrate this rise in connection with one item after another.

According to the I.Q test made by Mr. Webster the lad caught in the act is 16 with an I.Q rating of 7-11 (Mental Age). What form of punishment will you permit for boys who persist in this filthy business? I have tried to reason with them and employ various approaches. For the lad who will not respond to the normal decencies of life through the normal approaches is there any other way than to resort to the pleasure pain principle?

The other week he went up to the store and stole two guns. (Toy). He also went through Mr. Barton's home and stole a watch and used a 22 rifle. Another lad went up to the store and stole a purse. I do not want to see this one boy go to some jail eventually. I may belong to the old school but I believe that if we were permitted in these extreme cases to spank their posterior ends it might do some good. If you strap them on the hands they go down to the playroom and say they were not strapped hard. What do you think of it?

Dear Mr. Zimmerman:

I have for answer your letter of December 6. Some of the points have already been dealt with. I appreciate your frankness in broaching this matter of corporal punishment. We have corporal punishment regulations which we recommend to principals who are having difficulty with this matter. This often applies to new principals taking over a school and who wish to ascertain a sound policy to be followed in this regard. These regulations are as follows:

1. That corporal punishment will be used only where all other methods of disciplining a pupil have failed.

2. That corporal punishment will be administered only on the hands with a proper school strap (regulation 15" rubber).

3. That the maximum number of strokes on each hand in no instance exceed four in number for male pupils of over fourteen years of age and in proportion for boys under that age.

4. That all such corporal punishment be administered in the presence of the principal or by the principal.

5. That a Corporal Punishment Register be maintained at the school containing the following headings:

   (a) Date,
   (b) Reason for Punishment,
   (c) By whom administered,
   (d) Witness,
   (e) Signature of pupil punished.
6. That this Register be made available for inspection by all Indian Affairs Branch officials visiting the above.

You will find in the long run that it does not pay to strap pupils anywhere but on the hands. The above regulations "systematize the administration of corporal punishment and the very form which the pupil has to go through is in itself a deterrent. In other words it is the application of somewhat the same principle as used in British Courts or in the "Orderly Room" in the Army.

I hope that this will assist you in the solution of your problem.

Sincerely yours,

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Honourable and Dear Sir:

As Bishop of the Diocese of Huron in which the
Lahawk Institute, a school for Indian Children is situated,
I naturally feel a certain responsibility for its welfare.
I am therefore taking the liberty of drawing your atten-
tion to its present situation and needs.

I should say that I have asked certain men,
including the Principal of the School, to advise me in
the matter. That they are competent persons will appear
from the fact that one of them is the Assistant Super-
intendent of Schools in the City of London, another a
member of the Ontario Government's Royal Commission on
Education, and a third the Principal of a school in one
of our larger towns.

Let me say at the outset that I am happy to note
that conditions in the School have notably improved in the
past two or three years, both as to the personal welfare
of the children and as to farm productiveness and adminis-
tration generally. This has been due largely to the work
of the Principal, Mr. Zimmerman, to the active co-operation
of the Department and the material assistance of the Church.
This latter has been very substantial.

The recently developed policy of the Department
to strengthen the Day School System on the Reserves, a
policy which we cordially welcome, has however, as of
course your Department is fully aware, almost completely
changed the character of the School in Brantford. As a
result, a new situation now exists which would appear to
call for very definite developments in both policy and
action.
Until recently the School has served almost exclusively the families on the Mohawk Reserve, whether members of the Church of England or not, many of whose children were trained in the School in the ordinary way and not in the Day Schools. Now, however, the Institute has become a School mainly for underprivileged children, either as a result of broken homes or because of antisocial tendencies in the children themselves. Moreover, they are now drawn from a far wider field than the Mohawk Reserve. Such children require quite different treatment from those under normal conditions such as have prevailed until recent years.

In view of this fact, we regard certain changes as urgent. Even a casual study of the ages of the children and their academic progress, and a study of the School entrance results would indicate that there are very few children who are far below the achievement of normal children of the same age. No doubt this is due to emotional instability, immature mental ability or perhaps in some cases, definite mental defectiveness. These children cannot make satisfactory progress in a regular classroom. Might I suggest that a survey of the mental ability of these children might be made and if found necessary, special "opportunity classes," similar to those established in the public schools in Ontario towns and cities, be organized. This, of course, would require specially trained teachers, special equipment and above all, an enrollment of no more than twenty for each teacher. This, of course, would increase the cost of tuition, but it is clear that these special children cannot be educated for good citizens in ordinary classrooms.

With respect to the rest of the children, they appear to have far too much time on their hands owing to the fact that in certain grades they are only taught for part of the day. These include those five or six, whose instruction should be, in our opinion, continued throughout the day.

As is to be expected under the circumstances, as already mentioned, the average intelligence of the pupils in the School is much lower than it was a few years ago. A few, however, with high intelligence might be trained as "student leaders" to assist in discipline, in games, promotion, etc.

My dear Archbishop Seager:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of February 10th in which you submit for departmental consideration a number of proposals with respect to the operation of the Mohawk Institute at Brantford.

You are no doubt aware that a Special Parliamentary Committee is at present engaged in a review of Indian administration in Canada. It is my hope that the members of this Committee will undertake a complete revision of the Indian Act during the course of the present session and submit its final report to Parliament. In view of this fact, I naturally hesitate at this time to express an opinion with respect to the status of teachers employed at residential schools. I may state, however, that the advisability of increasing the per capita grants is now under consideration and I am hopeful that the amount necessary to increase the grants to an extent that will enable the Principals of residential schools to meet their financial obligations and operate the schools more efficiently will be approved by Parliament in due course. In addition to this, I am asking the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch, in cooperation with the Ontario Department of Education, to undertake a survey of the pupils enrolled at the Mohawk Institute. Mohawk Institute - Health Conditions

Last week Dr. Palmer phoned me from Montreal. He had intended to visit Ottawa to discuss various points concerning the Mohawk Institute with officials here, but his wife took sick which changed his plans and he decided to return directly home. He, therefore, called me before leaving Montreal.

He stated that in the past few months they have had three epidemics; chickenpox - 21 patients; mumps - 80 and measles - 20. Concerning facilities at the school, he does not like the way the milk is handled. There is no means of cooling milk and the Brant County Inspector of Health has done bacterial counts on the milk and has found them high and there is apparently a threat that the health authorities may make a definite move on discontinuing this milk service until improvements in the handling of it are made. He further states that the children get the skim milk and that the butter fat, 700 lbs. a month, is sold, and he feels that the children should have the benefit of this.

He also states that the ice for use at the school is obtained from the canal which has been condemned for use as drinking water.

The third complaint is with reference to the dishes that are used in the dining room. They were originally white enamel but apparently are so chipped and deteriorated that he feels it is somewhat of a health menace.

I advised Dr. Palmer that this school was administered by the Welfare and Training Division of Indian Affairs and that we had no financial responsibility in making any alterations in the school. Dr. Palmer impresses this office as a very efficient medical man. He is very conscientious in his work and I am sure that it was for no other motive than to improve health conditions of the school that he has made these complaints. I told him that I would let you know about this and I think we have previously discussed the same items. If you feel this should be discussed further, please give me a call.

The complaint about the cream being sold and the children getting only skim milk, - is an old one, and perfectly true.

Actually, the Principal is like all previous ones; he finds it hard to make ends meet with constantly increasing costs in all directions, - food - salaries - maintenance, - so he endeavours to increase revenue by selling the cream taking part of the value back in butter for the use at the school.

Personally, the writer has always objected to this practice, and so have Departmental officials, - but as it was never insisted that it be discontinued, it goes on; - and then in recent years some authorities have stated that skim milk has considerable food value.

With reference to your File 32-0-1(E.1) of the 8th of June concerning a memorandum received from Dr. Falconer with reference to the Mohawk Institute, - the following comment is made.

The writer interviewed the Principal and gave him assistance and direction as to the manner in which the milk could be better cooled and lower the bacterial count to satisfactory dimensions.

Actually, the final and only remedy which will satisfy the local health authorities is the installation of a modern milk cooling plant, such as farmers are installing everywhere.

The secret of fresh flavoured milk, free from odours, sourness and high bacterial count, is the taking off within about 20 minutes of milking, of the animal or natural heat, so the temperature is reduced to about 50°. In addition it must be poured into a covered can through a special type of paper strainer disc, which prevents even small particles of dust and dirt getting into the milk can and assisting in raising the bacterial count.

Cold water surrounding the cans with frequent stirring while the milking is being done, with what is known as plungers, - breaks up the cream crust which holds in the animal heat, and quickly reduces the temperature.

This was all explained to the Principal and he was to obtain the plunger, discs, etc., and see that the men kept cool fresh water around the cans throughout milking. This is now being done, and should reduce complaints, - if done as efficiently as it is possible to do, - until such time as we can install a proper cooling system.

Honourable and Dear Sir:

As Bishop of the Diocese of Huron in which the Mohawk Institute, a school for Indian Children is situated, I naturally feel a certain responsibility for its welfare. I am therefore taking the liberty of drawing your attention to its present situation and needs.

I should say that I have asked certain men, including the Principal of the School, to advise me in the matter. That they are competent persons will appear from the fact that one of them is the Assistant Superintendent of Schools in the City of London, another a member of the Ontario Government's Royal Commission on Education, and a third the Principal of a school in one of our larger towns.

May I say at the outset that I am happy to note that conditions in the School have notably improved in the past two or three years, both as to the personal welfare of the children and as to farm productiveness and administration generally. This has been due largely to the work of the Principal, Mr. Zimmerman, to the active co-operation of the Department and the material assistance of the Church. This latter has been very substantial.

The recently developed policy of the Department to strengthen the Day School System on the Reserves, a policy which we cordially welcome, has however, as of course your Department is fully aware, almost completely changed the character of the School in Brantford. As a result, a new situation now exists which would appear to call for very definite developments in both policy and action.
Until recently the School has served almost exclusively the families on the Mohawk Reserve, whether members of the Church of England or not, many of whose children were trained in the School in the ordinary way and not in the Day Schools. Now, however, the Institute has become a School mainly for underprivileged children, either as a result of broken homes or because of antisocial tendencies in the children themselves. Moreover, they are now drawn from a far wider field than the Mohawk Reserve. Such children require quite different treatment from those under normal conditions such as have prevailed until recent years.

In view of this fact, we regard certain changes as urgent. Even a casual study of the ages of the children and their academic progress, and a study of High School Entrance results would indicate that there are very many children who are far below the achievement of normal children of the same age. No doubt this is due to emotional instability, immature mental ability or perhaps in some cases, definite mental defectiveness. These children cannot make satisfactory progress in a regular classroom. Might I suggest that a survey of the mental ability of these children might be made and if found necessary, special "opportunity classes," similar to those established in the public schools in Ontario towns and cities, be organized. This, of course, would require specially trained teachers, special equipment and above all, an enrolment of not more than twenty for each teacher. This, of course, would increase the cost of tuition, but it is clear that these special children cannot be educated for good citizenship in ordinary classrooms.

With respect to the rest of the children, many appear to have far too much time on their hands owing to the fact that in certain grades they are only taught for part of the day. These include Grades five and six, whose instruction should be, in our opinion, continued throughout the day.

As is to be expected under such circumstances, and already mentioned, the average intelligence of the pupils in the School is much lower than it was a few years ago. A few, however, with high intelligence might be trained as "student leaders" to assist in discipline, in games programmes, and

In the general supervision of the work of the pupils in the house and on the farm. There is a number of "special or problem pupils" who should not be in the Institute. For example, a boy of sixteen years with a mental age of eight, and children with apparently uncontrollable anti-social tendencies should not, in our opinion, be in the School. It is obvious that for such developments as have been outlined the teaching staff would have to be increased to five or six in number and made up of persons competent for the special needs arising out of the special character of the School as it now exists.

In this connection, reference to the salaries of teachers is necessary. These, in the case of some members of the staff, are very low, and when they retire it will be impossible to secure successors at their present salaries. In our opinion, it would be advisable also that they should be included among the other teachers on the Indian Reserves with regard to benefits afforded to the teachers in Ontario's public schools. We are aware, of course, that an Order-in-Council has been passed giving the Indian Day School teachers permanent positions as to status and pensions. We regard it as necessary that teachers in such schools as the Mohawk Institute should be included in this plan, if this has not already been contemplated.

A leading factor in the altered situation is the vastly increased overhead costs of everything, including food, clothing, salaries and upkeep generally. We are, of course, aware that in 1947 the Department increased the per capita grants in the School by $20.00 per pupil. My dear Archbishop Seager:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of February 10th in which you submit for departmental consideration a number of proposals with respect to the operation of the Mohawk Institute at Brantford.

You are no doubt aware that a Special Parliamentary Committee is at present engaged in a review of Indian administration in Canada. It is my hope that the members of this Committee will undertake a complete revision of the Indian Act during the course of the present Session and submit its final report to Parliament. In view of this fact, I naturally hesitate at this time to express an opinion with respect to the status of teachers employed at residential schools. I may state, however, that the advisability of increasing the per capita grants is now under consideration and I am hopeful that the amount necessary to increase the grants to an extent that will enable the Principals of residential schools to meet their financial obligations and operate the schools more efficiently will be approved by Parliament in due course. In addition to this, I am asking the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch, in cooperation with the Ontario Department of Education, to undertake a survey of the pupils enrolled at the Mohawk Institute. When the results of this survey are before us, an attempt will be made to have one or two specially qualified teachers undertake the task of providing academic and vocational programs that will meet the needs of the pupils to whom you refer.

I am disposed to agree with you that the Institute is destined to become increasingly a school for children from disrupted homes. There appears to be
no escape from this conclusion in view of the day school building program the department has in mind for Southwestern Ontario. It is reasonable to expect also that a great many of the pupils, in the period that lies ahead of us, will be backward and in the low intelligence quotient class. It has been to me, however, very gratifying to learn recently that approximately fifty-three Indian pupils in the Brantford area are at this time proceeding with high school courses of study and that many of these pupils have already expressed the desire to proceed to normal schools.

It is indeed a source of pleasure to me to note the amount of thought you appear to have given the school at Brantford. I can assure you that the suggestions you have submitted will be very carefully and sympathetically reviewed by the officers of the department.

Yours sincerely,

Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY,

Inspection of Mohawk Institute.

I visited this school accompanied by Superintendent Kandle. We were to meet the Principal in the afternoon but as he had not arrived yet we took a glance through the school while waiting.

The new classroom block is quite an improvement over the former classroom. I am satisfied that this will contribute greatly to the efficiency of the education at this institute provided the proper type of teacher is secured.

My first impression especially when going through the dormitories and the playroom was a sense of depression. It is the old story of noticing children wandering without any purpose whatsoever during their free time. This can have a very baneful effect on their character and on their immediate conduct.

Two of the dormitories are rather badly served by two dormer windows and a fire escape door. I believe these dormitories handle as many pupils as wisdom will allow. There has been a question of double decker beds in some of the dormitories. We have placed some of these beds in some schools and have been satisfied with them, where the supervision is adequate. Where the supervision is somewhat lax, probably due to the lack of personnel, I would be reluctant to recommend this type of bedding. It might be wise to attempt a trial period before going all out for this system. There is a great deal of space lost in the middle of this school. This is due, I
believe to the fact that the Principal would be reluctant to have dormitories above his own living quarters. I think it would be wise to have other quarters for the Principal and to use the school to full advantage. There would be adequate space for bathroom facilities for the boys and girls dormitories if use were made of this space.

I would recommend that Mr. Buck be asked to have this surveyed to ascertain the cost of making these changes. I do not see any possibility with the present set-up of improving the toilet facilities in the dormitories. The present system has nothing in it that is recommendable especially in the boys dormitory. The toilet is open and very close to the beds. This should be eliminated and it could be done by a re-arrangement of the beds. Any change, however, would be of a temporary nature and would not rectify the faults that exist in the set-up. As mentioned above, a thorough survey should be made by the Engineering Branch.

Mr. Hundle is expected to make a report also on this condition and also to secure prices for temporary changes that would seem imperative.

Respectfully submitted,

A.J. Hundle,
Supervisor of Vocational Training.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Last November I was consecrated to succeed the late Archbishop Seager as Bishop of Huron. Previous to that time as Dean of the Diocese I had the privilege of visiting the Mohawk Institute and seeing the work in progress there under the Principal, the Reverend W.J. Zimmerman. As Bishop I have again visited the School, spoken to the teachers and children in their class rooms and inspected the farm buildings in company with the Principal and the Indian Agent of the Reserve. I have also had three long interviews with the Principal during which we discussed every phase of the work in great detail. I believe that I am coming to understand some of the problems that press upon us in this School, and I hope I am also beginning to see some light on an horizon that has not been in recent years very bright.

Together with Mr. Zimmerman I have gone over carefully the financial records, his records of the pupils and his teaching problems in the School. I have also studied the reports of the District Inspector regarding the I.Q. of the present students and the opportunities of education and development which they now enjoy at the Mohawk Institute. Also I have discussed with Mr. Zimmerman his own future as Principal of the School. He and his wife are among the most effective and devoted members of our Diocesan family and I am deeply interested in his continuation as Principal of the Institute. The progress I have seen myself during the last four years has been very remarkable, and I believe that if we can keep Mr. Zimmerman contented and happy in his work at the Institute, in another four years this School can become a shining example of the concern of the Government, the Community and the Church for the welfare of our Indian wards.

My reason in writing to you is twofold. First I should greatly appreciate the privilege of an interview with you when next you are in our vicinity. I hear that you are coming down to the opening of the school in Munsey. I am hoping that this will take place in March because I shall be able to make myself available throughout that month for a conference with you. I am to be away from the Diocese for ten days between the 13th and 24th of February. I mention this just to let you know that apart from the ten days I shall make any
Colonel F.B. Neary

February 10th, 1949.

re-arrangements possible in order to meet your convenience.

My second purpose in writing is to say that I have been studying the change in the type of boy and girl now being sent to the Institute, together with the urgent needs this change has brought before the Principal of the School. Most of the children whom we receive at the Institute are from broken homes or difficult home environment. In going over the list of pupils and their I.Q. ratings I find that only about 25 out of the whole school have normal I.Q. rating. The average mental age of the whole school is about two years below their chronological age. The School Inspector states that forty of the children should be placed in Auxiliary Classes under the care of teachers specially trained for this difficult and exacting work. At present we have three teachers struggling as effectively as possible with an impossible task. One will be retiring shortly. Her present stipend is $55.00 a month, plus her board, and there seems little likelihood of replacing her except at a stipend equal to that which a teacher would receive from outside schools. Our needs in the teaching end, therefore, are as follows:

5 teachers instead of the present 3 - 2 of the 5 to be specially qualified for the work and the other 3 all of them to be fully qualified teachers and to be paid at a rate at least equal to that received by teachers in Provincial schools.

After school hours we have two supervisors, - one woman in charge of 75 girls and one man in charge of 60 boys. These children need double the supervision and two of the supervisors should be qualified for leadership in sports and games. Also there should be equipment for arts and games and greatly increased equipment for Manual and Domestic Training for boys and girls incapable of sustained academic work.

The Church is profoundly interested in making the Mohawk Institute an important asset in our varied Indian problem. We lack the means to make any sizable financial contribution to this work. Our contribution must be made through interest, the recruiting of a staff, the loaning of one of our best clergymen for the principalship and the yearly gift of a small amount of money as well as a considerable gift in clothing and other supplies. The Government grant for teaching staff and expenses must be greatly increased without delay or else we must seriously consider withdrawing completely from the field of Indian work. We have been carrying it on, as you know, in many parts of Canada at the expense of our Indian Mission work and the shepherding of the older Indian Community. With the increase of day schools for Indians our Mission work on the Reserves becomes of front rank importance.

Since the Mohawk Institute has become almost a centre for the difficult and sometimes incorrigible Indian children its nature has changed radically from

the early days of its foundation when it ministered educationally to the boys and girls of the Six Nations. To-day our Church responsibility is greatly lessened. Only a small minority of the children are Church of England. Of 11 admitted in the December quarter of last year only 1 was Church of England. The others were Protestants of various groups, including the Lutheran, Baptist, United Church, Plymouth Brethren and Church of Jesus Christ. Now, we are glad to share in the partnership of the Mohawk Institute through the years ahead and I shall be delighted to take a continuous interest in its welfare in close and friendly co-operation with the Government officials at Ottawa and your local representatives on the spot; but unless we have early assurance of increasing aid from the Government in this special sphere of the difficult, subnormal and incorrigible children we cannot continue in the partnership.

I trust that I may soon have the privilege of discussing these matters with you and I assure you that I shall meet you in full appreciation of your helpfulness and fairness which Mr. Zimmerman has emphasized to me on every occasion.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Mrs. C. Fry informs me that she will not be remaining on the teaching staff of the Mohawk Institute after June 30, 1949. I feel that after many years of loyal and devoted service to the Canadian Indian she has become discouraged because of the reaction of our Senior Girls. I have offered her the Matronship but she has declined. We do need badly a full time Matron. Mrs. Zimmerman can only give part of her time due to Teddy and Jean. The interest of the school demands a full time Matron.

In view of the departure of Mrs. Fry I shall be confronted with the problem of a replacement. Mr. Webster strongly recommends the increasing of the teaching staff. I wish to place on record the endorsement of this recommendation. Owing to low I.Q.'s, irregular previous school attendance, lack of self-discipline, maladjusted home relations etc., many of our students present difficult educational problems. Small classes are a necessity. We have been delighted with the response of the boys to manual training. I should like to see in the school a corresponding program worked out for the girls. The girls I am certain would reveal more interest in the school if there was instruction in cooking, dress-making, hand craft etc. The routine of the school leaves too little time for many of these things. I believe the time has come when we require 5 teachers. Our teachers must be placed on an equal standing with those in other branches of the service. One must pay a decent salary if we are going to secure adequate teaching. Now that the school is administered by the Department I do not see how we can escape.

Since coming to the Institute one of the greatest disappointments has been the lack of time which I have been able to give to religious education. My time has been taken up with administration and other details. If the Church and State could work out some way whereby help was given in the office I feel that my time would be well spent in studying many matters which receive scant attention. I do not wish to take any child from the religious faith of its parents. The Province of Ontario offers certain materials which could well be used. A secretary when not needed in the office could pinch hit in other areas.
For example Mr. Pedbisky has begun Cadet training. When he is training the boys up at the Armouries there is no one to be with the little boys. If the boys are to attend the theatre and not pick up things in the stores they must be escorted. This leaves me with no one with the boys at the school.

The Brantford Council of Local Women are purchasing a movie sound projector for use in the Institute. This machine will mean much since we do not possess a gymnasium. I have accepted this offer since this group represents many organizations in the City of Brantford. I told them of many advances which had been made during the present few years and what the Department had done. I do not feel that one can go on indefinitely ignoring the recommendations of such a group. The Mohawk Institute is too closely situated to the city of Brantford to escape public observation and criticism. They asked me point blank if I would speak to them on the work of the school and I did.

Last week I spent two days on the Muncey Reserve regarding Marie Deleary. This girl had presented a problem for Mr. Joblin. She ran away from this school. When I interviewed her Father I saw where the problem lay. Her lack of school attendance Mr. Joblin feels has affected the Mount Elgin Day School. Girls say 'If Marie does not attend we do not have to'. Many excuses were given by Mr. Deleary. When Mr. Hall handed her school attendance record for the last 6 years the problem was evident. This is the record of days attended each year:

| Year   | Days |
|--------|------|
| 1940-1 River Settlement | 8½ |
| 1941-2 | 8    |
| 1942-3 | 27   |
| 1943-4 | 53   |
| 1944-5 | 69   |
| 1945-6 M.E.R.S. I year | 105 |
| 1946-7 River Settlement | 105 |
| 1947-8 Mount Elgin Day School | 139 |
| 1948-9 | 9    |

I am certain when you read this record you will understand why this office requires help if we are going to do case work and give the children the kind of care they need. This record bear eloquent testimony to the kind of pupil we are receiving. The plan, and the only one that seemed feasible to Mr. Joblin and Mr. Hall after we met in conference, was that if Marie behaves till the end of June she can remain at home and go to school next year. This seemed the only way to handle Mr. Deleary without too much ill will. This kind of decision affects the Mohawk Institute.

I do feel that there is important work to be done at this school but our staff will have to be increased if we are to deal with the current problems in a modern way.

Dear Mr. Zimmerman:

I have been informed by the Supervisor of Family Allowances that since the introduction of Form I.A. 1049, the administration of Family Allowances has become more efficient due to the prompt reporting of all admissions and discharges from residential schools to the Regional Director of Family Allowances.

This increase of efficiency in administration has been brought about largely by the cooperation of the various principals of residential schools.

There is one part of the administration which I am informed is not functioning too well, and that is where a residential school draws its pupils from all over the province and from many agencies. In cases such as this, the principal of the school does not know the Family Allowance number of the child concerned, neither does the Indian Superintendent in whose agency the child is situated, consequently the Regional Director is unable to identify the child or the agency from the report, as presently submitted.

The only way this difficulty can be successfully overcome is by the school principal completing in duplicate each Form I.A. 1049 for the various agencies. This means that new children from several agencies are affected in any month.
forms will be prepared in duplicate for each Agency concerned and sent to the various Indian Superintendents, who in turn will complete the last three columns and forward to the Regional Director for action.

At the top of the form, where Agency appears, would you in future fill in the Agency from which the child originates, instead of the Agency in which your school is situated, and mail at the end of each month duplicate copies to the Indian Superintendent concerned. The practice of sending copies directly to Mr. F. G. Jenkins, Regional Director of Family Allowances, Toronto, should be discontinued.

Your cooperation in attending to the details mentioned above would be very much appreciated.

Yours very truly,

To Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division,
Indian Affairs Branch.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I was disappointed to learn from your letter of September 10th that I had not been appointed to the Mohawk Indian Residential School staff, but I realize that a younger applicant and one of public school experience would be preferred.

I really enjoyed the experience I had at Elliot Bay and at Carlston in teaching Indian children, and particularly at the latter school. It was a pleasure to see how they responded to my really earnest efforts to help them.

May I, out of the experience I had, venture to make one or two suggestions for your consideration.

One suggestion, and I make this earnestly, is that the rule be established and enforced that Indian children attend school a full day and not a half day as at present.
A second suggestion is that an efficient
Indian Affairs Office be appointed on each reserve.

May I say further that I think Indian children
should not be isolated, so to speak, as they are at
present. I realize that with the present "Reserve"
system it is difficult to arrange that Indian children
attend school with white children. Nevertheless I
feel strongly that this companionship would benefit
Indian children greatly and help them to overcome their
language handicap and other disadvantages.

I make the final suggestion that a greater
effort should be made to see that the more intelligent
Indian children go on to High School. Lots of these
could readily be obtained.

I trust you will not think me presumptuous
to have written as frankly as I have. I am
deeply interested in the welfare of Indian pupils
as a result of my close contact with some of them.
I shall always be glad to suggest an Indian
school. Most of the children are very much in
favour of going to such a school.

Sincerely yours,

Alexander Macdonald.

Dear Sir,

Last night I was talking by phone to Mr. Zimmerman of the Mohawk Institute. He explained that I should write to you, since my formal application, sent to Ottawa about Sept. 9, had received attention in your office, but hadn't reached you personally.

I visited Mohawk Institute on Labour Day following Mr. Zimmerman's invitation not to do so, re the matter of your desire to have Auxiliary Education begun in the Institute. I think Auxiliary Classes there would be a great advantage to the entire set-up. I also talked to Mr. Webster, the Inspector, and found him willing to cooperate in your plans. I felt that Mr. Webster and Mr. Zimmerman were men with whom I could work to improve conditions in the present educational arrangement there.

I have a permanent First Class Certificate no. 53883 issued in 1939 - Permanent Auxiliary Certificate for Opportunity and Handicrafts. It is no. 12647, issued in 1947 - Elementary Agriculture also permanent. I am a graduate of Stratford Normal 1923-24. I have completed twenty-five years experience in three Ontario schools. My first two in a rural school in Bruce County under Inspector McCool of Walkerton, now retired. Sixteen in Stratford Public School mostly senior trade work under Mr. J. Wilson. I've found and since then I have been regularly employed here in Hespeler. I came here in 1942 to teach
Science and Social Studies in Grs. 6-10. During
the past few years we experienced such need for
Auxiliary Education in our school that in 1945 I
organized a class under direction of Dr. Stothers
of Toronto. Auxiliary Classes Inspector. My room has
been inspected regularly by some one of the
three Departmental Inspectors; Dr. Stothers, Miss
Delaporte or Mr. Kendall and our local Inspector
here is Mr. A.F. Hansuld of Salt. I am prepared
to organize a class or classes under your
direction at the Mohawk Institute or elsewhere.

I am forty-four years of age, married. My
husband is a partially disabled war veteran, receiving
a small pension. We have no children. We are
Protestants, Presbyterians to be exact, but willing to
fit into any Protestant Religious arrangement.

I have a wide experience in handicrafts. I've taken
advantage of many courses and have tried almost
every ordinary domestic craft. In our school here I
teach the girls to make their own pajamas, slips,
skirts, blouses and we have turned out several rather
well-made wool suits — to knit, socks, socks and
simple sweaters. I do leatherwork, feltwork
and woodwork, although I do try to push the
academic work as far as possible. Classes
are greatly, but as I see the situation at the
Mohawk Institute, there's a place for a very
practical course, and a place for every
useful article made.

I would like, if accepted, to live at the institute
if suitable accommodation could be provided on
the grounds.

Col. Neary, I still haven't found out what the
salary would be, and I am very anxious to know
what arrangements could be made regarding
superannuation with my twenty-five years
in the Ontario Service, I can't afford to lose out in a transfer. Would you please outline as simply as possible what arrangements could be made.

I realize that this proposed experiment is going to present difficulties, and no doubt there'll be mistakes made along the way, but I find myself most enthusiastic about it, and I'd like to see it a success.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Poveshell Carlaw

Dear Colonel Henry,

I thought you would like to know that Mrs. Zimmerman has been in hospital for about three weeks and reports to date are not too favorable as her condition is one of mental depression.

You will appreciate such a condition may take a long time to correct and in the meantime, it is disturbing to Mr. Zimmerman and cannot but upset, to some extent, the smooth running of things at the Mohawk Institute.

The doctor says he thinks it will be best if she visited her own family and get away from the Institute surroundings and if this were Mr. Zimmerman's case, I should be glad to assist him if necessary to facilitate his visiting his wife.

I have told Mr. Zimmerman that and hope that will help his wife feel better. It will be in our best interest, both from his and his family's point of view, to see if anything can be done to improve her condition.

I wish to assure you, I will of course keep a close frequent eye on her for these, and if you could write a word of good cheer, as he is anxious, not only about his wife, but about the Institute.
